HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Havel's Aides Meet U.S. Bankers On Investment in Czechoslovakia

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
While President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia visited with President Bush and addressed Congress yesterday, his top economic advisers worked at cultivating investment for their country.
Rather than meet directly with business executives, many of whom remain skeptical about investing in Czechoslovakia, the officials are trying to build a network of Wall Street advisers and investment bankers who would help the Czechoslovaks draw foreign investment.
Two key architects of the evolving Czechoslovak economy are traveling with President Havel: Vladimir Dlouhy, the Minister of Planning, and Vaclev Klaus, the Minister of Finance. Both are strong advocates of foreign ownership of Czechoslovak companies to make them efficient and competitive in world markets. 
 
Party at the Guggenheim
The two officials were guests in New York last night at a party at the Guggenheim Museum given by Salomon Brothers and at a private dinner at the home of William Luers, president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a former United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia.
The dinner guest list included E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York; Anthony Solomon, the bank's former president and now an investment banker; Robert Hormats, an investment banker at Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist who is advising the Czechoslovak Government.
Rather than rely on foreign loans to modernize industry - loans that might result in a burdensome foreign debt -the Havel team would encourage foreign companies to put businesses in Czechoslovakia and also to purchase some major state-owned manufacturing operations. Josef Tosovsky, president of the State Bank of Czechoslovakia, said yesterday in Washington that President Havel is not seeking credits or loans during his visit to the United States.
 
Legislation Planned
The Havel Government is drafting legislation that would permit foreign ownership and make other changes favorable to foreign investment. Under current law, a foreign company can be only a minority partner in a joint venture.
But anticipating that the necessary legislation will soon be adopted by Parliament, some big American companies are negotiating with state-owned Czechoslovak operations, particularly those manufacturers with products that could be exported to Western Europe, according to people involved in the discussions.
The General Electric Company, for example, is holding talks with the Skoda Engineering Works, a manufacturer of power equipment and other machinery, in competition against Siemens A.G. The Chrysler Corporation has held talks with a separate Skoda company, the manufacturer of autos. One competitor is Mazda. The idea is to produce an American- or Japanese-designed car at a Skoda factory for export to Western Europe. The lures are Czechoslovak engineering and manufacturing skills and low wages.
 
Talks on Glass Plants
Numerous Western companies, including some from the United States, have also talked with the Czechoslovaks about investing in that country's famous glass factories, particularly those making auto glass, said Jan Vanos, president of PlanEcon, a Washington consulting firm that specializes in Eastern Europe.
Smaller American companies have not gone beyond the inquiry stage, apparently preferring to wait until the new laws governing foreign investment are in place, said Fred Zeder, president of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, a Government agency that insures foreign investment by American companies.
Earlier this month, the Czechoslovaks asked Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, when he visited Prague, for help in forming a panel of American advisers. The group being formed includes Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve; John Whitehead, a former Deputy Secretary of State who is now an investment banker; Peter McPherson, executive vice president of the Bank of America, and Mr. Hormats.
''The panel is mostly a way for the Czechs to strengthen their ties with the American financial community and with companies that are potential investors,'' Mr. Hormats said.

HEADLINE: Foundation Sponsors Anti-Drug Effort

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Fifteen localities in the United States have been selected for a new initiative to curb alcohol and drug abuse, financed by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton, N.J.
The foundation will spend $27 million over five years, the largest sum from any single private source to combat substance abuse.
Each of the 15 communities, selected from 331 applicants, is to develop a program intended to reduce demand for alcohol and illegal drugs among local residents. They include the cities of New Haven and Worcester, Mass., where there has been an upsurge in drug abuse, and six other urban locations. Rural communities were also chosen, including an area of northwestern New Mexico that covers portions of the Navajo and Zuni reservations. 
The foundation's president, Dr. Leighton E. Cluff, said the aim is to develop successful models that can be copied elsewhere.
The foundation sought to involve several elements of the local communities as they planned the models, said Prof. Anderson Spikard, a drug-addiction specialist from Vanderbilt University, who is directing the program.
 
'We Need a Single Overview'
''Customarily, people involved in fighting substance abuse usually work on individual piece,'' he said. ''They look at the elephant from their own perspectives, seeing the head or the tail. We need a single overview.''
Dr. Spikard said the planning would be done in each community by a coalition of educators, health officials, law-enforcement authorities and representatives of labor, business, religious organizations and government agencies.
Each place will receive $100,000 annually for planning work - some may require two years - and will be encouraged to seek more money from other foundations, business and government. Eight of the 15 will then be selected to receive $3 million each to continue developing their models.
Dr. Cluff said in Washington yesterday that if all 15 programs were deemed worthy they might each win additional money from the foundation, which has assets of nearly $2 billion.
The communities were selected on the recommendation of a national advisory committee headed by Dr. John Brademas, president of New York University.
 
U.S. to Announce Program
Next month the Federal Government will announce a substance abuse program that will provide a total of $50 million this year to help 150 communities. Many of the unsuccessful applicants for Johnson Foundation grants already are applying to the Federal Office for Substance Abuse Prevention, said Gale Held, director of the Division of Prevention Implementation.
She said that the government and foundation programs would be complementary, but that the Robert Wood Johnson venture was more comprehensive because it would provide for substance abuse treatment, not merely referral.
''We're impressed by what the foundation has put together,'' she said, ''assisting the communities in exactly what's needed,''
The foundation limited its selection to localities with a population of 100,000 to 250,000 - in some instances, one section of a large city was chosen - and sought to include diverse ethnic communities.
Four of the 15 localities are in California. In Vallejo, where drug arrests have increased 1,000 percent in seven years, the community will work in collaboration with the local Navy base, which already has an anti-drug program. In East Oakland, the prevention program will focus on schools and parks. In San Jose, the program will concentrate on the city's east side, home to large numbers of refugees from Southeast Asia and Latin America. In Santa Barbara, efforts will be made to combat alcohol abuse, particularly among pregnant women.
 
How the Programs Will Vary
The program for New Mexico will focus on alcohol abuse in the border towns surrounding the reservations where alcohol is banned. In West Charlotte, N.C., assistance will begin with help for those at high risk, like school dropouts, and expand to other groups. In an area of San Antonio, where there are no treatment centers, a comprehensive aid and follow-up program is planned. In Little Rock, Ark., neighborhood groups will be organized to conduct forums, marches and other activities. Milwaukee's program will focus on family needs in the central city.
In Kansas City, Mo., 100,000 residents will receive training in fighting drug abuse. In Columbia, S.C., nine groups are developing strategies to curb alcohol and drug abuse. In Washington the program will mobilize groups to develop preschool prevention activities in public housing projects and will involve business leaders in counseling youth.
Newark's program focuses on offering economic opportunities to reduce the allure of the drug trade in the city's poorest areas.
New Haven, which has high incidence of drug-related violence and pediatric AIDS, will receive help in reaching youth and women of child-bearing age with prevention and treatment.
In Worcester the program will try to enhance prevention for youth and families and test the benefits of offering incentives to keep patients in follow-up programs.

HEADLINE: Voice From Tiananmen Now Heard at Wellesley

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WELLESLEY, Mass., Feb. 20

 BODY:
The Wellesley College basketball coach had nothing but praise for her new point guard.
''She's poetry in motion on the break,'' Roxanne Dale said of her player, Cai Jinqing.
As recently as last June, Miss Cai had little time to practice her best shot, a three-pointer from the corner. Then, the shy, studious Miss Cai was a straight-A chemistry major at Beijing University and a spokeswoman for the student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. 
But after the People's Liberation Army moved into the square on June 4, killing hundreds of students and civilians, Miss Cai managed to escape and made her way to Boston, thanks to help from friends and relatives in America.
Miss Cai knows she was exceedingly lucky. Only a few of the student leaders were able to flee. Most were arrested, and many of her classmates at Beijing University are now faced with uncertain futures and long hours of political indoctrination.
 
Repercussions in Beijing
She still gets letters from friends at Beijing University. The entire freshman class has been kept at an army base for a year of political study. Under a new rule, graduating seniors will have to work for at least five years before being able to study abroad, the dream of many Chinese students. Many of the seniors, under suspicion by the Communist regime, are unable to find jobs.
''My friends say they have given up hope,'' Miss Cai said. ''After all the events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, they think China missed its chance to modernize and become democratic. They are all very depressed.''
This background of tragedy makes Miss Cai's rapid adjustment to life at Wellesley, one of the most prestigious and affluent women's colleges, all the more remarkable.
In her first semester last fall, the 20-year-old Miss Cai managed to get three A's and an A-minus, in her classes in economics, chemistry and art, all this without any special help in English, which she was using in class for the first time.
''She's a very smart woman,'' said Prof. Karl Case, who taught her in a class on microeconomics, her first economics course. ''I would hand out problem sets, and hers would be the best.''
 
Tiananmen Voice Recognized
Miss Cai's escape was engineered by one of her three older brothers, Cai Jinyong, a graduate student at Boston University. One day last May, watching the demonstrators in Tiananmen Square on television, he overheard what he thought was his sister's voice broadcasting by loudspeaker. Amazed and worried, he called his parents in Beijing, who confirmed Miss Cai was indeed participating in the protests.
So when the crackdown took place, he went to Boston University's president, John Silber, to ask for help. Waiving its usual requirements, the school granted her admission and a $10,000 scholarship. Her brother then rushed this paperwork by Federal Express to Beijing. At the same time, Miss Cai persuaded a sympathetic faculty member at Beijing University to write a letter vouching she had not participated in the demonstrations.
Armed with these documents, she got an exit permit from the Ministry of Public Security and a visa from the American Embassy.
But when she arrived in Boston, Professor Case happened to learn about Miss Cai from another Wellesley graduate, who had heard she was a star basketball player. An inveterate basketball fan, Professor Case arranged for her to tour the campus and try out in front of Ms. Dale, the coach. ''She canned three three-point shots, and we were convinced,'' Professor Case said.
But by then it was July and Wellesley's admissions process was closed. Complicating the situation, the school's president, Nannerl Keohane, was in Paris attending the 200th anniversary celebrations of the French Revolution.
 
Full Scholarship at Wellesley
So when Dr. Keohane returned, Professor Case greeted her at Logan Airport outside Boston with a report on Miss Cai. Soon Miss Cai found herself the recipient of a full $20,000 scholarship at Wellesley.
''It was very unusual, almost unprecedented,'' Dr. Keohane said of the school's action. ''But with memories of Tiananmen so fresh in our minds, we thought it was well worth it.''
Now Miss Cai faced a difficult choice, which school to choose. She felt a moral obligation to Boston University, but since she had no money of her own, the Wellesley offer solved her financial problem. To try to compensate, she took flowers to the officials at Boston University who had helped her.
At Wellesley, Miss Cai joins a long list of distinguished students from China. The first arrived in 1906, after a visit by senior officials of the Qing Dynasty, who came to inspect the school at the order of the Empress Dowager. Then there was also Soong Mei-ling, who went on to become Madame Chiang Kai-shek.

GRAPHIC: photo: Cai Jinqing was a spokeswoman for the student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square before she escaped to Boston. She now attends Wellesley College and plays on the basketball team. (The New York Times/Jim Bourg)

HEADLINE: Army Says Cuts May Mean Losing Some Officers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
The Army told Congress today that the Bush Administration's plan to shrink the military might force the Army to dismiss some career officers ''as a last resort.''
In its annual statement to Congress, the Army said that while it was committed to recruiting and retaining high-quality soldiers even as overall troop totals are reduced, it might have to dismiss some of the 375,000 career officers and noncommissioned officers.
Such reductions would be a new problem for the military. After World War II, the Korean War and the Vietnam War, it was able to slim its ranks by turning loose thousands of draftees who were eager to re-enter the civilian economy. Today's soldiers and officers, however, are all volunteers, and for many the service is a career. 
The Army Secretary, Michael P. W. Stone, presented the statement in a closed hearing of the House Appropriations Committee's Subcommittee on Defense. Copies were issued at the Pentagon.
The other branches of the military said it was premature to discuss dismissals of career officers.
A spokeswoman for the Air Force, Lieut. Col. Peg Bowman, said: ''The Air Force hopes to accommodate the reductions in force through attrition, early-out programs, cutbacks in the number of people we are bringing in on active duty and of the number of civilians that we hire.''
A Marine Corps spokesman, Lieut. Col. Fred Peck, said: ''We don't anticipate any personnel cuts at this time. We have introduced a voluntary program where marines near the end of their period of enlistment can end their service up to 90 days in advance.''
In a statement, the Navy said it ''has worked very closely with Congress to protect personnel accounts from major cuts,'' and added, ''It would be premature to speculate on the impact to personnel until such time that Congress has made a final decision on the reprogramming.''

HEADLINE: Growers Reach for the Ballot in California Duel Over Pesticides

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 21

 BODY:
In a duel over pesticides that could have important implications for the rest of American agriculture, California growers today began collecting signatures for a ballot measure that they said would reform programs to protect food, water and farm workers from toxic chemicals.
The growers' measure comes in response to a separate ballot initiative proposed by environmental groups in October. That measure would gradually end 23 widely used farm chemicals by 1996 and transfer California's pesticide regulatory program from the state's Department of Food and Agriculture to the Department of Health Services.
The growers seek far less sweeping changes. If approved, their measure would increase penalties for unlawful use of pesticides. The growers said it would also expand the number of samples of fresh and processed food tested for residues of pesticides, establish panels of experts to study the hazards of pesticides and pay for research that would reduce or eliminate the use of some pesticides. 
Leaders of the farm groups said their measure is popular in California's Central Valley, the heart of the state's $16 billion farm industry, and expect to quickly collect the nearly 400,000 signatures needed to qualify it for the ballot in November.
 
The Importance of Pesticides
''Pesticides are a critical part of one of this state's most important industries,'' said Lee Stitzenberger, president of the Dolphin Group, a public relations company in Los Angeles that is managing the growers' campaign. ''Our reform proposal is based on sound scientific theories, not on scare tactics. In areas that we need more information to make decisions, we've proposed scientific panels to get the answers.''
Environmental leaders attacked the growers' proposal, calling it an effort to dupe voters and enable growers to continue using the most dangerous pesticides without interference. The real intent of the measure, they said, is approval of a provision in the growers' plan that says if both measures pass but the growers' initiative gains more votes, that plan will take effect.
''It's a classic fake reform,'' said Ralph E. Lightstone, a lawyer and pesticide policy specialist here with the California Rural Legal Assistance Foundation. ''It rewrites dozens of sections of existing law without any substantive changes.''
Albert H. Meyerhoff, a lawyer in San Francisco with the Natural Resources Defense Council who is a co-author of the environmentalists' initiative, said: ''What the growers have proposed is a plan to continue the use of cancer-causing chemicals. They want to manage cancer, not prevent it.''
 
Similar Conflicts Elsewhere
At the center of both initiatives are conflicting views about the accuracy of scientific data on the hazards of farm chemicals and the adequacy of California's pesticide regulatory program. The same conflicts over science and regulation have risen in Washington, where a new farm policy law is under discussion, and in farm states like Florida, Iowa, Minnesota, Texas and Wisconsin.
The outcome of the conflict in California, which in recent years has established most of the significant trends in pesticide regulation and in cultivation practices that reduce or eliminate pesticides, is almost certain to influence the debate elsewhere.
That facet of the dispute has not been lost on either side of the debate. Mr. Stitzenberger said the groups he represents, including the California Farm Bureau, the Western Growers Association, the California League of Food Processors and the California Cotton Growers Association, were prepared to spend millions of dollars on the campaign for their initiative.
''A lot of California farmers are already reducing their use of pesticides,'' said Jasper E. Hempel, a vice president for the Western Growers Association, a trade group based in Irvine, Calif., that represents fruit and vegetable farmers. ''But we are not going to let the environmental community put an arbitrary scientific standard on chemicals we can use.''
 
Separate Campaign Planned
Meanwhile, pesticide manufacturers are joining other industrial groups in planning a separate campaign against the environmentalists' measure. That campaign, also expected to cost millions of dollars, will be run by Woodward & McDowell, a political consulting group in Burlingame, Calif., which managed the campaign in 1984 to establish the state's lottery.
''We try not to telegraph what we're going to do,'' Jack S. McDowell, a partner in the firm, said in an interview Tuesday. ''But one feature of the campaign will be economics. People will know how costly the environmentalists' proposition will be to the state's economy.''
GRC Economics, a Washington-based consulting group under contract to the chemical companies, says the measures proposed by environmental groups to ban or restrict pesticides would lead to a 40 percent cut in the amount of fruits, vegetables, grain and cotton produced in California.
GRC Economics said late last year that the environmentalists' measure could lead to a $10 billion-a-year reduction in the state's economy by the end of the decade. Last month GRC revised the estimate of losses to $6 billion.
Mr. Meyerhoff was one of several environmental specialists who disputed both figures. For three decades, he said, farmers in California and elsewhere have predicted dire consequences each time a pesticide is removed from the market for safety reasons. ''It's never turned out to the be case,'' he asserted.
Mr. Meyerhoff also said some of the most successful and profitable farmers in California are those who produce food without pesticides.
''American farmers are being forced by consumers to consider more environmentally sound and safer agricultural practices,'' Mr. Meyerhoff said. ''These can be accomplished without severe economic pressure. We have the ability to turn the corner away from this chemical obsession in farming.''

HEADLINE: Why End Social Security to Save It?

 BODY:
The huge and growing surpluses in the Social Security trust fund make Congress uncomfortable. Some members don't like sitting on a large unclaimed pot of taxpayers' money. Others are angered by the use of a regressive payroll tax to pay the Government's bills. 
Representative John Porter, an Illinois Republican, offers a novel solution: Let workers own their own retirement accounts. He would return most of the present Social Security tax and then require workers to invest the rebated money in private savings accounts for their own retirement.
What would such privatization accomplish? First, it would eliminate the mammoth trust fund before Congress misuses the money. Second, the new investment would stimulate economic growth.
The idea is not as shrewd as it sounds. Sponsors are quick to advertise the benefits, loath to identify the costs. The omission is egregious because low-income families will bear those costs. Social Security skews benefits toward the needy. If the system is privatized, each family would fend for itself and the poor would be hurt.
Privatization attracts sponsors because of the forced new savings. Each worker's payroll tax would be cut, but so would his future retirement income. His private savings account would make up for the loss. That would be O.K. for the average taxpayer but it would mean a reduction for low-income families. Under the current system, those with low income would get less from a private savings account than they are currently scheduled to receive from Social Security.
And that's not the only loss involved. Many privatization plans would end other Social Security benefits like disability and survivors' insurance. A privatized plan would mean nothing to a young worker permanently disabled by injury or illness. The present Social Security system protects all such workers.
To his credit, Mr. Porter would overcome some of these problems. He would retain disability insurance and a minimum retirement benefit. But most low-income families would still do worse.
The most intriguing proposal has been made by Enid Borden and Bruce Schobel, both former high-level Social Security officials. They would return part of the payroll tax to workers. But unlike Mr. Porter, they would not reduce future benefits. The needy would be fully protected.
The drawback to this, and all privatization plans, is the fiscal reverberation. Giving workers back their Social Security tax would gut Federal revenue. To comply with Gramm-Rudman deficit targets while offsetting this precipitous decline, Congress would be forced to raise taxes and cut spending sharply.
In fact, the Borden-Schobel plan goes too far. It is, for one thing, an overly complicated way to raise the savings rate. The same goals could be more easily accomplished by revising the Gramm-Rudman target from zero to a surplus. Mr. Schobel argues that his way is better because Congress would find it easier to dodge new Gramm-Rudman targets than rebates to workers.
Schemes that sound too good to be true invariably are. Privatizing Social Security is no exception. It could raise the national savings rate. But that goal can be achieved in ways that don't devastate the elderly poor.

HEADLINE: A Worthy Setting for the Javits Center

 BODY:
New York City's Board of Estimate has a chance to make a good thing better today by approving a plan to rejuvenate the area around the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Four years after it opened, the Convention Center still sits in isolated splendor on Manhattan's West Side, surrounded by an uninviting mix of warehouses, parking lots, vacant land and commercial businesses, and a generous complement of prostitutes.
If the Board of Estimate approves the zoning changes, creating what's called a ''special district,'' the forbidding streets around the center would have a chance to come alive. The plan envisions a new hotel, a 49-story apartment building, plazas, trees and badly needed parking space - all without displacing anyone. 
The construction would generate jobs and transform a threatening wasteland into an inviting neighborhood that could only make the Convention Center itself more attractive. The center attracts three million visitors annually. But it is dark about 100 days a year, and operates at a loss. The center's health would surely improve if the area around it improved.
The City Planning Commission's plan for the special district has Mayor David Dinkins's endorsement. Other board members, though, have reservations. The new Manhattan Borough President, Ruth Messinger, is generally supportive. But she objects to the height of the apartment building, and worries that changing the neighborhood so fundamentally could displace nearby manufacturing jobs. Her concerns are worth the Planning Commission's attention and remedy, but are not worth sacrificing the entire proposal.
The Planning Commission has produced a good and thoughtful plan, one six years in the making. Even if the board gives its go-ahead, the city's fiscal dip may delay immediate development. But at the least, approval would set the stage for turning an ill-used piece of Manhattan into something of benefit to the entire city.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Ortega and Somoza

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
One Nicaraguan who believes that Violeta Chamorro actually may defeat the Sandinista President, Daniel Ortega, in Sunday's elections is Arturo Cruz Jr. - the son of a former presidential candidate, a former Sandinista himself, but also a former contra and national security assistant in the Reagan White House.
Few observers and not many more Nicaraguans agree; a final Washington Post/ABC News survey, for instance, gives Mr. Ortega a 48-to-32-percent lead, with 16 percent undecided or keeping mum. Mr. Cruz himself doubts that the unexpected victory he thinks possible would be the best thing for his country.
In a recent talk at the Americas Society in New York he suggested, but stopped short of predicting, that Mrs. Chamorro, the presidential candidate of a united opposition, could win because of respect for her prominent family, the disastrous economic decline of Nicaragua under the Sandinistas and her hard-hitting ''message'' - which he paraphrased as: ''We are fed up with Sandinistas, contras and the war.'' 
In a country where half or more of the population is under 30, with young men subject to the military draft, that could be an effective appeal. Even the U.S. invasion of Panama, as Mr. Cruz sees it, might help rather than hurt Mrs. Chamorro; it could encourage her supporters to vote, in the belief that if the election were stolen, the U.S. would come to her rescue as it claims to have done for Guillermo Endara in Panama.
Nevertheless, if Mrs. Chamorro should win against the odds, Mr. Cruz said, ''I think we are in trouble.''
A Chamorro victory, in his analysis, would force the Bush Administration to pour economic aid into Nicaragua; but such aid could not be effective because the country has suffered a massive loss of its ''human capital'' - half a million skilled artisans, professionals and managers who have fled a repressive regime.
''Money capital'' alone will not be able to redeem the Nicaraguan economy, Mr. Cruz predicted, and a Chamorro government would be blamed for continuing poverty and stagnation. Besides, he believes, the Sandinistas would have to yield the official government to her, but would manage to retain their control of the armed forces and thus keep a considerable hold on power.
A sizable victory for Mr. Ortega would not, on the other hand, constitute a Communist triumph. Instead, he sees Daniel Ortega as having converted the Sandinistas from ''a party of ideology'' bent on imposing a Marxist program to an ''electoral party'' organized to win elections and keep power.
On Feb. 14, The Miami Herald - a close observer of Central America -expressed a somewhat similar view, noting that ''Nicaragua has taken important steps toward a much more open and less repressive society than existed there just one year ago.'' One step cited was the release earlier this month of 1,033 political prisoners; another was the ''relative ease with which opposition parties have been allowed to organize and campaign.''
Daniel Ortega himself, The Herald commented, is ''behaving like a Western-style politician: trading his guerrilla outfit for civilian clothes, kissing babies on the campaign trail, and making substantial political concessions.''
Mr. Cruz dates the change from 1984, when Mr. Ortega was reaffirmed in power and the militant Tomas Borge (''the last believer'') was weakened. Now, Mr. Cruz thinks, ''Sandinismo is withering away'' as a Marxist-Leninist party; Mr. Ortega and his brother, Humberto, are moving instead toward a ''family over party'' regime similar to the Somoza dictatorship the Sandinistas overthrew in 1979, and one sadly familiar in Latin America.
Such a regime, in Mr. Cruz's judgment, can only make of Nicaragua another ''banana republic,'' with the processes of democracy and growth that once appeared possible having disappeared with the flight of so much ''human capital.'' Exports, for only one example, have fallen from $780 million in 1978 to only about $200 million expected in 1990.
Mr. Cruz does not expect Election-Day fraud, owing to the presence of effective international observer teams; but he believes Sandinista intimidation tactics during the campaign may have a substantial delayed effect on the outcome. True to his mixed political history, he also hopes for a mixed result in the voting - an Ortega victory by no more than 5 to 10 points.
An election that close, he believes, would force a coalition ''cabinet of national reconstruction'' including Violeta Chamorro and the united opposition parties. And that, Mr. Cruz claims to know, is also the secret best hope of the Bush Administration.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Drug War Victories

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
At the United Nations, in the vast hall of the General Assembly, one delegate after another gets up and announces how much his country hates narcotics.
The representatives of the big powers speak. So do representatives of countries whose yearly budgets do not amount to the value of the cocaine seized in one raid at one big drug warehouse in Los Angeles.
Mostly the speeches are lead dumplings, clunky with cliches; the ear glazes over. It seems like just one more talktalktalk U.N. meeting among more than 40 years of talktalktalk meetings. 
Then the realization comes that this week something important is going on at the U.N. That happens every once in a great while, maybe once a decade.
Some human issue, some human problem or yearning, becomes so important to the emotions of so many people that governments feel they must meet to be heard in support -even if they lack the money or influence or intent to do much about it.
Human rights was such an issue. So were hunger and the condition of women. The speeches of the delegates then were often hypocritical or meaningless.
Whole nations still starve. The brave are still tortured and imprisoned in dozens of countries. In the Middle East and Africa young women are still put under the knife for clitoral circumcision as they enter the flower of their youth.
But the fact that the governments represented at the United Nations, varied in virtue and villainy as they may be, feel they have to meet in special session to take up a human issue means something. It means they acknowledge that the concern has become a consensus beyond borders with a political potency that no longer can be ignored.
In that sense, a victory for political decency takes place at the United Nations.
And, almost unnoticed, a victory for cultural decency has taken place in the United States that is important in our own war against drugs.
The huge majority of this country's people have decided drug abuse is neither chic, amusing, sexy nor socially titillating but, in fact, rather disgusting. The popular decision -not unanimous, but strong - is that anybody who glamorizes drugs is not only a fool but a bore.
Proof is fairly simple. The attitude is now so widespread that our sensitive cultural delegates - the people who turn out movies, ads, TV series, lyrics and records - recognize its political and economic power.
Certainly we still have smirky, drug-loving rhymes from some of the rap-talkers, a more accurate description than rap musicians, and from time to time a sly reference to drugs in a rock record. But lyrics admiring drugs are no longer routinely expected or passively accepted.
And when was the last time you saw one of those once-endemic movies glorifying the drugginess of bikers or beatniks? Lord, how old-fashioned and dreary their self-pity seems now.
The growing revulsion and deglamorization of drugs comes mostly from common sense inducing common revulsion - too many lives are being lost or ruined for drug abusers to be entertaining anymore.
Particularly unamusing are well-off ''leisure'' abusers who provide most of the money that buys the guns and bullets for the drug killers.
Most sponsors and producers are grasping this, some because they don't see big profit in druggy entertainment but many others simply because they feel their own children endangered.
But many individual Americans, one by one, have actively helped arouse public disgust with drug criminality and abuse - preachers, teachers, mayors and members of Congress, professionals and volunteers in anti-drug programs of almost every industry.
And while we are at it, it would not hurt at all to acknowledge the work of William J. Bennett and the people who work with him, a professional, talented, drug-fighting team.
Professional drug fighters are realistic enough to know the distances yet to go to provide enough treatment slots for addicts, enough research money, enough police, enough Presidential attention to tie-ins between Americans and drug runners, such as the Honduran connection, detailed by James LeMoyne in The New York Times and by Mort Rosenblum in the current Vanity Fair.
But it is also realistic to acknowledge that, once in awhile, a victory in the struggle does creep up on us -whether in the General Assembly or in our national mind.
So a moment off for a tiny pat on the back, ours and the U.N.'s, then back to closing the distances.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Albany Redux: Faith and Politics Are in Conflict

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
''I'm a good Catholic,'' the Governor of New York, in the privacy of his Albany office, reminded a ranking Roman Catholic clergyman as they debated a proposed constitutional amendment.
''I'm bound to obey the Holy Father, and I'm bound to obey you in all matters of faith and morals,'' he said.
''But there's nothing in the law of the church that says I have to obey the church in matters that are economic, social or political. No, Father. That's not a part of the duty of the church to tell me that.'' 
''Any time you come to me on a matter of faith or morals where I've been wrong, you can be sure I'll go along with you, but this belongs to me. This is the Governor of the State of New York's duty, and it belongs to me. It doesn't belong to anybody else.''
The issue was children. The Governor was Alfred E. Smith. He was arguing for a Federal child labor law; leading Catholic clergymen were warning that government regulation would violate the sanctity of the family.
Sixty-five years later, the conflict between a Catholic public official's personal beliefs and his perception of his public responsiblity is reverberating in the conflict between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his church over abortion. Last month, Bishop Austin Vaughan, an auxiliary bishop of the New York Archdiocese, warned that Mr. Cuomo was ''in serious risk of going to hell'' because of his support for abortion rights. On Tuesday, Thomas V. Daily, the new Roman Catholic Bishop of the Brooklyn Diocese, in which Mr. Cuomo was raised, said he would bar the Governor from speaking at local churches. Invitations from several are pending; Mr. Cuomo is offering the parishes the opportunity to reconsider.
''We have a political difference,'' Mr. Cuomo said yesterday. ''The difference between me and the Bishop is a political one, not a theological one.''
In 1984, the Governor took a calculated political risk when John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, publicly questioned the logic of public officials who claim to be personally opposed to abortion, yet are unwilling to impose their personal views on their constituents. He suggested that Catholics could not in good conscience vote for candidates who explicitly support a woman's right to abortion.
Rebutting the Cardinal, Mr. Cuomo declared that Catholics should practice the compassion that their church preaches by setting an example, not by passing laws. Last month, though, he responded to Bishop Vaughan by turning the other cheek. On Tuesday, the Governor was slapped again.
But it would be wrong to interpret his reticience this time as acquiesence.
He is hoping that the new Bishop becomes better attuned to the political mood of a state where the Legislature, presumably reflecting public sentiment, seems unlikely to limit abortion rights. It is not he who has strayed from the mainstream, the Governor figures, but the church hierarchy.
Mr. Cuomo is also preparing to confront the conflict publicly, as he did in 1984, if the new Bishop persists in ostracizing the Diocese's most prominent Catholic elected official (and in reviving, in the minds of some, the historic tension between clergymen of Irish descent and their Italian-American co-religionists).
That confrontation is likely to focus on apparent contradictions, rather than on the clergy's right to speak: Is every Catholic who declines to translate private beliefs based on church teaching into civic law a sinner? If abortion is not merely a Catholic issue, then are non-Catholic politicians condemned to hell, too? What about officials who would permit abortion in cases of rape or incest? Or those who vote for a budget that pays for family planning clinics that dispense contraceptives? From what level of church teaching are lawmakers allowed to deviate?
Meanwhile, the Governor, again confounding his critics, is embracing a middle ground in which more of his constituents might find comfort - promoting alternatives to abortion, like sex education, abstinence, contraceptives and adoption, and championing children's rights beyond the womb.
This latest conflict between a governor and his church differs in some respects from the one 65 years ago. Opposition to child labor laws then was generated by individual clergymen, not by church doctrine. But there may be parallels, too.
When the visiting cleric left Governor Smith's office, which was adorned with a picture of the Pope, Smith turned to Frances Perkins of the State Industrial Commission and said: ''He don't mean any harm. If he knew what you and I know he couldn't talk like that. How would he get to know? There's no way he can know.''

HEADLINE: United Way to Aid Smaller Agencies

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Under criticism for supporting only long-established charities, United Way of New York City expects to devote $70 million in the next five years to bolstering scores of small local agencies that help jobless youth, illiterate adults, AIDS patients, victims of domestic violence and the homeless.
United Way officials say they will also increase financing for agencies working to reduce racial tensions and curb crime in the city.
But the officials said that the fiscal changes would not mean a reduction in allocations to the older organizations, like the Red Cross and the American Cancer Society. Rather, they said that an anticipated 5 percent annual growth from United Way fund-raising campaigns would be used to help support the small agencies. 
''We are not trying to be a civil-rights organization, but we can build bridges between the business leaders who serve on our board and the communities in our city,'' said Ralph Dickerson Jr., president of the city United Way since 1988. He said the program is an effort to reach New York City's most under-served people.
 
Grants Pay the Rent
United Way leaders emphasized that their grants pay the rent, light and heat bills and so enable hundreds of local agencies operating under city contracts, to deliver services.
Under the new initiative, money will be given to agencies that handle any one of eight problems: AIDS, crime, drug abuse, family violence, homelessness, illiteracy, racial tensions and youth unemployment.
Under the planned allocation, United Way expects its 1990 net campaign proceeds to reach $51.2 million and will provide $6.5 million for the eight priorities. By 1995, United Way expects its income to reach $65.4 million and to allocate $20 million.
United Way of New York City is one of the largest of the country's 2,300 independent United Way affiliates and its program to reach the smaller agencies could influence other affiliates to do the same, said Tom Nunan, vice president of United Way of America.
 
Federation of Service Agencies
In the New York region in the last several years, United Way affiliates have been increasing their support for the homeless and for programs concerning AIDS, drug addiction and illiteracy, said Janet Weinstein, senior vice president of United Way of Tri-State, which represents 36 independent United Way organizations in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
The New York City organization has already designated some money under the new program. A $100,000 grant, for example, will help the city's fast-growing Asian population create a federation of service agencies comparable to the federations that link Jewish, Catholic, Protestant, black and Hispanic agencies - all recipients of United Way money. In addition, $480,000 will go to improve the management and fund-raising methods of Associated Black Charities, a seven-year-old federation of 59 agencies.
Unspecified sums will help agencies working in racially tense neighborhoods, Mr. Dickerson said. For example, he said, more money will be channeled to agencies working with teen-agers on the Lower East Side of Manhattan and in the South Bronx.
United Way collects contributions from corporations, foundations and individuals participating in payroll-deduction programs. By long-standing custom it shares part of its proceeds with five established agencies, or ''partners'' - the American Red Cross, the American Cancer Society, the American Heart Association, the Salvation Army and the United Hospital Fund. Under a 10-year-old formula, the five share 48 percent of United Way's net campaign collections.
 
Growing Minority Population
The United Way of New York City campaign raised $72 million last year, and after expenses, divided $51.2 million among the 400 United Way members, including the religious federations. The Red Cross received the largest share, $12.4 million.
Some critics of the disbursement system complain that dividing funds by formula has slighted organizations representing the city's growing minority population, many created in the last decade.
''African-Americans and minorities need to build their own independent philanthropic organizations to meet the needs of their communities,'' said Kermit Eady, president of the Black United Fund, which declined United Way membership and raises its own funds. David R. Jones, president of the Community Service Society, noted that United Way's critics have questioned whether the existing sharing formula met the greatest needs of those living in poverty.
But Mr. Dickerson defended the partnership arrangement, arguing that the Red Cross and Salvation Army were major providers of shelters and services for the poor.

LENGTH: 867 words

HEADLINE: Bishop Mugavero Sees Liberal Legacy

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
The day after Pope John Paul II appointed a new, self-proclaimed conservative bishop to head the Diocese of Brooklyn, the departing bishop said that he was confident that his liberal legacy would continue in the diocese.
''It's not one person'' who sets the tone, Bishop Francis J. Mugavero said in an interview yesterday.
''And, remember, most of the priests and the religious and the lay people in the diocese were born in Kings and Queens,'' he added, using the official names of the counties that make up the two-borough Diocese of Brooklyn. ''It's in the blood.'' 
Since the appointment on Tuesday of his successor, Bishop Thomas V. Daily of Palm Beach, Fla., some Brooklyn Roman Catholics have expressed concern that their long-independent diocese would become subservient to its larger neighbor, the Archdiocese of New York, and its powerful leader, John Cardinal O'Connor.
 
Playing Down Differences
Bishop Daily, who has already criticized Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for his support for abortion rights, has expressed views closer to those of the Cardinal than Bishop Mugavero.
Bishop Daily, who spent most of his career in Boston, was appointed despite Bishop Mugavero's publicly stated preference for a successor ''who knows the territory.''
But in the interview, Bishop Mugavero, who has reached the mandatory retirement age of 75, minimized both the geographical and ideological differences between himself and Bishop Daily.
He said that he was confident that the diocese, with 1.6 million Catholics, was ''in good hands'' with Bishop Daily at the helm.
 
Similarities to Boston
''He had a great experience in Boston,'' Bishop Mugavero said. ''Boston is very similar to Brooklyn.''
He noted that like Brooklyn and Queens, Boston has a multi-ethnic population, large poverty-ridden pockets and racial divisions. ''He grew up in that atmosphere. He understands it.''
''He's smart, you know,'' the Bishop added. ''He can pick things up. He has good experience up there.''
As for the liberal-conservative contrast that has been drawn between them, Bishop Mugavero said the labels were insufficient to encapsulate issues that are far more complex. ''In terms of Catholic doctrine and faith, it's conservative,'' he said, ''but in terms of human services, you've got to be liberal.''
 
Wide-Ranging Issues
As Catholic bishops, both Bishop Mugavero and Bishop Daily are members of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, a body of 300 prelates who try to help apply Catholic teachings to the particular needs of Americans. The bishops have made a wide range of public statements on issues like abortion, homosexuality, AIDS, nuclear war and the American economy. While Bishop Mugavero has been associated with the liberal wing of the conference, Bishop Daily is regarded as a conservative.
At a news conference in Brooklyn on Tuesday, Bishop Daily embraced the conservative label and confirmed it when he said that he would bar Governor Cuomo from speaking in the diocese's 220 churches because of his views on abortion. The Governor has said that as a Catholic, he is opposed to abortion, but does not want to impose his views on others.
During his 22 years as bishop, Bishop Mugavero has written more than 20 official statements, known as ''pastoral letters,'' strongly condemning abortion. But, an aide said, his comments on abortion to Governor Cuomo and other Catholic politicians have been made in private rather than in public forums.
A review of Bishop Mugavero's tenure as Bishop shows that he has been involved in a number of issues.
 
Advocate for the Poor
He deplored ''racially motivated violence'' after the much-publicized racial murders in Bensonhurst and Howard Beach. He founded the Campaign for Human Development, a national fund-raising drive for self-help poverty programs, and was one of the founders of the Nehemiah housing program, which enables the poor to buy their own homes.
He also founded the first diocesan office to provide spiritual and social assistance to new immigrants. And has been a vigorous advocate for the rights of undocumented aliens.
Bishop Mugavero has been a strident voice for priestly celibacy, but he has maintained friendly relationships with priests who have left their parishes to marry.
He has been a strong advocate of keeping families together, but he has been understanding of families in distress. As a result, he has used the canons of the church to grant annulments where they are permitted. His diocesan tribunal, which rules on annulments, is one of the best staffed and most efficient in the nation.
When he ventured into politics, he was bipartisan. In 1973, for example, he wrote an open letter to the four New York City candidates for mayor saying that the city suffers from ''Manhattanopia,'' a syndrome that results, he said, in an excessive focus on one borough, often to the exclusion of the rest.
In his retirement, Bishop Mugavero will continue to live in the official residence in the Fort Greene section that he has occupied for 22 years. Bishop Daily will live in a nearby rectory next to the headquarters of the Brooklyn Diocese.
''It's better that way,'' Bishop Mugavero said.

Daily, his appointed successor, at the helm. (The New York Times/Marilynn K. Yee)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Architect's Challenge: Making 60 Rooms Cozy

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
EVEN its architect cannot seem to keep the number of rooms straight. ''I think there are about 60 of them, and 11 or 12 bathrooms,'' Francis C. Klein said of the mammoth private house that he has just completed on a 13-acre property in Fairfield County, Conn.
''What I do know,'' added the architect, who is based in Montclair, N.J., ''is that the house is as long as a New York City block.''
Three floors high, 200 feet long and 21,000 square feet in all, the house was completed last December after a two-and-a-half-year haul: six months to design it, two years to build it. Among its rooms are a squash court, a ballet studio, a dining room for 18, two laundry rooms, a 24-foot-square kitchen, and stair landings big enough to double as children's play areas. 
A recent inventory placed the number of telephones, each with 20 lines, at 50. ''They may get more,'' Mr. Klein said. And this is just a weekend and summer home.
''The only new house that I ever heard of on the East Coast that's bigger is Ivan Lendl's and that included an indoor basketball court,'' Mr. Klein said. Yet this house is about a third the size of the Aaron Spelling's two-year-old Hollywood mansion, which is 65,000 square feet. And it has about half as many rooms as Mar-a-Lago, Donald and Ivana Trump's home in Palm Beach, Fla.
Mr. Klein is no novice to large scale. He said he built about a half-dozen ''pretty large houses, 4,000 to 5,000 square feet, in the Hamptons.'' He said ''a normal house is about 2,000 square feet, and a big house in the New Jersey suburbs is 3,000 square feet.''
The clients, who want to remain anonymous, rent an apartment in New York City. The husband is a commodities broker and squash champion; the wife recently stopped working in his business to take care of their three daughters, all 6 years old or younger. Two older girls from his previous marriage visit often.
The architect said of his clients: ''He is New York and Brooklyn, and Coney Island is especially important to him. She likes simple things - large and simple things.
''She showed me clippings of English country and Shaker houses. He clipped Colorado ranches. I came out of a more shingle-style background.''
Mr. Klein worked for I. M. Pei & Partners in New York before opening his own firm five years ago. Two staff architects, Susan Guppy and Tim Fleck, worked on the project.
At a time when most architects are battling the problems of tiny spaces, Mr. Klein had the dubious privilege of designing a house that would look and feel smaller than it is.
''I call that a real challenge,'' admitted Mr. Klein, whose wife is the owner's sister. ''It was hard to make it human, and it's still pretty hard to comprehend the whole thing.
''Lots of light, big rooms and places to run around were my instructions. They're very informal, active people. Not tuxedo party types.''
Like the proverbial Topsy, the house just seemed to grow and grow. ''We realized pretty early on that it was very, very big,'' he said. ''It was my job to make it work.'' On the exterior, the house looks like a series of cozily scaled buildings - a mini-Main Street. The look is part hunting lodge, part Western ranch, part English country and part Alpine chalet, with touches of Shaker simplicity - a hard-won synthesis of what the clients had in mind.
The house is set on a hill and approached along a winding unpaved road that weaves through heavy woods. The final approach is surprisingly approachable; one could even call the 200-foot-long facade with robin's-egg blue trim quaint.
''Siting was very important,'' Mr. Klein said. ''If you arrived head-on, instead of at an angle, it would have been overpowering.''
The house is clad with Connecticut stone and tongue-and-groove vertical cedar siding with a copper-colored pigmented stain. The wood-shingle roofs are edged in copper, and the drainpipes are copper. The elements of the facade are connected with flagstone and fretwork-trimmed porches (''They had just been to Austria and brought back some pictures of chalets for me to think about,'' Mr. Klein said), and enlivened with what seems to be a catalogue's worth of bay, double-hung, casement and sliding windows and skylights.
''One of the basic concepts was to find a balance between coherence and variety,'' the architect said. ''Although all the normal family relationships take place - for example, keeping an eye on the kids, cooking, entertaining - everything is far.''
The architect compensated by balancing the 150-foot-long hallways with 8 1/2-, 10 1/2- and 20-foot-high ceilings and grouping the myriad windows in inventive configurations. ''Everything is overscale,'' the architect said.
Even the architectural drawings had to be printed on paper measuring three by four feet to be workable. ''When I first showed them to the structural engineer,'' Mr. Klein recalled, ''he thought I had the scale marked wrong on the drawings.''
Four 10 1/2-foot-high Tuscan pine columns define the marble-floored entrance hall, which opens to a 20-foot-high room. ''That's the family room,'' Mr. Klein said. ''There is no room called a living room in the house. This is a very child-oriented family. They don't sit around much.''
For the time being, that's just as well, as the house is essentially unfurnished. Recently a dozen beds were delivered; delivery trucks pull up often. But many rooms are still filled with boxes.
In the 24-by-40-foot music room, there is not only a grand piano but a sampling of the owners' collection of musical antiques, a pinball machine and a vintage jukebox. ''A merry-go-round will probably be next,'' Mr. Klein said.
Only the kitchen and the library are complete. In the library, glass-topped cases hold rare books, while floor-to-ceiling shelves are lined with titles that range from ''How to Design and Build Your Own Home,'' and ''How to Teach Your Baby to Swim'' to ''Boy Broker'' and ''Jefferson at Monticello.''
Piles of children's books surround the window seat. ''They really want to encourage reading,'' Mr. Klein said. A staircase leads to the children's wing on the second floor.
He added that inside, orientation was the major issue. ''Even the contractors - 'It's not a house, but an inn,' remarked one - had to think about it by areas,'' said the architect, who was concerned with providing the occupants and their visitors with visual cues. ''This can get very confusing, especially for small children.''
Mr. Klein said construction costs were in the $150-a-square-foot range.
''That's good quality, middle-of-the-road domestic construction,'' said Mr. Klein. ''Luxury building can be double or more. And there are some economies of scale. You pay for the truck whether you buy 3 or 250 windows.''
One potentially astronomical operating expense is air-conditioning. ''They hate it and will never use it,'' Mr. Klein said. ''But they put it in, in case they ever decide to sell the house.''
For the family's use, the architect installed about two dozen ceiling fans. Twenty transom windows, operated by two manual cranks, also provide ventilation. ''Just like in old schoolhouses,'' Mr. Klein said.
The architect also provided two exits for each of the eight second-floor bedrooms, ''in case of a fire,'' he said. ''The balconies, which are both exits and play areas, became an important design element.''
Most of the woodwork in the house is standard-issue including the main staircase with its 60-foot-long balustrade and 200 Shaker-style spindles. But the kitchen cabinets were custom made of cherry, with 110 Shaker style knobs.
Doors, bathroom sinks and tiles were all off-the-rack items. ''That was our attempt to be reasonable,'' Mr. Klein said. ''We didn't ransack the earth to get anything unusual.''
Nevertheless, the quantities are mind-boggling: 14,000 square feet of oak flooring, 1,000 square feet of floor tile, 1,000 square feet of marble tile, 1,000 light fixtures, close to 200 doors and 250 windows.
''That was a nice order,'' Mr. Klein said. ''I think the company sent me a monogrammed pen for specifying their product.''

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
Purchase of Cummins Stake Looks Less Sacrificial Now

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
When the family that founded the Cummins Engine Company bought out an unwelcome suitor last July, family members made much of the fact that the $72 million they had personally paid Hanson P.L.C. for its 10 percent stake was $5 million more than the going price.
''We ate the premium,'' boasted William I. Miller, a 33-year-old descendant of the family that put the world's largest independent maker of diesel engines on the map 70 years ago. ''It was not a very 80's thing to do,'' he added.
The story of their apparent sacrifice played well to a public hungry for examples showing the vulnerability of corporations and their financial backers in an age of easy takeovers and short-term profiteers. Hanson is a British conglomerate well known as a corporate raider. Statements at the time by the family patriarch, J. Irwin Miller, the 80-year-old retired chairman of the diesel-engine maker, reinforced the feeling that the family was taking a stand against a Wall Street driven by institutional investors preoccupied with quarterly gains. 
But the deal has returned to haunt the company and the three members of the Miller family. A large dissident shareholder of Cummins, Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., challenged the transaction's fairness in a suit it filed last week in Federal District Court in Indianapolis. In the suit, Industrial Equity contends that the Miller family was motivated by greed, not by charity, and that Cummins used the Miller family to disguise what was, in fact, ''greenmail,'' the use of shareholder money to buy off an unwanted predator.
Cummins's advisers declined to comment yesterday on the allegations because of the suit, and William Miller's secretary said he was out of the office and unavailable for comment.
But a closer look at the transaction shows that the family, while easing fears that an American institution and its community might fall into unfriendly foreign hands, bought the Hanson stake only to divest itself of its entire stock holdings immediately in exchange for an enviable package of new securities issued by Cummins.
The result should earn the Millers millions of dollars in annual profits that they would not have received otherwise.
In trying to force a public re-evaluation of the transaction, Industrial Equity faces some hurdles, not the least of which is the written opinion Cummins secured from its advisers at Morgan Stanley & Company attesting to the deal's fairness.
In addition, more than one United States company has paid greenmail to Industrial Equity, itself controlled by Brierley Investments Ltd., a New Zealand corporation. The practice of paying greenmail is legal but questionable, and it does not make the recipient too popular. Nor will it help Industrial Equity's case that it waited seven months before challenging the fairness of the July transaction. Bruce Hancox, a senior official at Industrial Equity, said the delay was largely to avoid impairing his company's campaign to secure a seat on Cummins's board.
But Industrial Equity's track record as a corporate raider and its slowness in challenging the transaction do not undermine its contention that the deal was generous to the Millers, and many securities analysts, traders and economic experts who reviewed the terms agree with it.
''They got themselves into a much better position than they were before,'' said George Froley, managing director of the Froley, Revy Investment Company, a Los Angeles money management firm that specializes in stocks and bonds that can be converted into other securities.
In fact, the experts say, the two-step deal should have raised red flags almost immediately. ''Anytime you have a large holder surrendering his equity stake and taking back securities, I think you want to look very closely at the terms of those securities to see if he might have gotten a substantial premium for his holdings,'' said John Finnerty, a professor of finance at Fordham University who specializes in securities innovation.
Complexity certainly helped obscure the true pricing of the Cummins deal with Hanson. Before the deal, the Miller family owned 580,269 Cummins shares, representing a 5 percent stake. In July, the family bought Hanson's 1.043 million shares for an average price of $69.33 a share - $4.83 above Cummins's $64.50 share price at the time.
Had the Millers stopped there, they would have insulated Cummins's management from charges of paying greenmail while boldly displaying their own vote of confidence in Cummins by increasing their exposure to the ups and downs of its stock.
But that did not appear to be their intention, as is clear from the back end of the transaction. The same day they purchased the Hanson stake, the Millers swapped their new-total holdings of 1.6 million common shares for a $104.7 million package of Cummins securities. Some securities were labeled subordinated debt and some were called preferred stock for Cummins's tax purposes, but they were otherwise identical - and equally generous to the Millers.
For one thing, the securities yield 10 percent annually, 6.6 percentage points more than the 3.4 percent that Cummins's common stock was yielding last July. Over five years, that fatter income stream will put $52.4 million into the Millers' pockets, versus the $17.6 million in dividends they would have been entitled to as owners of 1.6 million common shares. The $34.8 million differential might even be understated if continued losses and heavy capital spending force Cummins to cut its common dividend, as some analysts fear.
Then, at the end of five years, when the securities mature, the Millers can expect to receive at a minimum $104.7 million in cash, when the company redeems their holdings for 100 cents on the dollar, so long as the company is still a going concern. The Millers could do even better. Their securities are convertible at $83.85 a share, which means that they can turn their convertible stake into 1.248 million common shares in lieu of demanding that their $104.7 million holdings be redeemed at face value should Cummins's stock price soar.
This bit of financial engineering gives the Millers protection from loss in return for sacrificing only some of their potential gains. In effect they purchased a ''put option,'' giving them the right to sell their shares back to the company at a fixed price at the end of five years. That explains why the company's stock plunged right after the three-way deal was announced: the company's most influential investor had essentially moved from a bullish position on the company's stock to a hedged position.
The Millers' strategy would backfire only if the common stock, now at $45.875, surpassed its all-time high of $94.75.
''You've got to have fairly high appreciation in the common stock in order for the common stock to be the better alternative,'' Professor Finnerty said. ''There's that possibility, but a rational investor would probably take the 10 percent yield that goes with the convertible securities.''
Indeed, it is hard not to find the convertible securities the more attractive alternative. The Millers are poised to enjoy a fatter and more secure dividend income and to avoid losses on their stock holdings if the stock plunges. If the company gets into deep financial trouble, the Millers will also receive some preference over the common stockholders.
Given all that, the $5 million premium begins looking like a fairly cheap price to have paid for the privilege of being freed from the risks of a struggling company. Other shareholders will face all the fury of a fluctuating stock price.

HEADLINE: U.S. Policy On Deposits Is Criticized

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that regulators were searching for ways to permit very large banks to fail without the Government bailing out all depositors and creditors who might face losses.
Mr. Seidman said the regulatory policy under which the Government provides full protection for institutions it considers ''too big to fail'' had become too expensive.
That policy reflects the view of many regulators that many of the largest banks and savings and loans cannot be dissolved because they are so large that such action would create huge losses to uninsured depositors and send shocks through stock and credit markets.
 
Full-Coverage Policy
So the Government now routinely steps in to assure depositors that they will be covered for their full deposits. 
In effect, this policy has created unlimited depositors' insurance at the large institutions, in contrast to most Federally insured banks and savings and loan institutions, where depositors are guaranted against losses of up to $100,000.
Testifying before the House Banking Committee, Mr. Seidman suggested that the policy should change.
''You are going to have to have a system in which depositors at all institutions can lose something,'' Mr. Seidman said, adding that drains on the F.D.I.C.'s resources in recent years had led him to conclude that ''we have to find some way to reduce the risk and losses from deposit insurance.''
 
Congressional Consideration
To bring about the change Mr. Seidman is contemplating, regulators could simply adopt policies that abandon the ''too big to fail'' approach. Acknowledging that such a change would have broad and unknown effects on the financial markets and on investors, Mr. Seidman suggested today that such a step would be more appropriate for Congress.
But he cautioned that any change in how collapses are handled should retain protections against disruption of the financial markets.
Mr. Seidman said the F.D.I.C. had not agreed on any one approach to changing current policy, which was adopted in 1984 when regulators decided to cover all deposits and creditors at the Continental Bank and Trust Company in Chicago, rather than risk a financial panic.
Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, warned earlier this month that shakiness in vast areas of Government guarantees and insurance were almost certain to cost taxpayers ''tens of billions of dollars,'' and that measures had to be taken to reduce the taxpayers' exposure to such losses.
Since deposit insurance covers more than $3 trillion of funds at commercial banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions, it is at the core of concern about the potential liability to taxpayers.
 
Shift in Stance
Mr. Seidman has repeatedly told Congress in his four and a half years as F.D.I.C. chief that he saw no way around the ''too big to fail'' policy. But today, he noted that covering all depositors and most creditors in large bank failures has created by far the largest losses at the F.D.I.C.
The savings and loan bailout signed by the President last summer calls for spending $159 billion over the next 10 years to shut and sell hundreds of sick institutions. But lawmakers then did not address the deposit insurance crisis and how it has contributed to the increased risk-taking by some banks that landed them into deep trouble. Instead, the Treasury was directed to conduct an 18-month study on deposit insurance. Comments are to be submitted by the end of next month.
Financial experts have noted that in the early and mid-1980's, savings associations made extremely risky investments in raw land and building projects. To attract money to make such loans, the institutions offered high interest rates on deposits, gaining billions of dollars almost overnight. But in the end they had large losses.
 
Risks Often Ignored
Depositors who know they are backed by Federal insurance have little incentive to discriminate between conservative, well-run banks and high-flying, poorly run ones. This means that deposits flow to the highest payer, regardless of risk, and losses are borne by the Govenrment, and ultimately the taxpayer.
''Without any market penalties for assuming more risk,'' Mr. Seidman added, banks are actually encouraged to do keep doing so.
The ''too big'' policy has irked thousands of small bankers around the country for years. They argue that there is a double standard, since, when some of their members have become insolvent, the F.D.I.C. has observed its limits on covering deposits.
Mr. Seidman, who has been sympathetic to this argument, has said that the F.D.I.C. has tried to prevent depositors at small banks from losing by pushing hard to find buyers for the entire bank. But that policy has not always worked, and the F.D.I.C. has had to liquidate some small banks, forcing some depositors to take losses.
 
Several Proposals Studied
Mr. Seidman said the F.D.I.C. was studying several proposals. One would impose an immmediate 10 percent loss on all uninsured deposits when a bank failed, essentially returning 90 cents on every uninsured dollar. Another plan calls for the banking industry to establish its own form of private deposit insurance to cover amounts above $100,000.
Mr. Seidman said deposit insurance reform was vital if the Bank Insurance Fund, which insures deposits at commercial banks, was to remain solvent over the long term.
He said its reserves were close to an all-time low relative to total deposits insured, and that if the banking industry saw a repeat of the crisis in Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana, the money could be exhausted and taxpayers might have to bail out the system once again.
But he added, ''At this time, we don't see any area that is going to result in that level of bank failures.''

HEADLINE: Court Backs Broad Definition for Securities

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21

 BODY:
Endorsing a broad interpretation of Federal securities law, the Supreme Court ruled today that many unsecured promissory notes, sold privately and not traded on any stock exchange, were subject to Federal regulation as securities.
The 5-to-4 decision reversed a Federal appeals court in St. Louis, which held that some $10 million worth of notes sold by an agricultural cooperative, unsecured and payable on demand, were not securities.
In 1984, the cooperative went bankrupt and defaulted on notes held by more than 1,600 people, some of whom sued the cooperative's accountant for fraud. 
A jury awarded the holders $6.1 million against the accountant, Arthur Young & Company, now known as Ernst & Young. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, which overturned the judgment, ruled that Federal law did not apply because the notes were not securities.
In deciding today that the Eighth Circuit was incorrect, the Supreme Court resolved an ambiguity that has existed since passage of the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
Those laws provide a framework for Federal regulation of securities, defined to include stocks, bonds and a variety of other financial instruments including notes with a maturity of at least nine months.
But the term notes is so general that courts had little guidance as to what came within the laws' definition. The lower Federal courts had been widely divided.
The Supreme Court adopted an approach that has been developed by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in New York, and that is also favored by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The opinion, written by Justice Thurgood Marshall, outlines an analysis based on ''economic reality.''
First, Justice Marshall said, ''we examine the transaction to assess the motivations that would prompt a reasonable seller and buyer to enter into it.'' He said a note was likely to be a security ''if the seller's purpose is to raise money for the general use of a business enterprise or to finance substantial investments and the buyer is interested primarily in the profit the note is expected to generate.''
By contrast, he said, a note issued ''to facilitate the purchase and sale of a minor asset or consumer good'' or to solve a temporary cash-flow problem is most likely not a security.
The second step, Justice Marshall said, was to decide whether there was ''common trading'' in the note ''for speculation or investment,'' which would give the note the quality of a security. Next, he said, a court should assess ''public expectations.''
Justice Marshall said that if these factors indicated that the note was a security, a court should then consider whether Federal regulation was necessary.
Justice Marshall said a note should generally be presumed to be a security unless it bears a ''family resemblance'' to a list of transactions that the Second Circuit had identified as not being securities. These include mortgage notes and short-term business and consumer loans.
The Court said a note could still be a security even if it had no fixed term and was payable on demand, as was the case with the cooperative notes.
In a dissenting opinion, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said that notes payable on demand could not qualify as securities because they did not meet the statutory test for a maturity of at least nine months.
The majority opinion, Reves v. Ernst & Young, No. 88-1480, was joined by Justices William J. Brennan Jr., Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens and Anthony M. Kennedy. The dissent was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia.
