HEADLINE: Market Place;
Can Macy Endure Price-Cutting?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
MORE than three years after its leveraged buyout, R. H. Macy & Company is encountering doubts about its ability to survive if the current wave of price-cutting by major retailing chains continues. Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it was considering cutting the rating on Macy's already low-rated ''junk bonds,'' sending the prices of the bonds down further and prompting an angry response from the company.
The Moody's statement said the rating agency was worried that Macy ''might not have the financial flexibility to cope with any long-term price competition.''
The dispute centered on just how much Macy has been and will be hurt by the price-cutting that was prompted in large part by the financial problems of competitors, most notably the subsiaries of the Campeau Corporation, which have filed for bankruptcy protection. 
''We've done all the scenarios, and we have sufficient liquidity in every scenario we try,'' Myron Ullman, Macy's chief financial officer, said in an interview yesterday. ''We expect to return to historical levels of profitability.''
The reassuring statements from management provided little help for Macy's bond issues, which fell sharply and now show yields of well over 20 percent. Such a high yield signals substantial investor worry regarding the ability of a company to pay its bills. Just over a month ago, the Macy 14.5 percent senior subordinated debentures, due in 1998, were trading at $980 per $1,000 bond. Yesterday, the bid price fell $70, to $720, traders said.
There is no question that Macy had a rough time as 1989 ended. In a letter to investors last week, the company said December sales were up 9.5 percent, or 7.7 percent on a comparable store basis, but it added that price-cutting ''will have a significant adverse effect on margins and the bottom line.''
Reacting to Moody's yesterday, the company added that ''the quarterly results Macy's expects soon to report are the product of a previously stated plan to protect market share during the all-important Christmas season and enter spring with appropriate inventory levels.'' It said, ''That plan was successfully executed and Macy's continues to be a strong force in the marketplace.''
Macy has recently trimmed staffing and inventory levels in a reorganization eliminating some management positions.
Despite the heavy interest burdens stemming from its 1986 leveraged buyout and the 1988 purchase from Campeau of Bullock's, a California retailer, Macy reported a profit in the Christmas quarter a year ago. Figures for the recent quarter, ended Jan. 27, will not be out until mid-March, but a loss is expected.
Trying to reassure investors that things are getting better, Macy's statement yesterday said preliminary results for February ''indicate that bottom-line performance will be well ahead of last year's level.'' The company did not say whether it made any money in February of last year.
Macy called Moody's action ''totally unwarranted'' and complained that it had no contact from Moody's before the statement was issued. A Moody's official said that was standard procedure, and added that the company would get a chance to make its case before a rating decision was made.
Macy's statement said the company's ''financial structure is sound, with ample liquidity to meet the short-term as well as the long-term needs of the business.'' It added that ''Macy has recently met with its principal bank lenders and they are comfortable with Macy's financial position.'' ''We trust,'' it said, ''with the benefit of further information, Moody's will reach this same conclusion.''
Moody's currently rates the three major publicly traded Macy bonds as B-3, a low level of junk bond. A further cut would be to Caa, a rating that Bill Mendenhall, a Moody's analyst, said was ''a rating where you would really see the company having difficulty getting out of the situation they are in.'' Moody's main competitor, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, already rates some Macy bonds at CCC, a level equivalent to Moody's Caa.
Macy's results had indicated that the company was doing well enough to meet its obligations. Although margins dipped in the October quarter, the last that has been reported, for the 12 months through October it still had ample cash flow to cover interest payments.
Macy still has friends on Wall Street. Evan Mann, a high-yield bond analyst at Dillon, Read, said that even assuming margins stayed as low as they were in the October quarter, and that sales gains were poor, his projections indicate that Macy could meet all its obligations in future years.
''Assuming the economy doesn't really slip into a severe recession where consumers totally stop spending, the company should be a survivor long-term,'' Mr. Mann said.
But junk bond buyers, who have been burned before, are cautious. Mr. Mann said that investors he talked to found his calculations interesting, but they were unwilling to act until they saw the results of the Christmas quarter.

HEADLINE: Dow Finishes 13.29 Lower After a Big Decline Earlier

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday, pulled down initially by a report of a 1.1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for last month.
The larger-than-expected rise in the index was the biggest in more than seven years and and traders said it precipitated a drop of about 28 points in the Dow Jones industrial average shortly after the market opened.
But the Dow revived somewhat to finish 13.29 points lower, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,583.56. On Tuesday, it had tumbled by 38.74 points, or by 1.5 percent, as traders worried about a sharp rise in long-term Treasury interest rates. 
 
Lowest Since Jan. 30
The Dow's closing level yesterday was the lowest since Jan. 30, when the average finished at 2,543.24. Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday outnumbered advancing ones, 963 to 577.
The traders said yesterday's drop was also aggravated by a decline in the Tokyo stock market, where the Nikkei index of 225 issues plunged by 1,161.19 points, or by 3.15 percent, to 35,734.33. It was the third-largest daily drop in the indicator's history and the equivalent of about an 80-point drop in the Dow.
The Japanese market made a slight recovery today after an early selloff. The Nikkei index edged up 92.51 points, to close at 35,826.84.
The sharp decline in Japan was primarily attributed to concern over the worldwide increase in interest rates, although some analysts suggested that it was related to Tuesday's weakness in the American stock market.
''The market's decline here was in sharp contrast to the plunge in Tokyo,'' said Robert Ritter, the chief technical analyst at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. ''It appears as if either the Japanese market reacted to Tuesday's decline in the United States, or else the connection is not as precise as many observers seem to think.''
 
Considering Other Factors
He said higher interest rates and declines in profits were affecting equity markets in both countries, but other factors were also coming into play.
''In the United States, the budget deficit and tax policy are affecting different industry sectors, while a changing foreign policy should benefit several important industrial and economic areas,'' Mr. Ritter said. ''Japan has its own special economic and domestic problems.''
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dipped by 0.32 point, to 327.67, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell by 0.30 point, to 181.07.
Volume on the Big Board rose to a moderate 159.2 million shares, from 147.3 million on Tuesday.
Among individual issues, Digital fell by 1 1/8, to a 52-week low of 72 7/8, after the company said that it was ''walking a fairly thin line'' on whether it would report profits for its third quarter ending in March.
I.B.M., which rose by 2 points, to 104 7/8, helped stabilize the market.
 
Texas Instruments Up
Texas Intruments rose by 3/8, to 32 1/4, after the Dallas-based company said it had produced its first memory device that can store 16 million pieces of information. A company spokesman said the first high-memory chip was produced on Feb. 12, a day before I.B.M. said it had built its first 16 million-bit chip. Texas Instruments said such chips were prototypes and were not ready yet for commercial shipment.
USAir remained unchanged, at 28 1/8, although the company's stock was upgraded to ''buy,'' from ''neutral,'' by Edward Starkman, an analyst for Paine Webber Inc.
The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, jumped by 1 1/8, to 56 3/4. Timothy Pettee, an analyst for Merrill Lynch & Company, said he had raised his rating on the stock, also to ''buy,'' from ''neutral.''
 
UAL Rises to $132.25
The UAL Corporation climbed by 5 1/8, to 132 1/4. The stock of the company, based in Elk Grove Village, Ill., advanced before today's board meeting, but takeover analysts said the meeting should produce little other than the possible announcement of collective bargaining agreements with the company's three primary unions - the pilots, flight attendants and machinists. Together, they are seeking to acquire 75 percent of UAL, the parent of United Airlines.
The gains in UAL and AMR gave the Dow transportation average a solid 16.72-point advance, to 1,084.64.
The active blue-chip issues included Philip Morris, off by 1/8, to 37 5/8, and the busiest Big Board issue on a volume of nearly 2.3 million shares; A.T.& T., down by 1/4, to 38 3/4; General Electric, off by 3/8, to 60 1/2; Chemical Bank, down by 1/8, to 26 1/4, and W. R. Grace & Co., off by 1/4, to 29 1/4.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index fell by 1.93 points, to 352.95.
In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index declined by 2.31 points, to 421.52. Microsoft dropped by 4 1/8, to 96 1/8. The company, based in Redmond, Wash., said it knew of no developments to explain the decline, or a 2 1/4-point rise on Tuesday. Chemical Bankingd(Chemical)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Move Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly higher in thin, nervous trading yesterday after a mixed performance overseas.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $418 an ounce, down $1.90 from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $417.80 an ounce, off $2.10.
The dollar started out higher in Japan, but it fell back in Europe as dealers became unnerved by falling stock prices in Tokyo and a bond market rally in West Germany. Those worries, however, failed to have a big impact on traders in New York.
 
No Incentive
''I don't think there's any incentive to buy or sell,'' said Earl I. Johnson of the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago. ''The market needs more information on the U.S. economy.
The dollar had little reaction to a Government report showing a 1.1 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index for January, Increased inflation reduces prospects for lower interest rates, which would usually depress the dollar, dealers said.
They said the market had anticipated higher inflation when the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, testified before Congress on Tuesday.
In New York, the dollar traded at 1.6725 marks, up from 1.66835 marks on Tuesday, and 145.50 yen, up from 145.155 yen. The pound cost $1.7125, up from $1.7115.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4795 Swiss francs, up from 1.4785; 5.6730 French francs, up from 5.6670; 1,238.00 Italian lire, up from 1,237.50, and 1.19825 Canadian dollars, down from 1.20075.
Silver prices slipped, with silver for current delivery closing at $5.272 an ounce, down from $5.332 Tuesday. Silver fell 2 cents in London, to $5.33 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Bush, on West Coast, Skirts Two Conservation Issues

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 21

 BODY:
President Bush traveled on the West Coast today, raising campaign money and skirting two conservation issues that have complicated his effort to find new political ground on the environment.
In Portland, Ore., Mr. Bush offered his familiar "find-a-balance" formula to environmentalists and to Republican politicians and timber industry executives. They have been at odds over proposed restrictions to logging on millions of acres; environmentalists say the restrictions are needed to protect the Northern spotted owl from extinction, and opponents say they would wipe out thousands of jobs in logging communities.
In his public comments, the President seemed to lean slightly more toward those who argue that economic considerations outweigh the need to protect the owls. But he carefully avoided taking any clear position before June 23, when the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is to rule on whether the owl will be protected under the Endangered Species Act. 
"I'm interested in the owl," he said, "but I'm also interested in jobs for the American family."
 
Debate Over Offshore Oil
 Mr. Bush also stayed away from discussion of offshore oil drilling while in Los Angeles, where debate over exploration for oil along the coast has been a major political issue for him since the 1988 Presidential campaign.
Mr. Bush has come under mounting pressure from environmental and industry groups to announce a policy on Federal oil leasing off California and Florida, and promised last week to announce a decision within days. But White House aides made it clear in advance that the President was not going to use this trip to do so. Instead, he attended a Republican fund-raising event at a Bel Air mansion, where participants paid $15,000 to $25,000 a plate.
The day reflected Mr. Bush's grappling with environmental issues in the 16 months since he took office. While the President has earned praise from environmentalists for proposing revisions to the Clean Air Act to reduce acid rain, he has tempered his avowals of support for environmental causes by saying they must be balanced with economic concerns.
 
'Save Every Subspecies?'
 The Administration's recent handling of the protection of endangered species has been typical of this approach. Last week the White House rejected a suggestion by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. that the Endangered Species Act be revised to take economic considerations into account.
But Mr. Bush's comments in Portland seemed to reflect Mr. Lujan's notion. "I want to be known as the environmental President," he said, "but I also want to be concerned about a person's ability to hold a job."
In making his suggestion, Mr. Lujan also commented on a debate over whether to allow construction of an observatory in Arizona that environmentalists say will cause the extinction of a subspecies of squirrel, the Mount Graham red squirrel. "Do we have to save every subspecies?" he asked.
That argument had strong resonance in Oregon's debate over the Northern spotted owl, a subspecies of the spotted owl that lives in dense older forests in the Pacific Northwest. As loggers thin those forests, the owl becomes easier prey to the great horned owl. Last month an interagency commission recommended that logging be banned on 8.4 million acres of forest in Washington, Oregon and Northern California to protect the spotted owl.
No action can be taken until the Fish and Wildlife Service determines whether the spotted owl is a "threatened" or "endangered" species under the law. After that, the Administration and Congress would have to agree on a way to save the owl.
 
'A Passive Kind of Owl'
 Some opponents of a logging ban have echoed Mr. Lujan's arguments. "There are millions of owls in the world," said Representative Denny Smith, an Oregon Republican. "This little puppy just happens to be a passive kind of owl that's being run over by the great horned owl."
While Mr. Bush was in Portland on Sunday and today, Mr. Smith and others put pressure on him to take a stand on the dispute. Instead, he offered his split-the-difference formula.
Today, at a fund-raising breakfast for David Frohnmayer, the Republican candidate for governor in Oregon, Mr. Bush drew loud applause when he said: "I reject those who would ignore the economic consequences of the spotted owl decision. The jobs of many thousands of Oregonians and whole communities are at stake."
Then he added a sentence that left his audience silent but cheered some of the two dozen protesters who stood outside. "But I also think that we ought to reject those who do not recognize their obligation to protect our delicate ecosystem," he said.
"Common sense tells us to find a needed balance," he said in conclusion. "Together, I'm convinced we can work to find that balance."

HEADLINE: Big Funds Pressing for Voice In Management of Companies

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Many investment managers, who oversee funds with billions of dollars of company shares, want more of a say in how American corporations are run. And more of them are starting to use their financial muscle to try to obtain it.
The recent effort by several state pension funds to influence the selection process of a new chief executive at the General Motors Corporation is but one example of the new assertiveness of large investors. Increasingly, pension and mutual fund managers are challenging what they consider the inefficiency and wastefulness of many American corporations.
 
Seats on the Board Sought
While some are seeking better communication with directors, others want a seat on the board, either for themselves or for an appointed representative. Their stated aim: to improve corporate performance and thus increase the value of their shareholdings. 
''We're going to be as active as we can be,'' said Roland M. Machold, who oversees New Jersey's $28 billion in pension fund money for thousands of the state's employees.
Institutional investors are becoming increasingly important in the marketplace because the funds under their control are growing sharply while individual investors are leaving in droves. And as the investment funds hold ever-larger portions of major American companies, they feel they face no alternative but to get more involved. They cannot sell their holdings without taking big losses because the act of selling would drive down the value of the shares.
The trend toward investment-fund activism, should it gain momentum, would represent a significant shift in the balance of power in corporate governance, reducing the dominance of managers and giving greater influence to major shareholders.
The new activism differs markedly from earlier efforts. In the past, public pension funds typically pushed ideological goals - putting pressure on companies to withdraw from South Africa, for example. But this time, the fund managers are pursuing mainly a business agenda.
Moreover, academics and financial executives observing this trend assert that the critical ingredients for waging a successful campaign appear to be falling into place. The main ones include: a nucleus of pension and mutual fund managers willing to abandon their traditional role as passive investors and take the lead in getting more involved in company policies; encouragement in Washington from members of the Bush Administration for their efforts, and, perhaps most important, increasing economic necessity.
 
'An Ownership Culture'
Taken collectively, said Robert A. G. Monks, president of the Institutional Shareholders Service Inc., a Washington proxy-advisory firm, these steps are ''the beginnings of the development of an ownership culture.''
More aggressive owners could well pose a challenge to sleepy chief executives or those who treat their companies as personal fiefdoms. To be sure, fund managers are not owners in the traditional sense; they are fiduciaries, making investments on behalf of others, like employees or investors. Nevertheless, some of the country's leading institutional investors are exhibiting the kind of assertiveness associated with owners.
These are some of the examples:
* The fund managers of New York and California have been successful in getting General Motors management to discuss the criteria used to select and monitor the company's new chief executive.
* California's public pension fund has asked the directors of UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, to investigate the company's decision to pay $58 million in investment banking fees for a failed management-led bid for the company. Other large investors, including the public pension fund of Massachusetts, are supporting that effort.
* Two large money-management companies, Fidelity Investments and the Mutual Shares Corporation, have made changes in their investment policies to make it easier for them to join others in influencing managements and boards. Fidelity's general counsel, Robert C. Pozen, says his fund managers also work behind the scenes with companies they are concerned about.
* California's fund manager has submitted shareholder proposals to Avon Products, TRW and Occidental Petroleum to establish ''shareholder advisory committees'' that would work closely with the boards of those companies.
* California's pension fund has also written a letter to the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking 48 regulatory changes that would facilitate communication among large shareholders and give shareholders a greater say. Fidelity has expressed its support for such an effort.
 
Others Ready to Move
Clearly, efforts to date have been concentrated in a handful of public funds, like California's. But other fund managers said that did not reflect a lack of interest on their part, but rather a calculated decision to push the better-organized funds to the forefront.
''We've basically said, 'You guys take the lead, and we'll join you where it's appropriate,' '' said Paul F. Quirk, who oversees the Massachusetts public pension fund system.
Mr. Quirk noted that Dale M. Hanson, who manages more than $56 billion in assets for the State of California, has just been put in charge of a new strategic planning committee of the Council of Institutional Investors, which represents more than 60 public funds. The purpose of that committee will be to insure more coherence in efforts involving council members.
''There was more this year, and there will be a lot more of it next year,'' said Mr. Quirk, the chairman of the council's executive committee. Mr. Hanson has already engaged a research group to help identify companies with poor performance records.
 
Sharp Growth
Fund managers are in a better position to exercise their potential for power than even a few years ago because of the big growth of the money under their control and the simultaneous decline in the role of the individual investor in the market.
Twenty-five years ago, according to the Securities Industry Association, institutional investors owned 16 percent of all equities, with households making up the rest. By mid-1989, institutions made up 43 percent of stock ownership. And at large companies, ownership is even more concentrated: Big institutional investors own 52 percent of the equity of the top 50 companies in the United States, a Columbia University study found.
''By the year 2,000, they will own two-thirds of the equity of major corporations,'' said Ira M. Millstein, a lawyer at Weil, Gotshal & Manges who headed a study group for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York on this issue.
 
New Power Feared
To some critics, the prospect that a small group of money managers could wield influence over American corporations conjures up sinister images of smoke-filled rooms and greedy power brokers. And the fact that some of the leading figures in this movement come from state, as opposed to private, pension fund circles, serves to accentuate this fear since, as appointed or elected officials, they may harbor political, rather than business, agendas.
Fund managers are also frequently blamed for exacerbating corporate America's focus on short-term, quarterly profits, because that is how the managers are evaluated and paid.
Other fund managers, however, argue that a tighter link between the owners of companies and their managers is essential if corporate performance is to be improved and the United States is to become more competitive.
 
Keeping Management Alert
Indeed, with more states enacting laws that inhibit hostile takeovers and many corporate raiders now busy running the industrial companies they have acquired, pension fund activism is increasingly seen as one of the few ways of keeping management on its toes. Institutional investors are not necessarily regarded as wiser than individual investors -just larger and better organized and thus more to be reckoned with.
As Mr. Millstein, who has been particularly active in trying to nudge corporate pension funds, put it, ''If it becomes perceived that they won't vote, won't act, then to whom is corporate America going to be accountable?''
The Bush Administration, unlike its predecessor, seems to be encouraging a more activist approach. In a recent speech to leading chief financial officers, David Ball, an Assistant Secretary of Labor, said that if fund managers believe that a company is poorly run, they can persuade management to change its behavior, they can change management, or they can sell the stock. The latter - far and away the traditional response - is hardly satisfactory, Mr. Ball added, because the sale of a large block of stock could depress prices by as much as 15 percent, making that a costly exit.
 
Proxy Examinations Urged
''Institutional investors have a duty to carefully examine proxy proposals and to reject those which would benefit management as opposed to benefiting the company,'' he said.
Few corporate executives truly welcome new-found assertiveness by large investors, but none was willing to say so publicly for fear of antagonizing them.
''Most companies are very wary,'' said Mr. Machold of New Jersey. ''They regard any large shareholder not as an asset but as a liability. We can't even get them to return our phone calls.'' Mr. Machold's frustration points to the underlying flaw in the public funds' strategy. According to one leading acquirer of corporations, no one will listen to the funds until they are prepared to undertake a show of force, namely, the initiating and winning of a proxy fight.
In 1989, several funds won a proxy fight involving the Honeywell Corporation's attempt to stagger the election of its directors. Shortly thereafter, the management restructured the company and the stock rose. According to one leading public pension fund manager, ''We're looking for another Honeywell. That is one way to get the message across.''
Future efforts are also likely to focus on making boards of directors more responsive through such suggested measures as insuring that at least two-thirds of a board's members are completely independent of management and paying directors and managers less in cash and more in stock.

HEADLINE: A Rising Sun Beckons, to Highly Paid Drudgery

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil

 BODY:
At 24 years of age, Hiroyaki Chibana embodies a new kind of success story in Liberdade, this city's Japanese neighborhood.
Fed up with scraping out a living pumping gas and hawking meat pies, he set off at 18 to seek his fortune in Japan, a land his parents had abandoned decades earlier.
Today, he is the proud owner of a busy corner luncheonette, the fruit of earnings saved from a two-year stint in an Osaka metal shop.
''I just sent my brother off to Tokyo to put together a stake for a new venture,'' the young entrepreneur said, standing behind his counter, wearing a blue uniform embroidered in white letters: ''Lanchonete Chibana.'' 
 
Migration in Reverse
Brazil, once a country of such promise that it attracted this century's largest Japanese emigration, is now watching Japanese-Brazilians fighting to travel to Japan to take manual jobs disdained by Japanese.
Helping to sell out the economy-class sections of flights between here and Tokyo, Japan's robust economy is experiencing a labor shortage that is expected to grow to a million jobs by the year 2000.
On this end of the 27-hour flight, Latin America's prolonged economic stagnation is causing a reverse migration of some of the components of the melting pot. In Peru, much of Lima's Jewish population has quietly left for the United States. In Argentina, grandchildren of Italian and Spanish immigrants are leaving for ancestral homelands, now prosperous members of the European Community.
''It's not just the Japanese,'' said Akito Haneda, manager of Sol Nascente (Rising Sun), a company that helps Brazilians land jobs in Japan. ''It's the same at the consulates of Portugal, Spain and Italy.''
 
A Broken Promise
But with Brazil's Japanese population, the broken promise of development is perhaps the sharpest.
At the end of World War II, Japan and Brazil had roughly comparable living standards. Today, Japan has a per capita income of $20,000 and Brazil has a per capita income of $2,300. This month, prices in Brazil are expected to jump 70 percent -equivalent to more than a decade of inflation in Japan.
''When I was young, everyone said Brazil, Brazil, Brazil,'' recalled Seitoku Ifuku, who emigrated here in 1963 and who is now returning to work in Tokyo. ''Now, they say Japan, Japan, Japan.''
At the Japanese Consulate here, Shunsaku Ohno, the consul general, shuffled through files and came up with these statistics: In the last two years, the number of passports issued to Japanese citizens doubled to 9,418 and the number of visas issued to Brazilians tripled to 18,328.
Some Brazilians say they believe that the Japanese emigration could eventually hurt the supply of food to Sao Paulo, South America's most populous city.
 
Settled First on Plantations
According to Sao Paulo Shimbun, a Japanese newspaper here, job opportunities in Japan have drawn away at least 700 able-bodied workers from Bastos, a Sao Paulo town described as Brazil's largest center for egg production. In Mogi das Cruzes, a state center for vegetable production, a rural union leader said recently that his membership of 1,700 families has lost 600 members to jobs in Japan.
First arriving here in 1908, Japanese settled largely in rural areas. At the time, rapid industrialization and increased taxes impoverished rural Japan, according to Katsunori Wakisaka, director of the Center of Japanese-Brazilian Studies here.
With their 45-day steamship fares paid by the Japanese Government or by the Sao Paulo State government, the immigrants worked first on coffee plantations and then started truck gardens. After the United States largely barred Asian immigration in 1924, Brazil emerged as the largest destination for Japanese emigrants. With the exception of the war years, Brazil retained this position until emigration stopped in the early 1960's.
As a sequel to this movement, Brazil has 1.2 million people of Japanese descent, slightly more than the United States. A recent census showed 71 percent to be in Sao Paulo State and 12 percent to be in neighboring Parana State.
 
The Largest Colony
''My country is home to the largest population with Japanese blood outside of the Japanese archipelago,'' Brazil's President-elect, Fernando Collor de Mello, told a Japanese business group in Tokyo in January, in a speech intended to drum up investment and trade.
Brazilians of Japanese descent largely go to Japan on tourist visas to take jobs that the Japanese press calls ''the three k's'' - kitanai, kiken, kitsui (dirty, dangerous, difficult).
Living frugally, often in factory dormitories, workers often manage to save as much as $1,500 a month.
For many, a trip to Japan is the equivalent of a small business loan.
In Brazil, bank credit is largely reserved to large, established companies. One dental school graduate used his earnings to buy dental equipment. Others have used the money to pay for college educations or, like Mr. Chibana, to start small businesses.
''One generation died poor, their children are living poor, their grandchildren have the right to make money,'' said Noriko Bruce, a Japanese-Brazilian who has seen several cousins leave in recent months for Japan.
Despite their Japanese ancestry and, in some cases, command of the Japanese language, many Japanese-Brazilians complain that Japanese society greets them with almost the same chill reserved for manual laborers imported from other third-world countries like Pakistan or the Philippines.
 
Bias Taken for Granted
''We are discriminated against in Japan,'' said Celia Abe Oi, an editor for Diario Nippak, a newspaper for Japanese-Brazilians.
''Our parents went off to make their futures,'' she said over a plate of sushi at a restaurant here. ''We come back failures, not speaking Japanese well, and taking jobs that Japanese won't take.''
But everyone interviewed here predicted that the reverse migration will grow.
Enrollment in Japanese language lessons in Brazil has increased to 40,000. Japanese companies here are losing their personnel of Japanese descent. Last year, five Brazilian employees of the Japanese Consulate left for Japan.
Distilling the economic logic, the editor asked, ''If you were earning $1,700 a month, how would you like to go back to earning $200 a month?''

HEADLINE: U.N. Drug Plan Puts Stress on Reducing Demand

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 22 - T

 BODY:
he United Nations today approved a new anti-narcotics plan that stresses the need to reduce demand in the industrialized consuming countries and to compensate poor drug-producing countries for losses suffered by curbing the trade.
The plan, approved by a General Assembly committee and scheduled for formal adoption on Friday, continues the evolution in United States policy apparent at the Cartagena meeting between President Bush and the Presidents of Bolivia, Colombia and Peru, diplomats said.
At that meeting, the United States recognized its duty as the world's biggest market for illicit drugs to cut demand and aid producing countries that reduce output, in addition to taking vigorous measures against traffickers and destroying supplies. 
''This is the first time the world has so clearly recognized the need to address the demand and development aspects of the drug crisis instead of concentrating on production and trafficking,'' said Colombia's United Nations representative, Enrique Penalosa.
The American delegation leader. Melvin Levitsky, Assistant Secretary of State for International Narcotics Matters, said, ''The agreement has overcome the false division between demand and supply and stopped finger pointing as to who is responsible for the crisis.''
 
Not Legally Binding
The new plan and an accompanying political declaration are not legally binding. And nations attending this special session of the General Assembly gave no firm commitments to increase spending on the fight against drug abuse or to provide more aid to poor countries that eliminate their drug industries.
But the four-day meeting has demonstrated the depth of concern both developed and developing countries now feel about the drug problem and their willingness to share the task of combating it.
The plan commits all countries to the development of national strategies to ''give higher priority to prevention and reduction of drug abuse with a view to elimination of the illicit demand for drugs.'' These strategies should include an analysis of the causes of demand, educational measures to combat addiction and treatment and rehabilitation programs.
The United Nations will act as ''an advisory center'' for the collection, analysis and dissemination of information about the drug trade, with such specialized agencies as the World Health Organization playing an expert role.
The plan also commits countries in general terms to do more to aid the poorer producing nations overcome the economic losses many suffer from curbing output by developing alternative crops and providing markets for them.
During this week's special Assembly session, many speakers from the drug-producing countries of Latin America and Southeast Asia called on the industrialized world to do more to reduce demand and compensate them for eliminating their drug industries.
''The process must be gradual because narcotics accounts for 24 percent of our gross national product,'' Foreign Minister Carlos Iturralte-Ballivian of Bolivia said.

HEADLINE: Japan Backs Cheney's Troop-Cut Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Nearing the end of his trip to Asia, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney won general approval from Japan on Thursday for a proposal to reduce American forces in East Asia and the Pacific by 10 percent, including a 5,000 to 6,000 cut in troops stationed here.
After discussions with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and top Japanese officials and political leaders, Mr. Cheney also said he was pleased with way the Japanese received the American request that Tokyo increase its share of the expenditure for the American military presence here.
The Secretary and his aides said that no specific numbers were discussed on increasing the Japanese share of the $7.5 billion American military expenditure in Japan, which is now about 40 percent. American officials said details would be worked out later this year. 
Mr. Cheney is on a two-week tour of South Korea, the Philippines and Japan to discuss what the Pentagon calls an ''East Asian security initiative'' aimed at cutting military forces in response to the perceived lessening of the threat from the Soviet Union.
 
Preserving 'Combat Capability'
Whereas in Europe, American allies have welcomed a reduction in United States troop strength, American allies in Asia are more wary of what they say is a continuing Soviet threat, reflected by the hostility of North Korea and Soviet modernization of its ground and naval forces throughout the region.
Mr. Cheney was said by Japanese officials to have assured Mr. Kaifu and others that the proposed reductions would be carried out ''without damaging combat capability'' of American forces.
In response, Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama was said to have called the American proposals ''prudent and appropriate.'' But Japanese officials said Mr. Kaifu and Mr. Nakayama stressed that it was premature to think that East Asian and the Pacific were places of defused tension like Europe.
In a larger sense, Japanese officials say privately that they are worried that an overall reduction of the American presence in Asia would reawaken fears in other parts of the region about the growing influence of Japan.
 
Fear of Tokyo Military Threat
They say the United States is a healthy influence that reassures Asian countries that they need not fear the possibility of a Japanese military threat that would follow its expanding economic influence down the road.
According to a Japanese official, Mr. Nakayama told Mr. Cheney that despite welcome changes in other parts of the world, ''we have to be mindful of elements of instability and unpredictability'' in Asia.
The official quoted Mr. Cheney as in agreement, and responding in the meeting, ''Over all, the Asian Pacific situation has not seen as much improvement as we have seen in the European theater.''
American officials said Mr. Cheney has tried to avoid specific numbers in addressing the question of how best to reduce the general presence of American forces in Asia. But they said that 10 percent was a general goal, and that specifics would be worked out by military commanders.
 
Difficult Philippine Visit
The United States troop presence in East Asia and the Pacific consists of about 50,000 troops in Japan, 43,000 in South Korea and 18,000 in the Philippines. Mr. Cheney said a ''ballpark figure'' of 5,000 to 6,000 was the goal in Japan.
Last week, Mr. Cheney persuaded the South Korean Defense Minister, Lee Sang Hoon, to accept in principle the gradual withdrawal of about 5,000 noncombatants from that country. American officials said the Philippine Defense Minister, Fidel V. Ramos, also had ''agreed in principle'' on a reduction.
The rockiest part of Mr. Cheney's trip has been the visit to the Philippines, American officials said. There, President Corazon C. Aquino declined to meet with Mr. Cheney, in protest against American plans to reduce American economic aid to Manila.
In his meeting with Mr. Ramos, Mr. Cheney promised ''to do what he could to get the full amount pledged'' given to the Philippines, according to Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman.

Japanese officials approved of Mr. Cheney's proposed 10 percent troop reduction in East Asia. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Guardian of Baker's Door at State: A Quick Study Who Rose Rapidly

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
When people who have worked with Robert B. Zoellick are asked to talk about him, they sound a little like the brainwashed servicemen in ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' who uniformly refer to their sergeant as ''the kindest, bravest, warmest, most wonderful human being I've ever known in my life.''
For Richard G. Darman, the budget director who was Mr. Zoellick's boss at the Treasury Department, he ''can do more first-class work in 24 hours than 12 ordinary people could do in 24 years.'' For George D. Gould, a former Under Secretary of Treasury, he is ''the most talented man I ever worked with.'' Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, calls him ''one of the most effective officials in Washington.''
Is the 36-year-old workaholic whiz kid who serves as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's counselor and confidant really that good? Maybe. Maybe not. A Rapid Rise Mr. Zoellick is the kind of guy everyone would like to have working for him, a behind-the-scenes operative who combines intelligence, energy and good judgment. The brief against him is that he can be abrupt and abrasive and that he is in a position too powerful for his level of foreign policy experience and expertise. 
A Darman protege, Mr. Zoellick was discovered and promoted in 1986 by Mr. Baker, who was then Treasury Secretary. Later, using his influence in the Bush campaign, Mr. Baker wedged his young charge past longtime Bush operatives and installed him as issues director for the 1988 Presidential campaign. Then, when Mr. Baker took over at State, he jumped him to the head of the line. So far, Mr. Zoellick has kept his constituency of one very happy.
''He is an extremely capable and talented young man who is rendering extraordinary service to his country,'' Mr. Baker said. ''I rely greatly on his counsel and advice.''
As counselor, a sort of minister without portfolio, he is a combination ideas man, troubleshooter, adviser, hands-on negotiator and executive secretary for Mr. Baker. Every piece of paper that is sent to Mr. Baker must first pass through his desk, where, Mr. Zoellick said, he ''institutes some quality control.'' He is also the first to see the replies.
Most important, he integrates the strategic planning of the policy planning office with the department's day-to-day operations and even conducts some of the diplomacy himself.
 
Foreign Policy Novice
In May he went on a secret mission to Bonn with Robert M. Gates, the deputy national security adviser, to paper over differences with the Germans on short-range nuclear missiles. In October he accompanied Mr. Greenspan to Moscow to teach the Soviets about capitalism. And he largely wrote Mr. Baker's speech to the Berlin Press Club in December, which offered an American blueprint for the future of Europe.
When he took the State Department job a year ago, Mr. Zoellick was a foreign policy novice. He has learned a lot about geopolitics since the day last spring when he gave new ambassadors a global overview that one listener described as ''full of cliches.''
He has also learned the hard way about global travel. On his first visit to Oman, the socks, T-shirts and shirts he sent to the palace guest house laundry came back with a $100-plus tab. ''He now travels with lots of shirts,'' said Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman.
If Mr. Zoellick has one unique advantage in his job, it is that he not only has Mr. Baker's ear, he also has his eye. They see the world through the same geopolitical prism, focusing in on those policies with high potential for success and low risk for criticism at home. Mr. Zoellick can predict Mr. Baker's foreign policy strategies months in advance and present issues to him in precisely the form that Mr. Baker wants them.
''The nature of my job is to think in advance of what needs to be done and not wait to be asked,'' he said. ''One nice thing about my job is that I'm not frequently told what to do.''
 
Two Briefing as One
Mr. Zoellick and Dennis B. Ross, the director of policy planning at the State Department, who met on the Presidential campaign, have transformed the way the department makes decisions, largely eclipsing the role of the assistant secretaries. The duo has also assumed many of the responsibilities traditionally carried out by the department's No. 2 and 3 positions, the Deputy Secretary and the Under Secretary for Political Affairs. They have become so close that they routinely brief journalists as a single ''senior Administration official.''
Over the past year, veteran State Department officials have learned that the only way to Mr. Baker is through Mr. Zoellick. ''We've adapted,'' one senior State Department official said of Mr. Zoellick. ''We no longer view him as a rival. We view him as the person who can make things happen.''
Mr. Zoellick is not shy outside the department either. When Southeast Asian ambassadors had a luncheon meeting with United States Trade Representative Carla Anderson Hills and Mr. Zoellick several weeks ago, he was the one who explained American policy toward economic cooperation in Asia.
Mr. Zoellick dazzles some colleagues and frightens others with his rigorous work ethic. As a clerk for Judge Patricia M. Wald of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in 1982 and 1983, he worked until 10 or 11 every night and then ran the seven miles home. ''Uphill, I might add,'' he said. On route to Paris for a Cambodia conference last summer, he read biographical material on Prince Norodom Sihanouk while everyone else was sleeping. He carries his own cheese, crackers and raisins on the road because there is never enough time for room service.
 
Stickler for Detail
Like Felix Unger of ''The Odd Couple,'' Mr. Zoellick is also fastidious in his work habits and a stickler for detail. He approaches issues didactically, packaging them in discreet blocks with enumerated points.
''Look at his handwriting, with the little fine-point pens and pencils, neat and precise with numbers, letters and parentheses,'' said James P. Pinkerton, Deputy Assistant to the President for Policy Planning, who worked with Mr. Zoellick on the 1988 campaign. ''Here's a smart, organized guy who manages to pull it off without being a nerd.'' One European diplomat called him ''precise and meticulous,'' adding, ''He looks as if he could be an accountant.''
But as a function of his finely tuned sense of efficiency, he loses patience with those who he believes do not work as hard as he does or are not as smart as he is. ''If he has one problem it's that he could probably delegate more than he does,'' one colleague said. ''He doesn't trust many people in the building.'' When asked about his brusqueness, Ms. Tutwiler said, ''Sometimes he can be snappy. We all can. In any bureaucracy when you get served up the lowest common denominator or shoddy work there is a lower tolerance level.''
He does delegate responsibility, he insisted, up to a point. ''I'm quite happy when I find people who can help do the work to let them do it,'' he said. ''But I have very high standards.''
To prove that he can lighten up, he keeps an illustrated copy of ''Guinea Pigs: A Complete Pet Owner's Manual'' on his coffee table in his office. ''It's a test,'' he explained, ''to see if people react to it.'' He divides visitors into three categories according to their response: those who pretend the book is not there, those who see the book and are uncomfortable and those who are amused.
 
Working on 2 Degrees
The son of what he calls ''some plain old Midwestern people'' from rural Illinois, Mr. Zoellick got himself on the public policy fast track as Mr. Darman's teaching fellow at Harvard University while he was working simultaneously working on a master's degree in public policy and a law degree. He took a leave of absence from Harvard to work in the criminal division of President Jimmy Carter's Justice Department, and after graduation worked in law firm of Joseph A. Califano Jr., a Democrat who later served as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare under Mr. Carter. Mr. Zoellick then became assistant to the chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association before landing a job as Mr. Darman's special assistant at the Treasury Department.
Within a year, Mr. Baker, then Treasury Secretary, promoted him three times. ''He had a kind of key people strategy, that it was important to get to know key people and get the opportunity to watch people he thought would be leaders,'' Judge Wald said.
He denies that he is a workaholic. He eschews the Washington social circuit, preferring to read military histories or visit area Civil War battle sites. He and his wife, Sherry, a published novelist - whose books include ''Raise a Tiger'' - and amateur ornithologist, have identified 55 species of birds in their backyard in northwest Washington. They also enjoy hosting theme murder mystery dinners for costumed guests to guess the identity of the imaginary killer.
He described his relationship with Mr. Baker as strictly professional, which suits him fine. ''Some people need a constant sense that their boss is their friend or they want to socialize with him on the outside,'' he said. ''I'm quite pleased I don't have to go hunting or play golf.''
A self-described ''public policy junkie,'' Mr. Zoellick would like nothing better than to stay in government. ''I'd like to spend as much of my life and career in public policy as possible, but I recognize that's not very likely to be the case. But I'd be quite pleased if there was a period of Republican hegemony for the next 40 years.''
 
Robert Bruce Zoellick
Counselor of the State Department.
 
Born: July 25, 1953
 
Hometown: Naperville, Ill.
 
Education: Swarthmore College, Harvard Law School, Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
 
Key Washington jobs: Special assistant to Deputy Secretary of Treasury, Richard G. Darman (July to December 1985); counselor and executive secretary to Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d (January to July 1988); issues director for 1988 Bush Presidential campaign (July to November 1988).
 
Interests: Military history; long-distance running.

HEADLINE: Bush Vows to Combat Crisis of Medical Litigation

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Feb. 22

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he had directed his Domestic Policy Council to determine what steps were necessary to stem a malpractice litigation crisis that he said threatened the health of the nation's medical system.
Mr. Bush addressed the issue of malpractice in a speech to a group celebrating the 114th anniversary of Johns Hopkins University, one of the nation's pre-eminent medical research centers. As he spoke, some 200 demonstrators, including doctors and other faculty members from Johns Hopkins institutions, stood outside in the rain protesting his Administration's health policies. 
The President urged doctors to avoid practicing ''defensive medicine'' and said it was time to restore ''common sense and fairness to America's medical malpractice system.''
White House officials said Mr. Bush was referring to what he saw as an excessive number of malpractice lawsuits, and too high insurance premiums for doctors. The American Medical Association estimates that the cost of malpractice lawsuits and of doctors' insurance premiums related to malpractice is about $14 billion a year.
 
Incentives for State Action
An official said the Domestic Policy Council was looking at a number of options, including encouraging states to establish their own policies. For example, boards might be set up to handle malpractice cases to cut the number of lawsuits and damage awards.
Critics of the Administration's approach, including the American Trial Lawyers Association, cite studies by the General Accounting Office and the Rand Corporation concluding that the cost of lawsuits is not excessively high. The lawyers say most awards are relatively small and fully justified.
But today Mr. Bush said the fear of malpractice ''has not only hurt medical innovation and treatment, it's also hurt medical volunteerism.'' He added, ''Many doctors used to give a day a week to the needy, and I'm convinced that, if not for the liability issue, many more would donate time today.''
He also said: ''We've got to remember a simple truth: not every unfortunate medical outcome is the result of poor medicine. You cannot make life risk-free. No risk means no progress.'' #672 Signatures on Petition Outside, the protesters circulated a petition saying Mr. Bush had ''neglected as well as damaged'' the public health. They said they had collected 672 signatures, including those of 40 members of the Johns Hopkins faculty.
The petition complained that 70 percent of the money for the war on drugs went to law enforcement, leaving only 30 percent to be spent on prevention and treatment.

HEADLINE: Mr. Havel's Profound Paradox

 BODY:
''You can help us most of all,'' Vaclav Havel told Congress Wednesday, ''if you help the Soviet Union on its irreversible but immensely complicated road to democracy.'' The Czech President, who embodies his country's emergence from Soviet domination, called this remark paradoxical. Maybe, but it also expresses a profound truth and suggests a wise course of action for the West. 
Eastern Europe's democratic revolution owes much to Mikhail Gorbachev's policies of glasnost and perestroika. This revolution would surely be at risk if the reformers in Moscow fell victim to an authoritarian backlash. A restored hard-line regime in Moscow would do everything it could to eliminate nearby models of democracy that could inflame the Soviet people.
Mr. Havel did not spell out how the West could help democracy in the Soviet Union. He reiterated his support for East-West arms control treaties. In the past he has endorsed efforts to develop free markets in the Soviet Union and eventually tie them to the larger free trade economies of the West. President Bush and other Western leaders have made a good start in both areas.
But the import of Mr. Havel's words is that the West needs to do much more, and soon. Careful diplomacy and great tact will be required to engage proud Soviet leaders in such discussions. But there's no doubt the West could provide enormous help: technical assistance on everything from breaking transportation logjams to pumping oil; advice on how Moscow can best spend Western credits; the food aid and medical supplies that may also be necessary if Moscow is to navigate the next two years of retrenchment.
Mr. Havel is saying that the situation in the Soviet Union and the fate of Eastern Europe are inextricably linked. He is also courageously and sensibly asking the West to understand and act on that fact.

HEADLINE: New York Can't Go It Alone in the Fight to Control Acid Rain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I read with interest ''Acid Rain: Plenty Bad Enough'' (editorial, Jan. 29), which strongly supports the need for Congress to enact national acid rain controls. As you indicate, the time to address this serious pollution problem has long since passed.
While the recent work by the National Acid Precipitation Assessment Program has been noteworthy, I believe some additional facts regarding acid rain damage in New York and the state's efforts to address the problem need to be identified. 
New York began documenting the effects of acid rain in the 1970's. The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, in conjunction with the Empire State Electric Energy Research Corporation, recently completed a four-year survey of 1,469 Adirondack lakes. Your editorial states that 11 percent of the lakes in the southwestern Adirondacks are already acidified, and 36 percent are in danger of becoming so. The problem is more widespread. The lakes study concluded that 24 percent of the Adirondack lakes are acidified and have a pH of less than 5. Eighteen percent of the lakes have a pH between 5 and 6, indicating that they have either been affected by acid rain or are threatened by this pollution. These results speak more strongly for immediate action than the assessment program's results.
Obviously, whenever possible, political solutions should be based upon sound scientific judgments. In that spirit, I signed the State Acid Deposition Control Act in 1984. As a result of this initiative, the state has clearly identified three major areas that are especially sensitive to acid deposits: the Adirondacks, the Catskills and the Hudson Highlands. The 1984 law also set forth requirements to reduce the level of sulfur dioxide emissions from New York State sources.
As a result, New York became the first state actually to reduce emissions of sulfur dioxide in an effort to address the acid rain problem. In 1988 the first phase of reductions went into effect, and New York sulfur dioxide emissions have been reduced by more than 17 percent.
In the absence of a national initiative, New York has, like Minnesota, Massachusetts and New Hampshire, acted on its own to require reductions in the emissions that cause acid rain. However, the interstate transport of acid rain and acid rain precursors makes it impossible for individual states alone to solve the acid rain problem. Congress must move now to implement an acid rain program as part of its clean air debate.
Both Congress and the Administration have proposed a 10-million-ton reduction in sulfur dioxide emissions. We believe that, if properly targeted, 10 million tons is a reasonable minimum goal.
In addition, we support a proposal made by both the Administration and Congress to establish a cap on future emissions to assure that the benefits from actions we take are not eliminated by future growth.
New York State has led the way on acid rain control. I now repeat my plea to Congress and the Administration to resolve their remaining differences and to implement a strong national acid rain program that will protect New York, other areas of the country and Canada.
 
MARIO M. CUOMO, Governor
Albany, Feb. 6, 1990

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

California French
The California grill called Melrose, in the West Village, has recently dropped its prices by about 20 percent to become a solid economy-priced spot called Barrow Street Bistro. The setting has been modified slightly - sponged ocher walls, paper tablecloths, soft lighting - and the food by Lynn McNeely, formerly of the now-defunct Alex Goes to Camp, on Third Avenue, is an appealing blend of down-home country French and subdued California. Fine starters include ricotta-filled ravioli in a fresh tomato sauce potent with garlic and basil ($5); leek-and-goat cheese tart with an exceptionally delicate crust ($7), and crisp rosti potatoes served with salmon tartar, creme fraiche and sevruga caviar ($8).
For main courses, there are a delicious rib-eye steak in a shallot-sweetened green peppercorn sauce, with Swiss chard and gratin potatoes ($19); fresh, mild calf's liver with pearl onions and raisins ($13), and grilled lamb chops with terrific green lentils cooked with balsamic vinegar and smoked bacon ($19). The only flub was grilled chicken that got too close to the flames, leaving it acrid ($11). Considering that food prices are moderate, it is odd to see a wine list on which three of the four California reds are Opus One, from $48 to $95. Be forewarned, too, that at this stage, the kitchen can be annoying slow. Barrow Street Bistro, 48 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South (691-6800), serves dinner 5:45 to 11 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday; 5 to 10 P.M. Sunday. Mastercard, Visa and American Express are accepted.
 
The Changing Scene
Opening: Da Gianvito, 1373 First Avenue (between 73d and 74th Streets; 472-4272), an Italian restaurant opened by Gianvito Fanizza, former chef and co-owner of Marcello.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Sees End to Price Rises

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the surge in consumer prices last month was an aberration, was unlikely to continue and might already have eased.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks, in response to questions from senators, appeared to signal that the Fed would not raise interest rates soon to counter inflationary pressures.
The chairman, the Government's most important economic policy maker, also repeated his view that the danger of recession had probably passed. Thus, the prospect seems to be that the Federal Reserve will leave interest rates where they are for the time being. 
The Labor Department reported on Wednesday that consumer prices had soared 1.1 percent in January, the biggest monthly increase in more than seven years.
 
No Sign of Inflation
Asked about the figures today by members of the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan said that looking at all the data available to him he saw no indication that the threat of inflation had become more serious.
''As best we can judge, while the rate of inflation is higher than we would like, there is no evidence that it is accelerating,'' he said.
He said he would be ''most surprised'' if the Consumer Price Index continued to rise markedly and predicted that it might begin to drop.
Both the stock and bond markets were bolstered by Mr. Greenspan's remarks, traders said, and his testimony apparently contributed to a strong gain in the benchmark 30-year bond. The Dow Jones industrial average, however, weakened during the day and closed off 8.79, at 2,574.77.
 
Sequel to House Testimony
By law, Mr. Greenspan must appear before House and Senate committees every six months to discuss the state of the economy and the outlook for monetary policy. His Senate testimony today was a sequel to his appearance on Tuesday before a House subcommittee.
In response to questions, he made these new points:
* The main cause of rising interest rates in West Germany and Japan is the ''extraordinary'' investment opportunities provided by the changed political climate in Eastern Europe.
* The economic slowdown in New England does not represent a recession but ''feels worse than it is'' because of the extent of the economic boom there in the late 1980's.
* Measures to increase personal savings should be rejected if they increase the Federal budget deficit.
If the implication is correct that the Federal Reserve plans to leave interest rates alone for the foreseeable future, that would mark a significant change from the policy last year. The Fed pushed rates up in increments for the first several months of 1989 to try to fight inflation and then let them slide gradually for the rest of the year as a hedge against recession.
In general, higher interest rates are a rein on the economy, and lower ones stimulate it.
 
Demand for Savings
Real interest rates - the rates in excess of the inflation rate - are abnormally high in the United States, Mr. Greenspan said, for two reasons. First, he said, the supply and demand for savings are out of balance, with little savings and a great demand for money for investment. Second, he added, high inflation rates in the past have left a residual fear that inflation will return. Real interest rates are now running more than 4 percent.
His remarks echoed those of analysts who commented on Wednesday, after the release of the consumer price data, that they did not view the surge as disturbing because of the special one-month factors that contributed to it.
Asked about interest rates in West Germany and Japan, Mr. Greenspan said the sharp rise since the first of the year had resulted much more from events in Eastern Europe than from a potential for inflation in those countries, and he said he doubted that there would be a long-term effect on interest rates here.
 
'No Historical Precedent'
The ''huge investment requirement'' and ''potential for significant rates of return'' in Eastern Europe have ''no historical precedent,'' Mr. Greenspan said. Interest rates have risen, he continued, because there were not enough savings in the world to finance all the investment opportunities, and that ''led the markets to grope for an equilibrium.''
By now, he said, the markets have accommodated the expectations, and he does not anticipate further steep rises in rates overseas.
Mr. Greenspan said unemployment in Massachusetts was only 4.5 percent in the last quarter of 1989, well below the national average. He said that New England's economy had advanced in the late 1980's ''at a pace that was clearly unsustainable'' and that ''the process of slowing down exaggerates the underlying weakness.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
German Options On Money Union

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
CHANCELLOR HELMUT KOHL means to use his country's powerful currency as the catalyst for uniting East and West Germany. A cardinal aim of Mr. Kohl's plan for rapid monetary union is to check the emigration of Eastern workers to the West. Far more than 400,000 East Germans have moved into West Germany, and the exodus is continuing at a rate of about 2,000 a week.
Last week, West Germany's five leading economic research institutes stated, in a letter to Mr. Kohl, that his plan for quick monetary union with the East would be costly and ineffective in slowing the migration of refugees to the West. The institutes, which are official and independent advisers to the Chancellor, said monetary union would not solve the ills plaguing the East's economy. The enormous excess money supply of East Germany, they said, should first be blotted up through the sale of state assets to individuals and companies. 
But Chancellor Kohl has rejected this criticism and also that of Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany, who has complained bitterly of the West's unwillingness to provide immediate financial aid. Mr. Kohl means to hold back until after East Germany's first free elections on March 18, after which Mr. Modrow may be out of office.
Monetary union, with the valuable West German mark replacing the virtually worthless East German mark, would itself be a form of financial aid. And there is a good chance that introducing the West German mark in the East would accelerate the pace of economic reform. For the use of Western marks would restore a genuine relationship among East German wages, prices and productivity, and thereby get rid of the existing garble of monetary and economic relationships, sustained only by Government subsidies and controls. Substituting the West's marks for the East's would resemble the informal ''dollarization'' of economies in distress, like those of Argentina or Israel. But the use of dollars to replace national currencies, in the case of australs or shekels, was only a means of creating meaningful prices and providing a medium of exchange that would retain its value. The prospective German currency reform would go much deeper, linking wages, prices, productivity and profits. It would thereby set East Germany, with its entrepreneurial and technological traditions, on a course toward strong growth.
The best precedent for such a union was the currency reform of 1948, which set West Germany on its course toward becoming the most powerful economy in Europe. Adolphe Warner, an economic adviser to the Deutsche Bank, who served as deputy financial adviser to Gen. Lucius Clay in the United States military government after World War II, said in an interview this week that German monetary union should follow the basic pattern of the 1948 reform. That reform substituted the current marks for Reichmarks, which were in enormous surplus. The exchange took place at an average rate of 100 Reichmarks to 6.5 current marks. What is the right rate for exchanging marks now? Nobody can be sure, because the problems of valuation are extremely complex, and mixed with problems of macroeconomic management. The first and most essential job is to figure out the aggregate number of West German marks with which to replace the existing number of Eastern marks. If the substitution rate is too generous, there will be too much money and inflation will result. If the exchange rate is set too low, the aggregate money supply will be too small to sustain economic growth and high employment.
As in the 1948 monetary reform, different exchange rates could be used to meet different problems. For instance, the East's and West's marks might be exchanged one to one to provide retirement benefits and to sustain workers' earnings. That rate would tend to hold workers in the East. But beyond some per capita quota at the preferred rate, a much lower rate could be used to exchange the huge surplus of East German marks, held over in currency hoards or bank accounts, much of it gained in black markets. To mop up those surplus Eastern marks, Mr. Warner suggests an exchange rate of 10 to 1 - roughly midway between the former black-market rate of 13 Eastern marks to one Western mark and the more recent 6 to 1, which has been based on speculation that the East's marks would be converted.
Otto Lambsdorff, head of the Free Democratic Party, a partner in Chancellor Kohl's coalition Government, said in New York this week that although he, too, would have preferred to put economic reform ahead of monetary union, he thought monetary union would force the pace of economic restructuring in the East. He noted that ''capitalism'' remains a dirty word in the East and suggested using ''social market economy'' - the term coined by Ludwig Erhard, Economics Minister from 1949 to 1957 - as the basis for a new East German economy. A united Germany would remain firmly linked to Europe and to the West, he said, repeating Thomas Mann's plea for a ''European Germany, not a German Europe.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Nearly 2 Years Later, Pennzoil Fills Position

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
The Pennzoil Company yesterday named James L. Pate its chief operating officer, filling a vacant post in its top management.
Mr. Pate, 54 years old, who has been an executive vice president at the energy company, will be responsible for its operating divisions and corporate functions.
The post of chief operating officer has been vacant since April 1988, when Randal B. McDonald became chief executive officer and the likely successor to J. Hugh Liedtke, who continues as chairman. Mr. McDonald, 58, who came to the company from the Arthur Young accounting firm, had long been associated with Mr. Liedtke and Pennzoil's financial dealings. 
Mr. Liedtke, 68, who took control of the company in 1962, has been the company's only chairman and longtime chief executive.
The company, based in Houston, has spent much of the $3 billion it was awarded in 1988 from Texaco Inc., after a four-year fight over Texaco's purchase of the Getty Oil Company. Pennzoil has bought 8.8 percent of the Chevron Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest energy company, and Chevron is seeking to force Pennzoil to sell the stock.
Mr. Pate, an economist by training, joined Pennzoil in 1976. He has served as the company's chief economist, among other positions. In 1981, he won the first annual Silbert Economic Forecasting award, sponsored by the Sterling National Bank and Trust Company, for accurate forecasting of the gross national product and the inflation rate.
In 1974, President Gerald R. Ford named Mr. Pate an assistant secretary of commerce, and the economist subsequently became a special adviser to the White House. He was also director of business research for the B. F. Goodrich Company, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and an economics professor at Monmouth College.
Mr. Pate was away from the company yesterday and was unavailable for an interview, a spokesman said.

HEADLINE: Late Selloff Pushes Dow 8.79 Points Lower

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks fell broadly yesterday, depressed by late selling, and after being nearly 30 points higher than its opening level about 2 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average finished 8.79 points lower, at 2,574.77.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange, which had trailed advances by nearly 2 to 1, finished ahead of gaining ones, 753 to 715.
Volume on the Big Board jumped to 184.3 million shares, many of which changed hands in the last hour of trading, from 159.2 million shares on Wednesday.
 
Early Session Action
''Near the beginning of the session, a lot of traders realized that what happened in Japan earlier in the week, when the Nikkei 225-stock index plunged 1,161.19 points, or 3.15 percent, to 35,734.33, was influenced by index-arbitrage sell programs, not just by interest rate concerns or institutions unloading stocks,'' said Peter G. Grennan, the head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. 
The early market was also influenced positively by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, who told the Senate Banking Committee yesterday that rises in food and energy prices last month would reverse and that there was no evidence of expanding inflation.
The traders said the stock market began to weaken in the afternoon when a firm using the strategy known as ''tactical asset allocation'' - the switching between stocks and bonds - executed a large sell program about 2 P.M.
''Such shifting of exposure is usually done through the futures market, which is the fastest and most efficient way to accomplish the switch,'' Mr. Grennan said.
Although American stocks ended on a negative note, some experts remained optimistic.
''The stock market is consolidating from an oversold condition,'' said Harold A. Mackinney, the head of the investment policy committee at the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group in Providence, R.I. ''January's inflation results are now behind us, and they will represent the worst numbers for 1990. The bond market has overreacted to the recently released Producer Price Index and Consumer Price Index results, and significantly lower interest rates should be evident soon.''
 
Broader Gauges Fall
In the broader market yesterday, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped by 1.97 points, to 325.70, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped by 0.79 point, to 180.28.
Among individual issues, UAL fell by 5 3/4, to 126 1/2. The parent of United Airlines, based in Elk Grove Village, Ill., said its board had not received an acquisition proposal from its employee groups or any other party.
Honeywell edged up by 3/4, to 77 3/8. Analysts attributed the rise to a conclusion by investors that the recently released earnings of the company for the fourth quarter showed that it was benefiting from a restructuring begun last year.
Pfizer plunged by 4 1/2, to 59 1/4. The company, whose artificial heart valves by its Shiley unit have been the subject of lawsuits, will appear on Monday at a Congressional hearing in Washington on regulation of the medical-device industry.
 
Active Blue Chips
In other active blue-chip trading, Philip Morris rose by 1/2, to 38 1/8; I.B.M was off by 1 5/8, to 103 1/4, and A.T.& T. fell by 5/8, to 38 1/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market-value index rose by 0.40 point, to 353.35, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.23 points, to 422.75.
In over-the-counter trading, Apple Computer dropped by a point, to 33. The analysts said they expected more layoffs and price cuts on products than the company, based in Cupertino, Calif., has announced in recent days as it tries to lower costs to increase earnings and revenues.
Lin Broadcasting dropped 3 points, to 109. The traders said a Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette analyst, Dennis Leibowitz, had removed the New York-based company from his list of recommended stocks, cutting his rating to ''moderately attractive.''
