HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Late Rally Sends Prices Soaring

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
A late rally sent prices of Treasury securities soaring and yields tumbling yesterday.
Dealers said a combination of positive market factors developed in the afternoon that caused heavy buying of Treasury paper, especially long-term bonds.
In late trading, for example, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.5 percent issue maturing in 2020, were being offered at 99 12/32, up by 26/32, while the yield dropped to 8.56 percent, from 8.64 percent the day before. The long notes, the 8.5 percent ones of the year 2000, climbed by 14/ 32, to 99 25/32, with the yield falling to 8.53 percent, from 8.60 percent. 
 
'Classic Market Squeeze'
''What we witnessed today was a textbook example of a classic market squeeze,'' said Jonathan B. Greenspan, the chief trader at the Aegis Capital Management Corporation. ''There were four key ingredients for a squeeze in place when the buying panic began just before the close of the Chicago bond futures market at 3 o'clock, New York time.''
First off, most institutional and other retail investors have been absent from the bond market this week. This caused nervous dealers and speculators to protect themselves against a price decline by selling securities short, which involves selling contracts in the futures market of equivalent value to the securities held. If securities prices rise, those who have sold futures contracts, which are promises to buy or sell a certain amount of goods at a specified price by a certain deadline, will have to buy them back at a higher price. The value of the securities they own, however, will have risen.
In the early afternoon, it became apparent that strong Japanese interest contributed to the $30.1 billion in bids that were placed for the $8 billion in five-year Treasury notes auctioned yesterday, and that sale went well. Auctioned at an average yield of 8.53 percent for a 8.5 percent coupon, the notes quickly went to a premium, with the yield falling to 8.46 percent.
To further unnerve the short-sellers, the dollar was higher against the Japanese yen. Some of the dealers said this encouraged substantial Japanese interest in the five-year note sale.
 
Demand for 8.5% Notes
More bad news for the shorts came when $10 billion in 8.5 percent notes, which were auctioned on Wednesday at an average yield of 8.50 percent, were also in demand yesterday and fell to a yield of 8.39 percent late in the session.
The final blow for short-sellers came just before the close of the Treasury bond futures market on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The spot March contract closed up by 1.1 points, to 93.4. Mr. Greenspan of Aegis Capital Management said that ''many shorts who could not or would not buy out of their contracts in Chicago came into the New York cash market and bought Treasury paper to offset their positions and thus prevent further losses.''
Robert H. Chandross, the chief economist at Lloyds Bank, said some of the short-covering that developed yesterday in Chicago and spilled over into cash market might have also reflected the generally positive sentiment that pervaded the fixed-income market at the time.
''For one, the Government reported a $9.9 billion surplus for last month,'' Mr. Chandross said. ''With this week's note auctions out of the way, there won't be much new Treasury paper coming to market for a while, and the unexpected comments by chairman Greenspan before the Senate Banking Committee this morning also helped improve market sentiment.''
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Senate panel that inflation pressures were not as serious as suggested by the 1.1 percent jump in the Consumer Price Index for January. Some of the credit market analysts interpreted this as paving the way for the Fed to lower interest rates without seeming to concede to White House and Congressional pressures to ease credit and thus stimulate the economy. Most had expected the Fed chairman to reiterate his fears that inflation remained a threat.
 
Stopping 'Well Short'
''Mr. Greenspan stopped well short of promising to ease credit,'' Mr. Chandross of Lloyds Bank said. ''Perhaps overlooked in his testimony was that domestic interest rates should be attractive enough to encourage the inflow of foreign capital. We don't think the Fed is about to ease.''
As for the central bank, it again refrained from intervening in the money market. The primary interest cost, the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans, held at 8 5/16 percent for most of the day.
Meanwhile, discount rates on Treasury bills continued to fall. The rate on the 90-day bills dropped by 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.70 percent; six-month bills lost 4 basis points, at 7.70 percent, and the one-year bills declined by 6 basis points, to 7.58 percent.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auction of five-year notes:

HEADLINE: British Curb On Rate Swaps

 BODY:
Britain's Court of Appeal ruled yesterday that interest rate swaps are legal for local government authorities if they are used to limit interest rate risks but not if they are used for speculative trading for profit.
 
The decision involved the
Hammersmith and Fulham Council, which made dozens of speculative interest rate swaps totaling 6 billion (about $11 billion) that were not needed to manage its debt of 350 million. 
 
Last year, the London High
Court ruled that those swap agreements were not legal because the council was not authorized to trade speculatively.
By voiding the swap agreements, that ruling could have caused losses of $150 million for major American, Japanese and British banks. Banks led by Midland Bank, Barclays Bank, Security Pacific National Bank, Chemical Bank, and Mitsubishi Finance appealed.
The appeals court ruled that local British authorities may enter into interest rate swap agreements for the purpose of limiting rate risk.
In interest rate swaps, companies, local governments and banks agree to exchange interest rate payments on their borrowings for a specified period of time.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Closes Mostly Lower But Posts Gain Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose to its highest level since September against the yen but finished mostly lower against other major currencies yesterday.
Gold prices fell worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $415.70 an ounce, down $2.30 from late Wednesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold of $416.20, off $1.60. 
The dollar rose to its highest level since September against the yen, which languished amid dimmed prospects for higher interest rates in Japan. The market has been expecting the Bank of Japan to raise the nation's discount rate.
''Japan's interest rates are a lot lower than everybody else's interest rates,'' said Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston. ''Given that, people are looking for a much weaker yen.''
High interest rates make a nation's fixed-income securities attractive to investors, who need that nation's currency to make their investments.
Earlier in Europe, the dollar put in a mixed performance while confined to well-established ranges. When trading shifted to the United States, the dollar appeared to firm but ultimately finished lower against all major currencies except the yen.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 145.23 yen, up 0.08 yen from Wednesday's close. In New York the dollar continued to rise, closing at 146.53 yen, up from 145.50 yen on Wednesday.
In New York trading, the price of a British pound was $1.7133, up from $1.7125 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.6717 West German marks, down from 1.6725; 1.4755 Swiss francs, down from 1.4795; 5.6620 French francs, down from 5.6730; 1,236.00 Italian lire, down from 1,238.00, and 1.1949 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1983.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $417.45 an ounce, from $418.85 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold closed at $417.25, down $2.25 from late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $2.85 to close at $416.83.
Silver prices also fell. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery slipped to $5.268 an ounce, from $5.272 on Wednesday. In London, silver fell to $5.28, from $5.33 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;
Bush to Press Kohl at Camp David On Easing Poland's Border Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
When President Bush meets over the weekend with Chancellor Helmut Kohl, he will urge the West German leader to calm Polish concerns about the future of the Polish-German border, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Kohl arrives on Saturday morning for two days of talks with Mr. Bush in the informal atmosphere of Camp David, the Presidential retreat near Thurmont, Md.
Mr. Bush will ask Mr. Kohl to clarify his timetable for German unification and will urge him to address Polish concerns about the boundary between Poland and Germany, the Administration officials said. Poland has asked for guarantees that the current border, along the Oder and Neisse rivers, be made permanent and that a united Germany formally forswear any effort to reclaim part of prewar Germany that is under Polish control. 
Poland's apprehensions are rooted in history. Poland has often been a victim of German aggression. Germany invaded Poland in 1939, and the Nazis occupied Poland in World War II.
So far Mr. Kohl has been ambiguous about the border. When traveling abroad, he says Germany has no intention of tampering with the boundaries established after World War II. But when he is in Germany, he says the issue can be decided only by the parliament of a united Germany.
Mr. Kohl's vagueness is motivated in part by domestic politics. He does not want to lose the votes of strongly conservative Germans who might want to reassert territorial claims in western Poland.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl are also expected to discuss ways to keep a united Germany in NATO and defy heavy Soviet pressure to weaken German links with the Atlantic alliance.
Mr. Kohl is expected to ask Mr. Bush to support a speed-up in the process of unification that would conceivably permit East Germans to vote in West Germany's December elections.
The visiting German leader is expected to contend that only rapid unification can avert the economic and political collapse of East Germany and stem the flood tide of East Germans leaving for West Germany.
Mr. Kohl's visit comes just three weeks before East Germans go to the polls to choose a new government. One of the chief functions of the new government will probably be negotiating the terms of union with West Germany.
 
Food Subsidies Reduced
In the last few weeks, East Germany's economic crisis has become more severe. Alarmed at the reduction in Government food subsidies, East Germans have rushed to buy flour, sugar and meat, and the East German Government has promised emergency measures to keep up basic food supplies.
West German officials now say that East Germany might seek union as soon as possible after its March 18 elections.
Robert Gerald Livingston, director of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies at Johns Hopkins University, said that under the West German ''constitution'' - the Basic Law of May 23, 1949 - the constituent states of East Germany could vote to become part of West Germany. American officials say they believe that some of the East German states, or Lander, might do just that after the elections next month.
American and West German officials said Mr. Kohl would probably discuss that possibility with Mr. Bush when they meet over the weekend. The West German Interior Minister, Wolfgang Schauble, apparently discussed it with American officials when he was in Washington this week to help prepare for Mr. Kohl's visit.
 
'Reconstituting the Lander'
A Western diplomat said tonight that Germans were ''thinking more and more'' about that provision of the Constitution, Article 23, as a vehicle for the swift unification of the Germanys.
Mr. Kohl's plan for German unity, issued in December, made no reference to that article. But ''things are moving so fast in Germany'' that there is increasing interest in the constitutional procedure for incorporating East German states into West Germany.
After the March 18 elections, Mr. Livingston said, ''the East German Parliament will probably pass a law reconstituting the Lander'' abolished in 1952. Then in May of this year, he said, the constituent states of East Germany will elect their own legislatures, which could adopt resolutions to merge with West Germany.
Thus, it appears that Mr. Bush will get the clarification he seeks on Mr. Kohl's timetable for unifying Germany, and the Chancellor will make clear that he wants to achieve that goal sooner rather than later. Administration officials said that Mr. Bush believed it was in the long-term strategic interest of the United States for Germany to be unified and solidly anchored in the West.
Mr. Bush is expected to use his meeting with Mr. Kohl to underline the importance of continued German membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Mr. Bush will probably urge Mr. Kohl to stand firm in support of that position as a way to reassure his neighbors in Western and Eastern Europe that they have nothing to fear from a unified Germany.
 
Kohl's Vision of Unification
In Canada on Feb. 13, East and West Germany and the four major World War II Allies agreed on a framework for negotiating German unification after 45 years of division. Under that formula, the ''two plus four'' concept, the two Germanys would discuss the economic, political and legal aspects of unification. Then the four Allies would meet with the two Germanys to discuss security issues like the size of the army for a unified state and its ties to NATO.
'' 'Two plus four' is a misnomer,'' Mr. Livingston said. ''It will be one plus four. The Germans will come into those discussions with a united delegation. They'll come in under one flag.'' Administration officials said Mr. Kohl would discuss such questions when he lays out his vision of a unified Germany at Camp David this weekend.
The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl would talk about ''the full range of issues related to changes in Eastern Europe,'' including the future of NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
''We don't anticipate any new agreements or announcements,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. Rather, he said, the weekend provides ''an opportunity for the two leaders to discuss the status of events, where they think things are going.''

HEADLINE: DOUBTS ON SUPPLY SPUR PREDICTIONS OF HIGH OIL PRICES

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
New doubts about the world's ability to pump enough oil to keep pace with growing demand have convinced many analysts that oil prices will rise much more rapidly than previously expected, by about 50 percent within five years.
Increases are typically passed along to consumers fairly quickly, which means prices for gasoline and heating oil would rise sharply. From 1975 to 1981, a period when a barrel of oil went from about $13 to over $36, gasoline prices in this country more than doubled, from 58 cents a gallon to $1.33.
Until recently, most oil executives and analysts had anticipated that prices, now averaging about $20 for a 42-gallon barrel, would rise at a rate slightly above inflation during the 1990's, to not more than about $25 a barrel by 1995. But now they say $30 oil is likely by then. 
Many analysts say the supply-demand balance has been shifted by factors including declining output in the United States and the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producers outside OPEC; moves by newly independent Eastern European nations to buy oil from the Persian Gulf; energy demand in East Asia that is growing far faster than had been expected, and constraints on production arising in the oil-rich Persian Gulf.
 
'A Lot of Imponderables'
The speed of the climb in oil prices ''will catch a lot of people by surprise,'' said Mehdi Varzi, head of energy research at Kleinwort Benson Securities in London. ''By 1995, it is more than likely that we would have $30 oil.''
George F. Friesen, an analyst at the Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation in New York, said, ''There are a lot of imponderables, but I would say the risk of oil prices spiking is greater now than at any time in the last 10 years.'' He also said $30-a-barrel oil by 1995 is a strong possibility.
In interviews, about two dozen industry executives, securities analysts, consultants and economists agreed that future price increases for oil might be much steeper than had been predicted even six months ago.
 
Many Nations Taking Steps
A far smaller number disagreed, contending, among other things, that many nations anticipating such price increases are already taking steps to mitigate them, including installing more energy-efficient equipment and switching to alternative fuels like natural gas. These experts also say the Persian Gulf producers will be able to expand production capacity to meet whatever demand exists in five years.
A surge in oil prices would threaten the economies of major oil-consuming nations like the United States, Japan and West Germany with rising inflation, higher interest rates and slower growth or recession. Many economists attributed the 1981-82 recession in the United States, the worst since World War II, to the sharp increase in oil prices in 1979.
Within the United States, property values and employment would rise in energy-producing states like Texas, Colorado and Alaska, and decline in the Northeast and Midwest, said Stephen P. A. Brown, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.
With every $1 increase in oil prices, Texas adds 15,000 jobs and New York State loses 11,000, Mr. Brown said. The nation as a whole loses 78,000 jobs for every $1 rise, he said.
The nation's trade deficit, which included $49 billion in payments for imported oil in 1989, would soar with rising oil prices. Then, over time, some combination of conservation, a slowing economy, rising domestic oil production and more use of alternative fuels would ease import demand, economists say.
Because of the change in the supply-and-demand picture for oil, the widely held view now is that the average price for West Texas Intermediate crude, the American benchmark grade, will exceed $20 a barrel this year for the first time since 1985. The price of West Texas crude fell to $21.42 a barrel yesterday, and has remained above $21 throughout the winter even though unusually warm weather has lowered heating-oil demand since the year began. The average figure last year was $19.65, and in 1988 it was $15.98.
Most analysts expect the price to decline to below $19 a barrel by late March, when demand usually slows.
 
Trends Becoming Clear
But the price could well rise again after that, many industry experts said, because of trends that have become clearer in recent months. For one thing, global consumption has been growing - by an average of more than a million barrels a day since prices collapsed in 1986, to 52.1 million barrels a day last year, according to the International Energy Agency in Paris. Global consumption - excluding the Soviet Union, China and Eastern Europe - is expected to break the 11-year-old record of 52.3 million barrels a day this year.
Many economists say the rapid growth of demand in the Far East, where many nations' rapidly industrializing economies are growing quickly, will keep demand rising at close to that rate even if United States demand does not grow.
In Japan, the Government three years ago estimated growth in total energy use at 1 percent a year. But after a surge that put the total above 5 percent in 1988, the Government revised its estimate to an average of 3.2 percent through the 1990's.
Private economists also expect the growth in energy use in Southeast Asia to average 5 percent a year through 2000. Oil use is also rising rapidly in South Korea, where gasoline demand soared by 27 percent and 29 percent in the last two years.
 
Lower Soviet Exports
Eastern Europe could add three million barrels to demand for OPEC oil in this decade because the Soviet Union, with limited oil available for export, is starting to export less to the former Communist bloc, said David T. Mizrahi, editor of the Mideast Report in New York.
At the same time, the world's supply-and-demand picture for oil is being changed by falling production in the Soviet Union and the United States. In the last year, those two nations have together reduced output by about 5 percent, or a million barrels a day, to about 19 million barrels a day.
As a whole, non-OPEC nations -excluding the Soviet Union, China and Eastern Europe - are pumping about 29 million barrels a day, or about the amount they were when oil prices collapsed in January 1986.
But over the same period the 13 OPEC nations have raised output by nearly five million barrels a day, to an average of 21.7 million last year, meeting virtually all the extra demand.
 
Question Is Changing
Indeed, the question about OPEC is changing from whether the group can limit oil production enough to keep world oil prices at whatever levels it wants, to whether it can expand its ability to pump oil enough to match rising demand, experts say.
Some analysts say the Persian Gulf OPEC nations - Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia - will be unable to add enough capacity to overcome production declines elsewhere within OPEC. Three other members, Algeria, Gabon and Ecuador, are not expected to be exporting much oil, if any, by 2000.
OPEC's Secretary General, Subroto, said in Houston this month that OPEC sees demand for its oil rising to 29 million barrels a day in 1995. To meet it, he said, OPEC must expand daily capacity by at least a million barrels in each of the next five years.
Dr. Subroto, who is from Indonesia, said OPEC must spend $60 billion to add this capacity, and he called on governments, bankers and private oil companies in oil-consuming nations to link arms with the organization on the project. Both sides have a large stake in keeping oil prices stable, he said.
Dr. Subroto's contention is that without some combination of loans, investments and technical help from major oil-consuming nations like the United States and Japan, OPEC may be unable to keep its oil-pumping capacity ahead of rising demand. Western and Japanese bankers and private oil companies are wary of expanding ties with the Arab oil producers.
Dr. Subroto said OPEC nations fear a sharp increase in prices, remembering the early 1980's, when high prices slashed long-term demand and sent many of their economies into hard times.
 
Less Competition for OPEC
By contrast, analysts say, if oil prices rise only modestly, OPEC oil will face less competition from increased production in non-OPEC nations, where drilling costs are higher than in the Persian Gulf, as well as from conservation and uses of other fossil fuels like coal and natural gas, or nuclear energy.
The organization's current view is that it can keep demand for OPEC oil growing if prices average $18 a barrel, adjusted for inflation, over the next several years. At current inflation rates, the nominal price for OPEC oil would rise to about $23.40 a barrel in 1995 if OPEC can keep its output matched to growing world demand.
Many analysts and economists are skeptical of OPEC's assertions that it needs help in expanding its capacity, and question the group's real intentions. And some say the worries about a coming global production shortage in oil are vastly overblown.
M. A. Adelman, professor emeritus at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, estimated that Arab oil producers could easily finance five million more barrels of capacity from their own revenues at a cost of less than $6 billion. Most of the new production, and money, will come from Saudi Arabia, he said. That nation, already with a fourth of the world's known reserves, recently announced discoveries of large oilfields.
Philip K. Verleger Jr., an energy analyst at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said Saudi Arabia could expand its production capacity in five years ''without an enormous capital expenditure.'' Privately, Dr. Subroto has put the total required by Saudi Arabia at $30 billion, a figure many analysts dismiss as extravagantly high.

HEADLINE: BUSH PICKS A CHIEF TO LEND NEW LIFE TO RIGHTS PANEL

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
President Bush selected Arthur A. Fletcher today as chairman of the troubled Civil Rights Commission, a move that civil rights leaders lauded as a signal that the Bush Administration was taking the commission more seriously than the Reagan Administration did.
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said today that by nominating Mr. Fletcher, Mr. Bush hoped to show that he wants to restore the commission as ''an effective institution.''
''We have felt that it could be stronger and more forceful in representing the concerns of minorities and others and we expect it to operate in that fashion,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''We think they can do a better job.'' 
 
Longtime Bush Supporter
Mr. Fletcher, who is 65 years old, served as Assistant Secretary of Labor in the Nixon Administration, as a deputy Presidential assistant for urban affairs under President Gerald R. Ford and as an adviser to President Reagan. He is now a management consultant in Washington.
Mr. Fletcher said that the President had promised him ''open access'' today and had told him about the commission, in essence: ''You got the ball. Invigorate it.''
The new chairman said his first move would be a blanket review of ''every piece of civil rights legislation passed in the last 25 years.''
 
Restoring Panel's Reputation
''In the light of what is happening to the economy both domestically and internationally, the Civil Rights Commission needs to take a hard look at each piece of civil rights legislation passed by the Congress and make some determination about whether it is effective as it stands or needs improvement.''
He said he would try to restore the commission's old reputation as the conscience of the nation.
Civil rights groups, which complained that in the Reagan era the commission was discredited as the Government's enforcer of civil rights, praised the selection of Mr. Fletcher, who must be approved by the other members of the commission.
''It's a good signal to the civil rights community,'' said Althea T. L. Simmons, the director of the Washington bureau of the N.A.A.C.P. ''By selecting someone to serve as chair with some credentials in civil rights, it proves that the President has some sensitivity with reference to the commission.''
 
Concern About Overall Shape
But Ralph Neas, executive director of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of more than 180 organizations, said he worries that the overall tenor of the commission is still far too conservative. ''Regardless of the Fletcher appointment,'' he said, ''there are too many right-wingers on the commission to restore its credibility.''
He said he wanted to see how Mr. Bush proceeded with other appointments to the commission, adding that the President would also have to work with Congress to make the commission once again bipartisan and independent.
Mr. Fitzwater said there was another vacancy on the eight-member commission that will be filled soon. Congress appoints four of its members and the President appoints four.
The commission was established in 1957 to evaluate Federal laws and the effectiveness of the Government's equal opportunity programs. It also serves as a research center for civil rights information. The panel has no enforcement authority.
During the 1980's, the commission became a battleground where Reagan Administration officials and representatives of minority groups fought over competing visions of civil rights and equality.
A year ago, Administration officials indicated that Mr. Bush wanted to name Mr. Fletcher to the commission and later to the chairmanship, but the chairman, William Barclay Allen, refused to resign.
 
'What Is a Minority?'
Also last year, Mr. Allen was arrested at gunpoint on an Indian reservation in Arizona. The incident, in which Mr. Allen was questioned by the police and released, involved an allegation that he had kidnapped a 14-year-old Apache girl in an adoption case in which he had taken an interest. His colleagues on the commission learned of the incident only weeks later from Arizonans in Congress.
Mr. Allen also angered the other commissioners by delivering a speech titled ''Blacks? Animals? Homosexuals? What Is a Minority?'' The speech was formally condemned by a 6-1 vote of the commission as ''thoughtless, disgusting and unnecessarily inflammatory.''
 
Resignation Last Year
Hitting back at the Bush Administration as ''too reticent to contribute to the debate on civil rights,'' Mr. Allen finally agreed to resign late last year, with three years left of his term.
The commission has been criticized by civil rights groups who say it has become irrelevant. During the Reagan Administration, they complained that the President was stacking the commission with conservatives who took positions opposing affirmative action.
In the 1980's the commission lost its reputation as a bipartisan body. It was rent by a highly political internal debate over the basic principles of civil rights and the meaning of equality.
 
With Bush at United Nations
Mr. Fletcher was executive director of the United Negro College Fund for two years in the early 1970's, and in that period he also served with George Bush, the chief United States delegate, at the United Nations. Mr. Fletcher was an alternate United States representative to the 26th session of the General Assembly.
He was born in Phoenix and graduated from Washburn University in 1950. He did graduate work at Kansas State University and San Francisco State College.
Mr. Fletcher's involvement in the civil rights movement began early. In 1954, he was teaching in a rural elementary school in Kansas and, stunned by the unfair treatment of black students, helped raise money for the pending Brown vs. School Board of Topeka desegregation suit, which was successfully fought up to the United States Supreme Court.
In 1969, as President Nixon's Assistant Secretary of Labor, Mr. Fletcher fought for affirmative action and issued the order that spurred enforcement of the Equal Employment Opportunity Law.
He said his background made him want to try to get as much as he could out of government for the nation's nonwhite labor force.
Mr. Fletcher, who is 6 feet 4 inches tall, also played end for the Los Angeles Rams and the Baltimore Colts in the early 1950's. The career was brief, cut short by an injury.
He is known as a talkative and good-natured man who likes a good argument, and he says he has had his share of arguments over the years with blacks who did not understand how he could work for Republican Presidents.
Asked why he had become a Republican, Mr. Fletcher replied: ''I'm from the state of Kansas, where all blacks are Republicans. As a kid coming up, the role models I saw, lawyers, doctors, schoolteachers and businessmen, were all Republicans.''

HEADLINE: Anger in Congress Over Aquino's Snub

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23

 BODY:
President Corazon C. Aquino's refusal to meet with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney during his visit to the Philippines this week has stirred anger among Democrats and Republicans in Congress and accelerated proposals for moving American forces from that country to other locations in the Pacific region.
At a White House meeting this week, Congressional leaders from both parties expressed their dismay to President Bush over the diplomatic snub, echoing in more subdued terms some of the angrier comments expressed by legislators in floor speeches and comments over the last several days. Members of the House were particularly sharp in their criticism of Mrs. Aquino, and some suggested that cutbacks in American aid to the Philippines might also come.
Representative Toby Roth, a Wisconsin Republican who serves on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, noted that the United States had given hundreds of millions of dollars in aid to the Philippines and that Mr. Bush had assisted Mrs. Aquino's Government in December by calling in American fighter planes to help put down a coup attempt. 
''I have a solution to the problem,'' he said. ''Let them keep their bases. We do not want them, we do not need them. They are only an albatross around the neck of the American people.''
 
Domestic Needs Cited
Mr. Roth said there were plenty of domestic needs for which money now going abroad could be used.
''We like the people of the Philippines, but it is incumbent upon us to send them a strong message,'' he said. ''America is a strong horse willing to pull a heavy load, but we are not a dairy cow to be milked.''
The Subic Bay Naval Station and Clark Air Base are the principal American military installations in Southeast Asia and among the largest outside the United States. There are about 18,000 American military personnel in the Philippines, and 20,000 dependents. The United States is one of the major employers in the country.
In recent years, rising nationalism in the Philippines has made the bases a political target of rebels on the left and of more moderate opposition members who believe Mrs. Aquino is too close to the United States.
The 1947 lease covering six American installations including Clark and Subic Bay is scheduled to expire in 1991 unless the two nations can negotiate a new agreement.
Lawmakers in the United States are irritated at the direct linkage the Philippine Government appears to be making between the bases and increased economic aid. ''There has always been Congressional concern that we are paying rent through foreign aid even though those bases are supposed to serve mutual security interests,'' said a foreign policy aide to Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat who heads the Senate Appropriations Subcommitee on Foreign Operations.
 
Inaccurate News Reports Charged
A week before Mr. Cheney's visit, Mrs. Aquino announced that she would not meet with the Defense Secretary, saying American news reports had inaccurately characterized her discussions with other American officials who had visited recently.
Mrs. Aquino also complained that Washington had failed to live up to a 1988 aid agreement covering the last two years of the bases agreement because this year's allotment had been reduced by $96 million. Still, the Philippines ranks among the top five recipients of American aid.
Mrs. Aquino's complaints about the cuts in aid were generally supported by politicians in the Philippines, and some lawmakers here said they understood Mrs. Aquino's political need to demonstrate her independence from Washington. But even those most sympathetic to her said she had gone to far in refusing to see Mr. Cheney.
''I think that Mrs. Aquino's action was regrettable because the United States has been a great friend to the Philippines,'' said Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the House Appropriations subcommittee responsible for making foreign aid allocations.
Mr. Obey said the Philippines received $289 million in assistance last year and $467 million this year. ''If that's a loser, I'd hate to see a winner,'' he said. ''I think it comes with ill grace to the Philippine Government to object to a 62 percent increase over last year.'' He said this was the largest increase for any country in the foreign aid bill.
The Administration has already been reviewing alternatives to the Philippine bases. According to Congressional officials, Guam and Singapore have been examined as possible relocation sites for some installations.

HEADLINE: Ex-Trustee Buys College At Bankruptcy Auction

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 23

 BODY:
In what is thought to mark the first time that an entire educational campus was put on the auction block because of bankruptcy, Bishop College, once the largest black college in the Western United States, was sold this morning after years of scandal and financial distress.
When the bidding started, there was talk among spectators that the 130 acres and 22 buildings would be sold in parcels to real estate developers.
But when the gavel fell, the new owner was Comer J. Cottrell, a former trustee of the college, who paid $1.5 million for the property with buildings now boarded and crumbling. He plans to turn it back into a predominantly black college, perhaps as early as next year. 
 
'A Lot of Love Into That Place'
''I put a lot of love into that place,'' said a tearful Mr. Cottrell, a 58-year-old Dallas businessman who resigned from Bishop's board in 1986, two years before the college closed. ''It won't be precisely what it was before. It will be a college that is operated as a business.''
If ever a college was sold at a bankruptcy auction before today, nobody seems to know when. ''It's the first one that we've ever done,'' said Dick Ritchie, president of Assets Liquidators, which handled today's proceeding and has sold everything from hotels to marinas. ''I don't know of anyone who's auctioned a college.''
Last year, the Robert Morris College campus in Carthage, Ill., was put up for auction because of falling enrollment, not bankruptcy, and a community group submitted the only bid. The campus is expected to reopen as a school for Hispanic students.
At Bishop, the unusual sale was the latest twist in a story that began in 1881 when Bishop was founded by nine freed slaves and a group of Baptist missionaries. The college was named for Nathan Bishop, a white Union Army colonel who gave the money to start the college. It was originally in Marshall, Tex., but moved here in 1961 and flourished with Dallas's economy.
At its height in the early 1970's, the enrollment was nearly 2,000, and the college had a national reputation for producing Baptist preachers.
 
Falsification of Loan Applications
But in 1974, 15 administrators were charged with falsifying names on applications for student loans and cashing the loan checks themselves. Most of the group was convicted.
Five years later, the president and two top administrators were indicted on charges of mismanaging Bishop's finances. The president and one administrator were acquitted, and the second administrator was convicted on minor charges.
But the two incidents were the begining of the end for Bishop. Donations dwindled, and the school's annual budget, once over $9 million, dropped by a third. Enrollment began to decrease too, reaching a low of 300 when the doors closed in August 1988.
Mr. Cottrell, who owns the Pro-Line Corporation, a hair-products concern that is the 18th-largest black-owned business in the nation, played a prominent role in efforts to avert the school's collapse.
 
Layoffs and Fund-Raising Drives
In 1981, a year after an audit showed that the college owed $3.5 million to the Federal Government, Mr. Cottrell was named acting chairman, a position he held for five years. His tenure saw sharp layoffs and ambitious fund-raising drives, but to no avail. By 1986 the school was $7 million in debt. That year it lost its accreditation.
By 1988 the debt had grown to $20 million and a bankruptcy judge ordered that the property, already whittled down to 130 acres from 400 acres, be sold.
The attempts to sell the property were as ill-fated as the attempts to save the college. Last year, Panditha Sujatha Nadarajah, a wealthy American woman of Sri Lankan descent who lived in Lubbock and preached the Buddhist faith, offered $10 million for the property and left ten sapphires worth $75,000 as collateral.
She then went to Sri Lanka for the remainder of the money but was detained there when local gem dealers accused her of defrauding them of $4.2 million. The woman said she was being held hostage in her hotel room in Sri Lanka. The bankruptcy judge overseeing the Bishop case disqualified her offer and ordered that the property be auctioned.
 
Bidding Takes 10 Minutes
The bidding today, in a hotel conference room here, took only 10 minutes. Though there were dozens of spectators, only two people bid, Mr. Cottrell and a man in sunglasses and a blue suede jacket who left immediately after the auction.
The minimum bid was $1 million, and Mr. Cottrell said no one was more surprised than he when his $1.5 million bid was accepted.
''I expected to go about $5 million,'' he said, still shaking after the gavel sounded. ''Maybe that's why I'm so emotional.''
He said he did not know where he would obtain the estimated $40 million to renovate the crumbling campus, and had not decided whether to change its name.
''I just know it will be a college again,'' he said, adding that he hoped the first classes could be held in the fall of 1991. ''It will be in business and filled with kids, because I'm going to be electric.''

HEADLINE: Pittsburgh Urged to Revive Mills To Turn Out High-Speed Trains

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Carnegie Mellon University proposed today that Pittsburgh become the nation's center for manufacturing high-speed railroad lines that are being considered by many states.
The university's proposal, which was based on a six-month study in conjunction with executives of major Pittsburgh corporations, envisions a public-private venture that would use the city's idled steel mills to build high-speed trains and tracks.
As a start, the study recommends laying a $400 million, 19-mile line from downtown Pittsburgh to the Greater Pittsburgh International Airport, which is undergoing a $600 million expansion.
The proposal includes magnetic levitation, or maglev, in which powerful electromagnets raise passenger cars about six inches above a guideway and then propel them at up to 300 miles an hour. High-speed trains with steel wheels are slower and more costly to maintain. 
 
Overseas Prototypes Rolling
Many states are studying maglev as a way to modernize rail lines and relieve airport and highway congestion, and prototypes of maglev trains are carrying passengers on test tracks in West Germany and Japan.
The Department of Transportation, which committed $10 million to study maglev this year, estimates that if no improvements are made, traffic jams will waste 12 billion working hours a year by 2005 and airline delays will cost passengers $13 billion a year by 2005. Both estimates reflect a 400 percent increase over 1985.
''Maglev is the future,'' Dr. Richard M. Cyert, president of Carnegie-Mellon University, said before the announcement. ''It is also critical to the future of Pittsburgh.
 
More Businesses and Jobs
Seven years ago, he said, the university sought to develop a computer software industry in Pittsburgh, and now over 60,000 people work here in more than 600 high-technology businesses.
Carnegie Mellon's research was supported by city and county agencies, unions and half a dozen major Pittsburgh corporations, including AEG Westinghouse Transportation Systems, Union Switch & Signal and the USX Corporation. They have formed a corporation, Maglev Inc., that will conduct a final two-year study of technical and financial issues.
Pennsylvania has contributed $300,000 toward the $1.5 million study. A consortium of Japanese companies pledged $250,000 for it today.
''A new transportation system is an essential factor for the success of the U.S. economy,'' said Jitsuro Terashima, a spokesman for the consortium and general manager of strategic information and corporate planning for Mitsui and Company, a trading company.
 
Reawakening the Steel Mills
The Carnegie Mellon researchers reported that $27 billion worth of similar projects are under study and that the nation might ultimately spend $211 billion on maglev systems built in vacant Pittsburgh steel mills. Federal support is considered crucial in starting most maglev projects.
Another consortium of Japanese and German companies have agreed to build a 20-mile maglev system between Orlando International Airport and the Epcot Center at Disney World. The goal is to begin operation of that system on Oct. 1, 1994. Other potential routes under study are Boston-Washington, Boston-Albany, Cleveland-Chicago, Detroit-Montreal and Quebec City, Philadelphia-Harrisburg, PIttsburgh-Cleveland, Miami-Jacksonville, Tampa-Orlando and San Francisco-San Diego.
''There are circumstances in which high-speed rail is a good investment,'' said Louis S. Thompson, a railroad adviser to the World Bank in Washington. ''For the most part, you will not find the opportunity in the United States where the passenger revenues are going to justify the construction and operation of the system.''
 
It's New, but It's Changeable
The technology for magnetic levitation was patented by Dr. Gordon Danby and Dr. James Powell of the Brookhaven National Laboratories on Long Island, but companies in Japan, West Germany and Britain took the lead. A German company, Transrapide International, has developed the most advanced system, and Maglev Inc. in Pittsburgh is seeking the exclusive license to build Transrapide systems in the United States, said James C. Roddey, acting president of Maglev Inc.
''The operative word here is feasibility,'' he said, referring to the proposed maglev line in Pittsburgh and the creation of a new industry. ''We have Carnegie Mellon's preliminary feasibility study indicating that we are justified in going the next step.The difficult part is that we're dealing with a new technology that is changing rapidly.''
The project could provide thousands of jobs as well as impetus for major urban renewal, said Meyer Berger, a real estate developer and spokesman for Maglev Inc. He envisions razing a 65-acre South Side industrial slum between Station Square and the 10th Street Bridge and replacing it with a maglev terminal, hotels, office buildings and a check-in center for the airport.
''People would buy their airline tickets here, check their bags and ride out to the airport in five or ten minutes,''
Mr. Berger said. ''We would make it so darn easy for people that they would have to use it.''

HEADLINE: Talking Troops and Dollars in Korea

 BODY:
Korea's militarized North-South frontier remains dangerous even at the end of the cold war that prompted it. Pyongyang is still armed to the teeth, rigid and unpredictable. What has changed is the ability of South Korea, after years of stunning growth, to help pay for its own defense. 
The Pentagon, pressed by Congress to contain spending, now seeks a more balanced partnership. Reapportioning costs makes military and budgetary sense. South Korea agrees in principle, arguing only over specifics of numbers and timing.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney began discussions last week, at the start of his current Asia-Pacific tour. He did not announce Washington's target amounts for individual countries. For Korea, these are said to include doubling Seoul's present cash contribution of $300 million, shifting operational command to a Korean general and cutting back the current U.S. garrison of 44,000 by 10 to 12 percent. Mr. Cheney brought a similar message to Tokyo. The Bush Administration must come to terms with Congressional budget-makers as well as with Seoul. Secretary Cheney reports to Congress on his regional savings proposals April 1. Legislators will expect Korea and Japan to contribute their fair share. The hard-pressed Aquino Government in Manila has just been asked to swallow a cut in compensation payments for U.S. bases. How can prosperous, politically stable Seoul be asked for less?
Korean negotiators will point out that Seoul contributes more than cash. It also provides valuable real estate, tax exemptions and other items worth hundreds of millions. Counting the costs of South Korea's own armed forces, Seoul devotes a hefty 5.4 percent of its gross national product for defense, roughly the same percentage as the U.S.
Moreover, the U.S. gains other benefits from its Korea-based troops. Although their only formal role is to aid in South Korea's defense, they are a large factor in America's military presence in the Western Pacific. Even in the post-cold-war era, Asians worry about revival of the rivalries and ambitions of Moscow, Tokyo and Beijing. Many Asians find reassurance in that military presence.
Some Korean nationalists resent it, and object also to U.S. pressure on trade issues. The Korean Government argues that, by standing up to such pressures, it makes a further, intangible contribution to U.S. interests. In any case, Seoul will try to bargain for smaller troop cuts.
Yet South Korea, whose economy has more than doubled since 1983, can afford to pay more. And Washington can no longer afford to pass up reasonable defense savings.

HEADLINE: To Ortega: Throw the Election

BYLINE: By John B. Oakes; John B. Oakes is former Editorial Page Editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:
It isn't going to happen. But the smartest thing President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua could do for his country in the short run (and for himself in the long run) would be to do the unthinkable: throw tomorrow's presidential election to his principal opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro.
Mrs. Chamorro is, of course, the candidate of the ''united'' opposition, consisting of disunited anti-Sandinistas from every shade of the political spectrum. More important, she is also the candidate of President Bush and the State Department. In part, her campaign has been paid for by the U.S. taxpayer, and she has Washington's wholehearted moral and political support. 
If Mrs. Chamorro wins - even if the vote count is seriously flawed in this most closely monitored election in Latin American history - the last person to complain will be President Bush.
If President Ortega wins - even in an election judged by independent observers to be reasonably clean -there's still no telling what President Bush might do.
With such advisers on Latin American affairs as Vice President Quayle and chief of staff John Sununu, he is capable of declaring, in the face of the facts, that the election was a fraud and that the United States is not obligated to demobilize the contras and call off our shameful and illegal proxy war.
An Ortega victory, fair or foul, will also furnish President Bush with an excuse to continue the devastating trade embargo and economic war against Nicaragua, which has done at least as much as the Sandinistas' inept leadership to destroy their country's economy and reduce the standard of living to subpoverty levels.
A Chamorro victory would change all that. It would force Mr. Bush - if he expects to retain his fast-disappearing credibility in Latin American policy - to make an all-out effort to pull Nicaragua out of the economic mire into which we have done our best to sink it. Immediate lifting of the trade embargo would be a requisite first step. It would have to be speedily followed by a large-scale program of aid, at least comparable to that poured into Nicaragua's ''democratic'' neighbors Honduras, El Salvador and Panama.
It would be Mr. Bush's responsibility to help Nicaragua bring its raging inflation under control and to restore a modicum of the public services that a nation at war has had to allow to fall into ruin.
A Chamorro victory would, in short, relieve the Sandinistas of the impossible task of reviving the economy by themselves or with whatever help they could still squeeze out of the European democracies. It would shift a major part of the burden to the U.S., which would be morally bound to shoulder it.
The Sandinistas could relax while watching the bitterly divided Chamorro coalition fall apart between now and the next election. Nothing more than U.S. support and the hope of ousting the Sandinistas holds it together. Adding to the instability would be the questionable loyalty of the army in a non-Sandinista regime.
Along with the presidential contest, some 100 seats of the National Assembly will be up for grabs, as will be hundreds of local and municipal offices.
Even if Mr. Ortega is not lucky (or smart) enough to lose the presidency, the Sandinistas will surely have a sufficiently large voting block in the Assembly to give them a powerful position from which to criticize Mrs. Chamorro's government, demand dissolution of the contras (of whom 10,000 are still under arms in Nicaragua and Honduras) and complain of inadequate United States reparations.
Either way, with the probable victory of Mr. Ortega or the possible victory of Mrs. Chamorro, the bankruptcy of Reagan-Bush policy toward Nicaragua becomes clearer every day.
Either way, but particularly if, as expected, Mr. Ortega wins, Mr. Bush could show himself to be the statesman he claims to be by wiping the slate clean and beginning to build a decent relationship with Nicaragua. After all, the Nicaraguans can't be all bad, because their favorite national sport is baseball.

HEADLINE: Jose Napoleon Duarte, Salvadoran Leader In Decade of War and Anguish, Dies at 64

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Jose Napoleon Duarte, the former President of El Salvador who oversaw a shaky experiment in centrist civilian government after nearly a century of military rule, died yesterday at his home in San Salvador, his doctor said. He was 64 years old and had been diagnosed in May 1988 as having advanced liver cancer.
Mr. Duarte, who left office in June 1989 after a five-year term, played a central role in Salvadoran politics for a quarter-century. He was viewed by Republican and Democratic administrations in Washington as an advocate of democracy who could provide a bulwark against Communism in Central America. His Christian Democratic Government was therefore deemed worthy of vast amounts of American aid to counter a leftist insurgency and to try to address the country's harsh inequities.
But his Government was widely criticized in later years as ineffective and plagued by corruption, and in March 1989, with Mr. Duarte constitutionally barred from seeking another term, a rightist, Alfredo Cristiani, was elected to succeed him. 
Mr. Cristiani, who was in Taiwan yesterday, sent condolences to Mr. Duarte's family, Salvadoran radio reports said.
In Washington, the White House issued a statement saying, ''President Duarte was the father of Salvadoran democracy, a dedicated servant to the people of El Salvador and a firm friend of the United States.'' The Administration said Vice President Dan Quayle would attend the funeral.
Mr. Duarte showed physical resilience in his last months in office after cancer surgery in Washington in June 1988. Medical experts said he was not expected to survive to the end of his term, but he continued to carry out many functions of office and had a role in Central American peace initiatives.
Mr. Cristiani's decisive victory over the Christian Democratic candidate, Fidel Chavez Mena, led to concern that the post-Duarte era would be one of extremism and polarization, and to questions in Washington about whether El Salvador should continue to receive high levels of American aid. Mr. Cristiani's party, the Nationalist Republican Alliance, or Arena, has often been tied to the rightist death squads that have killed tens of thousands of Salvadorans.
 
The Middle Ground
 Some admirers of Mr. Duarte saw the voters' preference for Arena as an illustration of how Mr. Duarte was overwhelmed by the divisions and violence in Salvadoran society.
A well-to-do civil engineer, Mr. Duarte helped to found the Christian Democratic Party in the 1960's, becoming its first secretary general, and three times was elected Mayor of San Salvador, the capital. In the 1960's and 1970's he seemed to personify the hope that a middle ground could be found in easing the nation's perennial strife.
But in 1972 Mr. Duarte was denied victory in a presidential election widely viewed as fraudulent, and when he then gave support to an unsuccessful coup attempt by liberal military officers, he was forced into seven years of exile.
After his return, he joined a ruling civilian-military junta in 1980 and was appointed President later that year, serving until 1982. Mr. Duarte regained the presidency in an election in 1984 after two years out of Government.
Even with Mr. Duarte's election, the military was widely viewed as the country's most powerful institution, through which wealthy Salvadoran families traditionally wielded oligarchic power.
 
A Focus of Discontent
 As President, the sad-faced, stocky Mr. Duarte became the focus of discontent among ordinary Salvadorans, who accused him and his political allies of failing to run the country well.
Efforts to defeat the guerrillas militarily and to negotiate peace with them failed under President Duarte. The decade-old war remains at a stalemate, with more than 70,000 people dead, one in four Salvadorans displaced and the guerrillas in control of perhaps a third of the country.
The guerrillas' degree of success was achieved despite the fact that Salvadoran governments had received more than $4 billion in United States aid since 1981, much of it for the armed forces.
But while his efforts failed to resolve some of the most pressing social and economic problems of the country, they represented, after nearly a century of dictatorship, a step toward democracy in a profoundly undemocratic society.
Robert E. White, United States Ambassador to El Salvador during the Carter Administration, said Mr. Duarte stood ''for reform, for negotiation, and for an end to the savagery of the armed forces.''
Mr. Duarte's Government was often cited by the Reagan Administration as a prime instance of the spread of democracy in Latin America. The Bush Administration sought to sustain bipartisan support on Capitol Hill for large-scale United States aid to the new rightist Government.
 
Family and Early Life
 Jose Napoleon Duarte Fuentes was born on Nov. 23, 1925, in San Salvador to Amelia Fuentes de Duarte and Jose Jesus Duarte.
Mr. Duarte's beginnings have been described by himself and others as very simple, but in his memoirs, ''Duarte: My Story'' (G. P. Putnam, 1986), he wrote that his father came to be the owner of a fashionable tailor shop in San Salvador and was president of the Salvadoran Workers Society, a craftsmen's group.
President Duarte also wrote that his father declined the post of Labor Minister in 1931 but then took ''charge of the production of army uniforms'' for a time. Later the tailor shop went bankrupt, the son reported, and the father ''began baking and selling candy'' and went on to win ''a modest fortune in the national lottery.''
The younger Duarte attended the University of Notre Dame in South Bend, Ind., before beginning his career as a civil engineer in San Salvador.
He was drawn into politics in 1960 by a group that sought a middle ground between Communism and military totalitarianism. It was then that he helped found his party.
In 1972, he was one of four candidates in the presidential election and by all accounts was robbed of a victory.
Partial election returns indicated that he was ahead when the Government forbade additional radio reports about the outcome of the balloting. The following day, Col. Arturo Molina, the candidate of the governing National Conciliation Party, was declared the winner over Mr. Duarte by 22,000 votes.
 
From Exile to a Junta
 Not long afterward, on March 25, 1972, liberal military men mounted an unsuccessful revolt to which Mr. Duarte, speaking on the radio, lent his support. He was later arrested and beaten by plainclothes policemen before being released into exile. He settled in Caracas.
While in exile in 1977, Mr. Duarte later recalled in his memoirs, he visited Washington hoping to generate backing for the cause of democracy in his country. But he was given a cool reception. Only one Congressman, Thomas R. Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, was willing to meet him.
''My welcome to the United States has fluctuated in direct ratio to my political fortunes,'' Mr. Duarte wrote wryly in the memoirs.
After seven years in Venezuela - he took up painting there - he returned to El Salvador after a coup in late 1979, in which dissident military officers ousted the military strongman, Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero. At the invitation of the army, Mr. Duarte led a civilian-military junta, serving as President from 1980 to 1982. While in office, he denounced violations of human rights and spoke in favor of reconciliation with the insurgents. He also helped to undertake a controversial agrarian redistribution program, which fell short of its goals.
After the killing of four American churchwomen outside San Salvador in December 1980, he came under strong international pressure to bring the killers to account and to push El Salvador's largely dormant judicial system to respond.
''Americans find it hard to believe that our legal system is so different from theirs,'' he said in his memoirs, ''or that I had so little influence with the courts.''
''All the obstacles that had to be overcome illustrated how our justice system was the result of a corrupt society, a social breakdown, a loss of human values,'' he said.
Five men who were Salvadoran National Guardsmen at the time of the slayings eventually went on trial for them, but not until May 1984. They were convicted of aggravated homicide and sentenced to 30-year prison terms.
 
A Taint and a Victory
 Mr. Duarte's decision to join the junta had complex consequences. It led to his becoming President, but it also linked him, in the estimation of many, with the brutal aspects of the junta, notably the killing of thousands of Salvadoran civilians by the military and death squads.
In the months before the 1984 elections, critics in his party contended, as he wrote in his memoirs, ''that my participation in the junta tainted me, that I was associated in people's minds with the violence that took 40,000 lives.''
Still, Mr. Duarte proved widely popular; he received 54 percent of the votes in a runoff election. He asserted that peace would be restored, and assured the skeptical populace that even if he could not do it, the United States would do so swiftly, with its resourcefulness, its weaponry, its money. His admirers in those days saw him as high-minded and tenacious, although critics viewed him as a long-winded egomaniac.
In 1985, Mr. Duarte's Government had the guerrillas on the run, but it failed to introduce effective economic and social measures, just as land-reform measures earlier in the 1980's had proved ineffective, and the insurgency flourished anew, with rebels re-establishing a military and political presence in the capital.
Critics contended that as President, Mr. Duarte was simply not up to the challenges at hand in El Salvador, and they argued that the most dramatic example of this inadequacy was his reaction to the kidnapping of his daughter Ines Duarte Duran by rebels in 1985.
As part of a deal to obtain her freedom, he forced army commanders to set free more than 100 imprisoned rebels. She was released after being held captive for 44 days, but the army complained that the swap was a surrender to the rebels.
Mr. Duarte seemed deeply shaken by the episode, and some critics said it had a paralyzing effect on him.
Mr. Duarte is survived by his wife, Maria Ines Duran, and six children. Their son Alejandro was Mayor of San Salvador until he was defeated in the March 1988 elections.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY, 24, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 Many analysts are convinced oil prices will rise more rapidly than previously expected, climbing 50 percent within five years. They have new doubts about the world's ability to pump enough oil to keep pace with demand. [Page 1.] Auto sales fell 11.5 percent in mid-February, as a strengthening of the automotive market early in the month seemed to fade. Sales of domestically made light trucks were down 13 percent. Analysts said sales dropped off because rebates and other incentives were less generous than earlier in the year. [33.] A Senator is urging the F.C.C. to help break the stalemate in a dispute over rules that prevent the networks from owning a stake or sharing in the syndication profits of programs they broadcast. [35.] Athletes were urged to reject tobacco company sponsorship of sports. The Secretary of Health and Human Services spoke at a meeting protesting the Virginia Slims tennis tournament. [12.] The Justice Department defended its proposed deal with Exxon to settle criminal charges arising from the Alaska oil spill. [9.] 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 Renault and Volvo announced a far-reaching alliance under which each will own large shares of the other. State-owned Renault is the biggest industrial concern in France and Volvo is Sweden's leading industrial company. The deal creates the world's largest truck maker and a formidable force in the auto market. [33.] West Germany might use more than one exchange rate in forming a monetary union with East Germany, officials in Bonn said. For example, pensions and long-term savings of East Germans might be given a more generous exchange rate than money in circulation. The officials stressed that no decision had been made. [33.]
 
Companies
 Regulators seized Imperial Savings and Loan, one of California's largest savings institutions. Imperial, based in San Diego, had one of the savings industry's biggest holdings of ''junk'' bonds and has been hard hit by the steep drop in junk bond prices. [33.] Ernst & Young resigned as Pepsico's auditor after another client, Coca-Cola, issued an ultimatum that the accounting firm choose between the soft-drink giants, Pepsico said. [33.] Drexel said it paid $260 million in bonuses to its executives in the two months before the firm's parent filed for bankruptcy protection. Senior executives of the firm had previously said the bonuses totaled as much as $350 million. [37.] A proposed slate of directors for Lockheed was put forward by Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas financier who is waging a proxy fight for control of the board. [35.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Stock prices retreated again, pulled down by worries about interest rates and another exceptionally steep decline in the Tokyo stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day at 2,564.19, a drop of 10.58 points. For the week, the Dow fell 71.40 points, or 2.7 percent. [36.] Treasury securities prices were essentially unchanged, but the closing quotes masked volatile price moves here and overseas. [36.] The dollar rose against most major currencies but traders saidthe yen was again the center of attention. Gold prices slipped. [41.] Corn futures prices had their fourth straight day of gains, and analysts said the market could keep advancing into the spring. [41.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 Pumping devices to help ailing hearts were patented by two teams of inventors. The devices help patients survive until they can recover from a heart attack or undergo surgery.
 
Patents. [34.]
State tax collectors are becoming more aggressive, armed with computers and better investigatory skills that give them the tools to go after the maximum revenue due. ''People can't be so cavalier about state taxes,'' one lawyer warns. Your Money. [34.]

HEADLINE: Sales Drop In Vehicles Is Reported

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 23

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars fell 11.5 percent in mid-February, as a strengthening of the automotive market early in the month seemed to fade.
The seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales was 6.2 million cars, down from a rate of 7.2 million in the early part of the month. Last year at this time the rate was 7.7 million.
In the 10 days from Feb. 11 to 20, sales totaled 164,227, down from 185,672 in the comparable period last year. 
Light-truck sales also fell during the 10 days, to 93,836, from 107,822 a year earlier, a drop of 13 percent.
 
Combined Sales
Combined sales of cars and light trucks totaled 258,063, down 12.1 percent from 293,494 in the 1989 period.
The 10-day figures for domestically made cars represent roughly 70 percent of total car sales in the United States. Sales of imported cars are reported monthly.
A General Motors Corporation spokesman said that rebates had been trimmed slightly, possibly contributing to the slowdown in sales.
Joel Pitcoff, a Ford Motor Company sales analyst, said some incentive programs ended during the month's first 10 days. But he said, ''We continue to receive good reports on sales traffic in the showrooms and orders from dealers are increasing.''
 
Success of Transplants
The so-called transplants, cars made in this country by Japanese auto makers, continued to gain market share at the expense of the domestic companies. Car sales of transplants totaled 21,622 in the period, up from 13,615 a year earlier.
Cumulatively, more of the five Japanese transplants built in this country were sold than cars sold by the Chrysler Corporation, the smallest of the Big Three.
Since the start of the year, the Big Three domestic manufacturers have been reducing their stock of unsold vehicles by keeping production slow. Charles Brady, an automotive analyst for Oppenheimer & Company in New York, estimated that the current inventory stands at about a 65-day supply, which is ''a bit light for this time of the year.'' In early January, there was a 98-day supply.
''It's important to remember that in recent years the middle 10 days of the month always has been the weakest,'' Mr. Brady said. ''The question now is whether the companies will have enough cars heading into the spring selling season.''
Scott Merlis, an automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, said that ''the midmonth cooldown is understandable after a bang-up January,'' when incentives were large, encouraging strong sales. Mr. Merlis, noting the relatively low inventory, predicted that auto production could be strong in the second quarter ''and give the economy a nice shot in the arm.''
G.M. car sales were off 19.7 percent, to 75,232, from 93,715 a year earlier. G.M.'s biggest declines were in the Pontiac and Oldsmobile divisions. Buick, which has recently enjoyed some high quality ratings from outside analysts and has been promoting that aggressively, was the only G.M. division to post a sales increase for the period.
 
General Motors
G.M.'s light-truck sales, which include utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickup trucks, fell 7.4 percent, to 38,289, from 41,354 a year earlier.
Ford car sales fell 14.1 percent, to 46,943, from 54,662 a year earlier. Ford's light-truck sales were off 15.4 percent, to 32,466, from 38,382 a year earlier.
Chrysler's car sales were off 13.7 percent, to 20,430, from 23,680 a year earlier. Chrysler truck sales, a large part of which consist of the company's popular mini-van, fell 21.2 percent, to 19,569, from 24,841 a year earlier. Last month the No. 3 auto maker offered its first rebates ever on the mini-van, prompting strong sales but cutting deeply into profit; the incentives ended at the beginning of February.
Honda Motor Company's sales of cars built in this country were up 12.5 percent; the Toyota Motor Corporation's car sales were up threefold; the Mazda Motor Corporation had a gain of 56 percent in cars, and the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation's car sales rose 60 percent. Only the Nissan Motor Corporation had a downturn in car sales, off 2.1 percent. Nissan's truck sales, however, were up 8.2 percent.
 
CHRYSLER DELAYS PLAN
 HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., Feb. 23 (Reuters) - Chrysler said today that it had indefinitely deferred plans to slow down assembly lines at its plants in Belvidere, Ill., and Newark, Del.
The company also said its seven United States car and truck assembly plants will operate without interruption during March at current operating rates.
Chrysler plans to shut the Belvidere and Newark lines the week of April 2. The Belvidere plant may also be shut the week of April 9, Chrysler said. But Chrysler has dropped its plan to have production resume at the two plants at a lower level than before the shutdowns.
The No. 3 auto maker said there would be some hourly layoffs at Belvidere and Newark because of other changes in model production.
Reductions in production and manpower at Chrysler's assembly plant in Toledo, Ohio, will proceed as scheduled in April.

HEADLINE: Perrier Rival Talks of 'Serendipity'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
At Evian Waters of France Inc., some executives are uncomfortable with the word ''opportunity.'' It sounds, well, opportunistic when discussing the troubles at Perrier, the rival French water company that earlier this month recalled millions of its bottles of sparkling water after a few were found to contain traces of the chemical benzene.
On the other hand, Evian's chief executive, David S. Daniel, seems uncommonly fond of the word ''serendipity,'' using it several times in an interview this week. Now with bottles of Perrier, the industry leader by far, whisked off supermarket shelves and restaurant tables from Beverly Hills to Manhattan's Upper East Side, Evian starts a new advertising campaign on Monday. 
While the campaign was conceived last year, long before Perrier's troubles, it could not come at a better time for Evian. Trade publications estimate that the company will spend $6 million on advertising, 50 percent more than last year.
 
Distribution Broadened
Evian has also increased its distribution network. Mr. Daniel has spent the last 18 months signing up bigger and more aggressive distributors in important areas like Washington, Philadelphia and Southern California, where a lot of people like expensive bottled water.
''Serendipitously, we are ready for business!'' Mr. Daniel said. Evian, based in Greenwich, Conn., is a unit of Boussois Souchon Neuvesel, a large Paris food company that also makes Dannon yogurt and Lea & Perrins Worcestershire sauce.
Another fortunate circumstance for Evian is that it owns Saratoga water, which like the unavailable Perrier, is a sparkling water that people like as an alternative to liquor and wine. Mr. Daniel says East Coast restaurants are clamoring for Saratoga, which is produced by a small company in upstate New York. A new Saratoga ad campaign, about one-third the size of the Evian drive, will start on March 5.
But whatever Evian does is likely to leave it a distant No. 2 to Perrier. Distributors, many of whom sell both Evian and Perrier, report that while supermarkets are scrambling to fill their Perrier void with Evian and other bottled waters, they are still asking when Perrier will return. When Perrier announced its American recall Feb. 9, executives said the withdrawal might last as long as three months.
According to Beverage Marketing, Perrier Group has 23.9 percent of the American market, compared with 1.7 percent for Evian, which is the seventh-largest bottler in the United States.
 
'Making Tremendous Inroads'
Still, industry consultants agree that Evian is doing well. ''Evian is being plugged in everywhere and they are making tremendous inroads into Perrier's turf,'' said Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., a food and beverage industry consultant that conducted a nationwide survey of retailers this week. This was all the more surprising, Mr. Pirko said, because Evian, a still water like tap water, does not directly compete with Perrier.
Hellen Berry, market research director for the Beverage Marketing Corporation, an industry research company, said, ''Saratoga has been quite successful in getting into many, many bars and restaurants.''
Like Perrier, Evian sold itself as a 1980's power drink for what Mr. Daniel called ''the word that begins with Y, ends with E, and has two P's in the middle.''
 
New Look at the Market
But Mr. Daniel, 34 years old, said he thought the young professional image was a myth. A former marketer with Pepsico, where he worked on caffeine-free regular and Diet Pepsi, Mr. Daniel joined Evian in 1987 as marketing director and became chief executive in May 1989. He commissioned a market survey soon after he joined Evian to determine who was Evian's customer. Other than an age range that tended to cluster around 36, Evian customers are found in social and economic groups across the board, he said.
Unlike Perrier, Evian emphasizes that one can drink its water at any time of day. As a carbonated mineral water marketed mainly as a non-alcoholic aperitif, Perrier tends to be taken at meal times. That is why more than a third of is bottles are shipped to restaurants, hotels and bars, compared with 5 percent to 10 percent for Evian, a proportion the company wants to increase substantially. Both companies place the rest of their water in supermarkets, convenience stores and mass merchandisers like K Mart.
Earlier Evian television campaigns showed sleek athletes sweating in gymnasiums as a narrator, with Nautilus equipment clanging in the background, almost ordered viewers to buy Evian. More recent commercials showed men and women in repose around a swimming pool, as a Spanish melody played.
The new television ads, shot in Hawaii and Yosemite National Park in California, continue the more restrained approach. The campaign, both for print and television, was prepared by TBWA, a New York advertising agency.
 
Benefits Described
Directed by Bruce Dowad, best known for his warm glow, slow-motion ads for the Canadian tourism bureau, the Evian television ads emphasize it as a water so pure that it is ''Nature's Gift.'' Solitary runners, swimmers and bike riders refresh themselves with Evian. A new print ad, also running on Monday, describes the physical benefits of water and is unusually long - 2,500 words on a full page. The ad mentions Evian only incidentally because, as Mr. Daniel puts it, ''consumers still have a lot of questions about bottled water in general.''
Evian's print ads feature a photograph of the French Alps captioned ''Our Factory,'' and a close-up of a luxurious meal in a restaurant that is captioned, ''To improve this meal, just add water.''
In Philadelphia last month, Evian signed as its distributor Coca-Cola Bottling of Philadelphia, which services more than 25,000 retail outlets in that city and in Delaware and South Jersey. It replaces about 25 distributors with only 3,000 outlets. The casinos in Atlantic City are clamoring for Evian and Saratoga, said Ronald D. Wilson, the bottler's president. ''It's going to be a big winner,'' he said.
In Southern California, Evian replaced more than 70 small distributors in 1988 with 7-Up/RC Bottling Companies of Southern California, with more than 30,000 outlets. ''We're getting very positive vibes about Evian,'' said Roy Breneman, senior vice president for sales and marketing at the bottling company.
For its part, Perrier Group of America is holding on to much of its shelf space, said Jane Lazgin, a spokeswoman for the Greenwich, Conn., company, which imports Perrier from the Paris-based company, Source Perrier.

Because of an editing error, the Advertising column of Business Day on Friday about the increasing use of sophisticated market research in motion picture advertising misstated the role of Seiniger Advertising for ''The Hunt for Red October.''
