HEADLINE: Dow Off Amid Worries About Rates and Tokyo

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices retreated again yesterday, pulled down by worries about interest rates and another exceptionally steep decline in the Tokyo stock market.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended the day at 2,564.19, a drop of 10.58 points. For the four-day holiday-shortened week, the Dow fell 71.40 points, or 2.7 percent. 
After a fairly stable opening yesterday, a spurt of futures-related selling pulled the Dow down by more than 20 points at about 11:30 A.M. A gradual recovery managed to bring the Dow to the plus side by about 3 P.M., but it fell again near the close.
 
Declines Lead Advances 2 to 1
The broader market was much weaker than the Dow. Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1, with 987 issues down and 468 higher. About an hour into trading, losing stocks had exceeded advances by about 5 to 1.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.55 points, to 324.15, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.93, to 179.35.
Rumors late in the afternoon that CS First Boston Inc. might be encountering serious financial difficulties -rumors that the company denied -had little impact on equities.
Volume on the Big Board dropped to 148.5 million shares, from 184.3 million on Thursday. In Tokyo yesterday, the Nikkei 225-stock index plunged 935.87 yen, or 2.6 percent, to 34,890.97, in thin trading. That plunge followed a drop of 1,161.19 yen, or 3.15 percent, on Wednesday. For the week, the Nikkei index lost 2,569.35 yen, or 6.9 percent.
 
Interest Rate Fears
''Fears of an increase in the Japanese discount rate raised similar worry on Wall Street of higher U.S. interest rates,'' said Alan Titunik, managing director of the Davis/Dinsmore Management Corporation, a New York-based investment advisory firm. ''The market was also adversely impacted by the reaction of the bond market to the plunge in Japanese stock prices.''
Mr. Titunik said, however, that interest rates over the longer term should stabilize to their levels of early January. By late in the day, the pivotal 30-year Treasury issue was unchanged, at a price to yield 8.56 percent.
''The short-term performance of the stock market will be affected by global events,'' he said. ''We eventually should see a gradual stability in the marketplace with steady interest rates and higher earnings, especially in the energy sector.''
 
Energy Stocks Mixed
Energy stocks were mixed yesterday, with Phillips Petroleum down 1/2, to 25 1/2; Chevron off 1 1/8, to 66 7/8; Mobil up 3/4, to 61 1/4, and Exxon unchanged at 47 1/8.
Pfizer was the most active issue, falling 3 points, to 56 1/4, on a volume of more than 3.9 million shares. The company has recently come under pressure because of problems with defects in a heart valve it makes. Pfizer said yesterday that it would restate its 1989 earnings, lowering them to reflect the reduced valuation of a pigments division it plans to sell.
Active blue chips included Philip Morris, off 5/8, to 37 1/2; A.T.&T., unchanged at 38 1/8; Merck, off 1 1/2, to 68; I.B.M., down 5/8, to 102 5/8, and Upjohn, off 1/4, to 34.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index fell 2.25 points, to 351.10, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index declined 3.23 points, to 419.52.

HEADLINE: U.S. Issues End Volatile Day Unchanged

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Treasury securities prices were essentially unchanged yesterday, but the closing quotes masked volatile price moves here and overseas. One Treasury securities dealer likened the day's action to ''a football being kicked between players in Japan and West Germany with us as spectators.''
The first test of the Treasury securities market occurred overnight in Tokyo, where a plunging stock market caused a flight to quality that lifted prices of Japanese and United States Treasury bonds. The benchmark United States long bonds, the 8.5 percent issue maturing in 2020, jumped 10/32 in Tokyo, to 99 24/32, which proved to be the universal high for the day. 
William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, said the long bond was subsequently hit overseas by a press report that West Germany was planning a one-for-one exchange for East German marks. Such a move, he said, would be ''sure to create a burst of inflation in West Germany that would quickly lead to much higher interest rates there.''
 
Influence of an Article
The report in The Washington Post yesterday, which was attributed to unidentified West German officials, sent the long bond tumbling in Japan to 98 28/32, the day's low. The long bond, which serves as a surrogate for the long-term Treasury securities market and is the preferred vehicle for speculators on Government debt, recovered somewhat in subsequent London trading.
Mr. Sullivan said that when the New York market opened, the long bond was at 99 16/32 and then traded in a range of 99 3/32 to 99 27/32 for most of the session. Late in the session, the long bond was being offered at 99 14/32, up 2/32 on the day. The yield was unchanged at 8.56 percent. A week ago, the long bond's yield was 8.46 percent.
Shortly after midday, the bond and stock markets were briefly focused on rumors of financial problems at the First Boston Corporation. The investment banking house denied the rumors and later released some financial information to reassure traders.
Jeffrey Bowman, a credit analyst at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, said: ''In our opinion, there is nothing to the rumors about First Boston. We've affirmed CS First Boston's credit rating.''
He attributed yesterday's nervousness to traders passing along rumors. ''Traders like to stir things up,'' he said. ''It creates uncertainty and volatility, which they can make money on.''
 
Drop in Auto Sales
The bond market moved a bit higher toward the close as some investors responded to the decline in midmonth auto sales that was reported yesterday.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the 8.5 percent notes of the year 2000, which correspond to the Japanese 10-year long bonds, were unchanged at 99 25/32, with the yield at 8.53 percent.
The 8.5 percent two-year notes sold the day before at an average yield of 8.50, rose 1/32, at 100 6/32, but this did not change the 8.39 percent yield.
At the shorter end of the Treasury debt market, the discount rate on the 90-day bills dipped two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.68 percent. The six-month bills eased a basis point, to 7.69 percent, and the one-year bills lost three basis points, to 7.58 percent.
The Federal Reserve again refrained from intervening in the credit market. The key Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans, traded a bit softer at 8.25 percent, the Fed's perceived target level at this time.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher, but Attention Is Focused on Tumbling Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against most major currencies but traders said the yen was again the center of attention.
Gold prices slipped. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled at $415 an ounce, down from $415.70 on Thursday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid of $415.50, down from $416.20 late Thursday. 
The yen continued to lose ground yesterday as prospects faded for higher Japanese interest rates. Dealers said they still expected the Bank of Japan to raise the nation's discount rate.
''The yen has been center stage,'' said Robert Hatcher, a vice president of foreign exchange at the New York office of Barclays Bank P.L.C. ''We're still waiting for a move on interest rates.''
High interest rates make a country's fixed-income securities attractive to investors, who need the nation's currency to make their investments.
The yen continued to slide against the dollar despite interventions by the Bank of Japan to bolster the yen. Dealers said the bank bought yen and sold dollars twice in the Tokyo market, once later in European trading and once in New York.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 146.47 yen, up 1.24 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 146.95 yen. By the end of the day in New York, the dollar had jumped to 147.07 yen from 146.53 yen late Thursday.
Market watchers said the dollar also benefited somewhat from concern about German reunification, which hurt the West German mark.
The dollar finished in London at 1.6779 marks, up from 1.6695 marks late Thursday. It continued the advance in New York to end at 1.6785 marks, up from 1.6717.
In London, a British pound sold for $1.7090, down from $1.7145 late Thursday. In New York, one pound fetched $1.7095, less than $1.7133 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.4740 Swiss francs, down from 1.4755; 5.6825 French francs, up from 5.6620; 1,241.50 Italian lire, up from 1,236.00, and 1.1983 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1949.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $416.50 an ounce, from $417.45 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to $415.50, from $417.25 late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong dropped $3.14 an ounce to close at $413.69.
Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid of $5.27 a troy ounce from Thursday's $5.28. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery closed at $5.238 a troy ounce, down from $5.268 late Thursday.

LENGTH: 3403 words

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PULSE: The New York Region - A Special Report
NEW YORK REGION FACES SLOWDOWN OF THE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
After their greatest boom since World War II, New York, New Jersey and Connecticut face the prospect of years of slower economic growth.
Wall Street, which fueled much of the region's resurgence, is two years into decline, having already shed tens of thousands of jobs. The national economy has slowed, further dampening local growth. And the prosperity of the 80's has itself left an unfortunate legacy for an already crowded region: overdevelopment, choking traffic, expensive housing and a scarcity of qualified labor, all of which are likely to limit the future.
At a time when governments are under pressure to address some of these ills, the economic slowdown has left all three states short hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue, increasing the likelihood of tax increases, service cuts or both. 
 
Department Store Failures
Signs of distress abound, from a glut of unsold condominiums in Connecticut to unrentable office space in New Jersey to the failure and precarious condition of venerable New York City department stores and the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment firm that led Wall Street into the highly leveraged, fast-money era.
Some economists, many of whom were startled by the region's sudden rebound in the 80's, still speak hopefully, approaching the issue of a downturn with care, as if it were a puddle on a sidewalk. Having shifted from a more nuts-and-bolts economy to one built around the less tangible commodities of money and information, the region has a higher percentage of jobs than the nation as a whole in industries that are considered likely to grow. A downturn, if there is one, is not expected to be deep or long.
But there also seems to be a consensus that there will be relatively little or no job growth in the next year or two, and that a resurgence like that of the 80's will not soon be repeated.
The Regional Plan Association, a Manhattan-based research group, projects that New York City and the 26 surrounding counties in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will add about 100,000 jobs a year in the next few decades. That is a healthy figure by the standards of the early 1970's, but it is less than half the growth over the last 10 years, when two million jobs were gained.
''It's a time of tremendous uncertainty,'' said Dr. James W. Hughes, professor of urban affairs at Rutgers University. ''Much to the surprise of everybody, the Northeast as a whole was a dynamo. Right now, it's a laggard again.''
 
Not 'Falling Apart'
If the region is once again an economic also-ran, it has not suffered as much as some feared it would after Wall Street's fall. The economy is not one ''that's falling apart,'' but one ''that isn't doing what it was doing,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, at a recent year-end briefing.
And there are those who believe that a slowdown, if short-lived, could be, as Stephen J. Kukan, general manager of area development for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in New Jersey, put it, ''the pause that refreshes, because it's given us a chance to plan.''
But the needs are formidable, the resources scant and each day seems to bring more gloomy news. On Thursday, Standard & Poor's warned New York State that its credit rating might fall. On Friday, Sikorsky Aircraft laid off 300 white-collar workers, most of them in Connecticut.
''We have to provide the housing, we have to provide the transportation, we have to provide the labor force,'' Richard T. Anderson, the Regional Plan Association president, said of the task ahead.
''The region,'' he also said, ''is being challenged more than any time in recent memory.''
 
Fall, Rise and Fall
 
Economy Retooled After the 70's
New York City's revival had its roots in its despair. When government officials, municipal labor leaders and bankers pulled together in the 1970's to rescue the city from insolvency, they started an unexpectedly fruitful chain of events.
A balanced budget bolstered the city's image, helping it keep and lure businesses. Taxes were cut. More businesses relocated or expanded. Real-estate values rose. And as Wall Street prospered, the city and the region were well positioned to capitalize.
In the process, the economy was retooled. Early in the century New York was a center of maritime trade and commerce. In the 1940's it became the nation's dominant manufacturing center. But by the late 1960's it had begun a disastrous swoon; more than half a million jobs were lost between 1969 and 1976.
In the 1940's about a third of the region's employment was based in manufacturing; today only 13 percent is based in what Mr. Ehrenhalt has called ''the forgotten economy.''
But from 1977 to 1988, employment in finance, real estate and insurance increased by 44 percent. Other sectors flourished as well: Construction jobs rose 88 percent; services, 46 percent; self-employed businesses, 64 percent, and retailing, 26 percent. Manufacturing jobs dropped 15 percent.
 
Highly Paid Jobs Lost
Even a freshly rebuilt economy, however, could not withstand the shocks that lay ahead.
First came the stock-market collapse of October 1987, which led to the loss over the last two years of 25,000 financial-service jobs. Many, though not all, were highly paid traders and investment bankers: Wall Street's pay scales are two and a half times the city's average.
Then, last year, the national economy slowed, adding another damper on the region's growth. ''It's been like a balloon, deflating itself rather abruptly,'' said Allen Proctor, a former New York City deputy budget director who is executive director of the Financial Control Board, a state agency that monitors the city's fiscal health.
The effects of these developments have rippled through the region, from sector to sector and state to state. Among the main casualties is a real-estate market whose soaring values made many homeowners rich, at least on paper, while burdening recent buyers with heavy mortgages and shutting many families out of the market altogether.
The median selling price for a single-family home in the metropolitan area increased from $70,500 in 1982 to $194,000 six years later before sliding to $185,200 last spring, according to the National Association of Realtors.
After surveying three million housing sales in New Jersey from 1965 to 1988, Dr. Hughes and a Rutgers University colleague, Dr. George Sternlieb, said prices could drop by as much as 12 percent.
''Everyone expected the $800,000 co-op to be in trouble,'' Mr. Proctor said, ''but you're seeing an across-the-board decline.''
 
Stores in Trouble
Connecticut tops the list of states whose banks show the highest increase in bad real-estate loans during the first nine months of 1989, according to a survey based on bank reports to the Government. New Jersey is No. 11 and New York State No. 12.
The caution that pervades the real-estate market is also affecting other kinds of spending, and some well-known palaces of consumption have reflected the uncertainty and loss of confidence. Stores that have not survived range from B. Altman to Crazy Eddie. Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Stern's are caught up in the bankruptcy of their parents, Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, both part of the troubled Campeau empire. And Bonwit Teller, which lost $23 million in three years, is on the block and likely to close if no buyer steps forward.
Last year, as he kept watch over New York City's ever-more-disappointing revenues, Mr. Proctor said there was a ratcheting down of corporate profits ''worse than anyone had anticipated,'' a development that may continue to dampen hiring, wage increases and business investment.
''The economy is searching for its core,'' he said. ''It's looking for its feet.''
 
Where New Jobs Will Go
 
Faring the Best: North New Jersey
Wall Street accounted for more than a third of New York City's private-sector job growth in the 10 years before the 1987 stock-market plunge. But as prominent firms like Shearson Lehman Hutton, Merrill Lynch and Salomon Brothers made plans to eliminate hundreds and sometimes thousands of jobs, Wall Street became a major source of weakness.
Few expect the financial industry's complete resurrection. In fact, more contraction seems likely, even after the bankruptcy filing on Feb. 13 by the parent company of Drexel Burnham Lambert, which cost more than 3,000 employees in New York City their jobs.
But predictions that the stock-market drop would cause severe job losses beyond the financial district have not come true, at least not yet. In a year-end report last month, Mr. Ehrenhalt of the Bureau of Labor Statistics noted that New York City gained 14,000 jobs in the first 10 months of 1989.
 
Unemployment Rate Rises
The unemployment rate for New York State rose from 4.2 percent in 1988 to 5.1 percent in 1989 but is still below the national average of 5.3 percent. New Jersey's jobless rate is 4.1 percent and Connecticut's 3.8 percent.
The Regional Plan Association also notes that 57 percent of the region's jobs are in industries considered likely to keep growing, compared with 51 percent in the nation. But the association does not believe that the region will continue to capture the 8 percent of the nation's jobs that it gained in the 1980's, in part because of labor shortages, which will increase wages.
Still, the association concludes that the region's productivity and per-capita income will continue to grow. Thus it says that it is ''cautious about the region's economic prospects,'' but that the ''picture that emerges is favorable.''
The association expects New York City to continue to attract about a quarter of the region's new jobs. Among the possible sources of new business are increased trade with Eastern and Western Europe, although there is also the threat of increased competition from Chicago and Los Angeles, not to mention London and Tokyo.
The New York counties of Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Orange, Dutchess, Ulster and Sullivan will attract about 14 percent of the new jobs, the association projected, a slight increase over their share in the last decade.
The association predicts that the 14 northern New Jersey counties, from Ocean and Mercer to Sussex, Passaic and Bergen, which gained 35,000 new jobs in 1989 and may be the strongest part of the region now, will get an even greater share of the jobs in the coming years, nearly 40 percent.
 
Diversified Economy
Though New Jersey suffers from congestion and a glut of office space that has pushed vacancy rates to 25 percent in some areas, the state's diversified economy is less reliant than New York City's on financial services and has been cushioned by mainstays like research centers for the pharmaceutical industry.
Mr. Kukan, of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, said that during the year-end holidays, usually a quiet time, the utility received a surprisingly large number of requests for information from businesses seeking more space.
Connecticut, with its defense contractors, could find any cutback in military spending costly. But while Sikorsky, the world's largest manufacturer of helicopters, is trimming its work force to make the company ''leaner'' in the face of such cuts, Electric Boat in Groton has several contracts for new submarines and Pratt & Whitney Aircraft has reduced its reliance on the military for sales of its jet engines.
 
'I'll Take My Chances'
As for Connecticut's huge inventory of unsold homes, a state plan to buy 500 condominiums at bargain prices for use as subsidized housing would help. And if lending institutions already worried about real-estate loans do not further tighten credit and if interest rates do not rise, more home buyers might materialize and construction, an important industry to Connecticut, could pick up.
''If I'm going to be in New England, I'll take my chances in Connecticut,'' said Donald L. Klepper-Smith, an economist in the business research department of Southern New England Telephone Company.
Still, he worries that high taxes, high wages and high housing prices will lead to ''a softening of comparative economic advantages'' that helped the state become the nation's leader in per-capita income.
The prospects for Long Island seem less certain. Employment dropped last year for the first time since 1975, and the Regional Plan Association, citing an over-reliance on defense industries, an abundance of traffic and a scarcity of vacant land, predicts that Nassau and Suffolk Counties' share of the region's new jobs will decline to about 12 percent.
Three years ago Grumman Aircraft of Bethpage, maker of the F-14, a jet fighter with a dwindling market, pared its work force from 25,000 to 18,400. Now, in what seems as good a sign of changing economic conditions as any, the company plans to turn some of its 800-acre headquarters into a corporate headquarters center, with stores and a hotel.
 
Who Will Fill the Jobs?
 
The Boom Depleted The Labor Pool
What topsoil is to the Farm Belt, labor is to the New York region - a natural resource.
''We had the skills here, the know-how, and took advantage of it,'' said Dr. Adam Broner, executive director of the New Jersey Economic Council, a state agency, explaining his state's gains.
The recent expansion might not have been possible if not for the reservoir of women ready for recruitment. Three decades ago, about 40 percent of working-age women in the 31 counties in and around New York City were in the labor force; now, almost 60 percent are.
''The tremendous growth and job creation that we've seen over the past 10 years was fueled by a tremendous increase in the female participation in the labor force,'' said Robert A. Dye, director of the New York service of the WEFA Group, a forecasting organization based in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
A consequence of the boom has been the depletion of the labor pool, making further growth difficult. In some northern New Jersey counties, bounties are being paid for new workers.
Yet in Newark and other cities, people are unemployed because they lack a way to get to the jobs. #25% at Poverty Level In New York City, too, there is a mismatch between jobs increasingly based on the ability to communicate and work with ideas and the vast numbers of high school dropouts, immigrants and single parents. Many of these people are effectively barred from the more demanding jobs the economy is generating now, and sometimes from any jobs, because they lack the necessary skills or a mastery of English or child-care services.
Perhaps half a million people in the city are still not in the work force, and the percentage of those living at or below the poverty level has hovered near 25 percent despite years of peak economic growth.
''The division between those who are in the mainstream and those who are out of it grew more rigid,'' said Mr. Ehrenhalt of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, ''and the barriers to overcoming it became more formidable.
''A 38 percent dropout rate is just not compatible with the main direction of the New York economy,'' he said. ''A decade of growth didn't make a dent in these problems.''
But Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said ''the 90's should be different,'' at least for ''the next wave'' of workers.
 
Jobs for Every Student
The Port Authority anticipates that the low birthrate of the 1960's and 1970's will result in a labor force that will grow more slowly now. The population is becoming older as well. Even in a slower economy, the agency says, new jobs will outpace new workers by 120,000 over the decade. That will greatly increase the pressure on employers to get more working-age people into the work force.
Ms. Scanlon saw evidence of this trend nearly two years ago when she visited the Passaic County Vocational and Technical High School in Wayne. The school has students from New Jersey cities like Clifton, Paterson and Passaic and, she said, ''they had jobs for every single youngster.'' Some would be making $10 an hour.
Ms. Scanlon acknowledged, however, that demographic forces alone have their limits, and that better training was just one of the measures that will be needed if the vocational and social mismatch is to be broadly addressed.
And even so, she added, ''I'm not so sure that the most desperate people that we see under our feet are going to make it, no matter how strong the economy is.''
 
States' Empty Pockets
 
Unhappy Remedy: Higher Taxes
''The global economy wants to have a major share of its activities in and around New York City,'' said Mr. Anderson of the Regional Plan Association, explaining its projection of continued, if slower, economic growth.
But, he warned: ''Either we are going to provide the basis for those activities to come here and be nurtured here and serviced here, or it's not going to happen. There are limits to what people are going to endure.''
Although much money has been invested in the region's physical plant, it is standing-room-only on many rush-hour commuter and subway trains, and waits of a half-hour or more are common at tunnels and bridges leading to Manhattan.
Despite an oversupply of homes and offices, the area seems unlikely to lose its reputation as an expensive place in which to live and work. The surge in drug-related crime in New York City has only worsened its violent image.
But at a time when governments are under pressure to attend to these and other ills to attract new businesses, they seem least able to afford it.
 
Rainy-Day Fund Exhausted
In New Jersey, officials are projecting a 3 percent increase in revenues, compared with 11 percent a few years ago. A rainy-day fund of nearly $300 million to help tide the state over during times of budgetary stress has already been exhausted, and Gov. Jim Florio faces a $550 million deficit in the current fiscal year.
In Connecticut, sales-tax revenues will actually decline this year, and Gov. William A. O'Neill has proposed a spending plan that would eliminate 2,000 jobs.
Mayor David N. Dinkins has put forth a New York City budget that would delay hiring more police officers and raise taxes by $550 million.
New York State is in an even more precarious condition. Acknowledging that there is ''a huge gap between what we want to spend and what we can afford to spend,'' Gov. Mario M. Cuomo would cut dozens of programs, suspend a planned income-tax cut and raise $800 million in new taxes and fees.
But Standard & Poor's issued a ''credit watch'' last week, saying Mr. Cuomo's budget proposal would not put the state's finances on a firm enough footing to justify the current AA- bond rating.
 
A Rare Suggestion
Such are the fiscal troubles that last year the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry and its sister organization, the New York City Partnership, gave Albany recommendations for taxes that could be raised. Daniel Sandy Bayer, the vice president for economic and commercial development for the Partnership, said it was the first time in his memory that the business and civic organizations had done that.
This year the groups have gone further, Mr. Bayer said. Although they favor retaining the income-tax cut, they have suggested imposition of a two-year surcharge on both business and personal taxes to give the state time to assess its economic condition and find ways to improve productivity.
But it could be that the shifting demographics that might enable more people to find jobs in the 1990's could also yield unexpected dividends for Albany, Hartford and Trenton. Assuming that the region avoids a recession, Ms. Scanlon of the Port Authority said, the deepening labor shortage could push wages up, and tax revenues with them.
Most of the population growth, she said, will be among those 35 to 50 years old. Since there will be more people in these peak earning years, they will generate more taxes.
She also said an older population will be more willing to invest in the region, like those who, more than a generation before them, built the suburbs around New York City after World War II.
''What we're beginning to see is a change in behavior, a change in outlook,'' she said. ''I'm not sure if governments are aware of this yet.''

PUB-DATE: February 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1713 words

HEADLINE: 1990 Vote Will Test Power Of G.O.P. in the Sun Belt

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
The 1990 election campaign, which has so far generated little excitement despite a number of races with considerable significance, is approaching its first major event, the March 13 primaries in Texas.
From now until early November, the politicians will be campaigning for 36 governorships, 34 Senate seats, 435 House seats and 6,257 state legislative positions. Television programs will again be stuffed with political commercials. And unless the experts are all wrong, most voters will be little stirred.
No one expects much of a change in the Democratic dominance in the House and Senate, though there are a half-dozen close races on the docket. If form were to be followed, the Republicans would suffer, because the party holding the White House usually loses seats in the election after Presidential voting. 
 
Bush Had Short Coattails
But President Bush carried so few legislators to victory with him in 1988 that he was the only President ever elected with such a small share of Congress held by his own party. So the Republicans have relatively little to lose, and should also benefit from his popularity, the nation's general prosperity and the lack of other issues to roil the political waters, analysts say.
The governors' races constitute this year's high-stakes action, especially those in California, Florida and Texas, the three Sun Belt states that are about to emerge as the new powerhouse of American electoral politics.
After this year's census, according to most informed estimates, they will have 24 percent of the membership of the House of Representatives and 20 percent of the strength in the electoral college, the same share that New York, Pennsylvania and Illinois had exactly a half-century ago, dominating national politics. In 1940, Texas, California and Florida counted for considerably less, casting only 11 percent of the votes in the House, about what Michigan, Ohio and New Jersey will cast after reapportionment.
 
Seismic Shift in Strength
This seismic shift in political strength, which reflects the drain in population from the old Democratic industrial midsection, presents the Republicans with great opportunities, but to capitalize on them they have to control at least part of the state governments in the big Sun Belt states.
If the Democrats win the governorships and majorities in the state legislatures, they will draw the new House district lines so as to minimize Republican gains, regardless of conservative sentiments in the South and the West.
At the moment, the Democrats' prospects appear good. They already control both houses in 29 state legislatures, as against 8 for the Republicans. And they say they have reasonable chances of taking the statehouses away from Republicans in Florida, where Gov. Bob Martinez is in trouble; in Texas, where Gov. Bill Clements is retiring, and in California, where Gov. George Deukmejian is also retiring.
 
Republicans Trying Hard
Still, the Republicans are trying hard. President Bush flew to California earlier this month and will be there again on Wednesday to raise money and stir up enthusiasm for Senator Pete Wilson, the Republican candidate for governor in the state that has become the supreme political prize. As the President noted in Los Angeles on Feb. 6, the census ''will give California up to seven new House seats, meaning that nearly one of every eight Congressmen in Washington will represent California.''
No state has had that kind of influence in this century.
In the longer term, the Republicans seem certain to benefit from the change, especially in Presidential terms. Carrying the same states in 1992 that they did in 1948 and 1960 respectively, Harry S. Truman and John F. Kennedy would have lost, because their victories were built on states whose influence has declined. Florida now seems safely Republican in Presidential contests, and Texas is heading in that direction.
Only in California, which some Democrats consider their great hope for the future, do the two parties seem likely to compete on fairly even terms.
One major consequence of the change appears probable: a tremendous increase in the importance of the Hispanic vote. All three of the biggest Sun Belt states have large, diverse and growing Hispanic populations. In California, according to one estimate, Hispanic immigrants accounted for 50 percent of the state's growth in the last deacde, with other minorities accounting for an additional 31 percent.
Thomas E. Mann, a political scientist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, says Hispanic voters will form ''the dominant minority in American politics in the 21st century.'' Not surprisingly, the two parties are engaged in an intensive struggle this year for their loyalty and their votes.
 
What Democrats Need
If the Democrats are to rebuild their standing as the majority party, a crucial element in the equation will have to be the new immigrants - the Latins and the Asians - who are pouring into Texas, Florida and California. Fifty years ago, immigrants from southern and central Europe, settling in the industrial cities of the Middle Atlantic and Middle Western states, saw the Democrats as the best bet for economic growth and opportunity. But so far, a leading Florida Democrat says, ''we haven't convinced the new newcomers that we can deliver.''
Though they sometimes send a message to Washington like disgust with Democratic corruption in 1946 and resentment at a Republican recession in 1982, off-year elections more often lack broad national themes and are decided on local issues and personalities.
The cataclysmic changes in the world are unlikely to provide a focal point this year, in the view of Peter D. Hart, a leading poll taker who works mainly for Democratic candidates. Mr. Hart said he sees the Senate races and the few truly competitive House races being decided ''on small-bore considerations, with campaigns that are negative and not so inspiring.''
''I think the tone for the 90's will emerge more from the governors' races,'' Mr. Hart said. ''People are worried about things like drugs, education, the homeless, the environment -all adding up to a desire to look at our problems, to restore our own sense of community, our own well-being.''
In Florida, Representative Bill Nelson is the likely Democratic challenger. In Texas, the early favorite is Ann Richards, who made the memorable anti-Bush speech at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, but she has several rivals in both parties. In California, former Mayor Dianne Feinstein of San Francisco has suddenly taken the lead in the polls as the Democratic nominee to oppose Senator Wilson, who is running for governor only two years after winning a second Senate term.
 
Key Gubernatorial Races
Other important gubernatorial races will take place in Ohio, where Richard F. Celeste, a Democratic incumbent, is retiring; in Illinois, where a long-serving Republican, James R. Thompson, is stepping down, and in Pennsylvania, where Gov. Robert P. Casey, a Democrat who is opposed to abortion, will face Auditor General Barbara Hafer, a Republican who is running on an abortion rights platform.
The Republicans have fared better than the Democrats in recruiting candidates for the big Senate races. For instance, former Gov. James B. Hunt, a Democrat, declined to run against Senator Jesse Helms, a Republican, in North Carolina, and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale decided not to challenge Senator Rudy Boschwitz, a Republican, in Minnesota.
In addtion, the Republicans are fielding three popular House members in Colorado, New Hampshire and Idaho, states where Republican senators are retiring. All are beginning as favorites.
In four other states, liberal Democratic Senators, Tom Harkin of Iowa, Paul Simon of Illinois, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island and Carl Levin of Michigan, face House Republicans in what are likely to be close contests.
 
 
1990 ELECTIONS: THE BATTLEGROUNDS
 
RACES TO WATCH
 
TEXAS: Bill Clements, who's retiring, is the only Republican ever elected governor here. But Clayton Williams, a self-made millionaire who revels in his reputation as a brawler and a hard drinker, seems to have caught peoples' attention, and he's given a fair chance of upsetting the Democratic nominee who emerges from the primary on March 13 and the subsequent runoff.
 
CALIFORNIA: Republican Sen. Pete Wilson, who finished an exhausting (and successful) re-election campaign only 15 months ago, is now running for governor. His Democratic rival will be either Diane Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco, or John Van de Kamp, the state Attorney general. This is the one race that both parties would most like to win in November.
 
OHIO: A very good shot for a republican takeover. Democratic Gov. Dick Celeste, who has been involved in one scrape after another, is retiring, and the Republicans seem to be rallying behind Mayor George Voinovich of Cleveland, who could cut deeply into the usual massive Democratic margin in that city. The Democratic nominee is likely to be Attorney General Anthony Celebrezze.
 
FLORIDA: Almost from the moment he was elected, Republican Gov. Bob Martinez has struggled to establish his credibility. His anti-abortion stance has cost him dearly. Representative Bill Nelson, a smooth campaigner, seems the likely Democratic nominee, but he must face the seeminlgy irreversible trend to the Republicans in this state and plenty of help from Washington.
 
IOWA: No Democrat has ever been elected to two consecutive six-year terms in this plains state, but Tom Harkin seems to stand a good chance. His Republican opponent, Representative Thomas J. Tauke, who has been running for more than a year already, is a formidable politician with 12 years behind him in the House at the age of 40. But the Democratic trend here favors Harkin.
 
ILLINOIS: Sen. Paul Simon's 1988 Presidential campaign wasn't much of a success, except in one state: his own. He carried Illinois when he had already lost everywhere else, which showed great voter loyalty. His Republican rival, Representative Lynn Martin, is a tart-tongued campaigner who, though something of a moderate herself, is determined to paint him as a leftist.

HEADLINE: China Acts to Restrict Study Abroad

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 24

 BODY:
In the most tangible sign so far that China is retreating from its decade-long commitment to sending students abroad, new restrictions will make it virtually impossible for most university graduates to study in other countries unless they work first for five years.
The rules, which had been anticipated since early this month, took effect on Feb. 10. They have not yet been widely disseminated, although a copy was obtained here.
''If enforced as written, it's going to have a big impact,'' a Western diplomat in Beijing said. ''There have been competent Chinese graduate students going to the U.S. that won't be going there anymore.'' 
But many experts, noting that Chinese students have been adept at evading previous restrictions, said much would depend on how the new restrictions are put into force. End to an Academic Exodus? On their face, the regulations would considerably reduce the annual stream of about 12,000 students to the United States that had been one of the most remarkable aspects of China's former open-door policy.
The basic change in the new rules is a requirement that university graduates work for five years before they go abroad to study, although students with relatives overseas can pay for an exemption from the work requirement.
The regulations seem to be motivated by Government alarm over the large number of top students, educated essentially for no charge at China's best schools, who go overseas and fail to return to contribute to their country.
''It is a continuation of their concern over the brain drain,'' said Karen C. Stanton, consul at the United States Embassy in Beijing. ''They are losing their best and their brightest, and the reality is that past efforts have failed to control this flood.''
Although Chinese officials agree that the policy is aimed mostly at preventing an exodus of top minds, the new rules come at a time when China is again emphasizing ideological devotion over professional ability in hiring and promotion.
 
Socialism's 'Gravediggers'
Chinese and Western officials say the authorities are also concerned by the support lent by students abroad to the democracy movement at home.
''The Government does not want to help educate the gravediggers of socialism,''a Chinese teacher said.
The document describing the new rules was circulated by the state Education Commission. It states that only students who have not yet reached their final year in a university, or students with Chinese relatives overseas, can win exemptions from the work requirement.
Students seeking the latter exemption must apply for identification papers from a provincial Government office indicating that they related to a Chinese person overseas.
''I think there are going to a lot of fake relatives,'' a Chinese intellectual said. ''The authorities can't possibly check into everyone's background.''
Students eligible for the exemptions must pay for each of the years of university-level schooling they completed. Graduates must pay the equivalent of about $530 for each of their college years; students at the masters level, $850 per year, and students at the doctoral level, $1,275. If they return to China within eight years, their money will be refunded.
 
Few Can Afford Exemption Fees
Most students and their immediate families could not afford such fees, although some will be able to take advantage of loans from relatives abroad.
Several Western diplomats said the loopholes softened the impact of the rules. They noted that similar regulations were used in Eastern European and some Western countries. France, for example, has a work requirement for students educated at state universities.
''The pressure to go abroad is so strong, and it's on everyone's mind right now,'' a Western official said of China. ''If they just stonewall, then the rules would be called restrictive and coercive, like the old policies before. They open a small hole so people won't say they're not reasonable.''
Consular offiials say they will be unable to gauge the effect of the rules on visa applications before May or June.
The new regulations were announced to university officials earlier this month, less than two weeks after President Bush vetoed a bill that would have relaxed visa restrictions on Chinese students in the United States.
Beijing's new rules, which apply to students applying on their own as opposed to scholars sponsored by the Government, appear to be part of an overall tightening of control over university students.
Students sponsoring themselves have been receiving an increasing proportion of visas for study in the United States. Their applications are multiplying more rapidly than those of Government-sponsored students, who will not be affected by the new rules.

HEADLINE: Bush and Japan's Leader to Meet Next Month

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 24

 BODY:
President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan announced today that they would meet early next month amid signs that critical trade discussions between Japan and the United States are at a serious impasse.
A Japanese official said Mr. Bush telephoned Mr. Kaifu on Friday night to invite him to two days of talks in Palm Springs, Calif., on March 2 and 3, where he will seek to persuade Japan to take action in the trade area. Mr. Bush's call came shortly after the governing Liberal Democratic Party's election victory early this week.
The Prime Minister held back from agreeing to the date, but his aides said the meeting would occur soon if not at the time proposed by Mr. Bush.
Washington and Tokyo are engaged in a range of negotiations on a dozen different issues to bring down the American trade deficit with Japan, which has remained at about $50 billion since the mid-1980's and has become the focus of rising economic tensions. 
President Bush's telephone call came within hours of the conclusion of the latest round of ''structural impediment'' talks with Japan, in which Tokyo is being pressed to agree to several basic changes in the way business is done here in order to ease the way for more imports.
After the talks concluded on Friday, Japanese officials said the United States position was much stronger than they had expected. And Bush Administration officials made no secret of their disappointment with what seemed to be Japanese resistance to the American requests.
 
U.S. Happier About Arms Talks
By contrast, American officials said they were pleased with talks involving Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on security matters. He won approval in principle from Japan, South Korea and the Philippines for a roughly 10 percent cut in the American troop strength in East Asia and the Pacific.
Aides to Mr. Cheney say they were confident that Tokyo would be forthcoming in response to the request to increase its $2.8 billion contribution to the $7.5 billion cost of maintaining American forces in Japan. They say formal approval could come later this year.
In the more contentious trade area, however, Washington is pressing Japan to spend more for public works, weaken the influence of powerful Japanese business cartels and relax laws that allow small retail stores to block large stores from coming into their neighborhoods.
The Bush Administration thinks those and other steps would give American exporters more access to Japanese markets. But on Friday night, an American official said the steps proposed by Japan were ''not enough to be effective, lasting or credible.''
Japan is also pushing the United States to take its own steps, and Japanese officials say they too are less than impressed with what American negotiators have offered so far. Where Japan Faults U.S. Tokyo wants the Bush Administration to close the Federal deficit, increase savings in this country and change a range of corporate practices to place greater emphasis on long-term growth, education, and research and development so as to improve the ability of American business to compete.
In effect, Japan argues that the trade deficit is caused more by American shortcomings than by Japanese barriers, and the repetition of this theme in the trade talks has met with rising frustration among the American negotiators.
A United States official said tonight that Mr. Bush's telephone call to Mr. Kaifu was not prompted by the problems in the talks that concluded on Friday, but that a meeting between the two leaders was being sought to give fresh impetus generally to the stalled negotiations.
''With the election finished, Japan has a new Prime Minister and a new Cabinet, and there's plenty to talk about,'' the official said.
He added that several American negotiators agreed that ''we should have gotten much more'' out of the latest round of trade negotiations.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST;
Kohl Arrives in U.S. for Talks on Europe's Future

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMP DAVID, Md., Feb. 24

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany arrived here today for intensive talks with President Bush on the future of Europe and the accelerating pace of German unification.
''I view this as a very important discussion,'' Mr. Bush said. ''There is a lot of keen interest not just in Europe but around the world in these discussions.''
Mr. Kohl, wearing a dark blue suit, got off a Marine helicopter and walked with his wife, Hannelore, down a small walkway at the Presidential retreat here. They were greeted by Mr. Bush, who was wearing a leather jacket with a fur collar, and Mrs. Bush, wearing a parka and slacks. 
The Chancellor thanked his hosts, praised the quality of the cold, crisp air here at the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains and exclaimed, ''Wunderbar!''
 
A Steady Snowfall
After walking past a small military honor guard, Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl got into a golf cart. With the President behind the wheel, they drove off down a road that winds through the woods of Camp David. Within a few minutes, swirling flurries turned to a steady snowfall.
Mr. Kohl will be here for about 24 hours. Mr. Bush is expected to ask the West German leader to clarify his timetable for unification of the Germanys. In addition, Administration officials said, Mr. Bush will probably ask Mr. Kohl to reaffirm his commitment to German membership in NATO and to take steps to allay Polish concerns about the future of the Polish-German border.
But Mr. Bush declined to comment when reporters asked him about the unification of Germany in the minutes just before Mr. Kohl's arrival. Mr. Bush said he would discuss the substance of that issue at a news conference with Mr. Kohl on Sunday morning.
''Repeat after me: substance tomorrow,'' Mr. Bush told reporters, who kept asking questions about the momentous changes in Europe.
 
Conversations With Allies
Mr. Bush said he talked this morning, before Mr. Kohl's arrival, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada. Mrs. Thatcher has repeatedly emphasized the need for caution in discussing arrangements for the reunification of Germany.
In an effort to consult closely with America's allies, Mr. Bush discussed the future of Germany in a meeting on Friday at the White House with Prime Minister Jan P. Syse of Norway. And Mr. Bush said he would talk by telephone on Sunday with President Francois Mitterrand of France.
For the meeting with Mr. Kohl, President Bush tried to create an intimate, relaxed atmosphere. The number of officials on each side was strictly limited. Mr. Bush was accompanied by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and Robert Blackwill, an expert on German history and European affairs on the staff of the National Security Council.
 
Elections for Kohl
Mr. Kohl's visit comes three weeks before East Germany is scheduled to hold elections for a government that will presumably negotiate the terms of union with West Germany. Mr. Kohl himself faces elections in West Germany, now scheduled for Dec. 2.
In East Germany, the alliance of conservative parties supported by Mr. Kohl is trailing far behind the Social Democrats and is not expected to win the elections next month.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl plan to discuss West Germany's plans for economic and political union with East Germany, as well as security issues like Germany's future relationship with NATO, the size of its army and its borders with Poland.
The Bush Administration has firmly supported German aspirations to unify their country, but maintains that Germany must be firmly anchored in NATO to allay the anxieties of Poland, Czechoslovakia, Britain, France and other countries that have been victims of German aggression in the past.
Already West German officials are drafting plans for a monetary union with East Germany, including use of a single currency. In addition, East and West German officials have talked separately about establishing a combined army for a united Germany. But there will be no formal talks on that subject until after the elections because Bonn will not discuss a merger with a Communist government.
Jewish groups have prodded Mr. Kohl and the Bush Administration to address the fears that German reunification stirs among survivors of the Holocaust. Some American officials say that West Germans should assume responsibility for educating East Germans about the Holocaust.
In a recent letter to Mr. Kohl, Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center for Holocaust studies in Los Angeles, said that such concerns were being neglected in the current discussions about the political, military and economic aspects of a united Germany. ''To the victims of the Holocaust,'' he wrote, ''it is not the potential weakness of the Deutsche mark that is critical, but the consequences that may lead to a weak 'Deutsche memory.' ''
 
 NEWS CONFERENCE ON TV
 A news conference by President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany is scheduled for 11 A.M. today. Last night, ABC News and CNN said they planned live coverage. CBS News said no such coverage was scheduled ''at this point,'' and NBC News said it would break into programming as needed.

COUNTRY: GERMANY (99%); EUROPE (98%); UNITED STATES (92%); NORWAY (79%); POLAND (79%); 

STATE: MARYLAND, USA (91%);

HEADLINE: Nicaraguans Hope for Decisive Election

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 24

 BODY:
After a decade of revolution and war, Nicaraguans on all sides are counting on the national elections on Sunday to halt their country's long slide into fraternal strife.
At 4,391 voting places today, workers readied the registration lists, color-coded ballots and indelible ink that will give the country the first free, broadly contested election in its history. More than 2,000 international observers took up positions from the urban barrios of Managua to the rebellious hill towns of Jinotega. And 1.7 million voters buzzed with the excitement of a long-awaited, democratic showdown between the Sandinista Government and its opponents.
Yet for all the sense of an impending political battle, the greatest public anticipation has focused on a common, overriding hope of starting anew. Partisans on both sides are looking to Sunday's vote as a means of breaking the long communal conflict that has gripped Nicaragua from within and without. And amid the ruins of a shattered national economy, even the governing Sandinista National Liberation Front is ready to define itself in contrast to the country's current disarray. 
 
An Exhausted Population
''Everything will be better.'' reads the Sandinistas' forward-looking main slogan, now brushed in bright colors on buildings and walls throughout the country.
For an exhausted population, there is no question about the depth of the country's crisis, only about who should be held responsible. In the last 10 years, the Nicaraguan economy has lost half its value. Real wages have plunged to less than 10 percent of their former worth, and private consumption has fallen by more than 70 percent. An American embargo has helped put a virtual stranglehold on trade.
In the costly war against American-supported contra rebels, more than 30,000 Nicaraguans have been killed, leaving virtually no family untouched by violent tragedy. Another 10 percent of the population, fleeing everything from Government confiscations to contra predations to the military draft, has simply left the country altogether, creating a wrenching national drama of separated relatives, illegal emigration and abandoned livelihoods.
The decision that now awaits Nicaraguan voters is who should bear the blame for such misery. Is it a result of Sandinista policies, which even Government officials admit have polarized the public, creating a powerful and arbitrary government that even zealous Sandinistas say must be restrained?
Or is it a result of foreign aggression, the decision of the United States to finance a long and brutal war that has ravaged the Nicaraguan countryside, never seriously challenging the Sandinista's hold on power, yet arguably provoking their worst excesses?
After years of political conflict, most Nicaraguans remain deeply reluctant to discuss their personal views, and few experienced diplomats and foreign experts here have dared to predict how the public will express its answers to those questions at the voting booth.
Sandinista leaders have declared that there is not even ''a hypothetical chance'' that they could lose the election; opposition leaders are equally confident of their own strength.
 
Central Question
But the retrospective judgment is so central that it has overshadowed any other debate about future policies or even about the qualities of the two principal candidates, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of the Sandinista National Liberation Front and Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of the National Opposition Union.
Sandinista leaders believe the subject is so powerful, and the country's crisis so grave, that they have not tried to deny the public's discontent, but have used it as a springboard for their own nationalistic message. Addressing a vast crowd of 300,000 at the closing rally of his campaign here on Wednesday evening, Mr. Ortega abruptly became his Government's own critic.
''The situation of the workers, of the people,'' he shouted, seeming to float above the sea of his supporters on a narrow, extended stage that has become a trademark of his campaign, ''from the economic and material point of view, is it good or bad?''
''Bad,'' responded the crowd, timidly, as if uncertain how to respond.
''It's bad! It's bad! It's bad! Of course the situation is bad!'' Mr. Ortega prompted them. ''But are the people going to betray the revolution because of that?''
To 40-year-old Amelia Galo, who was standing deep among the crowd, the answer was a ringing ''No!'' and the question itself was proof of the candor and honesty of a leader that she has long admired and supported.
 
'Think Where We Could Be'
''The Sandinistas have accomplished a lot, and under the worst conditions,'' she said, wearing a Sandinista campaign T-shirt. ''If there was no aggression, no embargo, just think where we could be. Violeta is just a puppet of the United States. If she is elected, it would be like selling out.''
The mother of three girls and wife of an unskilled private sector worker, Mrs. Galo says her family does not depend on the Government for its living. But she said that she and her family would support the Sandinista Front ''100 percent'' because it had given Nicaragua a sense of national pride and unity that would have permitted it to progress if not for the war.
But just a few blocks from the broad plaza where Mr. Ortega spoke, Juanita Espinoza could hardly differ more with Mrs. Galo's views.
Originally from the north central province of Matagalpa, Mrs. Espinoza, who is 43 years old, came to Managua six years ago as part of the large influx of workers in the early part of Sandinista rule, when officials imposed a number of economic controls that favored urban over rural workers.
But for those six years, Mrs. Espinoza, her husband and their eight children have been unable afford a proper home and have lived in the ruins of an old cinema behind Managua's main square in the large urban wasteland that was left by a devastating earthquake here in 1972 and never repaired.
 
Barely Enough to Live
Mrs. Espinoza's husband does some construction, but is out of work, and her 13-year-old daughter sometimes finds work as a laundress. But it is all just barely enough to buy corn, beans and oil to live from day to day, and Mrs. Espinoza says she has placed her hopes on an opposition victory to repair Nicaragua's economy.
When the Sandinistas held their final rally on Wednesday, crowds of supporters swarmed past Mrs. Espinoza's home, in what used to be the upper lobby of the cinema, which has no roof or windows. But Mrs. Espinoza, who worries about the thin rain of stone chips that falls constantly from the cracked, fragile structure, says she was not impressed.
 
Longing for the Past
''All those people weren't there out of conviction,'' she said. ''It was just the thing to do. I haven't a Sandinista scarf, too. I use it for a pot holder.''
Mrs. Espinoza says she is particularly concerned for her two draft-age sons, who have evaded military conscription. But she says the economic crisis has told her all she wants to know about the Sandinista Government.
Before the revolution, Mrs. Espinoza recalls, she could afford to buy a bottle of cheap perfume for 40 cordobas, then about $5. ''Now things like that are in the clouds,'' she said. ''They are only to dream about, to call up from your memory. Oh, it was luxurious. Now it's all a lie.''
 
A NICARAGUAN ELECTION PRIMER
 
 The Candidates
 Sandinista National Liberation Front
 President: Daniel Ortega Saavedra, 44 years old, a member of the nine-member Sandinistia national directorate.
 
 National Opposition Union
 President: Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, 60, publisher of La Prensa, the country's major opposition newspaper.
Founded as an electoral alliance in 1989. Comprising 14 political parties and groups ranging from conservatives to Communists and supported by the Miskito Indian movement Yatama, it includes most of parties that boycotted the 1984 election. The presidential candidate is the widow of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Cardenal, an anti-Somoza newspaper editor who was assassinated in 1978, setting off an uprising that led to the Sandinista revolution.
 
 Other Parties
 
 There are eight smaller parties, ranging from the Social Christian Party to the Marxist-Leninist Popular Action Movement. But those parties combined are expected to receive less than 5 percent of vote.
 
 The Offices
 
 President and Vice President
 The two posts are elected as a ticket by direct popular ballot; there is no runoff vote.
 
 National Assembly
 It will include 90 deputies, and losing presidential candidates who receive a specified minimum vote. Each deputy will have an elected alternate. Ballots are cast for party slates, not individual candidates. Representation will be proportional.
 
 Municipal Councils
For Managua and large municipalities, the slate with the most votes will get at least half the seats. The remaining seats will be allocated according to the proportion of total votes received. Each council elects a mayor from its own members.
 
 Autonomous Regional Councils
 The two Atlantic-coast regions will elect 45-member regional councils, each based on proportional representation from 15 voting districts.
 
 The Voters
 
 Voting age: 16.
 
About 1,750,000 Nicaraguans, or more than 90 percent of the eligible population, registered to vote in October. More than 50 percent of voters are under the age of 30. More than 90 percent of the population is concentrated in the western third of country along the Pacific Coast.
 
 The Observers
 
 Nearly 2,000 official observers and invited guests from across the world will witness the election.
 
 United Nations Observers for Verification of Elections in Nicaragua
 
 A total of 239 trained officers from the United Nations staff will monitor polls by jeep, plane and helicopter. The group has been working in country since August, gradually building to full strength. It will conduct its own independent vote count on election night based on original tally sheets from all 4,391 polling stations.
 
 Organization of American States
 
 A total of 435 trained officers from the O.A.S. staff, which began working in the country in August, will also conduct an independent vote count on election night based on original tally sheets.
 
 Carter Center and Council of Free-Elected Heads of State
 
 Former President Jimmy Carter will lead a delegation of 39 distinguished observers. Delegation members have visited Nicaragua six times since August. They will coordinate election-day monitoring with the United Nations and the O.A.S. An official United States commission appointed by President Bush to monitor the election process was denied permission to enter the country by the Sandinista Government, which accused it of partiality.


GRAPHIC: Election workers yesterday preparing ballot boxes in Grenada. (Agence France-Presse); Graphic: ''A Nicaraguan Election Primer''
Photo: Nicaraguans are to go to the polls today in the country's first free and broadly contested election. Its results could end a decade of civil war.

HEADLINE: For Unions' Hierarchy, Good News Amid Grim

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23

 BODY:
The American people are always down on someone, the pollster told the trade unionists here: big government, big business or big labor.
But big labor finally seems to be on the ascent again, he added, with one-third of the public saying it instinctively sides with the union when a strike erupts and only one-quarter rooting for the company.
''This is the highest level of support for unions, and the lowest for companies, we've ever recorded since we began asking the question a dozen years ago,'' said the pollster, Edward B. Keller of the Roper Organization. In 1977, for example, 28 percent of those polled said they would instinctively side with the union in a strike and 32 percent with management. 
For the 35 leaders of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations who convene here each February, Mr. Keller's announcement was just one of several heartwarming ones this week. The agreement to end the Pittston Coal Group strike in Appalachia was ratified by a near 2-to-1 vote, and the Supreme Court supported the United Steelworkers' plea to stop the White House budget office from blocking worker-safety regulations.
 
'Monies, Bodies, Resources'
The leaders say the solidarity they showed in the coal strike, with all the federation's unions providing support, was crucial in gaining a favorable settlement with a company that they said was out to break the mine workers' union. As a result, the union leaders decided to do the same if 10 unions of The Daily News in New York go on strike, a possibility at the end of March.
''Monies, bodies, resources, we'll give it all,'' said Richard L. Trumka, president of the United Mine Workers.
Veterans of this annual meeting say the leaders also more closely resemble the people whom Roper polls than they did a decade ago. The balding and ample-bellied stereotypes of union bosses have largely been replaced by trim-looking men who have been wearing bankerly suits throughout the meetings and who are departing with no more of a tan than they came with.
But behind the upbeat mood here remain some stark facts unsettling to organized labor.
Despite the abundant resources that the 97 affiliate unions of the federation have deployed in behalf of 8,500 striking airline machinists, the strike against Eastern Airlines will reach its first anniversary on March 4, and those jobs may be lost for good.
Further, organized labor's standing in the American economy continues to slip. Workers who belong to unions are only 16.4 percent of the labor force now, as against 18.8 percent in 1984 and 23 percent in 1977. Last year, for example, the number of union members dropped by 42,000, to 16,960,000.
 
Improvement in Relations
The political environment for labor remains uncertain as well. The Bush Administration has raised tempers for refusing to intervene in the Eastern strike and vetoing Congress's proposed creation of an emergency board last year to look into the strike.
Nevertheless, Labor Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole has taken some edge off the sharp hostility of the Reagan years. She intervened in the Pittston strike by appointing a mediator, and she has beefed up enforcement of the worker safety and child labor laws.
On a personal level, Mrs. Dole seems quite comfortable with the union leadership. During her visit to the convention here, she seemed to know all the leaders by nickname, as in Morty Bahr, of the Communications Workers of America, and Rich Trumka. The unionists seem disinclined to extend to her their anger at the President.
Some people here say the A.F.L.-C.I.O. leadership ought to spend less energy flogging an Administration it cannot change and more on organizing all those workers whom the Roper poll suggests are more predisposed to think favorably of a union.
But that counsel is useless for groups like the United Steelworkers of America, whose president, Lynn R. Williams, noted that as production capacity in the steel industry has declined in the last decade, employment has declined even more, to 120,000, from almost 300,000. Still, the advice certainly applies to some others. In the service industries that have accounted for most of the labor force's growth, organized labor's share of the jobs is only 6 percent.
In one sector of the economy, government, unions are highly represented, claiming membership of 37 percent of the work force, and they are still gaining ground. Gerald W. McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said his union had gained 189,000 members in the 1980's, ''and we're already 20,000 ahead in 1990.''
 
Tackling the Abortion Issue
Many of these new members are women, who Mr. McEntee said are proving easier to organize than men.
But women have not made great strides in the federation hierarchy. Only 3 of the 35 members of the executive council are women.
Still, the rapid increase of women in the labor force has forced the federation to take up the issue of abortion. To define a policy, Lane Kirkland, president of the federation, established an unusually large committee of 14 members. When three union presidents complained a day later that they had wanted to be on it, too, he added them.
''I think people want to know where we stand on this issue,'' Mr. McEntee said. But several Catholic organiations have threatened to advise union members to withhold membership dues if the federation supports a woman's right to choose abortion.
''It's a generally pro-choice committee,'' said an official of the National Association of Letter Carriers, ''but there's a faction that says the issue is too hot to handle and might endorse both sides.''
The committee could recommend a position as early as May.

HEADLINE: SENATORS SEEK CAP ON AIDES' INCOME

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24

 BODY:
As the heat of ethics issues shifts from the House to the Senate, some members are seeking to tighten rules that permit Senate aides to augment their salaries unrestricted by limits that will soon apply to the rest of Congress.
Some Senate aides routinely accept fees for speeches and consulting work, sometimes from groups under their legislative purview, a review of their latest financial disclosure reports shows. Critics of the practice contend that it creates a potential conflict, as aides who wield power over legislation reap financial benefits from interested trade associations or other groups.
While the records show that the speaking fees for most aides are relatively small, generally under $10,000 a year, the absence of limits on outside income has permitted some of them to garner larger amounts, $20,000 to $25,000, for consulting work. 
 
Dodd Introduces Legislation
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, has introduced legislation to subject the Senate to the same rules the House adopted last year, which go into effect in January 1991 for members and staff. Starting next year, speaking fees for House members and aides will be banned and a limit imposed on outside earnings, excluding investments, of 15 percent of their salaries.
''Senators, like all employees, ought to be paid by the people they work for - the taxpayers,'' Senator Dodd said in a statement when he introduced the measure. ''The pay system that has evolved over the years, with the public paying the bulk of a senator's salary and a handful of interest groups picking up the rest, is untenable, and it must be changed.''
Congress, under strong pressure to curb the sometimes huge supplementary earnings of senators and representatives, passed legislation last year that in effect traded earnings from speechmaking for higher pay. But while the House banned speaking fees for members and staff and limited their outside income, the Senate only reduced the amount of permissible outside income for members, on a sliding scale over a period of years, and left staff members as unfettered as ever.
Speaking fees received by staff aides, the records show, generally range from $2,000 to $6,000 a year.
But a great deal more was earned by Kevin C. Gottlieb, a former staff director of the Senate Banking Committee, who resigned in January after news reports about his outside income and links to Charles H. Keating Jr., the owner of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, which the Government claimed was insolvent last year and took over.
In addition to speaking fees in 1989 that exceeded $35,800, Mr. Gottlieb received more than $700,000 in an 18-month break from Senate employment; most of it came in salary as head of the Outdoor Advertising Association of America.
 
Gottlieb Addressed Gatherings
As a Senate aide, Mr. Gottlieb addressed business executives or graduate students at a university consortium called the Washington Campus on scores of occasions last year, collecting $600 for each appearance. His total fees are not known because Mr. Gottlieb does not itemize his receipts and has not yet filed a disclosure form for 1989, which will be due in May. He did not return telephone calls about the matter.
Critics say that while speaking fees are legal for staff aides, they are nonetheless improper. ''It allows a relationship where private interests can put money directly into the pockets of a public official,'' said Fred Wertheimer, president of Common Cause, a lobbying group that specializes in issues of money and politics. ''That is a formula for disaster.''
An examination of disclosure forms shows that House and Senate staff members have commonly received payments and trips from those with whom they deal. The extent of the practice is unknown, since disclosure is required only of aides whose salary this year is at least $69,451.
Daryl H. Owen, majority staff director for the Senate Energy Committee, and D. Michael Harvey, the panel's chief counsel, each accepted $1,000 in 1988 for appearances before the Interstate Natural Gas Association of America. Charles H. Riemenschneider, majority staff director of the Senate Agriculture Committee, was paid $2,000 for a speech to the Rice Millers Association.
Charles N. Kahn 3d, a health care specialist on the staff of the House Ways and Means Committee, which writes tax laws, received $5,000 from medical societies and Johnson & Johnson, the pharmaceutical company, for speeches and writing.
 
Aide Calls Sessions Valuable
M. Lamar Smith, the Republican staff director and economist on the Senate Banking Committee, reported only two $500 speaking fees but took 15 trips in 1988 to meet mainly with bankers in places like Palm Springs, Calif.; Honolulu, Las Vegas, Nev., Miami and Key Largo, Fla.
In an interview, Mr. Smith said these are places ''where the trade associations choose to hold their conventions.'' He noted that legislative update sessions are helpful to him and almost obligatory.
Some say the acceptance of speaking fees and other payments is already on the wane because of increased attention to the issue.
In the new climate, said a 20-year Senate aide, ''Gottlieb stands out.'' A longtime staff aide in the House added, ''Nobody that I know speaks for money anymore.''
