HEADLINE: EVICTION FIGHT FOCUSES ON CITY HALL PROMISES

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Gershon Mamlak, a slight intense man, talks about his past and present in impassioned bursts. He stabs the air with a finger to press a point and pulls letters out of manila folders to document others.
His is, in many ways, an uplifting tale. He arrived in the United States in 1951, having survived Nazi concentration camps. He built a small upholstery business on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, sent three children to college and graduate school, and even earned a Ph.D. in ancient history. 
Perhaps the only thing that has marred Mr. Mamlak's American passage have been his encounters with the bureaucracy. Three times in the last 30 years, urban-renewal plans have forced him to relocate his business.
Now he is resisting a fourth move, as New York City is trying to evict him, after reneging on a plan to help him buy a nearby building. If it succeeds, he says, he will be forced into an unwanted retirement. Victim or Beneficiary? Mr. Mamlak, who is 67 years old, says his situation illustrates the shortcomings of a cold-hearted city government that puts too little emphasis on the needs of individuals.
''They are taking away from me a source of making a living, a source of satisfaction,'' Mr. Mamlak said. ''All I want is to continue.''
But municipal officials view Mr. Mamlak as a beneficiary of progress, not its victim. They say he has paid extraordinarily low rents in city-owned buildings for years. The real problem, they say, is that like other tenants who have remained for years in apartments and stores at artificially low rents, Mr. Mamlak is now shocked at the high rents the market commands.
The case is in housing court, where a hearing is scheduled for March 8.
Mr. Mamlak contends that the city failed to keep a promise, made three years ago, to help him relocate. But city officials say he will not consider other sites because the rent would be far more than the $184 a month he pays for a store at 135 Delancey Street, and storage space a half-block away.
Since his last relocation in 1971, Mr. Mamlak has done business on the ground floor of the six-story apartment building on Delancey Street. He has been the city's sole tenant in the building for the last five or six years.
 
Dispute Goes Back 5 Years
The city says the building, at the corner of Norfolk Street, must come down, because it is unsafe and to make way for three apartment towers to be built by the developer Samuel J. LeFrak. Mr. Mamlak maintains the building poses no danger and notes that the LeFrak plan has not yet been approved.
The roots of the dispute extend to 1985, when municipal officials suggested Mr. Mamlak vacate his store and buy a city building on the next block, at 125 Delancey Street. Mr. Mamlak said he reluctantly agreed. He said he paid more than $5,500 for appraisals and surveys. Both the community board and the City Planning Commission approved the sale.
But the day before the contract was to be signed in April 1987, the city withdrew the offer. Paul A. Crotty, then the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, said that officials had just formulated a new housing plan for a site that included both buildings. He conceded that the negotiations with Mr. Mamlak should have been halted sooner, and he promised to work with him to relocate the store.
Mr. Mamlak said last week that the city never made good on the pledge. ''I have letters,'' he said. ''They advised me to look for myself.''
 
City Says It Has Helped
City officials say they did try to help Mr. Mamlak. ''We have been following through,'' said Catie Marshall, a Housing Department spokeswoman. ''The problem here is that everything we have offered him has been basically at market-rate rents.''
In January 1989, Mr. Mamlak was given listings with private brokers for two storefronts on the Avenue of the Americas in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, said Roz Post, another department spokeswoman. Last month -after the first court hearing in his case - Mr. Mamlak was told of three more sites, two on 14th Street in Manhattan and another in Brooklyn, Ms. Post said. Landlords are asking as much as $1,500 a month, she said.
Mr. Mamlak contended that the city had offered him no real assistance until after the eviction proceedings began. He said he could not afford rents in prime Manhattan locations.
He also said the city owed him a chance to stay on the Lower East Side, partly because it had wasted his time and money on the proposal to buy 125 Delancey Street. City officials said there were no appropriate sites in the neighborhood.
The City Council President, Andrew J. Stein, who serves as a city ombudsman, has asked the Housing Department to reconsider Mr. Mamlak's eviction. His case, Mr. Stein said, ''shows how the city doesn't keep its word.''

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Washington U.;
Professors to Vote On Plan to Close A Department

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Nearly a year after Washington University announced that it would close its sociology department, debate over the the move still divides faculty members, who are to vote on Friday on a resolution in support of the department.
Supporters of the resolution, which was submitted by an informal faculty group with 90 co-signers, say the real question is whether a university can offer a liberal arts education without sociology, which they see as a crucial discipline. Those who would let the department die argue that the school cannot afford to do everything.
The dean of the faculty, Martin Israel, who last April decided to close the department in June 1991, said the decision had little to do with the content of sociology itself. He pointed to cuts at other top universities because of financial constraints. Columbia University is closing its linguistics and geography departments; Princeton is closing its statistics department, and Johns Hopkins is losing classics in the midst of a 10 percent cut in the size of the Arts and Sciences faculty. 
 
'A Unique Vision'
''It isn't only Washington University saying you have to be making choices,'' Mr. Israel said. ''Some of the people who favored this resolution are looking narrowly at the question of 'Should there be sociology?' The question must be 'Should we be planning; should we be making choices?' ''
For many in the faculty, though, sociology is too important to be eliminated. ''Sociology has a unique vision and view within the social sciences,'' said Daniel Kohl, a biology professor and leader of the department's supporters. ''The decision weakens the social sciences because it removes a unique contributor.''
The chairman of the sociology department, Marvin Cummins, said he recognized that ''universities face resource constraints'' but argued that if the university cannot maintain sociology ''there is a truth-in-labeling issue as to whether they bill themselves as a liberal arts institution.''
Others suggest that such a broad liberal arts education may no longer be possible. Robert Salisbury, a political science professor who sits on the committee that advised Mr. Israel in his decision, said, ''The expansion of knowledge and explosion of what there is to study has meant that for any particular field to do an adequate job, it has to grow.'' And for most departments to grow, some must be cut back, or in the case of sociology, cut altogether, he said.
 
Significant Discipline
The decision to cut sociology, Mr. Salisbury said, stems from what he termed weaknesses in the department, not in the discipline. While internationally respected 20 years ago, sociology at Washington University has seen a slow decline since, with no one having received tenure since 1974.
''I believe sociology represents a significant intellectual discipline, one that ought ultimately and ideally to be represented on our campus,'' Mr. Salisbury said. To make Washington's department respectable, though, would take ''an investment of a very large amount of money.'' The administration has not said how much that would be.
Others who support the closing are less affectionate toward the field.
''It seems to be well meaning but insubstantial,'' said Peter Riesenberg, a history professor. ''The creative period in sociology was a long time ago. It has lost its ability to identify new questions and develop new techniques,'' he said in an interview.
Mr. Cummins, one of three tenured professors in sociology, said this perspective showed ''a clear lack of understanding of the nature of sociology.''
''Political science does a wonderful job on questions of poverty as a policy issue,'' he said. ''Economics does an equally wonderful job of looking at it from an income-distribution perspective. But sociology asks how people in poverty live and do they aspire to other things.''
A psychology professor who supports the department, Arthur Shulman, said the interaction between sociology and related disciplines makes the department necessary. He said the psychology department could not run its organizational-behavior doctoral program without sociologists as collaborators.
''We couldn't have on this campus a viable physics department if we didn't have a viable chemistry department,'' he said. ''The same holds for psychology, education, political science,'' in relation to sociology. The vote on Friday is nonbinding. According to a telephone survey by Student Life, the campus newspaper, 59 percent of faculty members support or tend to support the department, while almost 25 percent oppose it. A full 17 percent were still undecided last week when the survey, with a 7 percent margin of error, was conducted.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Pennsylvania;
Volunteers Take To the Street For Safety Patrol

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
As freezing winds blew across Spruce Street, a sophomore at the University of Pennsylvania, John Steele, was on patrol trying to protect fellow students from crime and his hands from the cold.
Shining a flashlight down alleys and into backyards, Mr. Steele and a junior economics major from Norristown, Gerry Cosgrove, walked past row houses, restaurants and the veterinary school on their one-hour shift. Last semester, at least four students in the area were the victims of armed robberies. 
The pair greeted friends and surprised two women taking a shortcut. By 1:30 A.M., they had turned their equipment over to the second shift and gone home.
As part of a program begun this month, Penn Watch, students with flashlights, two-way radios and bright yellow jackets patrol their western Philadelphia campus at high-crime hours. In their two months, the volunteers have not been involved in any incidents. But students and the police said their efforts were making the school a better place to live.
''Even though we don't see much, our presence is known,'' Mr. Steele, a public-policy major from Lehighton, Pa., said. ''When people walk by, they check us out, because wearing these yellow jackets we are very visible. People know that something is going on.''
 
Aiding the Police Force
About 250 students have been trained to describe suspects and use the radio. They patrol seven days a week, said the coordinator, Joel Nied, a senior history major from Jacksonville, Fla. Each person will patrol ''about three or four times a semester,'' he added.
To join the program, students must sign a form saying that they ''take entire responsibility for their actions'' and acknowledge that they are not employees of the university, said Jane Combrinck-Graham, a risk-control specialist.
The program began in three areas with fraternity and sorority members. The chairman of the Penn Undergraduate Assembly, Benjamin Karsch, has since begun recruiting other students. Mr. Karsch said he would like two new areas, covering dormitories, patrolled by May.
''Any student who we explain it to is able to see the benefit,'' said Mr. Karsch, a finance and marketing senior from Tucson, Ariz. ''In short we are directly helping Public Safety,'' the Penn police force.
Mr. Nied said he and the two other fraternity members who began Penn Watch had been inspired by a similar program at neighboring Drexel University. The president's office at Penn paid $1,500 for the jackets and flashlights. The university police provides other support, and the volunteers are trained to watch for criminal activities and to call police officers to catch suspects.
''We are really the eyes and ears of public safety,'' Mr. Nied said. ''We don't want to get involved in an incident.''
A spokeswoman for the university police, Sylvia Canada, said Penn Watch was a welcome supplement to the 50-member force and that she hoped it would help people feel safer.

Students, above, patrolled on Spruce Street. Volunteers patrol seven days a week armed with two-way radios and flashlights. (Jay Brodsky)

HEADLINE: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;
Here, Doubtful Shoppers Are Advised to Pounce

 BODY:
On any given Friday, Saturday and Sunday, the U.S. No. 1 Flea Market and Antiques in New Brunswick, N.J., about 45 minutes down the turnpike from Manhattan, draws some 30,000 people. They push their way past sweatshirt vendors and bulletin boards announcing events like a Marvelettes concert at the local high school to get through the streaky glass doors.
Inside, 500 or so booths and tables are laid out more or less along a grid. The overflow of merchandise snakes around the floor, creating alleys and cul-de-sacs. 
Clothing lurks overhead along a profusion of racks, and the visitor who changes direction too quickly is likely to come nose-to-neckline with, say, an evening dress in an exuberant lame or black-and-silver beadwork. A bower of T-shirts and Nike pump high-tops forms a passageway into boutiques with bin upon bin of nylon stockings at discount prices.
 
Wrenches and Antiques
There is enough here for everyone: Down one aisle a tool stand sells, among other things, sprocket wrench and screwdriver sets at near-wholesale prices; down another, a baseball-card booth offers images of the boys of several summers under glass. There is a pet-products boutique, a car-stereo booth, an antiques salon. And at site after site, tables are weighed down with that populist commodity, the collectible. Where else can one still find eight-track tapes and Ferrante and Teicher albums?
With the building's expanse of 175,000 square feet and legions of bargain-hunters it is easy to get lost in the crowd. Among the shoppers, a young woman pondered a pastel continuum of bridal veils and solicited advice from her relatives. A Senegalese couple culled through the fresh produce in the farmer's market section of the building.
The international feel of the place is only five or six years old, said Barbara Witkowski, the market's advertising director. Some vendors, she said, use the flea market as the first step in an entrepreneurial career.
''It makes sense,'' she said. ''At malls, you pay for maintenance and electricity. We have low overhead costs. It's an easy way to get started in a business.''
But many vendors come only for the weekend and the fun. U.S. 1 encourages the rambunctious ambience by bringing in live entertainment on Sundays to play throughout the afternoon. Last weekend, Gabe Bay and the Country Crickets, a band from Milltown, N.J., ripped through a set of country-western and 50's songs, inspiring members of the audience to dance a modified Texas two-step. The bandstand's placement behind the Book Bazaar added a dimension to browsing through the better-than-average selection of current and remaindered books.
 
No Airs Here
U.S. 1 also encourages haggling, to keep the flea market from taking on the airs of its upscale cousin, the shopping mall. Some vendors set firm prices, but others let them float. Keep in mind that a flea market is not a department store with an infinite inventory. Pouncing may be the most appropriate economic behavior. A visitor last weekend who decided to ''come back later'' to buy a framed Miss Rheingold poster found that another consumer had made off with the prize.
Food is available inexpensively at several stations and ranges from pickles at the Pickle People booth to delis featuring the fare of Greece, Poland and the Middle East. An additional flea market blandishment is the game room, with pinball machines and video games, on the far side of the building.
To get to U.S. No. 1 Flea Market and Antiques, take Exit 9 (New Brunswick) off the New Jersey Turnpike and follow signs onto Route 18 North; take it to Route 1 North; take the first U-turn on Route 1 North, which will take you onto Route 1 South. U.S. 1 has its own exit on the right.
Admission to the market is free; there is a $1 parking fee on Sundays. Band sets, on Sundays only, begin at 1:15, 2:45 and 4:15 P.M. Hours on Friday are noon to 9 P.M.; Saturday, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M., and Sunday, 10 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. For information, call 201-846-0900.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
THE POSTHUMOUS ADVENTURES OF LOUIS KAHN

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
These are heady days for the memory of Louis I. Kahn. The architect died 16 years ago next month, perhaps the most respected presence in his profession. And the intervening years seem only to have enriched Kahn's reputation still more, to the point where it is now no exaggeration to call him the most venerated figure in 20th-century American architecture after Frank Lloyd Wright.
Tragic as Kahn's death from a sudden heart attack was - he left numerous projects unfinished, and at 74 years of age could have been expected to have had more creative years ahead of him - it spared him the experience of living through the 1980's, when architecture became ever more a matter of appearances, and less a matter of substance. To Kahn, substance was all; his buildings were quiet, profound presences, occasionally brooding, often uplifting, and never, ever, glib. Image did not matter to Kahn. The integrity of space, of light, of materials, did. His buildings are nearly mystical in their power, and every one of them is a testament to the ability of architecture to create a sense of both repose and awe. 
It is hard not to think that the growing adoration of Kahn comes, in part, as a reaction against so much of the architecture that has filled the landscape in the years since his death, the slick and facile decorated boxes of the opulent 80's. While Kahn's work was a critical influence on many of today's post-modern architects, who found in his determination to make his buildings sensual and emotional a kind of liberation from the coldness and austerity of modernism, Kahn would probably have had no patience with the last decade's fondness for ever lusher decoration. Indeed, he would probably have found the glitz of the last few years appalling. (Perhaps too much so, since I doubt that he was any more sympathetic to the more serious examples of post-modernism than he was to the sillier ones, but that is another matter.) Luxury to Louis Kahn emerged from the richness of materials and the discipline with which they were put together, not from the quantity of fancy doodads an architect could cram into a single project.
As we move into a decade in which architecture will be forced, by virtue of economic realities if not esthetic tastes, to be more rigorous and more disciplined, Kahn comes ever more to the fore. Not, to be sure, as an example of fiscal restraint - his buildings were in fact quite expensive - but as an example of a kind of intellectual rigor. He sets a tone for taking things seriously.
At his death Kahn left a relatively small oeuvre, and this too has served to enhance his reputation. A Louis Kahn building is a rare event: there are so few of them. There were little more than a dozen major Kahn buildings actually erected, as well as a handful of smaller ones. And of the important Kahn buildings, only three were museums, surely the most intensely examined building type of our time. These three museums, as well as a fourth that the architect had just begun designing at the time of his death, are now the subject of a thorough and unusually timely exhibition, ''The Art Museums of Louis I. Kahn.'' Organized by the Duke University Museum of Art, which published a lavish catalogue to accompany it, the show is now in New Haven at Kahn's first art museum, the Yale University Art Gallery, where it will remain on view through March 11. The exhibition will then move to Kahn's second museum, the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, and then to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.
This show comes at the right moment, and not only because of the rising tide of interest in anything Kahn did. Art museums are the cathedrals of our age, and if Kahn is our most revered architect, it would follow that those few museums he designed would possess the allure of shrines. That is particularly so in Fort Worth, where - as if to make this exhibition more timely still - the Kimbell Art Museum is now at the center of an intense and increasingly bitter architectural controversy over its plans to build a major addition to its Kahn structure, changing it irreparably.
Of Kahn's three museum buildings, two are right here in New Haven: in addition to the Yale Art Gallery of 1951, Kahn's first significant public commission, there is his very last building, the Yale Center for British Art, set directly across the street and finished posthumously in 1977. The Kimbell in Fort Worth was completed in 1972, between the two New Haven structures that bracket his career. At the time of his death he had just begun designs for his fourth museum, the Menil Collection in Houston, a commission that was eventually turned over to Renzo Piano and completed in 1987.
It is no insult to ''The Art Museums of Louis I. Kahn,'' which was organized by Michael P. Mezzatesta of Duke, who served for six years as a curator at the Kimbell, to say that the best thing about seeing it in New Haven is the chance it offers to revisit two-thirds of Kahn's museums. I don't know what the show looked like at Duke, but at Yale, one is constantly pulled away from the drawings and models to look up at the art gallery's ceiling of concrete tetrahedrons, a ceiling that seems at once rough and refined, like the building itself celebratory of technology and yet immensely disciplined and serene. And then across the street at the Yale Center for British Art all this contained energy is resolved into a building that is vastly warmer, grander, more sumptuous and more subtle, but never more self-indulgent.
The exhibition seems almost anticlimactic: a long, long footnote to the buildings. This is how Kahn would have wanted it, surely, since he was never one to elevate drawings and models above the reality of architectural experience. To him the drawings were a way into the thing, they were not the thing itself. But as a footnote, this exhibition is excellent: it contains 108 drawings and six models (plus an extra section, to be shown only at Yale, tracing the history of the Yale University Art Gallery), and they show us, as clearly as we could want, the tortured, slow process by which Kahn worked. He was not an architect from whom perfect things sprang instantly, but one who labored long and hard to bring forth his art. His first ideas almost always needed editing, and he was his own best editor.
Both early and late drawings for all the museums are shown here, and we see all the schemes evolve. Particularly striking are the initial drawings and model for the Yale Center for British Art, a version that was much too big and too assertive to have been built, almost bombastic, but still a richly potent, powerful design, in some ways even stronger now than 20 years ago. And the final presentation drawings for the British art center, renderings of the interior court spaces and the facades that were built, are exquisite, haunting pieces, invoking the very same qualities of softness and great power, of formality and self-assuredness with grace, that the finished building has.
There is a certain paradox to this: the best thing about the Kahn drawings is how they show us the process, yet the best drawings are the finished ones at the end of the process. Perhaps the answer to this riddle is that, as with all great artists, the thrown-off pieces of the creative process are not, in the end, quite as interesting as the idea that there is an arduous creative process. Just as musicologists may want to study rejected versions of a Beethoven quartet but the rest of us are content to experience the one that Beethoven felt he actually wanted to bring to the world, so, too, with Louis Kahn's drawings: the most appealing are the ones that show ideas most fully realized.
A final point about the show at Yale. As installed by Tony Hershel, assistant to the director of the Yale Art Gallery, it makes full use of the system of movable panels Kahn designed for the gallery, a tremendous advance for the early 50's that made exhibit space fully flexible. Unfortunately, the system breaks the galleries up into a warren of small spaces, and it is not easy to follow the development of the various projects sequentially. The layout is confusing and disjointed, not because of Mr. Hershel but because of Kahn. How ironic it is that Kahn's very system has somewhat done in this attempt to pay him homage!
We do not come off liking the Yale Art Gallery any the less for this. It is not a case of architectural hubris, a museum building designed with indifference to art. Quite the contrary: these are wonderful spaces to be in, and Kahn's system does not fight art at all. It just makes it very difficult to create a coherent installation that depends, as this one does, on the careful juxtaposition of various drawings.
All this is relevant to the continuing dispute at the Kimbell, which has heated up considerably in recent months, since part of the issue there is whether the opponents of the scheme to expand the museum are elevating Kahn's architecture over the museum's art. The Kimbell is Kahn's most beloved museum, and surely his most subtle: the one in which light and texture play the greatest role, the one in which the architect's ability to be at once forthright and mystical seems most fully realized. The Kimbell is also a superb exhibition space, although not a perfect one, and so the architect Romaldo Giurgola's plan to extend the building by literally replicating Kahn's design at either end seems particularly puzzling. To make the Kimbell bigger by copying Kahn is an odd way indeed to pay him homage.
I don't question for a moment that homage is what was intended, but this design embalms the original building. Under the pretense of both respecting Kahn and serving the needs of the art collection, it will blur the distinction between what Kahn created and what was added by someone else, thus compromising what has turned out to be one of the Kimbell collection's greatest possessions, which is the Kahn building itself.
This does not mean the museum cannot or should not become larger. If there is a true need for expansion (which has been questioned, given the small size of the museum's exemplary collection), then of course the Kimbell should expand in some way. But if there is any lesson to be learned from the exhibition ''The Art Museums of Louis I. Kahn,'' it is that Kahn went through his long and difficult design process to end up with profound and special places, not buildings that could be expanded as if they were made of blocks. If the Kimbell as Kahn designed it were a car, it would become a stretch limousine, expanded beyond its natural proportions.
In a presentation in January before the Architectural League of New York to defend the Giurgola plan, Edmund T. Pillsbury, the director of the Kimbell, spoke of the brilliance of the original concept for the Kimbell, prepared by Richard Brown, its first director and the man who hired Louis I. Kahn. Brown envisioned a museum that would have been somewhat larger than the present Kimbell, and all on one floor, as the Kimbell is. Mr. Pillsbury made much of the fact that the original designs for the Kimbell called for a bigger building than what was built, and presented the Giurgola scheme as consistent with Brown's vision for the museum - and claimed that both Kahn and Brown would have wanted to give the institution of the Kimbell pre-eminence over the building itself.
Perhaps so. Everyone, both for and against this addition, is claiming the spirit of Kahn as an ally. That part of the debate does no one any good, since Kahn is dead. But to suggest that this particular expansion plan is a mistake is hardly to say that Kahn's building as a work of architecture is more deserving of respect than the institution that occupies it. Both things, the building and the institution, are critical, and if the 18 years since the Kimbell opened have done anything, they have made the destinies of this building and the art it houses increasingly interdependent. What Brown, who died in 1979, could not have known when he wrote his initial wish for the museum is that the Kahn building would succeed beyond his wildest dreams, and would become one of the icons of 20th-century American architecture. The experience of living with the Kimbell has made its building more important than anyone, even Louis Kahn, might have expected: the Kimbell has become only richer and deeper and more significant as a part of our culture as the years have gone on, to the point where it now deserves to be cherished as much as anything else in the museum's collection. That is not architectural idolatry but simple fact, and far from denying it, the museum should be celebrating it.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Tokyo Teeters, But New York Holds Firm

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
In October 1987 and again two years later, Wall Street started panics that spread around the world, only to be slowed and eventually halted in Tokyo. Each time, the Japanese stock market slipped a little but soon rallied, to the great relief of traders everywhere.
These days, however, Tokyo is doing its best to seem like the old New York. Amid amazing volatility, share quotes plunged last week, while the yen also came under pressure. And just like the bad old days in New York, there were those who were eager to pin the blame on program traders. (Story on page 15.) On this side of the Pacific, the Nikkei's plunge was viewed nervously, but with a steely determination not to follow it down. All things considered, the New York market turned in a remarkably good performance. The Dow Jones industrial average fell each day of the holiday-shortened week, but on both Wednesday and Friday it showed considerable resistance to follow Tokyo's plunges. It ended the week down 71.40 points, to 2,564.19, and is just 20.95 points above the six-month low it hit in late January. 
Tokyo's problems are not unique, of course. Interest rates have been marching up in almost every market. Charles Clough, the chief strategist at Merrill Lynch, sees in that rise a message that the bond markets of the world fear inflation, and a warning that the economies of many countries are in trouble.
''When interest rates go up in parabolic curves, as they are now,'' he said, ''it usually indicates that the business cycle is near a peak.'' He recommended traders sell some stocks to raise cash, and said that worries about corporate profits are likely to intensify. That's what happened to Digital Equipment Corporation, whose shares fell to a four-year low as the company said it might post a quarterly loss.
While Japan was watched nervously, Wall Street's attention also was on Washington, where Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan gave testimony that some took to mean he was worried about inflation, and others took to prove the opposite. ''It is the job of the Federal Reserve chairman to be Delphic,'' said Abby Joseph Cohen, the erstwhile chief investment strategist at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. She thinks the hidden message is that he wants to be reassuring, but that he can't risk easing credit.
''He has the double-barreled problem of inflation and currency, which is quite wobbly on the foreign exchange markets,'' she said, adding that the current period of slow growth could yet turn into a recession.
Earnings, interest rates, currencies and the like are the things Wall Street likes to claim it watches. But the real focus last week continued to be the death throes of Drexel. Fred Joseph, who had kept his job as chief executive by persuading the Government he hadn't had the foggiest notion what Michael Milken was doing, seems to have preserved his reputation for obtuseness. Weeks before Drexel collapsed, it was learned, Mr. Joseph took his bonus from the firm in Drexel stock, while others more wisely opted for cash.

PUB-DATE: February 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1722 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

 
THE ECONOMY

 
The Greenspan Watch
 
Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan is likely to leave interest rates just where they are. He spent last week delivering optimistic statements, with the usual hedging. Before a House panel on Tuesday, he predicted modest growth and said the danger of a recession probably has passed. Fed watchers concluded he would not lower interest rates. Bond prices plummeted. On Thursday, when he told Senators that inflation was easing, despite a recent surge, Fed watchers said he was unlikely to raise rates. Bond prices recovered.
 
'Troubling' Inflation
 
Consumer prices climbed 1.1 percent in January, the largest monthly gain in seven years. Drop energy and food prices, which were bound to soar after December's cold snap, and the core rate of inflation still reached six-tenths of 1 percent. ''A troubling number,'' said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Georgia State University Economic Forecasting Center. He predicts inflation of 4.7 percent for the year, compared with 4.6 percent in 1989 - inflation rates the Federal Reserve has called unacceptable. 
 
F.D.I.C. Retreat
 
Imagine that every insurance company issued policies with a $100,000 limit, then covered all losses no matter how large. This has, in effect, been the practice of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in bailing out depositors at banks it considers too big to fail. But on Wednesday, William Seidman, the F.D.I.C.'s chairman, said this policy had become too costly to maintain. His possible solutions include paying back just 90 cents on the dollar for all deposits of more than $100,000 at a failing bank, or asking the banking industry itself to insure larger sums.
 
The Nikkei's Decline
 
Tokyo stock prices are tumbling. The Nikkei index fell 6.9 percent last week, to 34,890.97. Wednesday's 1,161.19-point, 3.2 percent decline was the third-largest ever. Traders blamed rising interest rates in Japan. Higher rates there and in Germany have raised American rates as well. American stocks also fell, but not as much as the Japanese market. For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 71.40 points, closing at 2,564.19.
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Tokyo: Charity Begins in the U.S.
The next American enterprise the Japanese seek to penetrate could well be the United Way. Japanese officials have told the nation's leading executives that their companies will be able to take heavy tax deductions for contributions to American charities. It is the latest effort by the Japanese to ease tensions over their growing presence in the United States. Japanese officials are also urging companies with United States operations to adopt the American ways of volunteerism. And then boast about it. As a new Japanese Chamber of Commerce handbook on corporate citizenship in the United States says, ''It is important in American society to take credit for good works accomplished.''
 
*
 
Japan's Liberal Democratic Party emerged from elections for the lower house of Parliament last week with renewed control and greater apparent ability to negotiate compromises on trade.
 
 
Volvo and Renault Swap
 
Volvo A.B. of Sweden and Renault S.A. of France said Friday they would swap much of their stock and combine many of the car and truck operations.
 
 
East Bloc Opportunies Knock
 
While President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia made the rounds in Washington last Wednesday, his top economic advisers courted the leaders of Wall Street. They want foreign companies to start operations and buy state-owned enterprises in Czechoslovakia. Several American companies, including the General Electric Company and the Chrysler Corporation, are already holding talks with manufacturers there. But first the Czechs need to do some housekeeping - like legalizing foreign business ownership.
 
*
 
American companies are looking to the East Bloc for bargains on brainpower. Monsanto, Perkin-Elmer and Du Pont are sponsoring research in the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia. Scientific research centers in these countries have had few incentives until now to market their findings.
 
 
COMPANIES
 
 
Bonuses for the Drexel Few
 
Would you hire an investment banker who didn't know his own company was collapsing? Executives of Drexel Burhham Lambert Inc. say they shelled out $350 million in bonuses in the last few months without dreaming that their parent company would have to file for bankruptcy protection on Feb. 13. Last Wednesday, Frederick H. Joseph, the firm's chief executive, told some creditors that, to keep key employees, Drexel had promised in early 1989 to award huge bonuses for the year - raising further questions about giving payoffs before performance. Some of the bonuses are said to have topped $10 million. Several of Drexel's creditors are livid. They plan to scour the firm's books and ask the courts to help them recover some of the payouts.
 
Good Ship Trump, Rough Waters
 
Trump casinos, Trump hotels, Trump apartment towers and Trump shuttles could be losing their allure due to the Trump marital feud, some marketing experts say. But Donald J. Trump himself said last week, ''The business has never been better.'' Advertising executives say that the public's sympathies are with his wife, Ivana, making her an ideal celebrity endorser. Although she manages the Plaza, one leading ad man, Jerry Della Femina, suggests she promote Ramada Inns. ''She knows what makes a good hotel,'' he said. ''She certainly has everyone's attention.'' And since her husband owns the Trump Shuttle, why not sign up Ivana to represent his rival? ''I just love the thought of her getting on the Pan Am Shuttle,'' Mr. Della Femina said.
 
Fat's in the Marketing Fire
 
The Monsanto Corporation is counting on millions of Americans to abandon fat for heated, whipped, filtered globules of egg whites and milk proteins. On Thursday, this product, called Simplesse, became the first low-calorie substitute for fat to win the Food and Drug Administration's approval. Nutrasweet, a Monsanto subsidiary, plans to begin selling a frozen dessert made with Simplesse by late spring. Next could come Simplesse mayonnaise, sour cream, margarine, dips and cheese. Some nutritionists hail Simplesse as a sure way to lower dietary fat. Others say that just as sugar substitutes have failed to lower consumption of sugar, a fat substitute will leave Americans and their diets just as fat.
 
Exxon and Justice Reach a Plea
 
Alaskan officials fear the Justice Department will let the Exxon Corporation off too easily. They said Thursday that Exxon and the Government have drafted a plea bargain that would allow the company to avoid criminal prosecution for its Exxon Valdez oil spill last March. Exxon would have to pay as much as $500 million, but would be protected for four years from Government lawsuits to recover billions more for environmental damage. Exxon is bound to see a lot more of Alaska this spring in any event, since the company agreed last week to resume its cleanup of blackened beaches.
 
Another Big Eye in the Sky
 
There's network television, cable television - and now, satellite television. NBC, Rupert Mudoch, the Cablevision Systems Corporation and Hughes Communications Inc. announced a $1 billion venture last Wednesday to beam programs straight into homes once Hughes launches a powerful new satellite in 1993. Sky Cable subscribers will need dishes - in appearance, more like panels - that are only about the size, and cost, of color televisions. Sky Cable will compete with the networks, the cable operators and another satellite service announced just the week before. The rival, K Prime Partners, expects to begin delivering programs by late summer or early fall, using an existing satellite and requiring subscribers to buy larger dishes.
 
*
 
In planning Sky Cable, Mr. Murdoch can draw on his experience of providing television by satellite in Britain. His Sky Television service lost money and failed to meet its growth forecasts in its first year. But it picked up hundreds of thousands of new subscribers since last fall, when it began renting satellite dishes for about $7.50 a month, instead of just selling them for $450 a month. A competing service, British Satellite Broadcasting, appears ready to begin operating this spring.
 
Lorenzo on the Line
 
Frank Lorenzo is betting his aviation empire on rebuilding Eastern Airlines. Eastern reached agreement with its unsecured creditors Thursday on a plan to pay them about 50 cents on the dollar, or about $490 million, and pull the carrier from bankruptcy. The deal required Mr. Lorenzo to pledge assets of Continental Airlines and the Texas Air Corporation, a commitment he had long refused. Continental, like Eastern, is a subsidiary of Texas Air, which Mr. Lorenzo heads. Airline analysts fear for the health of Texas Air, which lost $885.6 million last year. Texas Air said last week it had raised more than $250 million by selling a half interest in its computer reservation system to a General Motors Corporation subsidiary.
 
Deep-Discount Retailing
 
The deepest discounts at Macy's these days might be on its ''junk bonds.'' Some analysts doubt the chain can survive if competitors like Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus keep cutting prices.
 
In Brief
 
The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation agreed on Tuesday to accept the Georgia Pacific Corporation's $3.8 billion takeover offer. The deal creates the nation's largest forest-products company.
 
*
 
Federal regulators took control of the Imperial Savings Association, one of California's largest savings institutions, on Friday. Imperial, with $9.7 billion in assets, is the industry's second-largest ''junk bind'' investor.
 
Bad News on Oil Prices
 
Petroleum analysts say oil prices could rise 50 percent to $30 a barrel within five years, twice the increase they had expectd. They say that declining output in the Soviet Union and United States, growing demand in East Asia and production limits in the Persian Gulf could lead to much higher costs. In the United States, large oil price increases would increase the trade deficit and slow economic growth.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Mexico's Dismal Debt Deal

BYLINE: By JORGE C. CASTANEDA; Jorge C. Castaneda is a professor of international relations at the National Autonomous University of Mexico and co-author of ''Limits to Friendship: The United States and Mexico.''

 BODY:
The jury is now in on the 1989 debt restructuring agreement between Mexico and the international financial community. Unfortunately, the deal is a bad one for Mexico. The agreement, signed on Feb. 4, falls far short of the country's needs, has not and will not produce the desired effects, and leaves the nation in a woefully weak position for future negotiations.
Actual debt reduction will be virtually nil. Because 41 percent of Mexico's outstanding $48.5 billion in commercial bank debt was exchanged for new paper with a 35 percent discount, only $7 billion will be lopped off the country's total liabilities of about $95 billion. But to finance the $7 billion collateral fund that guarantees interest and principal payments on the discounted debt, Mexico was forced to take on $5.7 billion in new loans from Japan, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. 
The deal also provides Mexico with $1.5 billion in new loans over four years. Net debt reduction in 1990 is less than half a billion dollars. The deal is also inadequate in terms of yearly cash flow. Considering the current rate Mexico pays on its debt, the annual savings resulting from principal and interest reductions amount to $1.3 billion. New lending of $350 million per year must also be added. But then one must subtract interest payments for the collateral fund that is dedicated to purchase the United States Treasury zero-coupon bonds. The purchase of these bonds is a condition of the deal and serves to guarantee Mexico's principal payments. Final yearly net flow: less than $1.5 billion, or 10 percent of Mexico's 1989 gross debt service.
Despite efforts by Mexican authorities to disguise or doctor the economy's numbers (for example, the most recent trade figures available date back to last September), the Administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has acknowledged that the deal's chief virtues lie in its hoped-for indirect effects: reduced interest rates in Mexico; capital reflows from abroad, and increased foreign investment. Unfortunately, these numbers are not much more encouraging. Much has been made of the fact that Mexican interest rates fell last year by 20 points. But the decline was only of such a magnitude if one compares the highest rate, in June, with the lowest rate, in late August. In fact, from January 1989 to January 1990, the real decrease in the Mexican Cete rate - equivalent in importance to the 30-year United States Treasury bill rate - was marginal. It went from from 50.78 percent to 45.97 percent. Capital reflows to Mexico from abroad show a similar situation. Mexican Finance Minister Pedro Aspe has said that approximately $2.5 billion returned to Mexico in 1989. But the Bank of Mexico reported at the end of last July that $2 billion had come back during the first seven months of 1989. Thus, only $500 million returned during the five months following the debt deal. Mexican holders of dollar assets preferred to see what options foreign banks and investors finally chose.
But foreign investors have also reserved judgment. Aggregate figures for 1989 show foreign investment dropping slightly with relation to 1988, from $2.7 billion to $2.4 billion. The net hard currency inflow is estimated at $1.5 billion, far below the country's needs or the authorities' expectations. As for foreign banks, it seems inevitable that the overwhelming majority's decision to reduce its Mexican exposure instead of increasing it will have a spillover effect into the investment community. Why should potential new investors go to Mexico in droves when all but a handful of 450 banks are moving out?
But the debt agreement's main drawbacks are of a more strategic nature. If Mexico's foreign accounts force it back to the negotiating table soon, it will find itself in a much weaker position. Mexico has lost one of its most important bargaining chips: the threat of a suspension of payments, alone or with other debtors. The 18-month rolling interest-guarantee fund means that even if Mexico were to unilaterally cease payments as a negotiating weapon, the banks would not even begin to feel the pinch for a year and a half.
Moreover, to the extent that the debt deal exchanges commercial bank debt for official or multilateral lending, it also weakens Mexico. In addition to demanding greater conditionality, the World Bank does not renegotiate outstanding loans but simply increases lending to maintain positive flows. But events in Eastern Europe will inevitably reduce the availability of multilateral funding to developing countries.
Most importantly, Mexico will have missed a unique chance to lighten its debt burden. With time, it is obvious that Mexico and other Latin American debtors will face a more difficult situation. For political, ethnic and even sound business reasons linked to events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, they will face greater competition for money and sympathy than they found in 1989.
Thanks to the Mexican deal and rapidly diminishing geopolitical risks in Latin America due to the end of the cold war, the United States and other industrialized nations can increasingly put the debt crisis behind them. But for Mexico, the agreement may well be more than a mistake. It could become the symbol of an irretrievably lost opportunity.

LENGTH: 990 words

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Will Rising Assets Lower Fees?

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The mutual fund business recently rang in a record-breaking $1 trillion in assets, and that was good news for the industry. But it should also be good news for investors. Higher assets should translate into lower fees as costs are spread over a broader base.
But expenses at many funds are rising, too. And as a result, the average expense ratio - the funds' expenses as a percentage of average net assets - has been rising steadily since 1985, from 1.13 percent to last year's 1.26 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., a Chicago-based mutual fund research firm. 
While that change might seem small, ''If you expect a number to go down, any increase is large,'' said Joe Mansueto, president of Morningstar, adding: ''You should be concerned about rising expense ratios because they can be a potentially significant drain on your investment.''
To be sure, performance and how a fund fits into your overall investment strategy should be the most important factors when you consider buying a fund. But don't neglect expense ratios, because over time, a small difference in investment costs can make a big dent in investment returns.
Assume a person invests $10,000 in a mutual fund that returns 10 percent a year. A single percentage point difference in expense ratios would trim that compounded return by $719 over five years, Morningstar said. (A $10,000 investment yielding 10 percent would be worth $16,105 after five years; one yielding only 9 percent - losing 1 point for expenses - would be worth $15,386.) And the longer the money is invested, the greater the impact of differences in expense ratios.
What makes the rising expense ratios troubling is the fact that they shouldn't be rising. ''There have always been moderate drops in expense ratios as assets rise,'' said John C. Bogle, chairman of the Vanguard Group in Valley Forge, Pa.
Why not now? ''It's a question of what the market will bear,'' said Mr. Mansueto. A fund's expense ratio is available to all investors, but, he said, ''it's buried in the prospectus and overlooked by many investors.''
If the funds have more money than ever, where is it going? It seems to be building profits for mutual fund companies, going to their public shareholders or staying with the investment adviser, Mr. Mansueto said.
''That's why this industry has been so profitable,'' said Vanguard's Mr. Bogle. The biggest chunk of a fund's expenses is the fund's investment adviser, and most of that is pure profit, said Mr. Bogle.
There's another factor at work. More funds are lobbying their directors to permit 12b-1 plans, named for the Securities and Exchange Commission rule that lets funds skim off part of shareholders' money to pay for sales and marketing expenses. Fund executives argue that by beefing up promotion, they can bring in new customers - and cut costs for everyone.
The Morningstar numbers show that is not happening. And, Mr. Mansueto said, 12b-1 plans are driving up ratios further, by .05 percent to 1.25 percent.
Other factors are driving up ratios, too. New funds keep sprouting, and these are generally smaller funds, which tend to have larger expense ratios and thus pull up the average. And sometimes the economies of scale do not appear. Many funds' administrative costs rise in tandem with the number of customers because more accounts have to be serviced, more prospectuses printed and mailed and more telephone lines set up.
At the Keystone Group in Boston, the expense ratio on the Keystone Custodian Fund, Series B-2, jumped from 1.68 percent to 1.84 percent last year, while assets rose from about $916 million to almost $1 billion. The savings created by a bigger asset base were only ''modest,'' said George S. Bissell, Keystone's chairman, and went into extra customer services, such as new phone lines to help customers with I.R.A.s and taxes. ''That's O.K., if it's justified,'' said Kathryn B. McGrath, director of the division of investment management for the Securities and Exchange Commission. But, she added, she would like to compare the cost of the services to the extra money generated by the higher expenses.
At the Dreyfus Corporation, the expense ratio for the Growth Opportunity Fund rose from .91 to 1.04 during 1989 while assets rose from $567 million to $579 million. Dan Maclean, vice president and general counsel for Dreyfus, said the fund has an above-average advisory fee, which contributes to the expense ratio, and that's because ''you pay someone more because they do a better job.'' But lawsuits brought by fund shareholders in the last five years are prompting changes in fee structures. Shareholders insisted that funds rework their investment contracts to recognize economies of scale and the solution was to put in a series of breakpoints that lower fees as assets rise. Some funds now pay advisers a set percentage of assets for the first $10 million of assets, for example, and a smaller percentage for the next $50 million and so on.
 
POOLED MONEY
During the 1980's, mutual fund investors shied away from the stock market by shifting their money into high-yeild money-market and bond funds.
The runup in interest rates in the early 1980's brought spectacular yields of as much as 16 percent in the safe money-market funds. Government bond funds also did well, and the two hot sectors in the last several years - ''junk bond'' funds and Ginnie Mae'' funds, government bond funds that invest in mortgage-backed securities - pulled in even more investors.
Looking ahead, experts predict a complete flip-flop in how fund investors allocate their money. ''Stock market investments should pick up as interest rates decline over the decade,'' said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytic Services. And because more people will need bigger returns on their money to finance retirement, stocks - which have a higher return over time than bonds - are expected to be the investment of choice.

HEADLINE: Managing;
Revising Pay Packages, Again

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
During the 1980's, when inflation came under control and companies could get away with giving mediocre raises, they started tinkering with compensation packages. Instead of double-digit raises, they offered valuable employees stock grants, deferred bonuses and other potentially lucrative incentives if they attained higher profits, stock-price growth or other goals.
But now companies are finding that while those plans work just fine for keeping a stable company humming along, they are virtually useless when that company goes through massive divestitures, falls into debt or even introduces a new product.
Now, searching for pay policies that will help them cope with such critical situations, companies are tinkering with compensation plans again. Thomas L. Doorley, a senior partner at Braxton Associates, the strategic consulting division of Deloitte & Touche, says that 20 percent of his clients tailor compensation plans to different stages of development, up from 5 percent just a few years ago. Diane Posnak, managing director of Pearl Meyer & Partners Inc., a compensation consulting firm in New York, says the growth is even greater than that. ''Companies with special situation plans are becoming the rule rather than the exception,'' she said. 
Restructurings linked to takeover attempts are among the most common triggers for special pay plans. Until October 1986, for example, the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation based bonuses on return on equity, stock price gains and profits. Then, the company restructured to ward off a hostile takeover bid from the Wickes Companies.
''Suddenly we were highly leveraged,'' said Guy O. Mabry, executive vice president. ''We needed to persuade managers to stay with the company and return it to stability.''
Owens-Corning put in an all-stock bonus plan for 150 top people that would not pay out for seven years. The payout was not tied to specific goals. But managers knew that Wall Street would not recommend the stock unless they got debt down and profits up.
The scheme paid off: the management team stayed, Owens-Corning is ahead of schedule on paying its debt, and its stock, which was at $12 when the plan was instituted, is trading in the $20's.
Different plans are needed to retain managers during divestitures. In 1987 the Penn Central Corporation spun off Sprague Technologies, its Stamford, Conn., electronic components subsidiary. To persuade a handful of executives to go with Sprague, Penn Central offered a ''retention transition bonus.'' If they stayed with Sprague for a year, their Penn Central stock options, which normally expire 90 days after an employee's departure, would stay in effect, and they would receive an extra year's salary and bonus. The executives went with Sprague, and are still with the company.
Now things have changed at Sprague again. It is liquidating one of its divisions, and it has put in a one-shot bonus plan for the division's three key people, payable after the liquidation is over - and their jobs have been eliminated.
Although most special-situation incentive plans kick in when a company is shrinking, a few are aimed at encouraging growth spurts. In 1987 the Williams Companies, a gas pipeline company in Tulsa, Okla., set up a fiber-optics subsidiary, Williams Telecommunications, and charged it with grabbing market share - fast. Most managers in Williams's operating companies get bonuses based on cash flow and operating profit; the new subsidiary's managers bonuses are based on how well they use earnings to grow the new product line.
''We wanted them to reinvest money to grow, not just try to get profits out,'' said John Fischer, vice president of human resources.
Top managers are generally the beneficiaries of special-situation compensation plans. But some companies - particularly those making pharmaceuticals and consumer products - are starting to extend bonus plans to researchers, package designers and other mid-level people involved in product development. The plans, which usually involve cash bonuses, pay in stages - when a product is developed, when it is introduced, and when it grabs market share. After that, the profits the product generates all count toward the general bonus pool.
''These plans don't get much visibility because they are not reported in proxies,'' said Louis J. Brindisi Jr., a senior partner at Strategic Compensation Associates, a New York consulting firm. ''But they are a lot more common that most people realize.''

HEADLINE: NAGGING FEARS;
German Questions No One Wants to Ask

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
EVER since the possibility of German reunification arose, the Bush Administration has chosen to talk about it in the most delicate and positive terms, almost as if Germany's division had been an act of nature and not war. This has been intentional, an effort not to antagonize the Germans and lose their cooperation at a moment when it is most needed to insure that Europe makes a peaceful transition to a post-Cold War order.
But in recent days some American officials have conceded privately that something has been missing from Washington's public declarations. Thus far that something has only been whispered in the halls of the State Department and Pentagon.
It goes like this, an American official said: '' 'Well, you see, there was this thing called World War II, and the Germans started it. That's why their country got split in two.' Now how do we reassure everyone that a reunited Germany isn't going to do it all over again?'' 
With German unification now an immediate prospect, and an international framework for discussing it agreed upon Feb. 13 in Ottawa, the Bush Administration's ability to finesse this fundamental question is rapidly diminishing. And officials know it: They are hearing too many Polish, British and French concerns that a reunited Germany will, sooner or later, dominate the continent, as it has in the past.
Last week it fell to Mikhail S. Gorbachev to express the concerns publicly. ''No one has a right to ignore the negative potential formed in Germany's past,'' he said, adding that the Soviet Union ''has an inalienable right to expect, and the possibility to exert efforts to insure, that our country should not sustain either moral or political or economic damage from German unification.''
For now, senior Administration officials say they are inclined not to force the issue, and to devote their energies to getting the Germans themselves to reassure their European and American allies by being more explicit in their pronouncements. This is a primary reason why President Bush is meeting this weekend at Camp David with Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
Some Americans inside and outside the Government believe that what is needed now is a diplomacy more public than private. Michael Mandelbaum, an expert on East-West relations at the Council on Foreign Relations, says the United States is not doing Germany or its neighbors any favor by pretending in public that it is not concerned about the potential for a reunified Germany to destabilize Europe - or for a nervous Europe to destabilize a reunified Germany.
''There is no use pretending that Germany is just another country,'' Mr. Mandelbaum said. ''It is not that we have to be afraid that the Germans are going to come roaring back and invade the East. But there is a certain historical legacy here, and unless we are clearly on record regarding certain principles - principles such as what a united Germany's borders might be, the fact that it must not be able to build nuclear weapons, the notion that its army must remain of limited size and deployment - we are going to increasingly see a situation in which many Europeans will be afraid of the Germans and the Germans themselves will begin to grow afraid for their own security.''
Bush Administration officials say that they have hardly been deaf to these issues and that they have been the motivating force behind the Americans' private diplomacy. The so-called two-plus-four framework that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d helped arrange in Ottawa with the wartime Allies and the two Germanys was precisely intended to address the concerns. Under the arrangement, once the two German Governments agree on a path to unification, the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union will sit down with them and negotiate border and security issues.
The problem, said a European diplomat, is this: ''Two-plus-four is just a framework. What about the content?'' Here, the Bush Administration finds itself running up against some of its own best instincts. Since the fall of the Berlin wall last November, Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker have deliberately adopted the position that a low profile is the best profile - no dancing on the wall, no poking a stick in Mr. Gorbachev's eye, just quietly allowing the Soviets to keep backpedaling out of Europe and reaping the rewards later.
But the German question is another matter, one in which a more high-profile American approach may be called for. Historically, the United States has been trusted by all the parties, in large part because it is seen as the disinterested outsider.
 
A Plea From Poland
Without more explicit language from Washington, it seems that European and Soviet officials will continue to express concern that their interests are being ignored. That is what Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland did last week when he said the two Germanys should agree to a preunification peace treaty guaranteeing the Polish-German border. So great is the Polish worry that a united Germany might someday try to reclaim German territories ceded to Poland after the war that Mr. Mazowiecki said Soviet troops should remain in Poland as insurance until these ''ambiguities'' are cleared up.
Robert Gerald Livingston, an expert on Germany at Johns Hopkins University, makes the point that the United States has to remember that it ''is not just allied with Germany.''
''We don't have to say that we don't trust the Germans, but we can say that we understand why others don't,'' he said. ''I don't see any problem with our saying it out loud, since many Germans have themselves.''
Indeed, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has repeatedly affirmed his country's intention to remain in NATO and to respect its postwar boundaries, though Mr. Kohl has been less explicit on the border question. Bush Administration officials say that they are losing patience with Mr. Kohl's lack of clarity on the issue and are also concerned about his ability to resist Soviet demands and domestic political pressures that a united Germany be neutral.
Mr. Bush, said one official, expects some straight talk from Mr. Kohl.
In the view of Stephen Szabo, an expert on Germany at the National War College, ''It is really a job for the Germans, more than anyone else, to persuade those elements in our country and in Europe that past German patterns of behavior won't reassert themselves.''
The West Germans, Mr. Szabo said, have ''a very good record to build on'' - 40 years of a multiparty democracy, a record of unwavering loyalty to NATO and integration into the European Community.
Nevertheless, he said, the German leadership, West and East, has to make clear that a reunified Germany will continue along the same path, and also accept limitations on its military might.
Why? For all the talk about a two-plus-four framework of negotiation and new pan-European organizations to replace NATO and the Warsaw Pact, and for all the talk that in the post-industrial age, economic interdependence makes a war in Europe virtually unthinkable, these are little more than constructs in the minds of diplomats. At the end of the day, what will reassure Germany's neighbors is what always reassures neighbors: a stable balance of power. In this case, what is needed is a stable balance of power undergirded by a military structure that insures that Germany's potential to dominate will be held in check and at the same time will not make the Germans themselves feel vulnerable.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Western Europe Is Edgy Over the U. S. and Much Else

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
AFTER 40 years in an alliance held together by the Soviet military threat, the United States and Western Europe have suddenly realized that things may never again be the same between them. When Cold War issues dominated, Western Europe never questioned Washington's leadership. Today, trans-Atlantic ties are being pulled in all directions.
The result has been a strange mood of irritability among the allies. There is frustration that their relations are being determined more by unexpected developments in Moscow, Warsaw, Berlin and Bonn than by cool-headed decisions in Washington, Paris and London. But they have also recognized that they no longer have the same interests in common. 
Perhaps most fundamentally, several Western European Governments are alarmed that Washington, consumed by its victory over Communism and its new friendship with Moscow, has underestimated the anxiety being stirred here by the prospect of a rich and powerful single German state dominating the heart of Europe.
Poor communications between the two sides have caused misunderstandings, aggravated by the perception that Washington now views Bonn as its main European interlocutor. New competition over business opportunities opening up in Eastern Europe has also not helped, with the United States saying that some allies are ignoring security considerations in their rush for profits.
But if the central challenge for the alliance is to define the future role of the United States in Europe, it is here that the enormous complexity of dealing with Western Europe has become apparent.
Western Europe seems agreed in wanting the United States to remain a European power, with American troops stationed indefinitely on the continent. But on almost every other issue, Washington hears a chorus of different opinions.
There is no agreement, for example, over whether the new map of Europe should be drawn by the new two-plus-four forum comprising the two Germanys and the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France; by the 12-nation Economic Community; the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization, or the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
At the same time, West Germany, Britain, France and Italy are defending their particular interests, with London at loggerheads with Bonn over the pace of German reunification and with Paris over the pace of European integration. Smaller nations feel that they are being kept out of the debate and, while the European Community has tried to take a lead, a half-dozen other Western European countries are not members.
Western Europe's feelings toward Washington are no less ambivalent. It wants the United States to provide a security shield against both the Soviet Union and a united Germany as well as to contribute generously to the reconstruction of Eastern Europe. Yet Western Europe is also eager to take charge of its destiny and reduce Washington's political role.
Before the Malta summit conference between President Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev in December, Western Europe was annoyed by the idea that its affairs could be decided by the United States and Soviet Union. President Bush flew home through Brussels to reassure his NATO allies that Europe was not being carved up behind their backs. Nonetheless, President Francois Mitterrand of France does not believe that a United States-dominated NATO should manage change in Europe. He argues that the best way to anchor Germany to the West and to aid Eastern Europe is for the European Community to accelerate its own economic integration.
 
A List of Complaints
In contrast, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain long emphasized her ties with the United States over those with Europe. Since President Reagan left the White House, she has lost her special relationship; she makes little secret of her disapproval of the Bush Administration's wooing of Bonn.
The two-plus-four talks on German reunification will at least give France and Britain a privileged voice, although both grumbled that the Bush Administration took full credit for an idea that they claim to have originated. Italy, on the other hand, is upset that it has been left out. Complaints about inadequate consultation, then, are rife. Out of the spotlight, economic disagreements are brewing. Ten days ago at a meeting in Paris of a committee set up to limit the export of advanced technology to Communist countries, the United States blocked efforts to have most controls lifted, a move that would have benefited West German, French and Italian companies.
Yet the absence of a Western European consensus has enabled the United States to continue playing the role of final arbiter. This weekend the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, met with Mr. Bush. In coming days, the leaders of Ireland, Norway, Austria and Italy will follow. ''Quite suddenly,'' The Economist, the London weekly, noted Friday, ''the new European politics has spilled across the Atlantic.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Asia's Needs and America's Grow Harder to Synchronize

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IN the four and a half decades since World War II ended, aboard the battleship Missouri, an overwhelming American military presence in the Pacific has been an accepted fact of the postwar order. The United States, after all, was the country that rebuilt and protected a demilitarized Japan, contained Communism at the 38th parallel and offset Soviet power.
Now, as the Warsaw Pact unwinds and Congressional enthusiasm for Pentagon budget cuts begins to spill over into Asia, the reasons for the presence no longer seem so obvious. The paradox is that with the connections between the United States and northeast Asia more complex than ever, especially in trade and technology, the American stake in maintaining its influence and assuring stability may never have been greater. And more than once in recent times, American power has been called upon to bolster democracy in places where it is still precarious, most notably in the Philippines. 
That set of interests - a mix of trade politics and military strategy - kept Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on a precipice during a two-week tour of Asia that ended yesterday. Everywhere he went, the affable Mr. Cheney left troop cuts in his wake. In the next three years the United States will be cutting back about 10 percent, maybe more, of the 120,000 troops scattered from Manila to Seoul. But Mr. Cheney also found himself arguing that Asia is hardly Europe, and that it is vital for the United States to remain the dominant military power in the area.
''If containing Soviet expansion was all we cared about, we might be tempted to withdraw,'' he said. ''But that is not what we intend to do.'' If the United States folded its tents, ''a vacuum would quickly develop,'' he said. ''There almost surely would be a series of destabilizing regional arms races, an increase in regional tensions and possibly conflict.''
 
Reasons to Stay
Moreover, he said, with aging leaders and unpredictable Governments in North Korea, China and Burma, and the specter of new upheavals in Cambodia, ''it should be clear that the United States could not ever think of a withdrawal from Asia.''
Perhaps not, but from both Washington and Tokyo it is clear that the United States role in Asia is about to change, and, as in Europe, it may happen faster than the Bush Administration is prepared to handle.
Mr. Cheney's easiest stop was probably South Korea. With the Government of Kim Il Sung, the North's leader, as firmly in control as ever, no one needed reminders that the 43,000 American troops in South Korea are a deterrent to any expansionist moves. Nonetheless, American and Korean experts admit that in the Reagan years, as South Korea's own forces grew more powerful, America's grew fatter and inefficient; Mr. Cheney talked about bringing American troop levels down by 5,000 to 6,000, to where they were before the Reagan Administration's buildup. He also pressed South Korea to double its $300 million contribution to the cost of keeping American troops there.
Far more complex for Mr. Cheney was the Philippines. Before he arrived Congress had cut back military and other aid to Manila by $96 million, from $360 million, arousing such outrage that President Corazon C. Aquino refused to meet with him.
The subtext of the visit was the future of Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Station, where leases expire in September 1991. More than half of the Philippine Senate opposes renewal, while the others want to raise the cost phenomenally. Mrs. Aquino is caught in between. She cannot appear to give in to the United States, but she knows that American intervention saved her from being toppled in a coup attempt last December. At the same time, Washington is showing interest in alternative sites if the United States is thrown out. ''They are not here to stay forever,'' Mrs. Aquino told Asahi Shimbun, the Japanese newspaper.
In Japan, forever is the time frame both sides have in mind. At a time when Japan's annual defense spending equals that of Britain or West Germany, the United States presence here, which will drop about 10 percent from the current 50,000 troops, reassures Asian countries, which remember the horror of a militarized Japan. It also reassures the Japanese, who were happy to hear Mr. Cheney tell them not to take seriously a recent Congressional resolution urging Japan to triple its defense spending.
But the relationship is quickly taking a different tone. Until a year or two ago, Americans here said that the military alliance came first, and that trade and technological competition was a sideshow. Now, as Mr. Cheney himself said, commerce is becoming the main event. ''As Secretary of Defense, I seldom speak about economic affairs,'' he said, ''but the growing friction between our countries on trade issues contributed to the trade imbalances and may, if unchecked, spill over into other areas.''
Since Congress tried to block the transfer of aircraft technology for Japan's FSX fighter last year, out of fear of helping Japan's aerospace industry, the Japanese have realized that they will not be treated like Britain or Germany. Increasingly, there is pressure here for Japan to go its own way and develop its own weapons. And more than ever, as Mr. Cheney noted, the American military needs a flow of Japanese technology even beyond the memory chips and other electronic components that the United States no longer manufacturers itself.
Over time, Americans in the Pacific think, the military alignment in Asia will be somewhat as it was before the Korean War: a big American presence in Japan, a small one elsewhere. But that vision depends on managing a relationship with Japan that, with a $49 billion trade deficit and rising tempers on both sides, may be slipping from control.
 
OUTPOSTS OF POWER
Principal U.S. bases in the Pacific
 
JAPAN and OKINAWA)
Japan provides support for American forces in the northern Pacific as part of a United States-Japan maritime defense agreement. The country is also a hub for American reconnaissance, communications and intelligence activities. Principal American bases include Yokosuka, home port for Navy ships of the Seventh Fleet; the Navy air station at Atsugi; Marine installations at Iwakuni, Japan and Futenma, Okinawa, including a Marine division and air wing; and Air Force tactical fighter wings at Misawa, Japan and Kadena, Okinawa.
 
SOUTH KOREA
United States forces are part of a combined South Korean-American command formed under a bilateral treaty and United Nations mandate. The Army 2nd Infantry Division base at Tongduchon, and Air Force tactical fighter units at Kunsan, Osan, Suwon and Taegu are among the American installations.
 
PHILIPPINES
Provides naval and air facilities for American forces operating in the western Pacific and Indian Ocean. Subic Bay is a principal maintenance, support and storage base for units of the 180-ship Pacific Fleet; Cubi Point is a base for anti-submarine operations. Three Air Force tactical fighter wings and early warning aircraft are stationed at Clark Air Force Base.
 
GUAM
Backup base for Philippines and Japan. Base for Strategic Air Command Bomber Wing covering Southeast and Southwest Asia, and Navy support and communications installations.
