PUB-DATE: February 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 8; Page 5, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1770 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL NOTEBOOK;
Millionaires Won't Miss a Defector

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Cross Greg Gagne off the list.
Gagne, the Minnesota Twins' shortstop, signed a one-year contract last month for an even $1 million, boosting himself onto the ever-more-crowded plateau of players who will earn $1 million or more this season (yes, there will be a this season).
But then the other day Gagne and the Twins negotiated a three-year contract worth $4.5 million. The first-year salary ($700,000) and a pro-rated share of the $400,000 signing bonus ($133,333) now leaves Gagne short of the 1990 Millionaires Circle.
The circle, however, will not turn square over Gagne's defection. The membership remains healthy and hefty. 
According to a survey of salaries by The New York Times, based on contract information from management and player sources, 152 players - virtually 25 percent of all the major league players - are guaranteed $1 million or more in salary (and, where applicable, pro-rated share of signing bonus) for this year. Of that number, one player - Robin Yount of Milwaukee - will earn more than $3 million and 26 other players are in the $2 million-or-more class.
The numbers have risen dramatically year by year. Only three years ago, in 1987, 60 players - or 10 percent - were at the $1 million mark, including six at $2 million. The next year the total was 74, including 12 at $2 million. Last year the circle ballooned to 106, with 20 at the more stratospheric $2 million, though none yet at $3 million.
This year's total at both levels would be higher except for the lockout. Many players negotiated their contracts in a way that meant smaller salaries for 1990, thus risking the loss of less money during an in-season lockout.
Gagne did exactly that in negotiating his multiyear contract. Instead of possibly losing part of a $1 million salary, he took $400,000 up front as a signing bonus and now stands to lose a part of only $700,000 if the lockout extends into the season.
Two notable examples of those missing the $2 million level because of their lockout bargaining are Orel Hershiser of Los Angeles and Frank Viola of the Mets. Each had a 1989 salary of $2,766,667, but this year each is listed at $1,966,667.
Because both the Player Relations Committee and the Players Association compute yearly salaries by pro-rating signing bonuses, Will Clark of San Francisco emerges from his four-year, $15 million contract with a 1990 salary of $2.25 million - $1.75 million in actual salary and a $500,000, or one-fourth, share of his $2 million signing bonus. If his entire signing bonus, paid up front, were added to this year's salary, Clark would lead the list at $3.75 million.
As it is, Clark is just another player in the $2 million circle.
The Brewers have the highest number of $2 million players - Yount, Paul Molitor and Ted Higuera. Seven other teams, including the Yankees with Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield, have two players each in that group.
The Mets, who have no $2 million players this year, have the most earning $1 million or more. Their economically elevated 11 are two more than the next highest total in the National League, the Dodgers' nine, and one more than the Kansas City Royals' 10.
The million-dollar Mets, who no longer include Gary Carter and Keith Hernandez, are: Viola, Dwight Gooden, Darryl Strawberry, Howard Johnson, Sid Fernandez, John Franco, Ron Darling, David Cone, Kevin McReynolds, Bob Ojeda and Mike Marshall.
The rich Royals are: Mark Davis, Mark Gubicza, Bob Boone, George Brett, Danny Tartabull, Bret Saberhagen, Storm Davis, Frank White, Kevin Seitzer and Bo Jackson.
Two other players could join the Millionaires Circle if they make their teams' opening-day roster, which they most likely will. Bill Gullickson of Houston and Charlie Leibrandt of Atlanta have contracts that guarantee them less than $1 million, but their income will rise to or beyond that level come opening day.
 
Feeling Like a Millionaire
 Joe Johnson isn't on the list, but the salary the Boston Red Sox have given him should make him feel like a millionaire.
Johnson, 28 years old, hasn't pitched in the major leagues since June 1987, before Toronto sent him to Syracuse of the International League. The Blue Jays removed him from their winter roster, and California drafted him. He pitched for Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League in 1988, then was invited to spring training with the Angels a year ago.
Johnson, however, had ruptured his Achilles tendon during the off season and tore it again the second day of camp (camps were open last spring). Released by the Angels at his request, the right-hander did his next pitching in the Mexican League this winter and caught the attention of several teams.
A resident of Plainville, Mass., Johnson worked out for the Red Sox and they offered him a contract. If he plays in the minor leagues, his salary will be $38,000. If he wins a job with the Red Sox, his salary will be $275,000 and he would be able to earn an additional $220,000 in bonuses based on points - 2 points for a start, 1 for a relief appearance.
That means that Johnson, who has a 20-18 career major league record, could make $495,000, a remarkable possibility for a player who has had a hiatus of nearly three years from the majors and has only two years and 10 days of major league service. David Cone, by contrast, had two years and 58 days of service and was coming off a 20-3 performance when the Mets signed him last winter for $332,500.
 
Mattingly Record Stands
 A Don Mattingly record has withstood another assault, and the season hasn't even started (it will start). For the third successive salary arbitration period, no one has cracked the $2 million barrier in a hearing and eclipsed the record $1,975,000 award Mattingly won in 1987.
Eleven players submitted figures of $2 million or more this year, but only one, Lonnie Smith, reached the hearing stage, and he lost. The other 10 players negotiated contracts. In the previous two years, a total of six players filed at $2 million or more, but only Andre Dawson went before an arbitrator and, like Smith, he lost.
The irony of the $2 million arbitration barrier is that Mattingly could have broken it in 1987, but eschewing the competitiveness he displays on the field, he chose to be conservative and settled for $25,000 less.
Despite the absence of a record-breaker this year, nine players gained awards of $1 million or more in hearings, raising to 23 the number at that level in the 15 years of arbitration.
Joe Hesketh of Montreal was the only player to have an arbitrator cut his salary this year. The pitcher dropped from $417,000 to $375,000, becoming the ninth player to suffer a pay cut in a hearing. Six other players agreed to cuts in negotiations - Rich Gedman of Boston, Mike Witt of California, Gary Ward of Detroit, Juan Nieves of Milwaukee, Jose Guzman of Texas and Don Carman of Philadelphia. Nieves and Guzman were injured last season.
Over all, players eligible for arbitration did not lose. They raised their economic standing from an average 1989 salary of $422,135 to $852,074.
The Pittsburgh Pirates had the most players go to hearings since 1974, the first year of arbitration, when the Oakland Athletics had nine players reach that stage.
One of those Oakland players was Jack Heidemann. He lost his case, so instead of getting what he wanted, the same salary he had made in 1973, $15,750, he had to take the Athletics' figure, a maximum 20 percent cut to $12,600.
 
Lockout History Revisited
 Seventeen years ago today, labor representatives of the owners and the players completed negotiations on a new agreement that ended the owners' first lockout of players from spring training camps. Players began arriving in their camps the next day, Feb. 26, and the season began as scheduled, on April 5.
That gave the players five weeks or more to get into in-season shape. The 1990 season is scheduled to open five weeks from tomorrow.
The 1973 agreement was the one that created salary arbitration, which is the thorniest issue in this year's negotiations. In debating the arbitration procedure, the owners at one point proposed that the maximum 20 percent salary cut not apply to players eligible for arbitration. That's the same proposal the owners made last Wednesday, only to snatch it off the table 24 hours later.
 
Some Labor Questions
 Two labor-related questions:
 First, why is Ron Darling of the Mets, a member of the players' negotiating committee and a New York resident, playing basketball and golf in Florida while other committee members, such as Paul Molitor, Phil Bradley, Scott Sanderson, Orel Hershiser, Tim Belcher and Matt Young, fly back and forth across the country to attend bargaining sessions in New York? David Cone, who neither is on the negotiating committee nor is the Mets' player representative, as Darling is, attended more meetings last week than his teammate has all month.
Second, how can the owners talk at the bargaining table about restoring players' trust in them when Bud Selig, owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and chairman of the Player Relations Committee, withholds details of Robin Yount's new $9.6 million contract until every other arbitration case is either settled or heard? Molitor, Yount's teammate, who could have benefited from the terms, has declined to discuss the matter, but the Brewers apparently told him Yount's contract did not have an option year when, in fact, it does, at Yount's option.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1442 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Apartments as Investments;
Buyers Seek Bargains in Co-op Buildings

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
A GRADUAL realignment is under way in New York City in the ownership of renter-occupied apartments in co-op buildings.
Well-financed real estate investment firms that have converted many buildings from rental to co-op status are picking up the packages of apartments that banks have taken back from weakened sponsors. Or they are buying packages from sponsors themselves at steep discounts from the value of the apartments when vacant.
From the point of view of the resident co-op owners, the sales are a favorable development. With shares in stronger hands, there is less fear of default on maintenance payments. 
But they also show that despite a slower housing market generally, the investment appeal of apartments whose value cannot be realized until some uncertain time in the future still endures.
''You have to view the unsold apartments as a pack of zero coupon bonds that are being sold at a deep discount and have an unsure maturity date,'' said Charles Hack, president of Parkview Associates, a development and investment firm that has financed the conversion of 30 buildings with 5,000 apartments in New York City over 10 years.
''If the package is large enough you will have a certain number of 'bonds' maturing each year at an average rate.'' In addition, there is the prospect with inflation of a longterm appreciation in value of property generally.
The office of State Attorney General Robert Abrams says it is investigating 62 complaints of delinquencies in payments to co-ops, up from 40 a month ago. ''Some payments are being made,'' said Frederick K. Mehlman, assistant attorney general in charge of the Real Estate Financing Bureau. ''In some cases we will bring litigation. In other cases, we are trying to work things out with banks.''
A recent purchase by Parkview Associates illustrates why occupied apartments - at the right price - still look like an attractive investment to deep-pocket investors when the management capability is present. In January a group organized by Parkview bought a package of 10 renter-occupied apartments in a 35-unit East Side building, paying about $1 million. The apartments have a present vacanct value of about $5.2 million, Mr. Hack said.
The average rent for the occupied apartments is about $1,000 a month. The maintenance expense averages $1,500 a month. Mr. Hack and his associates intend to make up this deficit, running at a rate of $60,000 a year for the maintenance plus an additional $10,000 in management, insurance and upkeep and repair costs, in expectation of future gains.
Assuming a 5 percent turnover rate, apartments will become vacant on average once every two years. The investor looks forward to profits from resale averaging $180,000 a unit, even before figuring in the reduced fixed costs over time as the inventory shrinks and appreciation in market value. If there had been no deficit between the rent and maintenance cost, Parkview figures it would have had to pay $1.3 million for the 10 apartments, or 25 percent of vacancy value, instead of $1 million.
DEALING with institutions that have taken back unsold shares from a defaulting sponsor, Coronet Properties, one of the city's largest converters, has acquired a package of 134 occupied apartments at Glen Oaks Village in Queens and is negotiating for other packages. Coronet already owns and manages 3,000 occupied apartments in 40 New York City buildings.
The Stern Organization, a Manhattan brokerage, sold four packages of occupied garden apartments in Queens, with a total of 1,000 units, to investors from London last year, Erwin Stern, its principal, reported. The seller was Arthur G. Cohen Properties. And a national real estate company that has not previously invested in the city is understood to be examining the Time Equities portfolio of occupied apartments, estimated at 3,500. Time Equities is the conversion company that sent waves through the co-op marketplace when it reported a ''material change'' in its financial condition to the Attorney General.
The importance of all this for thousands of New Yorkers in co-op buildings still occupied by large numbers of renters is that it suggests that delinquencies in maintenance payments to co-ops may well be temporary. In some cases, co-ops with delinquency problems may attempt to seize the rents, or the shares themselves, from delinquent owners.
But eventually new investor buyers are likely to pick up the shares for occupied apartments that other investor-owners, or their lenders, are trying to sell.
''People like me are out there cherry-picking,'' said Mr. Hack.
AT the same time, the very presence of the cherry pickers in the marketplace is evidence of distress selling. In some case co-ops have mortgages that require debt payments that put maintenance costs too far beyond the rent income. And renters may constitute 50 to 75 percent of the occupancy in recent conversions.
The number of buildings affected are only a fraction of the 3,800 that have been converted either to co-ops or condominiums over the last 10 years. These buildings contain 270,900 apartments, of which about 131,400, or 48 percent, appear to be still renter occupied. Nearly all the rest - or 139,500 apartments - have been sold for owner-occupancy.
These owners, about half of whom live in Manhattan and a third in Queens, have a considerable stake in sustaining the health of the resale market for vacant apartments. And they will benefit if more renters in occupancy can be induced to buy. When the ownership of occupied apartments goes into new and stronger hands, a newly vigorous sales effort can be expected.
Over time, whether the current renters buy or not, most of the units will be vacated and sold for occupancy. Purchasers of large packages of apartments normally calculate that the overall turnover rate will be about 6 percent. If they own a large enough group of apartments purchased at a sufficient discount from market value, they expect ultimately to profit from resales.
Meanwhile, they hope that the combination of rising rents and favorable sales prices will induce more renter-occupants to buy.
Robert Cicchillo, president of Alexander Brett, formed two years ago to supervise sales and management of investor-owned apartments, gave the example of a one-bedroom renter-occupied apartment in the co-op at 14 Horatio Street, in Greenwich Village. It was offered to the tenant at an insider price of $76,500 six years ago, but not purchased. The outsider price at the time was $125,000.
Now the insider price will be $99,000 as part of a new offering to rent-stabilized tenants next month. The outsider value is estimated at $170,000, based on recent sales of comparable vacant units.
The rent has risen for the occupant by $128 to the present $561 a month since the conversion. The maintenance has risen only $30, to $619. For the tenant, the increase in housing costs would have been $156 if she had bought in 1984. If she buys this year it will be $58. She will still, of course, have to be willing to make the cash investment and take out a loan.
According to Mr. Cicchillo, sales to renters continue, if slowly. The company took over the management of 132 occupied apartments in the 350-unit Bell apartments on 218th Street near Corporal Kennedy Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, six months ago. It has made 14 sales since then, 12 of them to insiders. The shares are owned by one of the syndicates put together by Parkview Associates, for whom Alexander Brett manages 1,500 apartments in 30 buildings.
MEANWHILE, conversion sponsors with management capability still find it possible to put together investment groups for unsold apartments. The Ziegelman Organization, for example, packages renter-occupied apartments, after its initial sales in buildings it converts. In a typical situation a group of 40 with a vacancy value of about $4 million will be sold to an investor group for about $1 million.
Herbert L. Mendelson, a real estate lawyer with the firm of Herrick Feinstein in Manhattan, told of purchases he made of apartments in moderate-income neighborhoods with other lawyers in his firm and clients of the firm. The rent and maintenance expenses are roughly equivalent, he said.
When a renter vacates the apartment and it is sold, the investor gets his cash back, the Ziegelman Organization takes an equivalent amount, and the remainder is split 50-50, Mr. Mendelson said. While the renter is still in occupancy, the investor earns an 8 percent tax-deferred return and also accrues an additional 2 percent, which is paid after the sale. Vacancy prices typically range between $60,000 and $100,000.

LENGTH: 2925 words

HEADLINE: As Co-ops Spread, Discrimination Concerns Grow

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
AS more and more rental buildings in Brooklyn and Queens are converted into cooperatives, New York City's Commission on Human Rights is gearing up to tackle one of the stickiest of housing discrimination issues - the broad powers of co-op boards to reject would-be buyers without explanation.
Agency officials say they expect complaints of discrimination by co-op boards to increase as the conversions move increasingly into the middle-class reaches of Brooklyn and Queens, producing thousands of new affordable ownership opportunities for the city's large population of civil servants, teachers and middle managers, many of whom are minorities.
At the same time, officials said, the evidence of racial intolerance in predominantly white neighborhoods of Brooklyn and Queens has underscored the presence of racism in the city in recent years, as well as the need for city action to curtail it.
Craig Gurian, chief of the commission's enforcement division, cited the racially motivated firebombing of a black couple's new home in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn on Feb. 8, the racial killing of a black youth in that borough's Bensonhurst neighborhood last August and the white vigilante attack that led to the death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, in December 1986 as evidence that ''we still don't live in a city that is open to everyone.'' 
City officials have determined that racism motivated the firebombing of the two-family house at 1254 East 91st Street in Canarsie that Wilfred Phillips and his wife Agnis recently bought for $200,000. Neighborhood groups and city agencies are raising money to help the Phillipses repair the house.
The Bensonhurst killing prompted the Human Rights Commission to ''shake up'' the office and direct more energy to open-housing efforts, Mr. Gurian said. And one way to open the door to peaceful integration, he went on, is to counter the widely held belief that co-op boards are omnipotent and unchallengeable in their decisions to admit or deny would-be buyers.
''As you get more and more people who haven't been in the co-op management business before, I think you have an additional risk, and that is one of the reasons we are prepared to go out and meet with co-op industry people and provide training sessions for new co-ops,'' Mr. Gurian said. ''We are saying to people, 'Look, you may not know this and you may not like it, but here are some things you're just not allowed to do.' ''
Just last month, the Human Rights Commission levied its heaviest housing discrimination fine ever, $52,000, against the board of a Jackson Heights, Queens, co-op that, the commission ruled, had rejected a woman because her two children were black. The board was also ordered to approve the sale to the woman, Mary Smith Shoyinka.
While aggrieved co-op seekers have won discrimination cases against co-op boards in state and Federal courts before, the Shoyinka case against the co-op at 35-45 82d street was the first one handed down by the Human Rights Commission's internal judicial system of administrative law judges. The co-op is appealing the award.
The award money will be divided between Ms. Shoyinka and the seller of the $70,000 apartment, Pat Gavin, and was based in part on the amount Ms. Gavin lost because of the delay in selling the unit and Ms. Shoyinka's continued rental costs while waiting to move into the co-op.
Most complaints of discrimination by co-op boards are settled before they reach the administrative law level, Mr. Fisher said. That the Shoyinka case was the first simply reflects that, as the number of charges of co-op discrimination increase as co-ops become affordable to more people, the number that go all the way to trial is also likely to mount.
Discrimination complaints from middle-class co-op seekers in Brooklyn and Queens are a far cry from those involving expensive apartments and often prominent people - both buyers and board members -in some of Manhattan's leading co-ops.
Aside from persistent and widely credited reports of some buildings keeping Jewish owners to a quota, board acceptances and rejections at the upper reaches of both price and social status are often based on personal friendships and club or church memberships.
IN any case, officials of the Human Rights Commission said, rich and important people do not tend to sue when they believe they are being discriminated against, but look elsewhere for housing. Middle class families, with less money and fewer choices, seem to be less inclined to swallow a rejection.
''Think of buildings built in the 1920's, whether in Brooklyn or Queens, which are essentially segregated parts of the city, where there is a high percentage of tenants who are elderly and, in many cases, an all-white building,'' said Mr. Gurian.
''Then the co-op comes along and one of the things it produces is a lot more movement in an area. A tenant sees he can buy an apartment for $25,000 as an insider and flip it for $60,000 and suddenly that little corner of the world meets the rest of the city.''
A similar scenario can be played out in already integrated rental areas, said Harvey Fisher, director of fair housing at the commission.
''It's not that these neighborhoods were closed to renters,'' he said, ''but as they turn co-op it becomes easier to insulate yourself because boards and board members in co-ops can hide behind the shared values system of one another. Where the values are racist or homophobic or whatever, they can buffer themselves.''
The officials worry that many new co-op owners who thought nothing of living with blacks or homosexuals as renters may take a different attitude toward having them as fellow-owners.
Sponsors of co-ops struggling for sales and higher prices may believe that the way to ''upgrade'' a building economically is to discourage minorities, Mr. Gurian said. He said there was some evidence of this trend in Prospect Heights and lower Park Slope, in Brooklyn.
''People who have just bought their apartment may say, 'Wow, I bought it, I own it, and if a black person comes into the building, how can I be sure that the value will hold its own?' '' Mr. Fisher said.
Under current law, the commission is forbidden to impose punitive damages on landlords or co-op boards that have been found guilty of discrimination, but it may recover out-of-pocket expenses for plaintiffs and impose awards for pain and suffering. It may also mandate a sale or rental.
People who believe they have been discriminated against may also sue in Federal Court under the Federal Fair Housing Act and with the state's Division of Human Rights, which has its offices in New York City.
The state and Federal laws are less inclusive than city's antidiscrimination laws, however, because they have a shorter list of protected groups.
All three governments guard against housing discrimination based on race, color, creed, sex, national origin or handicap. The state and city antidiscrimination laws also cover marital status and age, while the Federal law was recently amended to ban discrimination on the basis of ''familial status,'' meaning the presence of children, in housing. Only the city also protects homosexuals and people who are infected with HIV, the virus that is the precursor to AIDS.
One or more of these categories must be alleged when bringing a housing discrimination complaint against a co-op board because the boards can be compelled to discuss their reasons for rejecting someone only if the turned-down buyer is in a protected class.
Armando Martinez, special assistant to the state Human Rights Commissioner for Fair Housing, said that what the city is finding in Brooklyn and Queens his division sees in the rest of Long Island.
''There's no question about it,'' he said. ''We have done several studies on this, and it appears clear that as the co-ops move out to Long Island, the housing becomes more expensive and that leaves a lot of minorities out and a certain group can be turned down by the co-op board because of discrimination.''
The Federal Fair Housing Act has been the favorite venue for settling charges of race or sex discrimination in housing, officials say, because since it was amended in 1988 there have been no limits on punitive or compensatory damages that may be awarded.
Last Monday, the largest housing discrimination settlement ever was announced when a Los Angeles apartment house landlord agreed to pay $450,000 to Allan Lopez, Rob Beaumont and the West Side Fair Housing Council in a settlement of a charge of discrimination brought by the NAACP Legal Defense Fund.
In 1984, the Federal Court in Manhattan handed down a landmark racial discrimination case in favor of Bertha Rogers, a black city school teacher and real estate investor, and against the co-op board at 66-36 Yellowstone Avenue in Forest Hills, Queens.
The court awarded Ms. Rogers $26,000 for expenses after it found that the board had violated her rights in turning down her application for ownership when it refused to believe she had accumulated $250,000 in savings lawfully. Since that ruling, co-op boards have been warned by their lawyers not to inquire too closely into the source of would-be buyers' resources.
THE New York State Attorney General's figures on conversions tell the story of the spread of cooperatives into the outer boroughs. In 1984, there were more co-op conversions in Manhattan, 10,200, than in Brooklyn and Queens combined, with 9,600. In 1988, the last year for which complete figures are available, Brooklyn saw 10,500 apartments turned into co-ops, Queens had 9,000, and Manhattan trailed both with 8,300.
The Bronx has seen a similar increase, from 700 units in 1984 to 3,200 in 1988, while the numer of conversions on Staten Island, where home ownership has been the tradition, the figure has been fairly constant at under 200 units a year converted.
The city's evolving housing market has introduced another arena for the Human Rights Commission, Mr. Gurian noted. That is the rapid increase in the number of investor-owned condominium and co-op apartments - there are about 100,000 scattered around the city at present - that are being privately rented and sold on an unadvertised, word-of-mouth basis by ''mini-landlords.''
The more apartment ownership is fragmented among many owners, some owning only one or two units, Mr. Gurian said, the less open the market for these properties is likely to be to groups facing prejudice and discrimination.
Although most of the commission's open-housing work still focuses on rental housing, its investigators have in recent months received a number of complaints from rejected co-op buyers complaining of discrimination.
Jan Edler and his wife, Janet Simmons, won a decision by one of the commission's five law judges, Cynthia W. Rountree, on Jan. 3 against Concord Village, in downtown Brooklyn on the ground that the co-op had rejected them because they were not married at the time.
Under the commission's system, the administrative law judge's decision is a recommendation to the full 15-member commission for a final order. The loser can then appeal to the state courts. The commission often orders a board to put a ''hold'' on a disputed apartment, pending the outcome of appeals, when it finds in favor of a rejected plaintiff.
''We applied for this apartment because we had the money, and the last thing we expected was to have a financial problem with the board,'' Mr. Edler said. ''But they they turned us down and they just stonewalled us,'' he continued. ''They said, 'We don't have to give you a reason, you can ask until you're blue in the face and we don't feel like giving you a second chance.' We thought about it and decided that they had no legitimate reason, and that it must have been because we weren't married at the time.''
The Edlers, who have since married, eventually paid $50,000 for a co-op in the former Ex-Lax building on Atlantic Avenue in downtown Brooklyn, more than the $43,000 price of the Concord Village unit and, to them, further proof that they had the money to be reliable members of the first building.
''I think it's clear that we had the funding to close on the apartment at Concord Village, and that that was just an excuse,'' Mr. Edler, a research scientist at New York University, said. ''It's obvious that that was just an excuse. It's also conceivable that they just made a bad call, but they're not allowed to do that. Marital status is protected like anything else, and you just can't make a mistake on something like that and get away it with it.''
But Adrienne Baker, president of the board of Concord Village, said in an interview that a co-op board must look beyond whether a buyer can assemble enough money to close on a purchase, It also must determine whether the would-be buyer's income is sufficient for a long-term ownership in a building whose future costs are hard to predict.
''IT looked like they were depending on future salary to make the closing costs, and everything else was borrowed,'' she said. ''We have to ask ourselves if there is an assessment or the maintenance goes up 5 percent, what do they do? They may say they'll be making more two years from now, but can they be sure? A co-op board has to consider such things.''
As to the charge of marital discrimination, Ms. Baker had a straightforward response: She is also unmarried, and she shares apartment ownership with her male companion.
''This whole thing is honestly upsetting to all of us, because we know we think of ourselves to be nondiscriminatory and committed to human rights.''
In another case, commission investigators on Feb. 8 held their first hearing in a complaint by Sharon Planer and her husband, Clint Bowie, that the co-op at 85-10 34th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, had rejected them as purchasers because Mr. Bowie is black. The Planer-Bowie case points up the difficulty of establishing bias under a system that gives co-op boards broad powers to pick and choose buyers without offering any explanation for rejections.
Co-ops have successfully resisted several attempts to legislate accountability into the purchaser-approval system with the argument that cooperatives are essentially partnerships that depend on social cohesiveness and cooperation to work.
Clifford Chew, a Great Neck, L.I., lawyer who represents the board at 85-10 34th Avenue, maintained in an interview that the biracial couple had alienated the board by being ''pushy'' and ''obnoxious'' and that racism had played no part in the decision to reject them.
''I don't want to wave the flag, because an accusation of bigotry cuts to the quick,'' Mr. Chew said. ''But this board has to ask, can a co-op board ever turn down a minority without facing a charge of racial bias? If you say you're looking for people who will blend in or fit in, you run into the discrimination trap, but that is really what you are looking for - people with whom you will be comfortable in running a large housing operation.''
Mr. Chew argued that one of the first tests of a co-op is whether the people in it can cooperate with one another. ''Most of the problems co-ops run into will have a social element,'' he said. ''If you're talking about raising the maintenance, you need someone who will be cooperative, if you're talking about a noise problem, you need someone who will see your point of view.''
Ms. Planer rejected the assertion that she had been uncooperative at the board hearings on the couple's application to buy.
''I swear to you, I really felt like they were doing everything they could to destroy me,'' Ms. Planer said. ''They even said they didn't like the way I dressed and that I looked like an unmade bed.''
Mr. Gurian said his department faces a widespread public view that co-op boards are unassailable, while in fact, he said, the boards may be required to explain their decisions if the commission suspects the kind of discrimination proscribed by law.
''The biggest problem we have is getting people to come forward in co-op cases,'' he said.
''If you ask people in the street, they'll tell you a co-op board can accept or reject for any reason, and that's not true. They can only accept or reject for any legal reason, and discrimination is not legal.''
 
FILING A DISCRIMINATION COMPLAINT
To file a housing discrimination complaint with the New York City Commission on Human Rights, a person may make an allegation in person or over the telephone based on the ''information and belief'' that an offense was committed by a landlord or co-op board. Following an investigation, commission officials will either decide that there is probable cause for prosecution before an administrative law judge, or reject the complaint as lacking probable cause.
There is an emphasis on mediation during the investigation, and many cases are settled at this stage. Those that go before the judge are tried by normal court procedure; the judge can dismiss the complaint or recommend a finding and an order to the full commission, which rarely rejects the recommendations and often goes beyond them. No fees are involved.
Besides ordering a sale or rental and damages for pain and suffering and out-of-pocket expenses for a successful complainant, the judge will normally require the board or landlord to take special steps to rectify the discrimination that led to the complaint.
The commission's offices are at 52 Duane Street in lower Manhattan. Call 964-7000 to make fair-housing or public- accommodation complaints.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: A Film Warning;
Perilous Play on Elevators

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
One fad that appears to be gaining momentum among the young in urban areas is climbing atop elevators and riding them up and down the shafts in high-rise buildings.
Once regarded as little more than a prank, this practice is now regarded as extremely dangerous; last year three youths were killed and 42 were injured on these joyrides just in public housing in New York City.
In the last five years, 10 children have been killed and 122 injured in the city's public housing despite the formation of an Elevator Vandalism Squad by the Housing Police of the New York City Housing Authority. Even the installation in many apartment buildings of closed-circuit television monitors and electric eyes that are intended to alert resident managers has been unable to stop the practice. 
In a further effort intended to call attention to the dangers of playing atop or even in elevators, the Housing Authority has just released a 20-minute film called ''Children Are Too Young To Die'' which graphically depicts the harm that this type of play can cause.
''We hope the film will show youngsters in no uncertain terms that playing with these elevators is often playing with injury and death,'' said Emanuel P. Popolizio, chairman of the authority. ''We also hope the film will alert parents to the fact that children are in real danger when they use elevators for purposes other than those for which they are intended.''
Copies of the film, which was written by Val Coleman, director of public information for the authority, and produced by Marc Cerutti, an independent filmmaker, are being made available to the city's Board of Education, as well as to civic and community groups in the five boroughs. Copies of the film may be ordered by telephoning the Housing Authority at 306-3322.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Columbus Avenue;
'Mom-and-Pops' Are Yielding to a New Makeover

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
COLUMBUS AVENUE, which remakes itself every few years, is in the middle of another transformation, marked by a high number of vacancies, lower rents, frequent turnover and the loss of the very stores and restaurants that once epitomized the avenue.
Three neighboring establishments that have done about a century's worth of business among them - the Cherry Restaurant, Grossinger's Home Bakery and Putumayo clothing store - face a shaky future in their present quarters. The Cherry will lose its lease in three days and may be out of business in four months. Grossinger's and Putumayo have other shops, but may disappear from their longtime location at 76th Street.
All three commercial tenants in the Aylsmere apartment house believe they are being squeezed out to accommodate a single business, perhaps a Gap clothing store. 
''To eliminate this section of the block is to destroy the backbone of the neighborhood,'' said Herb Grossinger, who runs the bakery that was founded in 1935 by his parents, Ernest and Isabella. ''To make a go of it, I would have to raise prices tremendously. It's difficult to raise prices on cakes. They're not like Gucci shoes.''
Richard Nishikawa, who took over the Cherry Restaurant in 1966, said he would probably stay open on a month-to-month basis through June, when summer vacations begin to cut into business anyway. ''Maybe that's a good time to quit,'' he said. ''I'm not too well myself. I want to take it easy.''
Both Mr. Nishikawa and Mr. Grossinger were around long before the quiche-fueled gentrification of Columbus Avenue that began in the mid-70's. Putumayo, which has apparel and accessories inspired by folk art, arrived 10 years ago. Its president and founder, Dan Storper, said, ''The implication is that we're all going to be booted out, one way or other, if the Gap signs a deal.''
The issue is not strictly about rent. ''My landlord has been very fair with me over the years,'' Mr. Grossinger said. That sentiment was echoed by Mr. Storper, who added: ''The fair market value appears to be $100 a square foot. We're prepared to pay that.'' But no such choice exists. ''They are not going to renew the lease,'' Mr. Nishikawa said, ''because they are negotiating with people who are going to take over the whole space.''
It is hard to find out what is going on behind the scenes. The Aylsmere is managed by Janoff & Olshan. A man at that office, who refused to give his name, said that ''at the moment, nothing is happening.'' He would not elaborate, saying that the person who could was out of town for 10 days. Before he could be asked much else, the man hung up.
A spokesman at Gap headquarters in San Francisco said the company did not discuss store openings until construction started.
Last year, a Gap was being built in the large space on the north side of 76th Street that was once Dobson's restaurant, another neighborhood institution that has vanished. One of the owners of that building, Dennis Shachnow, said he still has a lease with the Gap and that ''they've been paying their rent nice and promptly.'' He said the work was only ''temporarily stopped.''
Temporary or not, the effect is depressing. The large deserted storefront is covered with plywood boards and a crazy quilt of posters, contributing to the rather forsaken atmosphere that seems to characterize the whole avenue, particularly at night, when darkened shop windows stand out dismally.
Of 239 storefronts in the mile between 66th and 86th Streets, 13 percent - 31 spaces - are vacant, at least for the moment. In a similar count made in July 1987, 18 storefronts stood empty.
The situation is not as simple as what the passer-by sees. Leases have been signed for a number of these empty spots and they may be back in business soon. For example, what was once Miss Grimble's restaurant and cheesecake shop, near 74th Street, now appears vacant but will be a Chase Manhattan Bank annex by mid-year.
The actual vacancy rate may be closer to 5 or 6 percent, said Robert C. Quinlan, a major owner and developer on the avenue who is also president of Walker Malloy, a management and brokerage concern.
ON the other hand, vacancies or potential vacancies may be closer to 18 percent, says Steven B. Greenberg of the Greenberg Group of Hewlett, L.I., which advises retail chains on site selection. He said the citywide rate was less than 10 percent.
''Columbus Avenue has been overrated from the start,'' Mr. Greenberg said. ''It survived through an image. Columbus Avenue, more than any other retailing street in New York, has an enormous rollover of tenants. The volume of business does not support the rents that are being quoted.''
The chairman of Community Board 7, Robert Kupferman, said Columbus had once been compared to Madison Avenue, as the commercial thoroughfare closest to Central Park. ''A lot of fancy boutiques were being told that Columbus was the hot, new Madison Avenue,'' he said. ''But Broadway, midtown and department stores were more typically where West Siders would shop.''
''Broadway has remained more healthy and more fully tenanted,'' said Alan Victor, director of retail leasing at the Lansco Corporation, a commercial brokerage. ''What they tried to create on Columbus was more fashionable and more chic, but it's not Madison Avenue and they couldn't support it.''
Borrowing from Mark Twain, however, Mr. Quinlan insisted that any report of Columbus Avenue's death would be greatly exaggerated. ''Stores aren't doing so well anywhere in Manhattan,'' he said. ''To single out Columbus Avenue isn't accurate.''
''There's a great tendency to get more discouraged than the situation warrants,'' Mr. Shachnow said.
Nonetheless, Mr. Quinlan said, rents were down to about $100 a square foot from $125 two years ago. He said a store that might once have paid $10,000 a year rent for every foot of frontage on the avenue would now be paying closer to $5,000. Even if the vacancy rate is only 5 or 6 percent, as Mr. Quinlan said, that would be a considerable increase from the 1 or 2 percent of recent years.
Mr. Quinlan sees the future of Columbus Avenue more in ''simple, unflamboyant'' clothing stores than in the ''trendy, experimental'' boutiques of years past. ''I think the high-style aspect of Columbus will fade a bit,'' Mr. Quinlan said, ''and there will be more normal, conventional clothes, in a price range where you can spend $50 to $100 for something off the rack.''
''There are some national retailers coming,'' Mr. Greenberg said, ''and that will be helpful because they have staying power. If the revolving-door syndrome of tenants continues, then the problem is going to heighten and the vacancy factor will increase.''
The prospect of big national retailers is not one that cheers Mr. Storper, however. ''It's almost becoming mall-ification,'' he said. ''You can go the Stamford mall and see the same kinds of stores that will appear on Columbus. The Gap and the Limited don't have the soul of community stores that have grown over time.''
Grossinger's, for instance, specializes in a praline ice-cream cake that has been served as bombe glace in fine French restaurants. The Cherry, which has been around more than 40 years, offers eclectic and reasonably priced fare, with teriyaki, chow mein, veal cutlet parmigiana or chopped sirloin steak (for $6.50) on the menu.
And it offers something else. ''I'm from a small town in the South and this was the last small-town thing I had to cling to,'' said the illustrator Mel Odom, who lives nearby. ''Columbus Avenue has gotten so art-directed. This was the last holdout against that, the last place where you didn't have to worry that you weren't dressed right.''
The Cherry, he said ''was like my kitchen,'' a place so comfortable and accommodating that he could - and did - spend hours there, sketching or reading or joining his college friends for a weekly Thursday-night reunion.
Mr. Odom's decade-long patronage is not unusual. ''Most of the weekday evening customers are steady customers who have been coming for years and years,'' Mr. Nishikawa said. But as his neighbor, Mr. Grossinger said: ''It doesn't matter how long you're in business. When they decide they don't want you any more, that's it. The end.''

LENGTH: 397 words

HEADLINE: Valuations

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The fact that property tax assessments on major office buildings have not increased as sharply this year as in the recent past, as reported in ''A Slower Climb in Valuations for Office Buildings'' on Jan. 28, may be slight comfort to the owners of these properties as well as their tenants.
Commercial tenants, most of whom bear the burden of tax escalations, will continue to pay heavily for the privilege of doing business in New York City while small homeowners pay increasingly less of the city's tax levy and far less than their suburban neighbors.
From the writer's vantage point as an attorney specializing in property tax review, our concern continues to be the fundamental inequity of a system that blatantly favors homeowners at the expense of multifamily residential landlords as well as all commercial property owners. 
State law bars annual assessment increases of more than 6 percent for one- to three-family homes and limits annual increases on four- to 10-family dwellings to no more than 8 percent. Increases in assessment for all other property are unlimited. The law allows for assessment at whatever fraction of full value the city chooses, requiring only the same fraction to be used within each of four classes of property.
As a result, multifamily residential and commercial property is assessed on average at a level nearly five times higher than homes. Though the law was intended to preserve relative class shares as they existed in 1981, subsequent amendments have destroyed this concept thereby reducing the homeowner share of taxes by more than 15 percent between 1981 and 1989.
Moreover, as documented in a recent report by New York State's Deputy Comptroller for New York City there are gross disparities in assessment within the same classes of property, and properties in poorer neighborhoods often are assessed at higher proportions of market value than their counterparts in more affluent areas.
As the new city administration unveils its plans for higher taxes it might first re-examine the present assessment system and its increasingly negative effect on the city's economy, the unfairness of which could easily be corrected by assessment of all real property on the single standard of full market value.
 
ISAAC SHERMAN
 Manhattan
 
The writer is a partner in the law firm of Moroze Sherman Gordon & Gordon.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1439 words

HEADLINE: Teachers Say Yesterday's Texts Can't Keep Pace in Today's World

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:
LAST September, when students returned to Granby High School, they were greeted with brand-new social studies textbooks. ''If only we had waited a year,'' said Jeanette W. Wiggin, the school system's director of curriculum and instruction. Within months, the textbooks, which cost $16,000, became outdated by the sweeping changes in the world, especially in Eastern Europe.
School districts throughout Connecticut were caught with suddenly outdated books.
''Even before all this was happening, textbooks were out of date before they were printed,'' said Edward Bourque, Fairfield's Assistant Superintendent. ''But now, you're looking at a 40- or 45-year history which was completely destroyed in a very short period, and it's going to continue.'' 
Because of the sweep of world events - including the growing democratization of the Soviet bloc, the changing role of the Communist Party in the Soviet Union itself and the crumbling of the Berlin wall -social studies teachers are scrambling to update their curriculums.
The social studies consultant for the State Department of Education, Daniel W. Gregg, said he has long believed that textbooks should not be relied upon as the main source of material, and the recent changes have proved the point.
 
Overnight Change
''When events like these happen, it shows how much we rely on textbooks,'' he said. ''It points out a real problem - that in an area like social studies, the changes are very, very rapid. It can change overnight.''
Although some changes always occur between the time a textbook is written and distributed, the rapid pace of today's events has gone far beyond that, Mr. Gregg said. ''In this case, we're talking about a change in perspective,'' he said. ''Probably most teachers grew up with the cold war. It's just an accepted fact. And it's difficult for all of us to believe, right at this moment, that it's over.''
Like other educators interviewed, Mr. Gregg said he does not believe schools will discard their textbooks. Instead, he said, the books will be supplemented by newspapers and magazines. How are texbook publishers coping with the rush of history? ''We're furiously editing,'' said Sharon Barton, executive editor of the social studies division of Scott, Foresman & Company in Evanston, Ill. The company publishes ''History and Life: The World and Its People,'' the high school history textbook used in Granby.
The 1990 edition of the book had just been published when news came that the Communist Party would relinquish its monopoly role in the Soviet Union. ''We had to go into a reprint,'' Ms. Barton said. ''We wouldn't normally update unless it's cataclysmic. And this is really cataclysmic.''
The textbook company generally does a thorough revision of its textbook every three years. It has rushed updates into print only upon events like the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and the resignation of President Richard Nixon, she said.
Addison-Wesley Publishing is distributing a newsletter that focuses on the changes in Eastern European to supplement its textbook ''World History Traditions and New Directions,'' which is used in Norwalk. The company had made newsletters to accompany its economics text, ''but we've never had to do one for history before,'' said Thomas Prehn, executive editor of the publisher's social studies division in Menlo Park, Calif.
Another textbook used in Norwalk, ''Links Across Time and Place,'' is published by McDougal, Littel in Evanston, Ill. The book, published in 1988, was due for a revision, said Mercedes Bailey, product manager for social studies. ''We took out a picture of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and substituted a picture Lech Walesa addressing the U.S. Congress,'' she said. The new edition also expands coverage of Nelson and Winnie Mandela, although news of Mr. Mandela's release from prison in South Africa came too late to be included, she said.
Despite the publishers' efforts to stay current, the speed of changes in the world portends the end of the textbook as a classroom fixture, said Lee Hay, the 1983 National Teacher of the Year, who is now the Assistant Superintendant in East Lyme.
 
Images Replace Words
''The written word is being replaced by the image,'' Mr. Hay said. ''I think this will lead to radical changes in teaching. But many teachers are very uncomfortable with that. There's almost a guilty feeling if you show a film.''
Edward Welsh, who teaches world and American history at Norwalk High School, does not believe the textbook will become extinct.
''You can't eliminate the textbook,'' he said. ''If you teach history, you need to teach the sequence of events.''
 
'Throw the Textbooks Away'
But he acknowledged, ''as for world politics, there isn't a single textbook on the market today that can do it.''
''If you're talking about the Soviet Union, my God! You can throw the textbook away,'' Mr. Welsh said.
With the help of newspapers, he said, he has become accustomed to devoting up to half of his class periods to events that happened the night before.
''It's an unbelievable time,'' he said. ''I really can't describe it. If you study history, one of the things that you stay with is that the really dominant people, the Alexander the Greats and the Napoleons, shape the world. There is no question that 200 or 300 years from now, Gorbachev will be considered one of those. The students can see that, and it opens their eyes.''
Frank Gawle, the 1988 Connecticut Teacher of the Year and the chairman of the social studies department at Enfield High School, said the recent events took him by surprise.
 
Using Other Sources
''Last September, no one in our wildest dreams could have predicted what would happen,'' he said.
Next year, his school will offer a new course, ''The World in Crisis,'' which will deal with the changes, he said. It will use textbooks ''only as background.'' he said.
''I've always believed that if you operate with a single textbook, you're in trouble,'' he said. ''There isn't one with a decent history that deals with Vietnam.''
Carolyn Rosenfield, Norwalk's Assistant Superintendent for curriculum and instruction, said: ''Keeping textbooks up to date is becoming more frightening budget-wise, given the astronomical cost of them. We have to use other sources to fill in between the cracks.''
''Teachers are very creative, so they will be able to supplement these materials,'' Mrs. Rosenfield said.
Francis Lynch, a social studies teacher at Granby High School, said one of the school's textbooks talks about the hard-line approach of the Soviet Union.
''There is chapter entitled 'The Communist World Fragmented,' '' he said. ''But what they're talking about is the fragmentation between the Soviet Union and China. Nothing is said about the Soviet Union and its satellites.''
 
Good Guys and Bad Guys
Dennis Lobo, another Granby High School social studies teacher, who is also the curriculum coordinator, said, ''The approach these textbooks take between the United States and the Soviet Union is they're the bad guys and we're the good guys.''
Mr. Lynch, who also teaches American history at Central Connecticut State University, said he is encountering the same problem with his college textbooks. ''There's a time lag on whatever level you're functioning,'' he said.
''In my advanced high school class, I'm using a college textbook which talks about the thaw between American and Soviet relations but simply didn't anticipate the speed of the change,'' he said. ''So what's happened in the last year or so simply isn't there.''
At Field Publications, the Middletown company that produces My Weekly Reader and other national news publications for students, the recent events ''certainly created chaos around here, because we've had to pull a lot of things apart,'' said Patricia Sears, a company spokeswoman.
Louise Butts, My Weekly Reader's managing editor, said: ''It's been frustrating. The news happens so quickly, and its almost immediately seen on television. There's no way in our printed schedule we can do that.''
The articles, she said, try to anticipate news events by ''raising the question of what might happen.'' For example, a January article on the Berlin wall asked, ''Could there be a united Germany?''
For Mr. Gregg, at the State Education Department, the fact that textbooks are now at least partially outdated is ''a lesson in itself.''
''There is no question in my mind that, 5 or 10 years from now, when you pick up the history textbooks, the last half of 1989 and the first part of 1990 will be very well covered,'' he said.

LENGTH: 876 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT OPINION;
Parents Must Demand Better Principals

BYLINE: By Herbert F. Pandiscio; Herbert. F. Pandiscio has been Superintendent of Schools in Avon for 22 years.

 BODY:
MOST recent education reform has been a ''top down'' effort. The governors of several states and a handful of education commissioners have taken the lead in addressing problems in the schools. In Connecticut, both the Governor and the Commissioner of Education are acknowledged leaders in this area.
Most of the reform efforts address four areas: improvement in teacher salaries, tougher certification requirements, closer adherence to existing education laws and retraining for senior teachers. All these are vitally important to school improvement. These reforms have done much to attract and keep the most qualified teachers and have helped to build public confidence in our schools. 
But the inner workings of the schools, like those of private industry, are often not known to the clients. While information about the schools is more readily available, experience tells me that much of what parents anf the public learn about the schools is not very accurate.
For example, few parents understand the importance of the principal in the development of teachers. Most of the educational research in the 1980's indicates that the building principal has more influence in shaping reform than any other person or group in a school district. But parents usually know far less about the principal's qualifications than they do about their children's teachers.
Why should parents be concerned about the quality of school administrators when many local boards and state education departments are concerned only with the teachers? It's difficult to imagine a major corporation being careless in hiring a manager for an important profit center. Yet many school boards have an inadequate system for insuring that they hire the best candidates for administrative jobs.
I am not suggesting that governing boards have hired incompetent administrators. But they often hire people who are marginally competent because there are so few outstanding administrators available.
Why? The recent enhancement of teachers' salaries and benefits, without a corresponding improvement for administrators, has dramatically closed the economic gap between the two groups. A teacher employed for 185 a year days generally earns more for each day than an administrator. Consequently, many teachers who once aspired to administration no longer do. Coupled with the aging administrative population, this poses a threat to our schools' success.
Local boards and state officials have been remiss in not improving the relative economic status of administrators. Parents tend to believe that administrators have been given the same enhancements as teachers, when this is often not so. Unless action is taken to deal with the shrinking pool of qualified school administrators, public education will face a leadership crisis by the time the present kindergarten classes enter the upper elementary grades.
Once that pool of qualified school administrators has been expanded, administrators must be trained to lead effectively in the new millennium. Teachers are beginning to be treated as professionals. Accordingly, they demand an improved administrative climate in which to work.
Today's teachers want a principal who provides the opportunity for them to be part of a collaborative setting. Gone are the days of dominant, arbitrary leadership, when the principal viewed himself as the school's only visionary.
Creativity, vision, leadership, and brilliance reside in all educators, teacher and administrator alike. Therefore, each person must play a role. Principals, to be effective, must master the skills of collaboration and facilitation. They must demonstrate brilliance, not at pronouncing answers to questions only they have created, but in creating a climate in which all professionals are nurtured.
Where are these principals? Some manage our schools now. Most are yet to be trained, and they will be difficult to hire because the demand for their talents will far exceed the supply.
Parents, particularly those with preschool children or those with youngsters in the early grades, must demand better qualified administrators for their schools. Parents must work with their school boards, urging them to establish administrators' salaries that attract only superior candidates.
Whenever there is an administrative vacancy, parents must ask their board of education to define the criteria for hiring, to establish an attractive economic package, and to give assurances that assessment tools are in place to check candidates' credentials. Parents must know that funds are available to assure that the new administrator continues to receive training while working in the community. And parents should require that an effective and fair assessment process is in place to measure the principal's work.
Boards must place emphasis on hiring administrators who have mastered the skills of collaboration and who demonstrate the ability to work effectively with others. And like businesses, schools must underwrite new administrators' moving expenses.
Unless parents take the initiative in working for these improvements, their children will not be able to derive the maximum benefits from their teachers. Without outstanding leadership, there can be no outstanding schools.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 228 words

HEADLINE: No One Wants Affordable Housing

 BODY:
I think it is very humorous when pro-development speakers invoke affordable housing to justify the latest development action. Who is kidding whom? 
Affordable housing, by its very nature, implies high-density development. Can any rational developer hope to get approvals for a high density subdivision in an area that is already recognized as environmentally sensitive? Developers don't want affordable housing, adjacent landowners don't want affordable housing, potential buyers (neighbors) don't want affordable housing, Long Islanders don't want affordable housing. I wish everyone would stop using the specter of ''affordable housing'' to justify their own motives. When will someone actually do anything?
I am one of the statistics. I am a single white male, 28, with a master's degree. I have a good job, yet I make less than $30,000. Mandatory dual income (no longer an option, not even during child-rearing years) seems to be my only hope for housing.
I'm not whining. My future and direction seem very clear. If politicians, developers, contractors, banks, and all others involved take concrete action toward addressing the affordable housing issue, why should young educated professionals stay? The lure of beautiful New York beaches, becoming more polluted, more crowded, less accessible, can only stretch so far.
 
KEVIN R. DUBOIS
 St. James

LENGTH: 1993 words

HEADLINE: Port Authority's Incinerator Role Questioned

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
A $300 MILLION solid-waste incinerator being built in Essex County with fund provided by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is drawing criticism on environmental and financial grounds as the massive waste-to-energy plant nears completion.
Citizens' groups and environmental organizations say that use of the incinerator will discourage recycling and that its emissions will have a serious impact on the area's already poor air quality.
The Department of the Public Advocate has criticized the project on technical and financial grounds, and a coalition of community and labor organizations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut is questioning the role of the Port Authority as the developer and principal source of financing.
In addition, a Newark-based citizens' group has raised questions about licensing for the corporation that will operate the incinerator.
Supporters of the project, however, maintain that the state-of-the-art resource recovery plant will have minimal impact on the environment, will lower solid-waste disposal costs for Essex County residents and will, once fully operational in late 1990, generate valuable electrical energy along with a handsome return on the Port Authority's $300 million investment. 
The debate surrounding the project underscores the delicate balance that must be reached between public and private interests in dealing with the problem of solid-waste disposal in New Jersey, officials say. That problem, which by legislative mandate rests squarely on the shoulders of county officials, is now approaching crisis proportions, as landfills close and disposal costs soar.
The Essex County Resource Recovery Facility, in the Ironbound section of Newark just north of Exit 15W of the New Jersey Turnpike, is expected to process up to 2,300 tons of refuse a day, generating 60,000 kilowatts of electrical energy - enough to serve about 37,500 homes - when operating at peak capacity.
That, county officials say, along with the fact that only a fraction of the original volume of refuse will have to be placed in a landfill, will substantially lower the cost of solid-waste disposal for Essex County residents. The current cost to dispose of one ton of refuse is more than $100; once the plant is fully operational and all Essex County trash is processed there, the cost is expected to drop to $65 a ton.
Although critics question the reliability of those estimates, local officials believe that they are accurate.
''These are real solid numbers,'' said Nicholas R. Amato, the Essex County Executive. ''These numbers are not make-believe.''
The involvement of the Port Authority as developer and sponsor, Mr. Amato said, is a benefit to the residents of Essex County. The management expertise provided by the authority will ''bring the project in on time and within budget,'' he said, and the financing that the authority has provided will preserve Essex County's bonding capacity.
''We would have had to come up with $15 million in cash up front,'' Mr. Amato said, ''and then another $285 million in bonds.'' That, he said, would have diminished the county's ability to float bonds for other projects in the future.
''The Port Authority is performing a public service,'' Mr. Amato said. ''They're not going into this for a profit motive.''
But the authority's financing of the project through its general revenue bonds may, some officials say, be a problem.
''We here in Bergen County pay a lot of tolls at the bridges and tunnels,'' said Larry McClure, director of the Bergen County Utilities Authority, the agency responsible for disposing of Bergen County's solid waste. ''I have a little difficulty with their using those funds to finance an Essex County facility.''
Port Authority officials, however, say that toll revenues are not being used to support the project and that, in fact, the investment will ultimately help subsidize tolls in the same way that profits generated by the World Trade Center and local airports do now.
''Are we going to make money?'' said Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority. ''I sure hope so. It's not part of our basic and fundamental business, but this is clearly a public need that has to be dealt with if you're going to have an economic base that survives.''
The authority became involved in solid-waste disposal, he said, at the request of officials of New York and New Jersey who urged the authority to ''take the lead in the economic development of the region.''
Critics of the authority's role, however, take issue with that explanation.
''To invest $300 million in a project that will generate 60 permanent jobs is not economic development,'' said Stephen Strahs, director of the Tri-State Economic Justice Network, a coalition of community organizations and labor unions from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Mr. Strahs said his organization was planning to protest the authority's involvement in the project by holding a demonstration at the Newark office of the Port Authority chairman, Philip D. Kaltenbacher, on Tuesday.
''We're taking our message to the steps of his office in Newark and we plan on being heard,'' Mr. Strahs said. ''Instead of building incinerators, the Port Authority could just as easily be involved in sponsoring an effective and environmentally sound recycling operation.''
Rather, he said, ''They're acting like a private company whose only interest is to simply maximize their financial concerns.''
And if the Port Authority is to make money on the project, other critics say, then the corporation operating the incinerator, American Ref-Fuel of Essex County, will be making even more.
''This was a sweetheart deal for the operator and a rip-off for county residents,'' said Rob Stuart, program director for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, a nonprofit environmental and consumer organization in Trenton. The contract between Essex County and American Ref-Fuel, he said, includes a provision that requires the county to pay for a fixed amount of solid waste, in this case 680,000 tons a year, whether the county actually provides that amount of trash or not.
The provision also eliminates any incentive county officials might have to reduce waste through recycling because ''they're still obligated to pay for the cost of delivering that trash to the facility,'' Mr. Stuart said.
Indeed, officials already expect that Essex County will deliver less than the 680,000 tons of waste it is required to pay for.
''Right now, we are falling something a little over 100,000 tons short,'' Mr. Amato said. ''But I think that the situation will, over time, cure itself.''
But if it does not, experts say, Essex County could eventually be partly ''shut out'' from the incinerator it pays to support.
''If the county doesn't deliver its guaranteed tonnage during the first several years of the contract,'' said Joseph Bowring, a spokesman for the Department of the Public Advocate, Division of Rate Counsel, ''it loses its right to that capacity.''
If that happens, he said, American Ref-Fuel, which is based in Newark, can then sign long-term contracts with out-of-county and out-of-state providers to make up for the county's shortfall and any excess capacity that the plant may have.
But, according to the terms of the contract, Mr. Bowring said, county ratepayers will still be obligated to pay for the minimum 680,000 tons.
That payment, called the tipping fee when calculated on a per-ton basis, is designed to cover all the operating expenses of the plant.
Since the tipping fee from the county would cover all operating expenses, and since the company can derive additional profits from additional waste by selling energy, Ref-Fuel might then have an incentive to charge lower rates to outside providers to attract additional trash, he said.
As a result, Mr. Bowring said, Essex County ratepayers could end up subsidizing out-of-county and even out-of-state waste disposal.
And to make matters worse, he said, regardless of the amount of trash supplied by Essex County residents, the contract provides that the county is responsible for transporting and disposing of 100 percent of the ash generated by the incinerator, even ash that results from outside providers.
If a portion of the ash turns out to be classified as ''hazardous waste,'' as was the case recently with the Warren County incinerator, then the cost to dispose of that ash may reach ''astronomical proportions,'' Mr. Bowring said. ''The county,'' he said, ''bought into a bad deal.'' But officials of American Ref-Fuel said that all of the Public Advocate's concerns were addressed by state and local agencies before approval of the contracts between the company and the county.
''We've already dealt with all these issues,'' said William Glover, vice president of American Ref-Fuel. ''The Board of Public Utilities ratified the contracts as an acceptable approach to waste disposal and a fair deal to the county.''
Indeed, these and more than a dozen other concerns were outlined in a 33-page report prepared by the Public Advocate's office in May 1987, before approval of the contract by the Board of Public Utilities. The board subsequently approved the contract without specifically addressing the changes urged by the Public Advocate's Division of Rate Counsel.
''The board is not required to rule on whether the contract is just or reasonable,'' said George Dawson, a spokesman for the Board of Public Utilities in Newark. ''It is only required to make a finding as to the public interest. The advocate's report was a part of the review process.''
Mr. Bowring said that notwithstanding the board's decision to ratify the contracts, the ratepayers of Essex County have been placed at a disadvantage.
''Our opinion hasn't changed,'' he said. ''It's still a terrible contract.''
But although construction of the incinerator is almost complete and test-burning is scheduled to begin in early summer, there are still legal issues that must be resolved before the plant can begin operating.
The Ironbound Committee Against Toxic Waste, a citizens' group based in the Newark neighborhood that is home to the plant, has filed a lawsuit to force the State Department of Environmental Protection to decide whether American Ref-Fuel can do business in the state. Under current state law, a solid-waste contractor must be licensed by the department before it can begin operations in New Jersey. The company has received a temporary permit.
Michael Gordon, a lawyer representing the Ironbound group, said that if the lawsuit was successful, the Department of Environmental Protection would have to make an immediate decision on American Ref-Fuel's license application. The department, Mr. Gordon said, would have to take into consideration the fact that subsidiaries of American Ref-Fuel's parent company, Browning-Ferris Industries Inc., based in Houston, have pleaded guilty to antitrust violations in other states.
If the license is denied, he said, ''then construction would have to stop and American Ref-Fuel would have to find someone to purchase the project.''
Mr. Glover said the company supported the state's licensing procedures and was ''confident that the Department of Environmental Protection will find American Ref-Fuel to be a totally suitable operator.''
The suit, which was recently argued in the Appellate Division before a three-judge panel, is still pending.
In the meantime, and while waiting for the court's decision, the Ironbound group has joined forces with the Tri-State Coalition to protest the Port Authority's involvement in the project on Tuesday.
''There's nothing that can be done about their current involvement,'' said Arnold Cohen, spokesman for the Ironbound group, ''but we can really raise the roof if they try to expand the thing. The Port Authority should not be building incinerators. They should be about the business of transportation.''
