HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Where Did This Name Come From?

BYLINE: By Abraham Resnick; Abraham Resnick is a professor of social studies education at Jersey City State College and a textbook author whose works include ''New Jersey: Its People and Culture.''

 BODY:
A TRIP over New Jersey's highways and byways could become much more interesting if the automobile passengers - especially families with young children - engage in a hypothesizing exercise about how certain places got their names.
Since the state is so highly urbanized, there are more than 10,000 names that can be used for research or conjecturing - ranging from familiar ones like Bergen and Weehawken to lesser known ones like Ongs Hat and Penny Pot.
A list of 920 New Jersey place-name origins was compiled when the State Library Commission, in 1938, sponsored a research project that was carried out by the Federal Writers Program of the Work Projects Administration. The researchers delved into state and local histories and folklore and conducted interviews, and the study resulted in a publication, ''The Origin of New Jersey Place Names.'' 
There appears to be a renewed interest in the state's toponymy, the study of the origin of place names, with the intent of learning about the history and geography of an area. County historical societies have published studies about their areas. Their researchers were confronted with the same problem encountered by the W.P.A. writers: some of the information uncovered was speculative and contradictory.
Legendary accounts had to be closely checked for validity whenever possible. Names with Indian origins often proved to be unclear. Nevertheless, most of the place-name authenticity has been reasonably established.
It is not essential to refer to a gazetteer to become a toponymy enthusiast, although the New Jersey Gazetteer is a treasure trove of information. The State Department of Transportation has also produced an extensive list of places. Suppositions about names can readily be made by examining the names on a map: then the assumptions can often be verified when one is traveling about. Welcome signs sometimes explain the origins of a town's name, and historical markers and libraries are other excellent sources.
Names give a place an identity and an image, but most of all, they tell about its site, and topographical features and something about its past. Collectively, they are like characters in a regional folk story.
Unlike states of the Southwest, where many names are Spanish in origin, or Louisiana, where the French left their mark, New Jersey has predominantly English names. The state is named for the island of Jersey in the English Channel, birthplace of Sir George Carteret, one of the grantees receiving the Jersey land tract from James, Duke of York.
But Newark was apparently not named after England's Newark, as many people have thought. A number of scholars have returned to an earlier theory that the New Jersey city was originally named New Ark, or New Work, by the Puritan Congregational Church.
The Dutch presence in the state is indicated by such names as Bergen, Barnegat and Cape May, named for the Dutch explorer Cornelius Mey. In South Jersey, two names can be traced back to the Swedish and Finnish settlements along the Delaware - Finn's Point and Swedesboro.
During the later settlement periods, settlers chose to honor their native cities or countries. Such names as Vienna, Cologne, Stockholm, Bayonne, Berlin, Hamburg, Hibernia, Interlaken, Lodi, New Lisbon and New Russia are examples.
There is also a New Egypt, but its origin has no connection with Egyptian immigrants. The name first appeared in 1793 as Egypt; the New was added eight years later. There are two theories about the name's origin, both revolving about the supply of corn in the area; people said they were ''going to Egypt for corn.''
More than 190 New Jersey place names are said to be of Indian origin. Matawan, Secaucus, Weehawken, Paramus, Manasquan, Totowa, Mahwah, Metuchen and Rahway stem from Indian terminology. Perth Amboy combines an Indian term, ''ambo,'' which has various meanings, with the prefix Perth, honoring the Earl of Perth.
A broad array of men are honored by having places named for them. Audubon was a naturalist, Hudson an explorer, Kearny a general, Edison an inventor, Caldwell a parson and Emerson a poet. Paterson was named for a governor, Trenton for a landowner and Blairstown for a financier. Clark honored a signer of the Declaration of Independence, and Woodbridge's name was a tribute to a leader of settlers. New Brunswick's name was derived from King George II, Duke of Brunswick. In addition, scores of towns are named after the family names of their founders. Some pay tribute to founders' wives and daughters; Elizabeth, for example, was the wife of Carteret. Dorothy and Florence are found on a New Jersey map as well.
A few place names recall a special event - for instance, Washington Crossing, the site on the New Jersey side of the Delaware where George Washington and his troop-laden boats landed before the surprise attack on Trenton. At Double Trouble, a dam was washed away twice within a week, and Ship Bottom is a name linked to an 1817 disaster in which, after a storm, a ship was washed ashore with its hull bottom up.
In the western part of the state, Califon is believed to have been named during the California gold rush, because an enterprising mill operator sold a special cattle feed that resembled gold.
Early religious influences are evident throughout New Jersey in such names as Bethlehem, Tabernacle, Jericho, Zion and Zarepath.
Conclusions can be drawn about economic activities that were once significant for specific areas. Such names as Glassboro, Tansboro, Farmingdale and Stafford Forge tend to be quite explicit, as do Lumberton, Copper Hill, Milltown (a name that seven communities share), Mine Hill, Quarryville and Keyport.
Names of places that take on some aspect of the local geography are common, ranging from High Point to Short Hills. There are Stillwater, Deepwater and Changewater; Oakhurst, Maple Shade and Cedar Grove.
Not all of New Jersey's place names are so easy to explain. Some are hard to locate on a map. There may be formidable challenges in the search for the true origins of such interest-arousing names as Buckshutem, Treasure Island, Apple Pie Hill, Tranquility, Foul Rift and Mount Miser. Finding out how Penny Pot, Retreat, Helmetta and Cheesequake got their designations could be fun.
Ongs Hat, for example, is believed to have been named for an 18th-century tavernkeeper, Jacob Ong, who, it is said, painted a hat on his tavern sign, or was slighted by a young woman who flung his hat into a tree.
Then there is the community of Pole Tavern, which is said to have taken its name from the first liberty pole erected in New Jersey. The pole stood in the center of the village in front of the tavern, a scene of much activity during the outbreak of the Revolutionary War.
It would take a special effort to uncover why there is a Timbuctoo in New Jersey. After all, the ''real'' Timbuktu, the ancient caravan city, lies on the southern edge of the Sahara Desert in Africa.

HEADLINE: Continuing the Fight Against Illiteracy

 BODY:
The magnitude and urgency of the problem of functionally illiterate adults in New Jersey was well documented in the article ''Programs Combating Increase in Illiteracy'' (Jan. 14). But the generally upbeat tone of the report was somewhat belied by the statistics cited in its concluding paragraph. 
Particularly of note is the statement that current tutoring programs ''are reaching only about 5 percent of those who need them,'' according to the State Department of Education.
Because so much still needs to be accomplished in combating this problem, heightened public awareness of the economic and social consequences of the state's high rate of adult illiteracy should be a priority of the media. It was this belief that prompted New Jersey Press Women to convene the conference at Drew University to which the article referred.
It is obvious from the data that far greater resources will have to be expended, by government, industry and private groups.
While it is only fair to report, and gratifying to focus on its positive aspects, the battle against illiteracy, particularly of adults, is not a ''success story.'' It is up to the media to keep the spotlight on this deepening crisis.
 
EDITH SCHAPIRO
 President
 
New Jersey Press Women
 Rochelle Park

LENGTH: 1225 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
IN the asphalt potluck called Hoboken, people like Angela Servello say that when the wind blows down from the river carrying the musky smell of coffee from the Maxwell House plant, it's going to rain for sure.
Sixty-five miles away in Camden - poor, weary Camden - Mangaliso Davis and others who grew up in the shadow of Campbell Soup's Market Street plant say that whenever they stick their heads out the window for some night air, they know what's cooking down at Campbell's.
Such shared experiences, say planners and policy makers, are what make cities communities and tie people to them. City people say it simply is the way things have always been.
But probably not the way they always will be. Campbell's, now going through internal reorganization as it fights off a corporate takeover, is moving its last jars of Prego spaghetti sauce off the line of its old brick plant in Camden. At the end of next month, it will close. More than 900 workers will be laid off. For the first time in almost 100 years, Campbell's will not make any food in Camden. 
Things are almost as bleak in Hoboken. Rumors that the Maxwell House plant on the city's waterfront is shutting down float through Hoboken every couple of years. But last month the General Foods Corporation, which owns Maxwell House, scared the heck out of its 640 workers there when it confirmed that because coffee consumption had dropped sharply, it was reviewing its operations and would decide by the end of this year to close either the Hoboken plant or the other Maxwell House production site, in Jacksonville, Fla.
New Jersey is no stranger to factory closings, but these two will stand apart from the others. For one thing, the fact that they could come so early in the new decade of the 1990's is viewed by some economists as a signal that New Jersey has not yet stanched the hemorrhaging of factory jobs. The state lost about 90,000 blue-collar jobs in the 1970's and thought the worst was over. Then in the 1980's more than 133,000 manufacturing jobs disappeared.
''In the 80's, the impact of these losses was masked because the substanial growth in office jobs offset the declines,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of labor statistics for the United States Department of Labor. ''Now this hemorrhaging becomes a more serious focus of concern in New Jersey because there isn't the other growth we had before in the office sector.''
Mr. Ehrenhalt said he was worried that the loss of Campbell's, and perhaps of Maxwell House, could mean that the 90's would not be kind to New Jersey's industries, which still represent 650,000 jobs, about 20 percent of all jobs.
Of course, both Camden and Hoboken will survive the closing of one more factory, even if, as is the case in both communities, it is the last major blue-collar employer in town. But again these two represent significant social shifts because of what they mean to the cities in which they have operated for so long.
Campbell Soup was not just another company in Camden. For many people it was Camden, its red and white label a symbol of how much this city by the river could do if it had a mind to.
Until the late 70's, the city's rhythm was determined by the plant's production schedule. Workers were not allowed to take vacations in August or September because that was tomato harvest season. Hundreds of trucks from the southern New Jersey flatlands snaked through city streets, spilling tomatoes near potholes until the streets ran red.
Youngsters, Mr. Davis says, would grab some of those loose tomatoes, keep the good ones and use the rest as ammunition for fights with the truck drivers. The drivers, who were weary of waiting to get into the plant, would try to splat a ripe one on the head of a streetwise kid.
In Hoboken, Maxwell House once employed whole families, many of whom lived in the city and walked to work. Traffic used to come to a standstill on Hudson Street when Maxwell House changed shifts. Most walked home, stopping at stores or bars on the way.
A tavern on 11th Street, a block down from the plant, is still called Maxwell's, although rock bands now play there. The ''Good to the Last Drop'' sign on top of the factory is what many New Yorkers think of when they think of Hoboken.
Officials in both cities try to make the best of the situation whenever they talk about the threat of a plant closing. Mayor Aaron A. Thompson says that Camden ''is not going to roll over and play dead'' when Campbell shuts the plant. He points out that the company will still keep its headquarters and 1,800 office workers in the city, although there are rumors about those jobs leaving too.
Patrick Pasculli, the Mayor of Hoboken, thinks Maxwell House can be persuaded to stay, and he wants it to because the company diversifies the city's shaky tax base. But if General Foods does decide to ride with Jacksonville and shut down Hoboken, it will probably be because it believes that the 24 acres of waterfront property will be worth more for real-estate development than for making coffee.
As it is, the Maxwell House plant is about the only part of Hoboken's once brawny waterfront that still works with its hands. It reminds everyone that gentrified Hoboken was once a working-class town. But the Port Authority piers shut down in the 1970's, the shipyard in the 80's. Most of the waterfront now is either vacant or being cleared to make way for new office buildings and apartment complexes that could be built as soon as the real-estate market gets stronger.
In that sense, Hoboken is in better shape to absorb the loss than is Camden. But both cities will forfeit some intangible part of what makes them communities, just as they did when the local theater went dark and the neighborhood soda fountain junked its red leather stools.
''It's another thread in the fabric of our community that we could lose,'' said Peggy E. Thomas, director of Hoboken's Department of Planning and Community Development. ''It cannot be replaced.''
Data processing doesn't smell like anything. You can't take a whiff outside an office building and figure out what is going on inside. The smells of old factories like these, and like Colgate-Palmolive in Jersey City or the Pabst brewery in Newark, tended to connect the neighborhoods of a city, pulling them together in a way that years later can exert a strong pull over people who have long since moved away.
Eventually, it could be that all such operations are removed from New Jersey cities and that when they're replaced by office buildings the neighborhoods will look and smell more and more like suburbs.
''It's hard to add up all the little individual losses, but collectively the effect of such things on a community is very great,'' said Lawrence O. Houstoun Jr., a planner in Cranbury who admits to having a soft spot for the past and its symbols. Though his profession involves laying out new communities - be they an office park, a downtown shopping district or a whole new town - he says that such strong community totems as Campbell's or Maxwell House are almost impossible to replicate and that their absence ''subtracts something from people's lives.''
''I look at my daughter, who's 10,'' Mr. Houstoun said, ''and I just don't know what her identifications with community will be when she's my age. I really don't.''

LENGTH: 1034 words

HEADLINE: More Than Counting Heads

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
IT still asks homeowners if they have indoor plumbing, and there are 232 communities in Mississippi that currently do not. It asks if the kitchen has a sink, range and refrigerator, and there are thousands of illegal apartments, including hundreds in Westchester, that do not.
Next month, the 21st United States Census form will be mailed to 250,000 Westchester addresses in a $2.2 billion national effort - and a $3 million county effort - that will determine voter representation in Congress, redraw local political boundries and allocate Federal, regional and local financing into the next century.
This year's count is the largest and most complex survey yet undertaken by the Census Bureau, as it sets about describing the education, training and domestic life of 250 million people. Each of the nation's estimated 106 million housing units will receive a questionnaire, mostly by mail. Census staff members will personally visit residents of remote villages from Alaska to upstate New York, elderly residents of nursing homes, college students in dormitories and the homeless in shelters and on street corners. 
 
The Challenge in the County
Each region of the country offers its own set of challenges, but census officials covering Westchester are particularly concerned about recruiting the estimated 1,700 full- and part-time workers needed to complete the mammoth survey in a county where unemployment last month stood at 3.3 percent.
''Unemployment is so low, we are concentrating on full-time employees who may want to earn extra income in the evening,'' said Donald R. Byrnes, manager of the Census office in White Plains. High school and college students and the elderly are also being targeted for the survey work, which pays an average $7.50 per hour.
Counting Westchester households will provide a different kind of challenge because so many residences are ''hidden'' and want to remain that way, Mr. Byrnes said. Homeowners with illegal apartments may decide to omit mention of their tenants when filling out the census forms, Mr. Byrne said, fearing that the tenants will be evicted or that their property will be reassessed.
 
Confidential for 72 Years
The information is confidential, protected by Federal laws that prohibit any institution, including welfare agencies, immigration, military and tax authorities from gaining access to census material. Information from the 1990 Census will be kept confidential for 72 years, Mr. Byrnes said, until the year 2062.
Census Bureau officials estimate that each respondent represents $200 worth of services in a given community, funds that will be lost if the individual fails to respond.
''A lot of people think it is just a head count, but the census is far more than that,'' Mr. Byrnes said. ''A small shortfall can really afect a community. Just missing 10 people in a small town can equal $2,000 in one year, money that could help pay for an additional police cruiser, for example.''
 
The Effect in Yonkers
In Yonkers, where ''lots of people don't want to be counted,'' Mr. Byrnes said, ''the effect can be pretty harsh.'' Yonkers, like most urban centers in the county, has significant numbers of people living illegally in public housing, Mr. Byrne said, a population that depends on Federal help.
Census facts have helped communities address a number of specific problems, said the Department of Commerce, which administers the Census Bureau. The high number of working mothers the census identified in one community helped speed approval for a day-care center; the large number of older people in another helped that community gain approval for a community center.
Census officials are also concerned about the growing cynicism with which a society flooded with ''junk mail'' may greet another piece of mail addressed to ''occupant.''
The envelope is marked ''official business'' and has ''U.S. Census'' clearly marked on the outside. But ''lots of junk mail looks official these days,'' Mr. Byrnes said. ''Besides, the return address says Jefferson Valley, Ind.''
 
'A Law With No Teeth'
Responding to the census is required by Federal law, but Mr. Byrnes said: ''It's a law with no teeth. There are no penalties other than to yourself and to your community.''
Between March 23, when the long and short forms are mailed out in Westchester, and April 1, the deadline for mailing them back, one member of every household is expected to answer 14 basic questions about the race, ethnic origin, age and marital status of each member of the household.
One out of every six households will receive the ''long form,' which asks 45 additional questions about ancestry, employment, education, income, type of housing and utilities. From April 23 to June 6, hundreds of field workers will be deployed to follow up on those who don't respond.
Although census officials in the county expect close to a 75 percent response by the end of April, ''that still leaves 75,000 households to visit,'' Mr. Byrnes said.
 
Counting the Homeless
On March 20, a few days before the census forms are mailed, Westchester census workers will conduct a special 12-hour count of the county's homeless population. Beginning at 6 P.M., they will visit shelters and certain street locations that the police have identified as popular spots for the homeless to gather.
A number of other steps have been taken to assure an accurate census count in the county. Fliers with the slogan ''If you're not counted, you don't count'' have been mailed to schools, churches and community centers. In early January, a special municipal review was completed, identifying 17,700 of an estimated l9,000 housing units that local officials said census planners did not know existed.
A Westchester County 1990 Census Complete Count Committee has been formed to promote public awareness of the census and to encourage public cooperation with it. The committee's co-chairmen are Peter Q. Eschweiler, the county's Commissioner of Planning, and Mayor Richard E. Jackson Jr. of Peekskill.
Those interested in working for the Census Bureau must be 18 and pass a simple comprehension and math test. For more information, call 694-1932.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 26, Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 968 words

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Why Was Sharpton Marching in Yonkers?

BYLINE: By Jennifer Green; Jennifer Green, a native of Yonkers, recently returned to the city after graduating from the University of North Carolina at Greensboro.

 BODY:
WHY would Al Sharpton come to Yonkers? That's the first thought that came to my mind when I read that the black activist, who lives in Brooklyn, was coming here to protest the city's long opposition to building equally dispersed low-income housing to spur integration.
Yonkers has always been a community of contrasts. Back in the late 1930's and 40's, it was known as an ideal commuter's neighborhood for people who worked in New York City. The emigrations of black people from southern states, from 1945 to 1960, and of Hispanic people from Puerto Rico, changed the complexion of Yonkers. The city still kept minority residents in the southwestern sections while keeping the northeastern part of Yonkers predominantly white. Black and Hispanic people who tried to move into northeast Yonkers were discriminated against. After the turbulence of the civil rights movement and the affirmative-action policies following it became history, minority Yonkers residents began, slowly, melting into the northeastern part of Yonkers. There were still problems. Some who bought houses on the northeastern side reported attempted bombings, as well as racial slurs written on their houses. 
In all this, the voices of the Yonkers minority community have been muted. As a black woman, I have a lot of trouble empathizing with the radicals on either side of this fight. On the one hand, you have people who feel a large number of minority people in low-income housing would mean crime, drugs and low property values. They fear their new neighbors will bring the slums with them.
Unfortunately, these people are so afraid of losing the neighborhoods they worked so hard for that they don't see that the residents for the projected low-income housing sites are working people, just like them. The problem is, if their children stay in the slums, the slums will be in them for life.
On the other hand, you have the radicals, who want to force any housing plan down the throats of people who worked hard to give their kids a better life, a better school, a better chance. They think all middle-class people are imperialistic bourgeois capitalist pigs, Uncle Toms, Aunt Jemimas, assimilationist wimps who have no respect for non-Eurocentric civil rights imperatives. Black people who offer even a mild criticism are ostracized as traitors to the ''cause'' of black people.
Black people in Yonkers aren't radicals. They do, however, resent the implications that they are morally incapable of living in decent neighborhoods because of the twin ''disabilities'' of their color and socio-economic status. The black middle-class community in Yonkers, although small, is very close-knit. It has ties with black organizations that have worked for years to remedy discrimination, like the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. They know racism does exist, not because of good intentions to protect one's own property or children, but because of fear of losing these things.
I honestly don't know if Mr. Sharpton and his associates are radicals. Undeniably, however, they have a different perspective on minority relations than the one that exists here. New York City's advancements are clear in the election of Mayor David Dinkins. There is racism in New York City also, but there is more opportunity now for genuine change.
Yonkers needs a more moderate perspective: someone who will genuinely listen to concerned but good-hearted people who want to see segregated housing end in Yonkers, but who don't want their neighborhoods to become slums. If I owned a house, I would be afraid of something like that happening to where I lived. What I am afraid of is that Mr. Sharpton's presence will cause the situation in Yonkers to be viewed in a false light. I think we have to start understanding the whole picture. We have to ask ourselves why segregation dehumanizes people and why a radical perspective reinforces the segregation it claims to remedy. The hard-liners on either side don't seem to get it: there is nothing dignified about being called a black woman, a Hispanic man or an Asian man instead of being called a good neighbor.
Yonkers has to own up to its growing interracial heritage. Yonkers has to start dealing with the reality that segregating people on one side of a city will eventually worsen the slum problems middle-class people fear so much. Trying to keep problems insulated in one area is like keeping a volatile gas, under pressure, in a balloon. Just like the bubble, which bursts under pressure, scapegoating the residents here and not dealing with the problems afflicting southeast Yonkers will make those problems strong enough to spread outward on their own.
I would feel more comfortable if Mr. Sharpton had a history of working with Yonkers, promoting a progressive perspective that didn't rely on color so much as on a desire for justifiable change in the way things are done. At one time he criticized an N.A.A.C.P. leader as an ''Aunt Jemima,'' which makes me feel hurt and disappointed.
Getting such outside help, from New York City, may be a mixed blessing. It may bring Yonkers more exposure, but it won't facilitate the attitude change that must occur about why desegregation is necessary. This must be understood by Yonkers residents themselves. Being tough may be good for show, but it won't address the problems on a humane level. It won't stop the stalemating of desegregation initiatives.
Why shouldn't Mr. Sharpton have marched in Yonkers? No reason, but I would have liked it if he had unified the white and minority communities who genuinely want change, not just appealed to or inflamed the radical elements on both sides. Yonkers resident must still deal with this themselves. We should stop fighting the integration plan and move forward, together.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 3, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1669 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: MICHAEL LEVIN;
Private Analyst Tracks Public Spending

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
SHIFTING the spending categories in the state budget will cost more in the long run, says Michael Levin, the vice president of the Connecticut Public Expenditure Council, which monitors government spending.
The council, a private research organization that was started in 1942 and is financed largely by corporate contributions, is entering its busiest time of year, as it begins analyzing the Governor's annual budget proposal and prepares to study the budgets that will be presented by the state's 169 municipalities over the next few months.
Mr. Levin came to the council nine years ago as director of research after more than 10 years as a budget analyst with the Massachusetts House Ways and Means Committee.
In an interview at the council's offices in Hartford, Mr. Levin talked about the budget process. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:
Q. Why are there so many interpretations of the Governor's budget this year? 
A. That has to do with what's gone on in the last three years with the budget process in Connecticut. We have debased it in a certain way, in the same way the Federal budget process has been debased. In 1989, we started to see a downturn in revenues, but we still had a lot of money squirreled away that we had built up during the good times in the 1980's.
We were able to keep spending high by relying on these surplus pots of money, which was a bad philosophy, not because of what we were spending the money on, but because we really didn't have the money.
We violated a rule of budgeting, whether it's private or public, in that we used nonrecurring revenues to fund recurring, or operating, expenses, which began our decline.
So we have relied increasingly on putting some money ''off budget'' - putting it into bond funds, taking money out of the transportation fund. With all these shifts and gimmicks, it's very hard for an outside party to say how much the budget is actually increasing. It depends on what you're counting. Also, it's hard to say what's being achieved or not achieved in a given budget. The net result is confusion. If everything were kept in one fund, and you said, ''I paid for this last year, and I'm paying for the same thing this year,'' you'd be able to compare.
Q. What kinds of shifts are in this year's budget?
A. The Governor proposes to take about $291 million that last year was funded in the general fund and put it off budget. A lot of it is going to the bond fund. Some of it's going to the revenue of the Connecticut Housing Finance Administration. If you put it back and left things the way they were last year, spending would be going up about 8.7 percent, which you could call the real spending increase.
Another $76 million is simply not being paid this year - that's one-quarter of the payments to the teachers' retirement fund. The state is only going to make three quarterly payments next year, and the last one the following year. Then a big part of it is coming from another fund we had established when the times were good, the local property tax relief fund. It was supposed to give out $42 million per year for 10 years, but now they're going to use maybe $140 million this next year, and it's going to pretty much wipe out this fund.
Q. All that sounds like complicated bookkeeping. What does it mean to the taxpayer?
A. There hasn't been much outrage over the use of gimmicks. I don't know why, but I have some speculations. People are so cynical about the way budgeting occurs at the state level and government level that they don't really care, unless they get a tax increase. And some of the money being taken out of the budget is not going to come back, according to the Governor's claim. So there is a certain constituency that supports what the Governor is doing.
I don't know if you could say it's a ''so what'' for the average person, but it's not going to affect them a lot in terms of everyday living right now. I think it's important, though, for a couple of reasons. This kind of practice can lead to a tax increase the following year.
While not all of it's coming back to the budget, between $100 million and $200 million, depending on how you count it, could come back. The second reason is we're going to pay these costs no matter where they're put. And in some cases the bill will be higher.
If you shift something to the bond budget, you have to pay twice as much for it because of the interest costs. For school building projects, we're really paying four times, because the towns finance the projects, and the state reimburses them. But now the state is going to pay that reimbursement out of bond money. We're borrowing money to pay off their borrowed money. It's costing us a lot more.
Q. What difference does it make if the state or towns run a deficit?
A. When you run a big deficit, it means you can't do your job, and it forces you to borrow money to pay for things. All the interest you pay, that's money you can't have for something else, like highways or housing or social programs.
On the state level, the state has a balanced budget amendment. In this state, we have kind of a weak amendment that allows us to carry it into the next year, but we have to wipe it out the next year. It's the same with local budgets.
To the extent you run a deficit, you have to restrict your program growth or increase your revenues. For a town, that means you raise the property tax or cut programs.
Q. Why are expenses increasing so much quicker than revenues?
A. At the state level, there are two points of view. One group says the state has a lot of unmet needs. Another group, which I would put myself in, says, ''Yes, we have needs, but your needs will always exceed your revenue.'' It's the nature of life.
Our group would say we take on a lot more than we have to take on. For example, we took on a teacher salary program that raised salaries by huge amounts. We didn't have to do that. We could have done a smaller program and had the same effect. You have to live within your means.
So there's always a tension between those two groups, and in this state, in the last 10 years, that first group has been in power.
Q. Has the Connecticut tax burden gone up in recent years?
A. You have to answer that question in two ways. If you look at taxes as a percent of personal income, that burden has not gone up substantially in the last 10 or 15 years. We have a lot of personal income, so you could argue we have the ability to pay. But if you look at per capita tax, we've skyrocketed. A lot of people say that isn't the best measure, but it's one measure.
We're fortunate that our income has been growing, but if our income growth slows down, the tax burden relative to income could grow quickly, because slow income growth won't automatically trigger slower spending. The problem is, has the increase been in needed spending? Just because you have a lot of income, you don't have to spend it.
Q. What kind of things should people be on their guard for in municipal budgets this year?
A. Municipal budgets are going to be very troublesome this year. State aid is being constricted. And on the other side, the spending, is still going to be quite high because of mandates put on cities and towns, like binding arbitration for contracts.
A big issue for state government is to give towns the tools to constrict their own spending growth. They can do certain things now that they might not want to do, such as laying off teachers. They probably would prefer to give a smaller salary increase and keep the teachers on.
Q. Support seems to be building for an income tax. What are the council's views on an overhaul of Connecticut's tax system?
A. I think there have been more people come over to this camp in the last few years. There always was a lot of support for an income tax in the corporate community. It's probably still a minority, but a larger minority. Our position is it remains a viable option, but Connecticut has shown an inability to get its fiscal house in order, which would be a sign to taxpayers and to groups like ours that we could support a balanced tax system.
For instance, there's been opposition to a constitutional spending limit. Some of the states that have one don't have an income tax. The argument in Connecticut is, we don't have an income tax, so we don't need a constitutional spending limit. But we're still spending the money.
I'm not sure we have the best tax structure to go into the 1990's with, but I'm not sure the elements are there to do real reform. The biggest supporters of an income tax just want to raise more revenues, which undercuts their effort to change and reform the system.
Q. If the towns and the state government were businesses, how long would they be around?
A. I think they'd be around. We've seen a lot of businesses badly managed, it's not just the public sector that mismanages. And I think the cities and towns generally have a good management record, much better than the state's. One of the things about the property tax is it's very close to the citizenry, so they keep a watch on their own budgets.
I think the state has had problems in the last few years and has to do more to create a better structure for its own budget. Ultimately, though, legislators are responsible, and they do try to address the problems of the state.
You can't compare state spending to inflation. In some areas, like salaries, you could. But in some areas, if the populace decides it wants to do something, like prison spending, you could spend 20 times as much as inflation because the people want it. But you have to strike a balance between the revenues you have the ability to raise and the spending needs you want to fund.
To the extent the state does that, it's doing its job. But in the last few years, it's tilted toward funding those spending commitments all the time, to the detriment of the tax and revenue side. When those get balanced again, the state will be back on the right course.

GRAPHIC: Photo; Michael Levin of the Connecticut Public Expenditure Council, a private group monitoring government spending (NYT/Steve Zavatski)

PERSON: HAMILTON, ROBERT A; LEVIN, MICHAEL MICHAEL MCMAHON (52%); MICHAEL MCMAHON (52%);

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: February 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1984 words

HEADLINE: Legislators Consider State Limits on Atlantic City's Powers

BYLINE: By JAMES RUTHERFORD

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
NO one is talking anymore about a miracle in Atlantic City, about a phoenix by the sea rising from the rust of urban decay. The way some prominent state lawmakers assess the resort's flagging fortunes, what is needed now is a salvage operation.
Recently, a legislative movement has been building to strip Atlantic City of many, if not all, of its significant governmental powers.
The movement comes 12 years after the first bet was placed in a Boardwalk casino, 5 years after former Mayor Michael J. Matthews went to jail for taking a bribe from organized-crime figures, 1 year since a casino went bankrupt and shut down, 6 months since a second casino sought Federal protection from its bondholders, 8 months after the arrest of Mayor James L. Usry and three city councilmen on corruption charges and 2 months after the indictment of Mr. Usry and 14 others in connection with those charges.
Many legislators say they feel that the special status given to Atlantic City as a casino resort has been squandered on corruption instead of invested in redevelopment, and that a crackdown is overdue. 
''It's the one item left from the original Casino Control Act - the last piece of unfinished business,'' said Assemblyman William P. Schuber, Republican of Bogota.
Mr. Schuber is sponsoring the first of at least two bills that would subject the resort's budget and its zoning and planning prerogative to state oversight. Specifically, it would vest that oversight in a seven-member commission appointed by the governor.
The Schuber bill is closely modeled on a more publicized proposal that Richard J. Codey, Democrat of West Orange, plans to submit in the State Senate this spring.
To Mr. Codey and Mr. Schuber, their proposals simply enforce an unwritten compact between the state and Atlantic City that was sealed with the passage of the Casino Control Act 14 years ago, the enabling legislation that granted the city the state's sole franchise on casinos. Mr. Codey was the author of the act.
In return for a sure-fire formula for prosperity, Atlantic City promised to prosper: specifically, Mr. Codey said, to remake itself into the national tourist destination it was in its heyday. This, he said, the city has not done.
''Atlantic City is not doing the job for itself or the rest of the state when we allowed them to have casino gaming,'' he said. ''Atlantic City got what no other urban area in this state ever got or probably ever will get: the greatest urban renewal tool the world has ever seen. And they have not used that to redevelop the rest of the city. ''There is absolutely, positively no excuse for it. It's a disgrace to walk on the Boardwalk today, with all those casinos surrounding it, and all you see are those same rundown, rotten shops that you saw before. The Boardwalk should be a promenade with some of the nicest stores in the state. The business district should be nice, and it isn't.
''Why would a couple from Camden want to spend a weekend in Atlantic City, other than if they were gambling addicts? No reason. They don't have the amenities you need to make Atlantic City a first-class resort destination. I want to see it become that. And it will not as long as what is going on continues to go on.''
Mr. Codey's bill, as yet unwritten, has nevertheless drawn the hottest fire from officials in Atlantic City and the surrounding Shore communities.
Assemblywoman Dolores G. Cooper, Republican of Atlantic City, called the bill an ''outrage'' in a letter sent to Mr. Codey in January. Mrs. Cooper, a candidate for mayor in Atlantic City in a May 8 election, added: ''I intend to lead the fight against this undeniable attack on home rule.''
From the other side of the aisle, Assemblyman Alfred D. Scerni, Democrat of Smithville, has dismissed all talk of state intervention as ''extreme'' and ''premature.''
''I don't think it's necessary or a viable way to manage municipal government,'' he said.
Rosalind Norrell-Nance, an aide to Mayor Usry, said the Mayor and his administration were totally opposed to the kind of takeover proposed by Mr. Codey.
''The only instance where that kind of action is warranted,'' she said, ''is where there have been significant financial problems, and in Atlantic City that has not been the case. The city has an excellent bond rating, and the city budget has consistently operated in the black. There is simply no reason for it.''
Mr. Usry and the other defendants in his case have denied the charges, and he is a candidate in the May election.
Mr. Codey has already retreated several steps from his original initiative, which was to give a state commission powers over land use and transportation within Atlantic City's burgeoning suburbs as well. The plan ran afoul of Senator William L. Gormley, Republican of Margate, who by virtue of his strong showing in the 1989 gubernatorial primary has emerged as one of the most powerful politicians south of Trenton.
Mr. Gormley has indicated that he wants no interference with his own bill to create a regional authority to manage and develop Atlantic City International Airport, 10 miles west of the city in suburban Egg Harbor Township. Plans to expand the airport, seen as a key to the resort's progress, have been mired for years in a political tussle between the city and the county.
''Senator Codey and I have areas of common agreement,'' Mr. Gormley said, ''such as the need for a regional airport and to not have Atlantic City control the airport facility. I feel that in matters of regional concern, Atlantic City should have a diluted level of control.''
Mr. Codey compromised, agreeing to hold back his bill until an airport agreement could be hammered out on the state level.
Further, by early February, when Mr. Codey went to Cherry Hill to address the Chamber of Commerce of Southern New Jersey, he outlined a revised plan under which state intervention in Atlantic City would stop at the city's borders.
Mr. Codey says he intends to press ahead with the more limited - and apparently more politically palatable - alternative, and says there are sufficient votes in both the Senate and Assembly to make it law.
Senator Daniel J. Dalton, Democrat of Laurel Springs and the majority leader, who acted as a mediator between Mr. Codey and Mr. Gormley, has thrown his considerable influence behind the idea that ''something has to be done in Atlantic City.''
 
'Losing of Edge' Is Seen
''Generally, the thought of intervention I am not repulsed by in any way,'' Mr. Dalton said. ''I think if we don't move forward in a positive fashion with regard to intervention in some part of the jurisdiction of the city, then the state and, more specifically, the people of the region will be the losers. Because if things aren't improved, and improved significantly, the city will lose its edge to other governmental jurisdictions that are considering casino gambling.''
Casino proposals have been under consideration in Florida, Indiana and West Virginia, among other states.
Mr. Codey's sentiments have the ardent support of the gambling industry, which submitted a host of complaints of its own to the Governor's office in January in a detailed position paper written by the Casino Association of New Jersey, an industry trade group.
The paper came on the heels of a report by the Atlantic City Expressway Authority that tourism was falling off for the first time since the casinos opened in 1978. The casinos' combined win - the money retained after bets are paid but before other expenses are paid - declined 2.7 percent in January compared with the amount for the same month in 1989, according to figures supplied by the State Casino Control Commission.
Only four properties reported increases from the previous year, despite the fact that there was one less competitor, the Atlantis having shut down in May as a result of a prolonged bankruptcy. Another casino, Resorts International, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code in September.
 
Criticism From the Casinos
The Casino Association paper, in addition to a repetition of its calls for a loosening of state regulations, was highly critical of local officials and requested state intervention in municipal budget and land-use policies.
Nor is it only Atlantic City's future at risk, Mr. Codey said. Sinking fast, or so he fears, is the assurance that the millions of dollars in revenue generated by the industry, and the services they buy statewide, will continue to grow as they have in the past.
''I think legislators, hopefully, will understand that the senior citizens who live in our districts throughout the state have a big stake in Atlantic City because of what Atlantic City casinos provide'' in money to back such programs as low-cost prescriptions for the elderly and the Lifeline utility bill abatement program,'' Mr. Codey said. ''This is not parochial, this is a statewide thing, and people should look at it as that.''
Even Mr. Gormley, acknowledging a growing impatience on the state level, is co-sponsoring a separate bill of Mr. Codey's, which would remove the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority from the city's political influence by making its members serve at the pleasure of the governor.
The bill would allow Gov. Jim Florio to replace the current membership of the agency, which is empowered to invest a 1.25 percent tax on casino gross revenue in redevelopment projects in Atlantic City and throughout the state, and whose leaders have been closely aligned with the Usry administration. The change is among those advocated in the Casino Association's position paper.
One consequence could be to divert the authority's investments from low-income housing, a priority of Mr. Usry's, to the construction of a new Atlantic City convention complex, which the Governor, Mr. Gormley and others have characterized as vital to the city's progress.
 
'A Trustee in Limited Areas'
Mr. Gormley, in the meantime, has outlined his general conditions, which he guardedly describes as ''strictly hypothetical,'' for support of state intervention.
''What I would support would be something in a limited area, a trustee in limited areas to monitor and protect the rights of the citizens of Atlantic City,'' he said. ''But I wouldn't want to see an entity that strips them of their franchise, their prerogative to vote by effectively making Atlantic City the District of Columbia.''
Ms. Norrell-Nance said the city has had to shoulder a disproportionate responsibility to care for the region's homeless and to provide affordable housing for the poor.
''We would welcome state assistance with regard to the social problems that have been dumped on Atlantic City,'' she said. ''We would appreciate some indication that other cities will be made to assume their fair share.''
Mr. Gormley said: ''I can understand there are certain state interests in Atlantic City, but at the same time the citizens of that city should not be limited in their ability to elect officials to make those normal decisions affecting the health, safety and welfare of the community, whether they be good or bad decisions. That's the nature of a democracy.''
The Governor's office has obtained Mr. Codey's promise that it will get to review the bill before it reaches the Senate floor.
Steven Perskie, Mr. Florio's chief of staff, said: ''We're looking at all the issues related to Atlantic City. The position of the administration is that the state has an obligation to take a participatory approach on a partnership basis for the benefit of both the citizens of the region and the state. The form and extent of state involvement is still an open question.
''You can look at it, depending on your perspective, as state interference or state assistance. What we're looking for is the easiest, most efficient and most effective form.''

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: A DISQUIET ON GERMANY;
Bush and Kohl Struggle for Notes of Calm As the Headlong Rush to Unity Gives Pause

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25

 BODY:
President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany spoke at length today about their ''similar views'' and ''common dreams,'' but on the difficult aspects of German reunification, they spoke with distinctly different voices while avoiding outright discord.
Reaching for a word to describe the two countries' views on the sanctity of the German-Polish border, for example, Mr. Bush came up with ''alignment,'' rather than ''agreement,'' as if he and Mr. Kohl found themselves, after two days of meetings at Camp David, on the same road, heading the same way, but with one ahead of the other.
The headlong dash of the two Germanys toward unity - toward what Mr. Bush called ''a golden moment'' in German history - has begun to worry people. This weekend's conference, for all its emollient words, is not likely to calm them, chiefly because the Chancellor, a most artful dodger, spoke much more equivocally than the President. 
 
Worry in Warsaw
Poles are worried that Germany might claim bits of modern Poland like East Prussia and Silesia, where some ethnic Germans still live although their numbers are not known. Poland is so worried, in fact, that it has demanded, so far unsuccessfully, a place at the table where the terms of reunification are to be decided. Czechoslovaks have similar concerns about the Sudetenland. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, ever the Churchillian, seems haunted by memories of World War II. Even President Francois Mitterrand said recently that ''Germans should bear in mind the obligations that link us to each other, as well as European stability.''
Two men in their 70's, both longtime Atlanticists, used the same metaphor on different sides of the ocean this weekend to express the disquiet that many people feel - and that Mr. Kohl and Mr. Bush were struggling to contain.
''The train of German unity is rolling along the tracks,'' said Willy Brandt, 76, the Social Democrat who won the Nobel Prize for improving relations between the two Germanys two decades ago. ''Now we must make certain that nobody falls under its wheels.''
''The West German Government of Helmut Kohl is rushing to achieve its goal of reunification, regardless of the concerns of its allies and neighbors,'' Richard M. Helms, also 76, who headed the Central Intelligence Agency from 1965 to 1973, said in an article in The Washington Post today. ''German reunification has become a kind of runaway freight train that nobody - East or West - seems able to contain. And that doesn't bode well for the future.''
 
Kohl's Phrasing
Though he rejected a central role for Poland in German reunification talks, the President stated crisply, ''The United States formally recognizes the current German-Polish border.'' But Mr. Kohl, for all his talk about the feelings of ''our Polish neighbors,'' for all his protestations that West Germany had no desire to change borders, resorted again to the kind of phrasing that sends shivers up spines in Warsaw and elsewhere in Europe.
''The border question will be settled definitely,'' he said, ''by a freely elected, all-German government and a freely elected, all-German parliament'' - without pre-unification pledges from East Germany or West Germany, in other words, and without the participation of other nations in the decision.
The best Mr. Kohl offered the Polish Government was the bland comment that ''there is a particular interest on the part of the Poles, and I'm sure that in the course of this process, we will find ways and means of adopting solutions satisfactory to everybody.''
Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl also seemed to have different focuses on the question of American troops in Germany.
The President, emphasizing the importance of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and full German membership in it, swept aside recent suggestions that Germany might follow the French pattern, belonging to the organization but not integrating its troops into the NATO command structure. And he insisted that American troops could remain in Germany even if all Soviet troops left.
The Chancellor, on the other hand, emphasized that ''a united Germany has a sovereignty of its own,'' and characterized proposed Soviet and United States troop levels in Central Europe as part of a ''transitional period.''
 
Domestic Political Reality
That did not sound very different from comments last week by Czechoslovak leaders, including the Foreign Minister, Jiri Dienstbier, who said on American television that ''in the long run there is no reason to keep foreign troops on foreign territory if there is no enemy,'' and President Vaclav Havel, who told Congress that ''for another hundred years, American soldiers shouldn't have to be separated from their mothers just because Europe isn't capable of being a guarantor of world peace.''
Each of the leaders was reacting, as politicians almost always do when discussing foreign policy, to the dictates of domestic political reality.
Mr. Kohl feels pressure to move reunification along; he is in a race to get the building blocks of the new Germany in place before the old East Germany collapses. He feels pressure as well because his best chance for victory in the West German elections in December is to identify himself with the great nationalist issue, reunification.
With the end of the long, painful split in sight, furthermore, the nationalist candidate cannot afford to seem to sanction the indefinite presence of foreign troops in Germany.
Finally, competent politician that he is, Mr. Kohl wants to delay as long as possible offending the 8 million to 10 million West Germans with family roots in places like East Prussia and the Sudetenland. If he can avoid making any ironclad commitment to present borders until after the election, so much the better.
 
A New Enemy
Mr. Bush's perspectives, not surprisingly, are different. First of all, he is determined not to run down American military strength too rapidly. With the Soviet Union no longer a credible threat, some American officials have been describing the mission of United States troops in Europe as keeping an eye on Germany, but the President could hardly say that today, so he had a new formulation: the enemy now, he said, ''is instability and unpredictability.''
Remembering the fate of the Weimar Republic, the isolated, disarmed and effectively neutral German state after World War I that set the stage for the rise of Nazism, he is reluctant to permit any distance at all to creep between NATO and a unified Germany. He is also sensitive to the concerns of Poles and of Polish-Americans - a group with considerable ballot-box clout.
But at the same time the President feels compelled to maintain the best possible relations with the Germany that is being born, which may soon be an economic, political and diplomatic power on a par with the United States.

HEADLINE: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: THE GERMANYS;
Bush and Kohl Try to Allay Fears Of a Reunified Germany's Powers

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMP DAVID, Md., Feb. 25

 BODY:
Ending two days of talks, President Bush and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany declared today that there was no reason for anyone to fear the economic, political or military power of a united Germany.
Mr. Bush said they agreed that the nation being reborn in the middle of Europe should be a full member of NATO and take part in the alliance's military structure.
The two leaders played down fears of reunification expressed by some of the two Germanys' neighbors.
''I think we have learned lessons and we do not want to repeat the errors of history,'' Mr. Kohl said at a news conference with Mr. Bush.
''This is not 1945; this is 1990,'' Mr. Kohl said at another point. [Excerpts on page A9.] The Chancellor declined again to say explicitly that he accepted the permanence of the existing Polish-German border. But he offered Poles somewhat more assurance than he has in the past, saying, ''Nobody wants to link the question of national unity with changes in existing borders.'' 
During World War II, Poland was occupied by both Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union. As a result of postwar negotiations, the Soviet Union kept most of the Polish territory it had occupied, compensating Poland by giving it control over eastern Germany.
Various agreements signed by European countries in recent years have confirmed the postwar boundaries. But Poland has been uneasy about sentiment voiced by right-wing parties in West Germany critical of the realignment of territory.
 
Border Question Delayed
Mr. Kohl said at the news conference that ''the border question will be settled definitely by a freely elected all-German government and a freely elected all-German parliament,'' neither of which has yet been constituted. Many Polish officials want the current border to be confirmed before reunification by the separate Governments of East Germany and West Germany.
Mr. Kohl's critics say he is keeping the border question alive to satisfy rightist politicians who want the border to be an issue in the campaign leading up to the West German national elections in December.
On the border question, Mr. Bush was more categorical. He did not allow Mr. Kohl's comments to stand alone, but jumped in to say: ''The U.S. respects the provisions of the Helsinki Final Act regarding the inviolability of current borders in Europe. And the U.S. formally recognizes the current German-Polish border.'' The Helsinki accords were signed in 1975.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Kohl discussed the future of Europe and the pace of German reunification, which has been faster than either leader had expected. Mr. Bush said nothing that would suggest he seeks to brake the rush toward reunification, which he described as ''a golden moment in the history'' of Germany.
 
On NATO Membership
In an opening statement, Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Kohl agreed that ''a unified Germany should remain a full member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including participation in its military structure.'' Mr. Bush thus seemed to rule out the possibility that a united Germany might have a special status in NATO like that of France.
France pulled out of NATO's integrated military commands in 1966, but otherwise remains a full member of the alliance.
Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Kohl also agreed that ''U.S. military forces should remain stationed in a united Germany and elsewhere in Europe, as a continuing guarantor of stability.'' But the President said they also agreed that the land now constituting East Germany should have ''a special military status that would take into account the legitimate security interests'' of the Soviet Union and other countries.
Neither leader defined that special status. They were presumably referring to an arrangement that would exclude NATO troops from what is now East Germany. The Soviet Union has stated that it wants a unified Germany to be neutral.
 
The American Attitude
Mr. Bush said the American position was ''not to be afraid of German reunification,'' but to welcome it. He said he looked forward to the day when the four major World War II Allies would not have to look ''over the shoulders of a democratic unified Germany.''
Similarly, Mr. Kohl said that ''nobody needs to be afraid'' of a united Germany. He said the new German state would have close ties to the United States and be embedded in a European Community moving toward economic union and closer political cooperation.
American and West German journalists posed more questions to Mr. Kohl than to Mr. Bush, who nevertheless volunteered his comments at several points. The West German leader smiled with apparent satisfaction while Mr. Bush spoke at the news conference. Mr. Bush often scowled and squinted while the Chancellor spoke.
The news conference was held in a recreation hall at Camp Greentop in the Catoctin Mountain park, just outside the gates of Camp David.
 
Timetable Not Discussed
Mr. Kohl and Mr. Bush said that the precise details and timetable for German reunification were not decided over the weekend.
Mr. Bush was asked to explain the ''two-plus-four'' formula, under which the two Germanys are supposed to negotiate the economic and political aspects of unification as a prelude to discussions with the four Allies on security issues.
''Those details have not been fully worked out in terms of timing of meetings and things of this nature,'' Mr Bush said. He said the formula was approved by the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the two Germanys on Feb. 13 in Ottawa, ''and we simply have not tried to sit here in Camp David and fine-tune the procedures.''
Mr. Kohl said that swift unification was needed to stem the flow of East Germans to the West. Since Jan. 1, he said, some 110,000 people have left East Germany for West Germany. Their exodus has accelerated the move toward reunification, he said.
 
Expects Separate Elections
Some West Germans have said that the union might be consummated in time for East Germans to vote in West German elections scheduled for Dec. 2.
But Mr. Kohl said he believed those elections would be held in West Germany alone. East Germans vote March 18 for a new government that will presumably negotiate the terms of union with Bonn.
The Chancellor sounded testy when a journalist suggested that other countries should receive assurances on ''borders and security'' before the two Germanys merge. ''The question of German unity is a question of the right of self-determination, and all peoples of this earth have the right of self-determination,'' he said. He made no mention of the legal powers that the World War II Allies technically retain in Berlin and in Germany as a whole.
Mr. Kohl also bristled at the suggestion that a united Germany might drift away from NATO toward neutrality. ''In 1983,'' he said, ''I put my political existence at stake by agreeing'' to the deployment of American missiles on West German soil, ''so nobody has to tell me what a reliable partner is.''
 
Dismisses 'Neutralism'
''Neutralism would be a very false solution for us,'' Mr. Kohl said. ''I can't see that there would ever be any majority in the Federal Republic nor in a united Germany for a neutralized Germany.''
Without mentioning the Nazis, Mr. Kohl acknowledged, ''We have a certain history,'' and said, ''We must understand that there are certain fears on the part of our neighbors,'' particularly Poland.
He said he was confident that in melding the two Germanys, ''we will find ways and means of adopting solutions satisfactory to everybody.''
Mr. Kohl was asked if a united Germany could have any ties to the Warsaw Pact or if it would allow the stationing of Soviet troops within its borders. ''One thing is clear,'' he said. ''A united Germany cannot belong to two different pact systems.''

HEADLINE: ELECTION IN NICARAGUA;
NICARAGUA IS CALM IN HEAVY TURNOUT FOR CRITICAL VOTE

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 25

 BODY:
Under intense international scrutiny, this war-battered country voted today in the first free and broadly contested elections in its history. There were few reports of violence and strong signs of an overwhelming voter turnout.
Exit polls and unofficial projections were prohibited by the election authorities, underscoring the uncertainty that has surrounded the contest, which pits President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of the governing Sandinista National Liberation Front against Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, leader of the 14-party National Opposition Union.
Anticipation was heightened further late tonight when election officials failed to make a scheduled announcement of official returns amid signs of a close race. They offered no explanation for the slowness of the count. 
 
'It's Very Solemn'
Hundreds of thousands of Nicaraguans streamed to the polls in what all sides view as a decisive referendum on 10 years of Sandinista rule. In contrast to the festive air of the recent election in neighboring Costa Rica, the mood at most voting tables was one of purpose and privacy.
''It's very solemn, like a Mass,'' said former President Jimmy Carter, who is leading one of the major delegations of observers here.
Asked for his impression of the balloting. Mr. Carter said, ''So far, very good.'' But in at least one rebel stronghold in the mountainous countryside, the voting went forward under a cloud of fear. [Page A6.] The election, in which Nicaraguans are voting for President and Vice President, a National Assembly and municipal councils, comes after more than 10 years of turbulence and war in Nicaragua. Since 1979, the country has seen the fall and assassination of a dictator, the rise of a revolutionary Government, a civil war in which Washington armed and trained a rebel army, and an economy staggered by a United States-imposed trade embargo and mismanagement. #30,000 Dead in War The opposition of the Reagan Administration to the Sandinista Government, which it accused of aiding leftist rebels in El Salvador, led it to arm and train the contra rebels. The civil war left an estimated 30,000 Nicaraguans dead. President Ortega said on Friday that if he won re-election, he would end support to the Salvadoran rebels and seek better ties with Washington. [In Washington, the Bush Administration indicated that it would look to improve relations with Managua if Mr. Ortega won a fair vote and the Sandinistas abided by the promise not to arm the Salvadoran rebels.
 
Page A6.]
As early as three hours before the scheduled 7 A.M. start of the balloting, long lines formed at the 4,391 voting stations set up in schools, banks and public offices across the country. Officials from the Government and the opposition parties said they expected the final turnout to reach as high as 90 percent of the country's 1.7 million registered voters. The voting age is 16 in this nation of 3.5 million.
 
Some Stations Fail to Open
The care put into the elections was evident in the balloting. Nicaraguan voters moved through a set of special procedures intended to prevent fraud or repeat voting. In interviews, many refused to comment on their views, pointedly repeating official assurances that their vote was secret.
''The people know how important this moment is,'' said Mario Jose Gonzalez Lopez, a 23-year-old Managua repair-shop worker who would not reveal his preference as he waited to vote. ''They're taking it very seriously.''
Electoral officials announced that a total of 9 voting stations did not open and 12 others were relocated for security reasons because of the threat of contra rebel activity. But the changes, affecting only a fraction of the electorate, were not expected to have a serious effect on the vote.
 
Teams Find Compliance
Throughout the rugged Nicaraguan countryside, coordinated teams of 700 trained foreign observers from the United Nations, the Organization of American States and a delegation led by Mr. Carter carefully monitored voting stations, traveling by jeep, boat, horseback, helicopter and plane.
An additional 1,300 foreign observers and invited delegations from places as diverse as Gdansk, Poland, and McFarland, Wis., also fanned out across the country to guarantee the integrity of the vote. And as many as 1,000 journalists received credentials to report on the election process.
There were no immediate reports of serious violence or irregularities, and the security forces remained well away from most voting areas.
President Carter and other observers said this evening that a problem had developed with a lack of permanence in the ink used to stain voters' thumbs to prevent them from voting more than once. But he said that it would not affect the overall vote.
Instead of finding disruptions or fraud, observers in most places said they found almost universal compliance with the smallest details of the electoral law.
The country has been filled in the last few weeks with campaign clothing, headbands, hats and other giveaways, particularly from the Sandinista Front, and thousands of Nicaraguans have become accustomed to wearing campaign T-shirts. But such clothing is forbidden near polling areas by rules that ban partisan publicity, and throughout Managua today the items vanished in a striking display of obedience.
''I think it shows a maturity and democratic spirit,'' said Oscar Melendez, who presided over the electoral preparations for the region.
 
The Critical Issues
In voting lines around the country, those willing to express their views provided a portrait of an election that has revolved around the critical issues of the long contra war and the country's deep economic decline.
In Masaya, a city 15 miles southeast of Managua that was the object of intense campaigning by Sandinista leaders and their opponents, Ivan Cordoba Zuniga, a 23-year-old law student, said he had voted for the Sandinistas to protect Nicaragua's sovereignty.
''We have to determine the dignity of our people,'' said Mr. Cordoba, who said he served in the army for two years at the height of the contra war. ''We won't be like Panama, Grenada, or the Dominican Republic.''
But Marlon Blanco Jimenez, a 17-year-old student, emerged from the voting booth to say that he and other draft-age friends had put their faith in the main opposition coalition, known by its Spanish acronym as UNO.
''I am very conscious of what I just did,'' he said. ''The vote is secret but it's easy to know who I want because I'm young. We don't want the military service, we want to go to school.''
 
For and Against
Voters in Monsenor Lezcano, an older working-class neighborhood on the west side of Managua, predicted that their block, which includes large numbers of military families, would vote almost unanimously for the Sandinistas. ''This neighborhood is completely revolutionary,'' said Maritza Pena, who is 40 years old.
The Sandinista platform has centered on promises to end the eight-year contra war and to begin rebuilding the economy through new foreign aid and a lifting of American trade restrictions imposed at the height of the contra conflict, in 1985. United States officials have acknowledged that the contra war and the restrictions would lose much if not all their rationale if the Sandinistas were to win fairly.
The opposition coalition, headed by Mrs. Chamorro, the 60-year-old widow of a crusading newspaper editor whose assassination in 1978 helped set off the Sandinista revolution, has built its campaign around popular unhappiness over years of inflation, deteriorating wages and shortages of basic goods.
It has gained important support for its promise to end the military draft. It has also capitalized on the discontent of the private business sector, whose confidence, it asserts, will never be regained by the Sandinista Government.
