HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Pepsi Is Open for Business in India

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Feb. 25

 BODY:
A company called Pepsi Foods made its debut in India last week, selling cumin-flavored potato chips and an Indian version of Cheetos seasoned with fenugreek.
Pepsi-Cola itself - or Pepsi Era, as it will be known here - will come later, probably in April when the weather turns oppressive. By then, the controversy promises to be as hot as the weather because the company has to pay as much attention to politics as to the competition and its market share. 
It has been more than a decade since Coca-Cola was forced out of India by a strongly nationalist Industry Minister, George Fernandes. Mr. Fernandes is back in the Government again, although not as Industry Minister, and is leading a crusade against Pepsico Inc. The American company owns 39.9 percent of Pepsi Foods Private Ltd.
The Indian-registered company, whose other shareholders are Voltas, a subsidiary of the giant Tatas group, and the Punjab Agro Industries Corporation, a state government company, has set up food-processing and drink-making operations in Punjab state, an area where jobs are needed to help curtail the growth of a Sikh separatist movement that draws on unemployed young men.
 
Potato Chip Factory
More than 300 people are already at work for Pepsi Foods, many in a potato chip plant at Channo, in Patiala district. The company calls the factory ''the most advanced snack-food plant in Asia.''
Pepsi Foods says that by the end of the year 20,000 people will have benefited indirectly from the company's operations, most of them in farming communities.
As part of the agreement that allowed Pepsico to enter India, even as a minority partner, the company agreed to set up agricultural research and training centers to improve crop yields and introduce new varieties of fruits and vegetables. Punjabis, who brought about India's Green Revolution in wheat and rice, are considered the country's most able farmers.
The company announced last week that it had just secured a huge export order for four metric tons of tomato paste, to be produced by a new fruit and vegetable processing plant in the Hoshiarpur district. Pepsi foods also hopes to process chilis, mushrooms, pears, guava and citrus fruits.
With an eye on local politics, Pepsi Foods somewhat defensively introduced the managing directors of Pepsi's Chinese and Soviet operations at a news conference last week. Those executives showed films about the high level of cooperation between Pepsico and those countries.
 
Objection to Luxuries
Mr. Fernandes's objections to American soft drinks, which he regards as unacceptable luxuries in a land without clean drinking water, find acceptance among many Indians brought up on a creed of self-reliance and a deep-seated fear of Americanization.
An assortment of other left-of-center politicians and a large Indian soft-drink manufacturer, Parle - which controls 70 percent of the annual sales of 6.52 million bottles - have joined in Mr. Fernandes's drive against Pepsico.
The first television advertisement, to be broadcast today, is clearly aimed at Westernized Indians, with its rock music and skyscraper graphics. The Pepsi snack foods are selling under the English-language brand name Hostess. Pepsi Era, the soft drink, will have labels in Hindi and English.
Ramesh Vangal, the managing director of Pepsi Foods, said he was not entirely surprised that controversy should arise as Pepsi Era prepares to enter the soft-drink market. He said that from the day the company first expressed interest in entering the Indian market, there have been campaigns of misinformation at crucial stages of negotiations.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chase Official to Head Global Securities Unit

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Bank, believing that institutional investors are taking a global approach, has combined its domestic pension trust and global custody business and put Marshall N. Carter in charge.
Mr. Carter, 50 years old, who has headed up the global side of the Chase operation, said that the business of acting as custodian for the assets of pension funds is changing rapidly.
With the new setup, ''We expect significant growth,'' Mr. Carter said. ''This has been a U.S.- and U.K.-based business that is now expanding into Europe and Asia as European investment firms and pension funds in many cases are allowed to invest outside their own countries.'' 
Historically, the custodial business has offered services for settling securities trades and for safekeeping the securities. Now, Mr. Carter said, speed in servicing the account and increased information about the account are increasingly important. The institutional client can also get analytical information about the account, allowing it, for example, to play ''what if'' games to test investment ideas. But the bank does not provide investment management advice.
The newly combined unit, which has $250 billion in assets under custody, is called the Chase Global Securities Services.
Mr. Carter came to banking by way of West Point, Vietnam and a program known as the White House Fellowships. After West Point, he served two years, 1966 and 1967, leading a Marine infantry company in heavy combat in South Vietnam. He did a second tour in 1970 and 1971 as an adviser to South Vietnamese Marines.
Before he joined Chase in 1976, Mr. Carter was a White House Fellow serving at the State Department and the Agency for International Development. The State Department service included membership on the department's 1975 Sinai peacekeeping surveillance mission.
At Chase, Mr. Carter was sent to Rochester, to help merge a newly purchased bank, Lincoln First, with Chase, before he got into the trust and custodial business.
Mr. Carter, whose title is senior vice president at Chase, is a colonel in the Marine reserves and is a commercially licensed airplane pilot. He spends about a week a month in Europe on the Chase job. Mr. Carter and his wife, Missy, live in Greenwich, Conn., where she has her own business as a career counselor. They have two children.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Further Rises in Rates Expected

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Upward pressure on interest rates in Japan and West Germany is expected to continue to influence the domestic credit rate structure this week and in the near future.
The rise in domestic interest rates last week would have been higher had it not been for plunging Japanese stock prices and mounting fears of inflation in West Germany. Both developments strengthened the dollar and placed a lid on the rate increases.
The Bank of Japan did not make an expected increase in its discount rate from the current level of 4.25 percent. The delay was seen as an effort to arrest a further weakening of Tokyo stock prices, which lost 7 percent of their value last week. As it was, the Bank of Japan reportedly bought large amounts of bonds to keep interest rates from rising further. 
West Germany's moves to hasten political and monetary integration with East Germany heightened fears of inflation, which was reflected in rising interest rates throughout Western Europe.
 
'Japanese Taking a Big Risk'
''If Japan behaved like West Germany and ignored the upward pressure on interest rates, we in North America would be in even worse trouble,'' said Francis A. Scotland, managing editor of the International Bank Credit Analyst in Montreal. ''By trying to hold the line on interest rates and letting the yen fall against the dollar, the Japanese were taking a big risk of inflation. But supporting their stock market appears to be their main concern.
''The decline in Japanese stocks partly spilled over into the United States equities market and caused a flight to quality, which helped prevent yields from rising further.''
Nevertheless, interest rates continued to rise. The yield on the Japanese Government's 10-year bond, its longest maturity, rose to 6.90 percent at last Friday's close, up from 6.86 percent the week before and 5.72 percent at the start of the year. The yield on West Germany's 10-year bond soared to 8.72 percent from 8.55 percent a week earlier and 7.26 percent at the start of 1990. By comparison, the yield on the United States 10-year Treasury notes climbed to 8.53 percent last week, from 8.41 percent the week before and 7.91 percent on Dec. 31. Yields on longer Treasury maturities showed similar increases.
Leif H. Olsen, who heads an investment management consulting firm bearing his name in New Canaan, Conn., said that the fixed-income market's expectations of further easing by the Federal Reserve ''have been clouded, to say the least, largely by developments overseas.''
 
Fed Committee Takes Action
Mr. Olsen said the Federal Open Market Committee had acted in December to reduce the key Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, to roughly 8.25 percent, from 8.50 percent. The reason was that most members of the committee believed that the sagging economy needed help.
''This help was promptly eliminated by a surge in bond yields,'' he said. ''Now, two months later, market interest rates across the board are higher than they were the day after the funds rate was reduced. The bond market behaves as if it believes the economy will grow vigorously without additional rate cuts and, in fact, with rate increases as we have just had. These are contradictions. Somebody must be wrong.''
Mr. Olsen, who spent many years at the Federal Reserve and as a bank economist, thinks long-term rates have risen largely because of fears that bond investors would move money abroad and not because the domestic economy will soon improve. ''If anything, the flow of economic data will continue to underscore the fact that the domestic gross national product will grow at a weak 1 to 2 percent this year,'' he said, ''and this should convince the bond market that Fed easing is justified.''
As for the fears of a flight of capital to overeas markets, Mr. Olsen said they were groundless. Foreign exchange markets are so termed because this is the place where financial assets change ownership, he went on.
''If liquidity actually moved abroad one would have expected to see bond rates in Japan actually decline. But that has not happened,'' he said. ''Indeed, even the yen has moved down against the dollar, indicating weakened demand by foreigners seeking to buy Japanese securities.''
But William M. Brachfeld, executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc., the domestic arm of the large Japanese financial house, laid much of the outward confusion in the credit market to the difficult position faced by the Fed as well as overseas pressures that the central bank cannot control. ''On one hand, the Fed faces mounting pressures to cut interest rates as a means of stimulating the economy,'' he said on Friday. ''But it also fears that by cutting rates it will inhibit foreign investors from buying the ever-increasing volume of debt created by our budget and trade deficits.''
The Fed is also concerned about the financial health of a number of Wall Street houses, Mr. Brachfeld said, adding: ''Hardly a day has passed since the bankruptcy of Drexel Burnham Lambert on Feb. 13 that rumors of the impending failure of this or that house hasn't swept the marketplace. All this at a time when once prominent thrift institutions are indeed going under almost every day. Small wonder investors in fixed-income securities are demanding protection from more than just rising inflation.''

HEADLINE: Turnover in Nicaragua;
Washington set to End Embargo And Aid Chamorro Government

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Elated by the election results in Nicaragua, the Bush Administration said today that it expected to lift a trade embargo imposed in 1985, provide economic aid and send an ambassador to Managua if Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the President-elect, takes office as scheduled on April 25.
But the Administration's satisfaction was tinged with doubts about whether President Daniel Ortega Saavedra would peacefully surrender power, and especially his control over the Nicaraguan Army and security agencies.
Mr. Ortega said today that he would ''respect and obey the popular mandate.'' But in the election campaign, Sandinista officials like Interior Minister Tomas Borge Martinez suggested that members of the military and security forces would resist orders from a Chamorro government. 
 
Debate Rekindled
The defeat of Mr. Ortega gave all sides in Washington an opportunity to rekindle one of the most divisive foreign policy debates of the last decade. Conservatives praised the results as a vindication of the Reagan Administration's support for the contra rebels. Opponents of the contras said the election proved the merits of negotiation rather than military action. [Page A14.] White House and State Department officials and members of Congress from both parties said they were delighted with the results, which President Bush described as ''another victory'' for democracy in a remarkable year of political change.''
''Given a clear mandate for peace and democracy, there is no reason at all for further military activity from any quarter,'' Mr. Bush said in a comment widely read as a message to the Nicaraguan rebels, the focus of United States policy throughout the Reagan Administration.
Ronald Reagan's ardent support for the contras caused countless fights with Congress and led indirectly to the worst scandal of his Administration, as White House officials sold arms to Iran and diverted the proceeds to the Nicaraguan guerrillas.
At the State Department, an official said today that ''people here are ecstatic about the outcome'' of the Nicaraguan elections.
 
Promise of Support
When Mrs. Chamorro visited Mr. Bush at the White House on Nov. 8, he told her that ''the United States would be ready to lift the trade embargo and assist in Nicaragua's reconstruction'' if she won the election.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said today that the Administration would follow through on that commitment. Lifting economic sanctions ''will be a matter of first consideration,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
The sanctions, imposed by President Reagan in 1985, prohibit the import of Nicaraguan goods to the United States and the export of most products from this country to Nicaragua. Nicaraguan aircraft are barred from the United States, and Nicaraguan ships are excluded from American ports.
Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said the United States would ''do any and everything we can'' to help Mrs. Chamorro and her government rebuild the economy of Nicaragua, which has been battered by war, high inflation, high unemployment and the United States embargo. She said Washington would urge other countries to help Managua.
 
Source of Aid Unclear
Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, said Managua would need ''big bucks'' from the United States because ''the Nicaraguan economy is flat on its back.'' No one seems to know where the extra money can be found at a time when Congress and the Administration also want to provide new aid to Panama, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia.
Liberals and conservatives agreed today that the contras should return to Nicaraguan society. About 10,000 are in camps in Honduras, subsisting on aid from the United States.
''The purpose of the contras was to bring democracy to Central America, particularly Nicaragua,'' said Representative Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee. ''When Mrs. Chamorro is sworn into office, there will be no reason for the contras to continue to exist.''
 
Aid Through Feb. 28
The inauguration day is April 25. American aid to the contras for food, clothing and medical supplies runs through Feb. 28. Goods bought before that date may be delivered in March or early April.
Mr. Fitzwater said the Administration had not decided whether to seek additional aid. The Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas S. Foley, said he did not ''see any reason for further aid to the contras,'' except for some funds to help them return to Nicaragua.
Miss Tutwiler dropped a heavy hint to the rebels. The Bush Administration has always favored ''the voluntary repatriation of the contras back into Nicaragua under safe and democratic conditions,'' she said. ''This election obviously goes a long way toward safe and democratic conditions.''
The United States Agency for International Development gave slightly more than $2 million to Mrs. Chamorro's coalition, the National Opposition Union. The agency gave an equal amount to Nicaragua's Supreme Electoral Council, as required by Nicaraguan law. The United States also gave $800,000 to the Institute for Electoral Promotion and Training, supposedly for nonpartisan voter education.
An Administration official said the aid was ''very helpful in persuading people that their votes would make a difference and would remain secret.'' The ''civic education messages encouraged voter turnout, which was good for the opposition, and also allowed people to vote their consciences,'' he said.
 
Spreading the Credit
Administration officials and some members of Congress said the election proved the wisdom of a bipartisan accord on Central America signed by Mr. Bush and Congressional leaders in March 1989. The accord ended the bitter, divisive debates on Nicaragua that had characterized the Reagan years.
Parceling out credit for Mrs. Chamorro's victory, Administration officials praised Nicaraguan voters. Mr. Bush congratulated Mr. Ortega on ''the conduct of the election.'' Some officials said Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, had played a constructive role by encouraging elections.
Some Administration officials seemed reluctant to give credit to the contras, whom they see as a vestige of Reagan policy.
But Representative Jim Courter of New Jersey, speaking for many conservative Republicans, hailed the elections as a ''vindication of the Reagan doctrine,'' which supported insurgents fighting leftist governments around the world. Senator Gordon J. Humphrey, Republican of New Hampshire, said Mr. Ortega had agreed to hold the elections only because of pressure from the contras.
By contrast, Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, said the election results demonstrated ''the failure of the contra war'' and the virtues of the regional peace plan devised by President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica. The plan emphasizes negotiation and reconciliation.
Liberals described the election results as a victory for democracy and a defeat for clandestine military operations. ''This election is not a victory for the contras, who from the beginning were not a politically viable force,'' said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1820 words

HEADLINE: Turnover in Nicaragua;
NICARAGUAN OPPOSITION ROUTS SANDINISTAS; U.S. PLEDGES AID, TIED TO ORDERLY TURNOVER

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The leader of Nicaragua's opposition coalition crushed President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in national elections here on Sunday, apparently bringing an end to 10 turbulent years of Sandinista rule.
The landslide victory by the opposition candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, turned the closely monitored elections into a powerful repudiation of one of Latin America's most prominent and fiercely debated revolutionary Governments.
Celebrating her victory early today after the results were made public, Mrs. Chamorro said, ''We have shown the world an example of civic duty, demonstrating that we Nicaraguans want to live in democracy, want to live in peace and, above all, that we want to live in liberty.''
 
Ortega Pledges Acceptance
President Ortega, looking subdued as the results became known, said, ''The President of Nicaragua and the Government of Nicaragua are going to respect and obey the popular mandate coming out of the vote in these elections.'' [Excerpts from the two speeches appear on page A12.] Despite Mrs. Chamorro's victory, and President Ortega's seeming acquiescence in defeat, there remains skepticism that Mr. Ortega, a lifelong revolutionary and politician, will be able to persuade the Sandinista Front to accept a Chamorro government. Mrs. Chamorro is scheduled to be inaugurated on April 25. 
The vote lays the groundwork for the first democratic transfer of power that this country has known, a turnover that parallels to some degree the changes in Eastern Europe, where Communism has little by little given way to democratic change.
 
Lead of 14 Percentage Points
Mrs. Chamorro, 60 years old, is the widow of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, the newspaper publisher whose assassination touched off the rebellion that led to the Sandinista takeover. She ran as the candidate of the 14-party National Opposition Union, a coalition of leftists, rightists and other Nicaraguan parties.
The official voting results, supervised by a large contingent of international observers, including former President Jimmy Carter, gave Mrs. Chamorro a lead of 14.4 percentage points. Her vote total with 82 percent of the ballots counted was put at 633,357, or 55.2 percent of the presidential vote. Mr. Ortega of the Sandinista National Liberation Front received 468,040 votes, or 40.8 percent of the total.
Small parties received the rest of the votes as Nicaraguans elected a President, Vice President and National Assembly, which the opposition will now control.
Across the country, beginning in the early morning, there was the almost surreal sensation of imminent change. Nicaraguans shared a widespread sense of awe at the power of their own votes, and disbelief that something so pervasive and apparently entrenched as the Sandinista Front had suddenly been swept aside. A huge rally planned near Sandinista headquarters slowly dissolved into a mournful gathering, while opposition loyalists whooped it up at the restaurant that has become their staging ground.
The Chamorro victory has stunned many political analysts, and American officials also appeared to be caught off guard by the depth of the Sandinista defeat. Polls by outside groups consistently suggested that the Sandinistas would sweep to victory, and just last week the Government mounted a rally of at least 300,000 people, dwarfing similar opposition demonstrations.
But reporters and other outsiders who spent hours interviewing average citizens in working-class neighborhoods became convinced that the polls were misleading. Their view was that the electorate of about 1.7 million in this country of 3.5 million was articulating support for Mr. Ortega while secretly looking to oust the Sandinistas after a decade of civil war and economic ruin.
In recent days the White House softened its line toward the Sandinistas, suggesting that after an expected Ortega victory, Washington would try to mend relations with the Government, against which it has waged a civil war by proxy for about eight years. Today, President Bush exulted in the opposition's victory.
 
Threats to Orderly Transition
But an orderly transition is far from certain. In recent weeks, Interior Minister Tomas Borge, who controls the secret police and is considered one of the most rigid members of the nine-member Sandinista National Directorate, has repeatedly suggested that the election of Mrs. Chamorro would make Nicaragua ''ungovernable.''
Tonight, truckloads of Interior Ministry riot troops clashed with crowds of youthful opposition supporters in Managua. Using tear gas and truncheons, the police repeatedly charged at the youths, who responded by throwing sticks and pavement stones and taunting the officers.
In the ranks of the Sandinista People's Army, which is headed by Mr. Ortega's brother, Humberto, and in the Interior Ministry, virtually all officers and most enlisted men are subject to Sandinista political training. And Mr. Borge has pointedly said that attempts to change the current leadership would be met by insubordination and even violence from Sandinista forces.
The military is particularly suspicious of members of the opposition coalition who have longstanding ties to the United States-armed contra rebels. The civil war has killed 30,000 Nicaraguans since it began in the early 1980's.
''Given the existence of revolutionary armed forces,'' the official Sandinista newspaper Barricada said, describing Mr. Borge's views, ''how could the officers obey the wild orders of those who were named Minister of Defense and Minister of the Interior?''
 
No Comment From Borge
Aides to President Ortega said he was speaking for all Sandinista party members and officials, including Mr. Borge, in his promise to respect the election results. But Mr. Borge did not appear at the gathering, and he has made no public comment on the defeat of the Sandinista Front, of which he is the last surviving founder.
The election results appeared certain to produce a dramatic improvement in deeply strained relations between Nicaragua and the Bush Administration, which gave political and financial support to Mrs. Chamorro's candidacy. They were seen as a virtual guarantee of an end to the American-sponsored insurgency. And they promised to deal a powerful blow to American adversaries like the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, and to the leftist guerrillas in El Salvador, both longtime allies of the Sandinista Government.
Mr. Ortega, who said in an interview on Friday that Mrs. Chamorro did not have ''even a hypothetical possibility'' of victory, compared his party's defeat to the bitterest moments of the Sandinistas' long guerrilla war to overthrow the former dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle. He said the party would accept without malice the prospect of leaving power.
''We were born poor and are satisfied to die poor,'' said Mr. Ortega, who remained composed as he spoke to journalists and cheering supporters at a large, modern Government convention hall here. ''We worked in these elections to emphasize a project which has become a challenge to the intelligence, the imagination, the creativity of the people in their permanent struggle for their liberation.''
The Associated Press reported tonight that Mr. Ortega briefly visited Mrs. Chamorro at her home to offer his congratulations. Accompanied by several foreign observers, including Mr. Carter, he hugged the victorious candidate, who spoke to him affectionately.
Mr. Ortega reportedly said, ''You know that I respect you, and that I love you and congratulate you on your victory,'' adding, ''I am ready to contribute to the national reconciliation.''
 
Effort to Reassure Military
Seeking to allay fears of possible retribution or wholesale dismissals from the military and security forces, Mrs. Chamorro and her advisers have repeatedly emphasized that they will remove only high-ranking Sandinista officers, and will not take abrupt or arbitrary action against soldiers or other social or political groups.
''This is an election that will never have exiles, or political prisoners, or confiscations,'' Mrs. Chamorro said in her acceptance statement. ''Here we have neither victors nor vanquished.''
There was no immediate word on how such a policy might be received by the estimated 10,000 remaining members of the contra army. Nor was there a clear sense of how contra fighters who return to the country under an expected total amnesty would be received by former Sandinista military units, or integrated into those units.
But both issues promised to add to the burdens of the diverse and frequently divided opposition leadership, which has never shown the success at internal politics that it showed in Sunday's balloting.
 
Results Were Delayed
Although election results were promised to reporters and international observers beginning just two hours after the 6 P.M. close of voting, initial returns were abruptly discontinued at mid-evening on Sunday. Official radio stations stopped broadcasting news reports, playing only a stream of music.
Questioned by reporters, election officials attributed the problem to slow receipt of information from outlying districts and inexperienced computer technicians at the large convention center, where hundreds of special phone and telex lines were installed to process the election results.
Several diplomats suggested that the counting had been stopped to give international officials time to persuade Mr. Ortega and other Sandinista leaders to accept the vote. But that version of events was denied by Mr. Carter, who said the announcement was held up by a previous agreement among the political parties not to release incomplete results. So far, independent election observers have reported few if any irregularities, and appear ready to judge the voting fair.
At the barn-like Managua restaurant that has served as an opposition meeting place during the campaign, hundreds of cheering, dancing, crying opposition supporters arrived to celebrate Mrs. Chamorro's victory, yelling loud chants and signaling ''No. 1'' with their fingers. The coalition's acronym, UNO, means ''one'' in Spanish.
Across town at a large fairground that had been reserved for a Sandinista victory celebration, crowds began appearing before the scheduled start of the midnight rally. In place were giant sound systems, spotlights and the other equipment that has become a standard feature of mass Sandinista rallies.
But as the news of Mr. Ortega's defeat filtered through the crowd, preparations for dancing and drinking gave way to silence and ashen faces.
In the working class neighborhood of Batahola North, 25-year-old Lorena Sanchez Barrios sat with her child and wept openly as she listened to Mr. Ortega's speech accepting the results.
''I can't believe it,'' she said, expressing an emotion shared by supporters of the Sandinistas and the opposition alike. ''I just can't believe it.''

HEADLINE: JAPAN INTERVENES TO GIVE STABILITY AFTER STOCK DROP

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 27

 BODY:
After a week of turmoil on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, topped by Monday's 4.5 percent plunge, the Government and the exchange itself intervened to restore stability.
The turbulence in Tokyo, however, failed to disrupt markets in the United States, where both stock and bond prices ended the day up strongly, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 38.29 points, to 2,602.48. [Pages D1 and D18.] Analysts said the Japanese market had moved up so much more sharply than other markets that some downward adjustment was due and could be weathered. [Page D8.] In Tokyo on Monday, the key 225-stock Nikkei average fell 1,569.10 points, to 33,321.87. At one point in the early afternoon, the average had fallen nearly 2,500 points before rebounding slightly.
 
An Initial Bounce-Back
On opening Tuesday, the market quickly bounced back an additional 600 points before heading downward again. At the mid-day close, the average had erased all of its gains and was down 171.30 points. The strong market in New York and signs that the Japanese Government's efforts were helping to stabilize the yen were credited for the small, temporary rebound, but the subsequent drop was taken as a sign that market confidence was still fragile. 
Some foreign brokers expressed dismay on Monday afternoon over signs that many Japanese were attributing the market's huge decline to foreign investors and foreign securities firms. As emotions flared, at least one American securities firm disclosed its trading data to try to dispel the idea that Americans were behind the market slide.
In its effort to calm the Tokyo market, which is in the midst of its largest decline since the stock crash in October 1987, the Bank of Japan on Monday offered short-term loans to banks to make sure the market had enough cash to operate. And the Finance Ministry bought bonds to push long-term interest rates lower. Rising interest rates, which tend to squelch economic activity, have been widely cited as one factor that prompted the decline.
The Bank of Japan also intervened heavily all day in the currency markets to try to halt the dollar's rise against the yen, reportedly spending $1.5 billion in this futile campaign. The dollar closed here at 148.65 yen, up more than 2 yen, to its highest level since June.
The yen's weakness has been particularly worrisome to the Japanese, since Japan, the United States and other industrialized nations have sought to strengthen the yen for the last five years to curb Japan's bulging trade surpluses and reduce growing trade frictions tearing at American-Japanese relations. The weakening yen, which would tend to increase Japan's exports by making them cheaper, threatens to aggravate those tensions further.
The last tool the central bank has to protect the yen is to increase its official discount rate in what would be the fourth such move since May. The expectation of such an increase in the rate, which is charged on loans to commercial banks, has been behind a smoldering confrontation between the Finance Ministry and the central bank.
 
Rare Public Dispute
In a rare public dispute, the Finance Ministry has fought a rate rise for fear it would slow the economy and push the stock market even lower, while the central bank has encouraged it to stem growing inflationary pressures.
Analysts have said anticipation of a rate increase had hurt the market, but now the uncertainty surrounding the Bank of Japan's plans has itself added to the market's skittishness.
The most controversial move to help stabilize the market on Monday was a late-afternoon announcement by the Tokyo Stock Exchange that it was ''requesting'' securities firms that have engaged in program trading to limit drastically their computer-driven sales of shares, except under certain conditions.
The exchange asked firms engaged in program trading not to sell shares except at the morning opening and when the market reopens in the afternoon after a two-hour lunch break. The announcement, which was interpreted by securities houses as a demand, will be effective only until the current stock index futures contract expires on March 8.
In the type of program trading being blamed for some of the market's turmoil - stock index arbitrage - an investor, aided by programmed computer orders, simultaneously buys or sells the stocks that make up a stock index, such as the Standard & Poor's 500, and takes the opposite position in the stock index futures market. The technique allows the investor to profit from discrepancies between the price in the cash and futures markets. Although Tokyo's market is the world's largest in terms of the value of shares, it is inefficient, and such price discrepancies often occur.
 
A Mix of Reactions
The announcement on program trading created a mix of reactions among traders and securities executives here. Some applauded the step as a sincere attempt to stem the dangerous volatility of the last week.
But some foreign firms, particularly American ones, saw the move as both an inappropriate change of the rules in the middle of the game and as a step toward making foreign firms scapegoats in the market tumble. Most program trading is done by the American firms Salomon Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Goldman, Sachs.
With the issue threatening to boil over, Salomon Brothers disclosed its precise level of trading to try to dispel reports from Japanese securities firms that the Americans had precipitated the market tumble.
Deryck C. Maughan, chairman of Salomon Brothers Asia, said his firm had sold a total of 33 million shares last week in program trading-related transactions, out of total trading during the week of 2.1 billion shares. Salomon, he said, did no program-related selling on Monday.
''I refuse to believe that our 33 million shares led the other 2 billion down,'' Mr. Maughan said.
But the chairman of one of Japan's top financial institutions remained steadfast in blaming foreign firms and program traders, saying that his company and a number of other major financial institutions here with huge stock portfolios had not sold a single share in the last week. Trading volume has been running extremely low, in fact, and Monday's level of 400 million shares was about half the daily level last year. Volume continued at a modest level on Tuesday morning.
 
'It's the Foreigners'
''Well, where do you think the selling is coming from, then?'' he said. ''It's the foreigners and the program traders.''
An official at Nomura Securities, the world's largest securities firm, said his analysis also pointed to foreigners as the source of most of the selling, although he said he had no figures to prove his contention.
In fact, the share of trading volume here by foreign investors has declined over the last decade, from about 20 percent to less than 10 percent. Also, foreign investors were net sellers of Japanese shares last year, unloading more than $15 billion worth, thus reducing significantly the shares in foreign hands to sell in the current bear market.
Clearly, Japanese authorities have also been bothered by the fact that the fall here has had few repercussions outside Japan. While small movements here in the past have caused sharp swings in Europe and on Wall Street, the market in New York last week fell less than half as much as Tokyo's.
 
Seen as Dangerous
That was all the more reason that the Tokyo Stock Exchange's announcement that it was altering for now the way program trading is done was regarded by some program traders as unnecessary and possibly dangerous.
''This impairs the free operation of the market,'' one American executive complained. ''It was done without notice or consultation with anyone in the industry, as far as we can tell.'' He added that there had not even been an official notification of what was effectively a rule change.
The official reports on the stock market crash in New York in October 1987 placed much of the blame on program trading, and there is much concern here about the strategy. But officials at the American firms insist that the volume of trading they do is so small that program trading could not possibly move as vast a market as Tokyo's.
''The point is, it puts all this trading in a tiny little box, where it's easy to observe, and easy to control,'' said an American executive. ''If they changed the rules once, you don't know if they will be changed again. That's why this is intimidating.'' The executive added, in a comment echoed by others, that even if the Tokyo market manages to regain its balance soon, the problems of the last week have left a residue of mistrust that may take longer to repair.

HEADLINE: Israel Letting 16 Arab Colleges Reopen

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The Israeli military authorities announced today that they were allowing 16 community colleges in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to reopen. But the universities, shut down along with the colleges in the fall of 1987, will remain closed.
Israeli military officials said the colleges were being allowed to reopen as part of a program to relax tensions as the Palestinian uprising, now almost 27 months old, seems in the army's view to be losing force. 
But the announcement came on one of the most violent days ever in the occupied Gaza Strip, where Palestinians reported that 91 people had been wounded by army gunfire. Hospital officials reported that 100 other people were examined or treated for tear-gas inhalation after the army dropped gas cannisters from helicopters into crowds of rioters.
Political leaders in Jerusalem also suggested today that the Government might be close to agreement on terms for moving to the next step in Israel's plan for Palestinian elections. #5,000 Students Affected Military officials said the 5,000 community college students in the West Bank would be allowed to return to school gradually starting next month. The schools would be allowed to remain open, they added, only as long as they are not used as centers for violence.
They gave no date for when the 18,000 Palestinian university students might be allowed to return to classes. All the colleges and universities were closed in October 1987. Israel said they were used as planning and staging grounds for violence.
Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who approved the plan to reopen the community colleges, told a group of high school students in Rehovot today that in his view, ''we are now in a position to take a first step toward peace with the Palestinians which is firmly anchored in political reality, and which compels us to give a yes or no vote.''
The Labor Party, the United States, the Egyptian Government and presumably the Palestine Liberation Organization all appear to have agreed on a plan to open peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians. Only the approval of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and the Likud Party is needed.
The key issue of debate is the makeup of the Palestinian delegation. The agreed plan would include two Palestinians deported from Israel and two with addresses in East Jerusalem among the other delegates from the West Bank and Gaza.
 
Shamir Seems Receptive
Today, Mr. Shamir seemed disposed to at least consider the idea.
The question of deportees and East Jerusalem Arabs, the Prime Minister said, ''is part of a whole complex of things, and it's just a small part.'' He added, ''When we have to decide on the next step, we'll decide on everything.''
The Labor Party is threatening to bring down the Government if Mr. Shamir does not decide to go ahead by March 7. Senior Labor officials repeated that threat today.
But at the same time, five far-right members of the Likud faction in Parliament led by Economics and Planning Minister Yitzhak Modai - angry that Mr. Shamir is even considering accepting the negotiations formula under discussion now - formally asked to withdraw from the party and form their own faction today.
With that and other foment in Likud, it appears that whatever Mr. Shamir decides, he will cause a Government crisis from either the left or the right.

HEADLINE: Turnover in Nicaragua;
Excerpts From the Speech by Ortega

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a speech this morning by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua, as recorded and translated by The New York Times:
Friends of the national and international press:
The electoral process of historical proportions for the whole Nicaraguan people is coming to a close, during which we committed all our efforts and revolutionary convictions so that in Nicaragua everything would be better for all Nicaraguans.
The Sandinista National Liberation Front headed the struggle against the Somoza dictatorship. It lived the bitter moments of the fall of the dictator Somoza, the moments of pain when we lost a brother in combat, and we Sandinista militants learned to forge ourselves in the difficult moments facing adversity.
With the Nicaraguan people we conquered the rights to freedom, independence, democracy and peace on July 19, 1979. 
 
Years of Suffering
During those 10 hard and difficult years, cruel for the Nicaraguan people, the Sandinista Front with its revolutionary Government knew how to stay in the forefront of the defense of the interests of the people, in the forefront of the homeland, the national dignity, sovereignty, at the forefront of the struggle for Nicaraguan self-determination and of that struggle for peace.
Just as we succeeded in overthrowing Somozacism, we also defeated the counterrevolution, and also brought to trial before the world those who provided that policy of death against the Nicaraguan people, and in an act of historical transcendence for the people of the world, the World Court condemned the United States of America for its criminal acts against the people of Nicaragua and called on the United States of America to cease those acts and called on the United States of America to give indemnity to the Nicaraguan people. . . .
We went to these elections of the 25th of February 1990 with the conviction that in this battle in the electoral field must be decided once and for all an end to the war, a little peace, stability and tranquillity for the Nicaraguan people.
That is the Sandinista Front, which with more political and historical force with the patriotic and flourishing Nicaraguan people has in these elections faced U.S. policy, the contras, the economic embargo, the economic erosion provoked by the war, with confidence in the people certain that the end of this electoral process would give all Nicaraguans that peace and that stability which we so need to reconstruct this country, to lift up the economy, to free well-being in the official areas, and aspire to a minimum of political stability. . . .
 
World Is Watching
Never in the history of any independent country have elections been carried out that have been so well observed as have these here in Nicaragua, with observers from the United Nations, the O.A.S., the Carter Center, observers from Europe, Latin America and other parts of the world.
Hundreds of journalists also covered and observed this electoral process, proving that the political will of the revolutionary Sandinistas have never been fixated on power; that we were born poor and we are satisfied to die poor because we carried out our efforts in these elections to emphasize this project which has become a challenge to the intelligence, the imagination, the creativity, of the people in the permanent struggle for their liberation, their independence, their self-determination and for economic and social justice. . . .
 
Respecting Mandate
I wish to express in my name, in that of my family, of my companion, of my brothers in the National Directorate of the Sandinista Front, of my brother militant of the F.S.L.N., in the name of the heroic self-sacrificing, courageous, conscientious people who have participated in this electoral process and have given their support to the F.S.L.N., I wish to say to all Nicaraguans and to all the peoples of the world that the President of Nicaragua and the Government of Nicaragua are going to respect and obey the popular mandate coming out of the vote in these elections.
I consider that in this historic moment, the principal contributions of the Sandinistas, the Nicaraguan revolutionaries, are making to the Nicaraguan people is that of guaranteeing a clean, pure electoral process, that it may heat up our consciences even more, that it may shine with the sun of this dawn, the 26th of February, in this 1990, that it may shine towards the consolidation of democracy, the consolidation of a mixed economy, toward the consolidation of a free, independent and democratic Nicaragua, in peace without intervention by any foreign power where all of us Nicaraguans may be capable of demonstrating to the world that we can change these dreams, these hopes, into reality. . . .
Thank you, Nicaraguan brothers. Thank you, brother militants of the F.S.L.N., thank you brother combatants of the Popular Sandinista Army and of the Ministry of the Interior who with your blood fertilized this labor defending the right of Nicaraguans to exercise their right to vote, thanks to the blood of our heroes and martyrs, thanks to the pain full of hope of the mothers of Nicaragua, thanks to every Nicaraguan brother.
I urge you today more than ever so that we may act firmly with the security that the steps we have taken are the correct steps, that we have been consistent with the proposals we have made, that if after all we have pledged so much sacrifice, so much effort during these years, that once again we Sandinistas will be victorious, once more we Sandinistas will be conquerors because we have changed our words into deeds in spite of all of the campaigns raised against this electoral process, in spite of all of the distrust that was intended to be generated around this electoral process, in spite of the systematic actions of the counterrevolutionaries assassinating people during the electoral campaign. . . .
We feel proud to be contributing to Nicaragua, to be contributing to the peoples of Central America, Latin America and the Caribbean, to the peoples on the road to development, to be contributing in this unjust world divided between the strong and the weak, to be contributing a little bit of dignity, a little bit of democracy, a little bit of social justice from this small territory in Central America which saw the birth of men who made Nicaragua shine in the world as did Dario and Sandino.
Thank you, Nicaraguan brothers, and go forward, go forward with our struggle and our battle cry which is the cry of Sandino - ''Free fatherland or death.'' MUST KEEP GRAF, following subhed ''Respecting Mandate,'' that begins: ''I wish to express ... in these elections.

HEADLINE: Turnover in Nicaragua;
Sandinistas' Loss to Be Felt By Other Leftist Movements

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The overwhelming defeat of the Sandinistas in the elections on Sunday could affect the politics and military balance in much of Latin America, diplomats, military commanders and other experts said today.
In addition, the victory of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro promises to have a psychological and intellectual effect in the hemisphere, several diplomats and scholars said.
''It will be the cause of considerable soul-searching and head-scratching in Latin America,'' said a diplomat with years of experience in Central and South America. ''It really has important consequences in the hemisphere and, certainly, in the region.'' 
Mrs. Chamorro's victory not only crushed one of the hemisphere's most influential revolutionary governments but served to repudiate the Sandinistas' leftist ideology, Western diplomats and scholars said. They noted that Mrs. Chamorro, who heads a 14-party coalition of strikingly divergent and often conflicting views, owed her victory in large part to the rejection of President Ortega and his decade-old revolutionary movement.
So his defeat is also likely to be a striking setback for the hemisphere's revolutionary movements, they said. Ebullient after the victory of the Sandinistas a decade ago, many had looked to them for guidance and had sought to follow in their footsteps.
''The election shows that the romanticism of violent revolution has long passed,'' one Western diplomat said. ''The ideological fervor isn't stirring the people the same way any more. And Latin leaders are trying to forget revolutions and concentrate on the bread and butter issues and hungry stomachs.''
In Central America, the Sandinista defeat anchors the ideological balance of power firmly on the right. That promises to deal a sharp political and military blow to leftist guerrillas fighting in El Salvador and Guatemala.
Military commanders in El Salvador and United States diplomats there said they thought the Sandinista defeat would cripple the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, one of Latin America's best guerrilla armies.
 
They Can't Survive'
''They can't survive without the Sandinistas,'' Col. Rene Emilio Ponce, the Chief of Staff of the Salvadoran armed forces, said in a recent interview.
In return for critical help during the Sandinista revolution, Nicaragua has for years provided important political and military aid to the Salvadoran guerrillas. Among other things, this country has been an important staging area and logistics base. It is home for most senior guerrilla commanders and, in the past at least, has provided some of the guerrillas' arms.
Mrs. Chamorro has not publicly laid out how her Government will deal with the Salvadoran guerrillas. But the Bush Administration has conditioned the granting of vitally needed aid on ending Nicaraguan support for the rebels.
The Chamorro victory is seen by diplomats as a vindication of President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica and his Central American peace plan. The plan appears to have achieved by peaceful democratic means what years of United States military and economic pressure could not. Nonetheless, the weight of American sanctions and support for the rebels left the Government so impoverished and the people so exhausted that a political turnaround seemed inevitable.
Even when many of his advisers were convinced that the Sandinistas would win by a landslide, President Arias remained steadfast in his conviction that the election would bring radical change to this impoverished and war-racked country.
''If Ortega wins I'm going to have to go back to school and relearn everything I know about voter behavior,'' Mr. Arias said last year. He was the first head of state to call to congratulate the victor, But perhaps the most obvious result is the further isolation of President Fidel Castro of Cuba, an ardent supporter of the Sandinista revolution and of President Ortega's Government. Once the ideological beacon for leftists throughout Latin America, his stubborn rule is increasingly viewed by Latin Americans as a vestige of a failed era.
The Cuban leader now is the only major remaining leftist leader in the hemisphere. But his international pillars of political and commercial support are crumbling one by one. Diplomats here began talking about President Castro's future on Sunday afternoon as soon as they first sensed the Sandinistas' impending defeat and hours before President Ortega conceded.
Still, the first direct fallout from the election is likely to be felt in Central America. The Sandinistas' defeat removes the raison d'etre of the Nicaraguan rebels, the 11,000-man insurgent army that started eight years ago as a proxy for the Reagan Administration in its efforts to overthrow President Ortega.
Provided that the Sandinists agree to transfer political and military power, Mrs. Chamorro's victory should lead to the quick disbandment of the insurgent force and an end to the nagging, fraternal conflict, diplomats said.
On El Salvador, the President-elect's supporters and many Western diplomats in the region presume she will quickly move to comply with regional peace accords by stopping any arms shipments and preventing Nicaragua from being used as a base by the Salvadoran guerrillas.
 
A Severe Blow
The rebels have acknowledged that losing their Nicaraguan safe haven would be a severe blow. But in the short run at least it is unlikely to be fatal. While it would certainly complicate logistics operations, even the army has acknowledged that the guerrillas have stockpiled enough arms and ammunition in El Salvador to continue offensive operations without resupply for almost a year. In addition, the rebels have a committed base of support within El Salvador.

HEADLINE: Turnover in Nicaragua;
Nicaraguan Decade: War, Ruin and Turnabout

 BODY:
1978: Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, editor of the newspaper La Prensa, is shot to death on a Managua street by unidentified assassins, intensifying discontent that undermines the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza Debayle.
July 1979: The Sandinistas overthrow the Somoza Government. General Somoza flees in secret.
April 1980: Mr. Chamorro's widow, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, quits the governing leftist junta. She begins criticizing the Sandinista leadership. 
November 1980: First attacks by anti-Sandinista rebels, who become known as the contras.
February 1981: The Reagan Administration accuses the Sandinistas of arming Marxist rebels in El Salvador and suspends aid to Nicaragua. Congress approves $19 million in covert military aid for the rebels.
December 1982: Congress approves $19 million more for the contras as part of a classified appropriations bill. After the Boland Amendment is passed, barring the use of funds to overthrow the Sandinista Government, the Central Intelligence Agency spends $10 million in emergency funds to aid the rebels.
1983: The contras launch their first major offensive, and the Sandinistas impose rule by decree. The House votes to end aid to the contras, but in a compromise the rebels receive $24 million, and the C.I.A. is prohibited from using special funds to help the rebels.
1984: Central Intelligence Agency involvement in the mining of Nicaraguan ports is disclosed. The Sandinistas win the first general elections since 1979 with Daniel Ortega Saavedra, a member of the Sandinista junta, becoming President. Congress adds restrictions to contra aid, saying the C.I.A. and the Pentagon cannot spend money on paramilitary operations in Nicaragua without legislative permission.
April 1984: Nicaragua asks the World Court to order the United States to stop aiding the contras. The Reagan Administration refuses to recognize the court's jurisdiction.
January 1985: Talks between Nicaragua and the United States collapse.
May 1985: President Reagan imposes new trade sanctions against Nicaragua, including an embargo.
August 1985: The Senate votes to release $14 million in aid that had been set aside in 1984, but the House votes against it. Congress eventually approves $27 million in aid to the contras restricted to non-combat use. The C.I.A. and the Pentagon are barred from distributing the money.
June 1986: The House approves $100 million in both arms and non-combat aid. Restrictions on the C.I.A. are lifted, but the agency remains barred from spending special funds on the contras.
October 1986: A cargo plane with a crew of Americans is shot down over Nicaragua. The survivor, Eugene Hasenfus, is captured and implicates the C.I.A. in contra supply operations.
November 1986: Attorney General Edwin S. Meese 3d acknowledges that Reagan Administration officials sold arms to Iran and secretly gave the profits to the contras.
February 1987: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica proposes a regional peace plan. The proposa, for which Mr. Arias wins the Nobel Peace, Prize calls on Central American countries to stop aiding insurgent groups and for negotiated cease-fires, amnesties and press and political freedom in Nicaragua, El Salvador and Guatemala. The presidents of five Central American countries endorse the plan in August.
The House approves a moratorium on contra aid in an effort to hold up the last $40 million of the money approved in 1986, but the measure dies in the Senate.
January 1988: President Ortega announces that talks with the contras will begin.
February 1988: Congress suspends military aid for the rebels, but continues the non-combat aid.
March 1988: The Nicaraguan Government and the contras agree on a 60-day cease-fire starting April 1. Negotiations on a permanent peace break down in June, but both sides say they will not mount new military offensives.
May 1988: The Sandinistas extend the cease-fire omonth to month while the contras say they consider the truce indefinite.
July 1988: Ambassador Richard H. Melton is expelled from Nicaragua along with eight other United States diplomats. They are accused of trying to destabilize the Sandinista Government. Washington retaliates by expelling the Nicaraguan Ambassador, Carlos Tunnerman, and eight other diplomats.
September 1988: Talks between the Sandinistas and the contras break down. Thousands of contra soldiers move from Nicaragua into camps in Honduras.
January 1989: President Ortega announces an austerity program to combat inflation, which has run out of control.
February 1989: The Central American Presidents sign an agreement committing Nicaragua to democratic change and early elections in return for the disbanding of the contras.
Aug. 4, 1989: The Sandinistas and Nicaraguan opposition parties sign an accord calling for disbanding contra units in Honduras and elections in February 1990.
Aug. 7, 1989: Five Central American presidents, meeting in Tela, Honduras, announce an accord to dismantle contra base camps in Honduras by December.
Sept. 1989: Mrs. Chamorro is chosen as the presidential candidate of the recently formed opposition alliance, the National Opposition Union.
Nov. 1, 1989: President Ortgea lifts the 19-month-old cease-fire. After several attacks,. the fighting subsides.
Nov. 27, 1989: Mr. Ortega does not deny Nicaragua's role in a shipment of missiles found in the wreckage of a small plane in El Salvador. Washington accuses the Sandinistas of continuing to help the Salvadoran guerrillas, who mounted an offensive on Nov. 11.
Dec. 8: The deadline for contra demobilization passes without action.
Dec. 12, 1989: President Ortega and four Central American presidents call for the demobilization of the Salvadoran guerrillas and the contras.
Feb. 25, 1990: Mrs. Chamorro's coalition defeats President Ortega in national elections.

HEADLINE: Plantations Slip Into Texas History

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLD OCEAN, Tex.

 BODY:
John Holland Bannister enjoyed one last glance at the white clapboard house that his great-grandfather built with a crew of slaves in 1837 in the Texas wilderness.
Then he turned to look at the huge oil refinery and petrochemical complex that has grown and grown in recent years so that now it looms over his ancestral home. A deep rumbling like distant thunder came from the maze of pipes and machinery until one of the many metal towers spewed out a big plume of smoke.
''It's just time to load up and leave,'' Mr. Bannister said. A few weeks ago, he reluctantly sold the last 840 acres of his great-grandfather's plantation, which once encompassed 25,000 acres, to the Phillips Petroleum Company. State officials believe that only a handful of parcels once owned by the original settlers of Texas are still in the hands of their descendants, and now there is one less. 
 
Plans for an Incinerator
Phillips plans to build a toxic-waste incinerator less than a mile from the Osage orange tree, still standing, that the master of the plantation, John Sweeny Jr., climbed in 1865 to tell his slaves they were free.
Along much of the once lonely Texas Gulf Coast, the petrochemical industry has expanded beyond its old enclaves in cities like Houston and Beaumont, taking advantage of low prices for its chief raw material, crude oil. A similarly rough passage has occurred in many other parts of the country when auto plants and other producers sought open frontiers in rural areas.
''It is a matter of old ways giving way to new ways,'' Mr. Bannister said.
As he spoke, the moving crew packed a Bible dated 1788 and chairs that slaves crafted from the wood of trees felled nearby. Each time a cardboard box was carried away, one of the many thin strands that bind America's present to its past was being broken.
''There are still some of the old families, proud of their heritage, who stay on around here, but a lot of them have moved off and gone on as industry has moved in,'' said Linda Wood, the research librarian at the Brazoria County Historical Museum.
 
Family Came to Texas in 1832
In 1832, Mr. Bannister's great-great-grandfather, John Sweeny, father of the man who would build the clapboard house, left Tennessee with his nine children and bought into the vast real estate development that Stephen F. Austin established as a colony before Texas declared independence. Now all that is left of the Sweeny Plantation, which produced sugar and cotton, is the old house and a slave cemetery.
The Phillips Sweeny Complex covers more than 3,300 acres, employs 1,200 people and produces more than 4 million gallons of gasoline a day among other things. Through the sheer weight of its presence, the plant came to exercise a claim on the land that eventually overpowered John Sweeny's heirs.
With the noise of the plant all but drowning out his voice as he stood in his own yard, Mr. Bannister said, ''It is too big to fight, and I am too old to fight it.''
Mr. Bannister, 67 years old, spent much of his childhood on the Sweeny Plantation, about 60 miles southwest of Houston. ''I used to ride my horse all over the county,'' he recalled, ''having lunch with one family or another, and I would go into the woods a lot hunting with my grandfather.''
In 1940, he left to go to college, then to war, then on to a career selling drilling equipment in oil fields around the world. In 1981, prosperous and retired, he returned with his wife, Nancy, to the 840 acres that his family still owned, the rest having been sold off by various relatives over the years starting in the mid-19th century..
 
'The Place Had Changed'
''I was starry-eyed with all these nostalgic dreams of coming back to live the life of the country gentleman here, but the place had changed,'' he said.
A small refinery built by the Federal Government to make aviation fuel in World War II was bought by Phillips in 1949. It grew gradually at first and then very rapidly in the 1980's.
''I didn't realize how much the old times were gone,'' Mr. Bannister said. ''Even the people had changed. They all have a connection to the plant because someone in the family works for Phillips, and all they want is more industry.''
Living in Phillips's shadow, Mr. Bannister gradually became more concerned about the environment. Three years ago, he helped organize a community protest that persuaded Phillips to quiet noisy operations, especially at night. In 1988, he raised the alarm over a leak of fluoride gas that turned hayfields and trees brown. Most recently he questioned the safety of the proposed toxic-waste incinerator at a town meeting.
 
Little Support From Neighbors
Yet he drew little support from his neighbors and concluded that not much could be accomplished. When 23 workers died in an explosion last October at another Phillips petrochemical complex on the outskirts of Houston, he decided, ''people were not meant to live next door to a great big time bomb.''
Phillips had repeatedly offered to buy the Sweeny land, and Mr. Bannister's brother and a cousin who held the title with him were willing to sell. Mr. Bannister insisted that the oil company sign a pledge to maintain the old plantation house and the slave cemetery in their present condition with two acres of open land around each. In turn, Phillips obligated Mr. Bannister not to disclose the sale price or anything about the sale other than the pledge.
Mr. Bannister did not show a hint of sadness as he prepared to leave. Both he and his wife are excited about their new life in San Saba, a rural community in the Texas hill country. ''The air is clean,'' he said. ''There won't be any industry, at least not in my lifetime.''

In the distance is the oil refinery to which he is selling his land. (The New York Times/Sam Pierson); map of Texas showing location of Old Ocean (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Study Shows Racial Imbalance in Penal System

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
Nearly one of every four young black males is behind bars or on probation or parole, a study released today said.
The report by The Sentencing Project, a nonprofit organization that promotes changes in punishment practices, calls for changes in the system to make first-time lawbreakers less likely to become repeat offenders. 
''These new findings should be disturbing to all Americans,'' said Marc Mauer, assistant director of the organization and the author of the report. ''We now risk the possibility of writing off an entire generation of black men from leading productive lives.''
Based on data from the Justice Department, the report says 609,690 black men ages 20 through 29 were under control of the criminal justice system - in prison, in jail, or on probation or parole - in mid-1989. The figure represents 23 percent of the black male population for that age group. It also exceeds the number of black men of all ages who were enrolled in college in 1986, roughly 436,000, the report said.
For white men in the same age category, 1,054,508, or 6.2 percent, were incarcerated or on probation or parole. As for Hispanic males, 238,255, or 10.4 percent, were in the justice system.
The report blames social ills, including high unemployment rates, for the disproportionate number of black men in the prison system.
Stu Smith, a spokesman for the Justice Department, said the report's numbers were accurate, but he declined further comment.
Representative John Conyers, a Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, said he would ask the General Accounting Office, a Congressional investigatory agency, for a study to corroborate the findings. ''These are shocking, disturbing numbers,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Widespread Abuses Reported in Insurance for Nursing Home Care

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Reka Hinderks, a widow hospitalized with osteoporosis at the age of 77 last year, was so concerned about her future care that she decided to buy a $2,400-a-year insurance policy to cover nursing home costs. The agent visited her in the hospital to collect the first premium.
Mrs. Hinderks, who lives in Renville, Minn., was discharged from the hospital after a month. Two months later she entered Ren-Villa Nursing Home, where the agent came to collect her second premium. But when she filed a claim, the insurance company denied it and canceled the policy, saying it did not cover patients who were hospitalized when they purchased coverage. 
Insurance to cover the high costs of nursing care has caught on rapidly in the last five years. But a report released yesterday by Families USA, a Washington advocacy group for the elderly, said that many elderly policyholders, like Mrs. Hinderks, have found their long-term-care insurance useless.
 
'Grotesque Abuses'
''There appears to be a pattern of widespread insurance industry abuse, in terms of deception about what is covered and the experience people have when they file claims,'' said Ronald Pollack, executive director of Families USA. ''It's not just a few fly-by-night companies. We have documented grotesque abuses by some of the most stable, A-plus-rated companies.''
He said that agents aggressively oversell the policies, that companies arbitrarily deny benefits and that policyholders often face long delays in collecting benefits or refunds.
''We need a thorough investigation by Congress and the Federal Trade Commission, and we probably need more regulation to protect frail elderly people,'' Mr. Pollack said.
The House Energy and Commerce Committee, which has the power to direct the trade commission to investigate the industry, plans hearings on the issue.
The industry defended its record yesterday and said it would welcome such an inquiry. ''I think the private market is trying to do a very good job of helping people,'' said Susan Van Gelder of the Health Insurance Association of America, a Washington group representing the leading long-term-care insurers.
''These are heart-wrenching stories,'' she went on, ''and if there are bad apples, let's get rid of them. But let's not discredit the whole private market, because this is a product people need.''
Earl Pomeroy, president of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, also took issue with the Families USA report, saying the group was predisposed to find fault with private long-term-care insurance. ''Some groups that want to see a Government long-term-care program believe the development of private long-term-care insurance will get in the way of that,'' said Mr. Pomeroy, whose group represents the state commissioners who regulate the industry.
 
Coverage Is Spotty
With people over 85 the fastest-growing segment of the population, the long-term-care problem has become an explosive public issue. Nursing home care costs an average of $30,000 a year, and in some places the cost can top $80,000 a year. The Government has estimated that the total cost of nursing home care will be $47.7 billion in 1990, with patients and their families paying about half the bill and the Federal and state governments most of the rest.
Medicare does not cover routine long-term care, and while the requirements vary substantially from state to state, Medicaid is intended to cover nursing care only for the poor, including those whose care has used up their assets. And though the Medigap policies available on the private market pay some costs not covered by Medicare, they do not cover most nursing home stays.
So elderly consumers have been eager to buy private long-term-care insurance. The Health Insurance Association of America estimates that as of mid-1989, 1.3 million policies had been sold nationwide. According to Families USA, the average policy covering two years of care, after a 100-day waiting period, costs $307 a month for a couple in which the husband is 72 and the wife 69.
''That's Chevrolet coverage, not Cadillac coverage,'' Mr. Pollack said, ''and still 84 percent of today's seniors cannot afford to buy it.''
What the policies actually cover varies enormously. Some exclude the first 20 days in the nursing home; others require a wait of 100 days. Some provide coverage for one year, others for longer. Because of all the limitations on coverage, some policyholders have found their claims denied, or their policies canceled, when they actually need care.
 
'I Think It Stinks'
Joseph and Beverly Wiley of Ossipee, N.H., paid $1,176 a year for a policy that would pay $70 a day, after a 100-day waiting period, for up to three years of nursing home care, if the stay began within 30 days of a hospital stay that lasted at least 3 days.
Last spring, Mrs. Wiley, a 70-year old with severe Parkinson's disease, went into the hospital, weighing 68 pounds and suffering from a lung infection. She was in the hospital for 10 weeks before being discharged to a nursing home.
But in August, when Mr. Wiley filed a claim, the Bankers Life and Casualty Insurance Company denied it, saying Mrs. Wiley had not been in the acute-care unit of the hospital, as the policy required. Although the hospital and the State Insurance Department have sent letters saying Mrs. Wiley was treated as an acute care patient, the company continues to deny the claim.
''She did not meet the terms of the policy,'' said Gerald Robinson, of the company's claim review department. ''We do offer policies without the three-day hospital requirement, but they cost more and that's not what she bought.''
So Mr. Wiley pays the $82-a-day charges. ''I think it stinks, to put it bluntly,'' he said. ''I knew nothing about one unit or another; I just knew she was in the hospital. Our insurance agent is the local minister, and I'm sure he didn't know either, or he would have told me to move her.''
 
New Guidelines Taking Effect
In 1988, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners recommended that states prohibit the sale of policies with restrictions based on prior hospitalization or level of care, and last year the group recommended that insurers be required to offer policies with inflation adjustments. At least 35 states have adopted those guidelines, but they cover only new policies, not those already in effect.
''Because it's a new and evolving product, our regulatory standards are changing,'' said Mr. Pomeroy, the president of the association. ''Long-term-care insurance is complex, expensive and sold primarily to the market most susceptible to abusive marketing practices, namely the elderly. So it requires very strict regulation.''
Later this week, the Bipartisan Commission on Comprehensive Health Care, established by Congress in 1988, is likely to issue recommendations on financing long-term care.
''Our mandate is to come up with a solution to the long-term care problem, and the health problem, and develop a blueprint for a national health care policy,'' said Philip Shandler, a spokesman for the commission. ''There has been a growing clamor about long-term care, and there is definitely a consensus that we have problems with long-term care insurance.''

HEADLINE: Blacks Move South for Positive Reasons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Vernon Briggs makes a specious argument when he claims that job competition from recent immigrants is forcing Northern blacks to migrate to the South (letter, Feb. 1). Indeed, 1980 United States Census data show that American-born blacks have lower out-migration rates than any other racial group. Mr. Briggs himself makes this latter point in a 1988 Population Reference Bureau publication, using 1980 Census data.
New York City Planning analysis shows that blacks who leave the city tend to fall into two groups. The first consists of adults in their prime working years who are well educated and already earning a good living. Like many other people who move to the Sunbelt, they are moving because better economic opportunities beckon from the South. In other words, they are being ''pulled,'' not ''pushed.'' 
The second group consists of retirees and women with children under age 18 who wish to rejoin family networks. Unlike other out-migrants, many blacks are returning to their state of birth. For example, more than half of those people who move to South Carolina or Alabama were born in those states. Here too, blacks' migration from the urban North is governed by desirable aspects of life in the South, not by problems of competition in the North.
Anti-immigrant sentiment has arisen continually in this country over the last 200 years. Each wave of immigrants believes the later waves will destroy the social fabric in one way or another. Today's anti-immigrants are becoming increasingly creative at finding ''liberal'' justifications for their sentiments. Mr. Briggs wants to protect American-born blacks from unfair economic competition. Who can disagree with that?
There isn't any evidence to support Mr. Briggs's contention that immigrants are hurting American-born blacks. Cities have enough troubles without academic support for ethnic strife.
 
ELIZABETH BOGEN
Director, Office of Immigrant Affairs
Department of City Planning
 New York, Feb. 8, 1990
