HEADLINE: A New Drain On Housing In New York

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

 BODY:
Brightwater Towers, many of its tenants say, is a fine place to live, with many apartments looking out over the Coney Island Boardwalk to the steely Atlantic beyond. It is, in fact, so fine that the owner plans to pay each household as much as $38,000 to get the residents to leave.
The 738-apartment complex in Brooklyn was built more than two decades ago under the Mitchell-Lama program, widely considered one of the most successful efforts in the nation to create moderate-income housing. But now Brightwater's owner has pulled out of the program, forfeiting tax abatements and low-interest mortgages but gaining the right to convert the complex to cooperative apartments at prices from $92,000 to $270,000.
Because their profits are limited by law, more and more owners are picking up their options to buy their way out of the Mitchell-Lama program when their buildings turn 20 years old. 
And legislators in Albany, for the fifth year, remain deadlocked over how, or even whether, to stanch the loss of this huge stock of scarce affordable housing, where monthly rents average $500.
 
'Allowed to Drift Away'
''It just doesn't make any sense,'' said Paul Podhaizer, a retired postal administrator who is chairman of the Brightwater tenants association. ''You hear so much about the need for this kind of housing, and here it's just being allowed to drift away.''
Many lawmakers, along with state housing officials and tenant leaders, support a moratorium on Mitchell-Lama conversions.
''Is now really the time to let this middle-income housing go, when we can't replace it at six times the cost?'' asked Myron Holtz, deputy commissioner for housing operations at the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
But others say that New York has no right to change the rules in the middle of the game.
Unless the owners are amply compensated for staying in a program that limits their profits, they argue, future developers will be discouraged from dealing with the state at all.
So far 20 of the 421 projects built under the Mitchell-Lama program have been removed. Twenty-one others have buyout applications pending. If their applications are granted, a total of nearly 20,000 apartments will have been lost.
 
Program at Crossroads
More than 80 percent of the 170,000 apartments constructed are in New York City. But with most of the projects past or near their 20th anniversaries, the pace of conversions appears likely to accelerate unless the Legislature acts.
Until now the loss of Mitchell-Lama housing has been slow and not particularly dramatic. Regulations protect tenants from eviction and also limit rent increases. Still many tenants say they fear harassment from landlords with a strong economic incentive to force them out.
''It's slow erosion, not mass devastation,'' said Patricia Belanoff, president of the Mitchell-Lama Residents Coalition, a statewide group that wants to stop the buyouts.
 
Resistance by Some Tenants
At Brightwater Towers, the owner, a family consortium headed by Reuben Glick, has not announced when sales of cooperatives will begin. But already many tenants are vowing to remain, no matter what inducements they are offered to leave.
''Of course we don't want to do that,'' said Mr. Podhaizer, the chairman of the tenant association, referring to the proposed relocation offers. ''Even with that kind of money. Tell me, where would we go in this city?''
Mr. Podhaizer also said that the ''insider'' prices to be offered to tenants to buy their apartments as cooperatives were far too high for most people to be affordable. The prices range from $15,000 to $50,000 below the planned market prices, At Westgate Apartments, a cluster of buildings on West 96th and 97th Streets in Manhattan, many residents are also up in arms over a notice filed by the owner, KSLM Apartments Inc., to convert the apartments to cooperatives. The owner has assured tenants that they will not be evicted and can pay rents subject to rent stabilization guidelines, but many people remain bitterly opposed to the conversion of vacant apartments.
 
'An Emergency in Housing'
''The times just don't warrant this,'' said Abe Schwartz, a retired printer who has lived in the building since 1968. ''We're in an emergency in housing. Even after we go, somebody else should have the right to move in and pay a decent rent.''
The income of most people who live in Mitchell-Lama housing qualifies as low or moderate. According to 1986 figures, the latest available, the median household income of these renters is around $20,000.
But some have much higher incomes and remain. This is because people who originally qualified to move into the apartments are not evicted if their incomes later exceed the guidelines for the program; they pay surcharges of up to 50 percent, based on the amount of their higher income.
Under the Mitchell-Lama plan, created in 1955 and named after its legislative sponsors, developers and nonprofit groups got significant tax abatements and low-interest mortgages for agreeing to charge low rents.
One factor clouding the Mitchell-Lama situation is that it is not a simple landlord-tenant issue.
At some Mitchell-Lama cooperatives, there are residents who strongly favor a buyout. Theoretically residents who invested as little as $3,000 or $5,000 to move into the cooperative could make tens of thousands or more in windfall profits by selling their apartments once they are removed from the Mitchell-Lama program. Many lawmakers are trying to head this off by insisting that most of the profits be plowed back into a fiscal pool to build affordable housing.
 
Bitter Legislative Differences
Negotiations in Albany on a bill setting a 15-year moratorium on buyouts collapsed on the final day of the Legislature's session last summer. Bitter disagreements between the Assembly and the Senate appear to have carried over into this year.
In interviews, leading officials on the housing committees of the two legislative houses contended that they were unable to figure out the other side's position this year. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, in his State of the State address in January, beseeched lawmakers to move to preserve the Mitchell-Lama program, but no action has been taken.
In general, the Assembly has been more sympathetic to tenant concerns and has pushed for a moratorium, which would include changes that could offer a higher rate of return to owners. The Senate has also sought to link any moratorium to a package of measures that would benefit landlords, both in and out of the Mitchell-Lama program.
 
Rise in Profits Suggested
The moratorium backed by the Assembly would increase the landlord's allowable annual return on original investment to 8 1/2 percent from the current limit of 6 1/2 percent. But many owners do not make even 6 1/2 percent.
''I don't want to sound facetious, but the 8 1/2 percent you don't get is just the same as the 6 percent you don't get,'' said Albert A. Walsh, a lawyer and former New York City Housing Commissioner who represents the Mitchell-Lama owners committee of the Association of Builders and Owners of Greater New York.
He said the state had an obligation to let the owners take advantage of the buyout provision, which he contended had lured many into the program in the first place.
The state's Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, Richard L. Higgins, disagreed with that assertion, saying that the tax breaks and low-interest mortgages were far more substantial lures.
''Very few developers went in to the Mitchell-Lama program with the specific idea that 'aha, I'm going to make a whole lot money 20 years from now,' '' said Mr. Higgins, who has been struggling to fashion a moratorium agreement that both the Assembly and the Senate can accept.
In the Legislature, the housing committees tend to blame each other for the impasse.
 
Legislative Finger-Pointing
Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Housing Committee, attributed the failure to ''this death grip the landlords seem to have on the Senate.''
Richard Runes, counsel to the Senate Housing Committee, asserted that Assemblyman Grannis and others ''walked away'' from an agreement last summer on a range of housing measures that included a Mitchell-Lama moratorium.
Several officials in Albany have suggested that the leaders of the Legislature -Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino in the Senate and Speaker Mel Miller in the Assembly - take the matter away from their bickering housing committees and try to work out a compromise themselves.
That the matter remains unresolved has angered many residents of the Mitchell-Lama buildings.
''Mitchell-Lama was a wonderful plan, and it worked,'' said Jean Kane, a resident of Westgate Apartments in upper Manhattan for 21 years. ''To allow that whole program to go down the drain is an outrage.''

HEADLINE: Pumping Sand: New Jersey Starts to Replenish Beaches

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEA BRIGHT, N.J.

 BODY:
Since the beach here disappeared about 50 years ago, all that has stopped the Atlantic from swallowing the rest of this skinny Jersey Shore borough is a stone seawall the length of Ocean Avenue.
Now, after years of study and debate, Sea Bright may have a beach again, at least for a while. Cranes have begun lifting 10-ton boulders into place along the base of the sagging wall. After the wall is rebuilt, the Army Corps of Engineers will pump sand from offshore to create a beach at least 100 feet wide.
The rebuilding of the seawall is the beginning of one of the nation's largest, most ambitious and most expensive shore projects. It would be about twice the size of the recent reconstruction of Miami Beach. 
As work is completed here, the cranes and sand pumps would move, rebuilding the shorelines of Monmouth Beach, Long Branch and other towns along most of the coast as far as Lavallette, 30 miles south.
 
Disappearance of the Sand
The $250 million project is imperial in scope. It is planned to use 90,000 tons of rock and 23 million cubic yards of sand, enough to bury one lane of Interstate 80 from New York to California under 12 feet of sand. And that is just in the initial stages.
To some people, the rebuilding is essential to protect thousands of lives, restore millions in lost tourism dollars and restore some of the most badly eroded beaches in the country.
For others, especially old hands who have seen six feet of beach disappear in a single northeaster, the work would be a thumb in the dike, a pork-barrel favor and a colossal waste of money.
Whatever happens, the new beaches would be open to the public. The few patches of sand that now exist here, in season, are generally restricted to residents or beach club members. ''It's a whole new beginning for tourism and beaches,'' said Representative Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of Long Branch.
The executive director of the American Littoral Society on adjacent Sandy Hook, Dery Bennett, said: ''My guess is that it's going to cost them a great deal more than they estimate and that it will last half as long as they expect. I don't see why the Federal Government would spend 4 cents on it.''
Washington is committed to paying 65 percent of the project. President Bush's budget proposes $29 million for the first section. Additional appropriations would be needed later. State, county and local sources have to pay the remaining 35 percent. The seawall rebuilding is classified as a state project. For many people, the project reflects the influence wielded by Mr. Pallone's predecessor, James J. Howard, before his death in 1988. The Democrat of Belmar, who represented the area for 23 years, was chairman of the powerful House Public Works and Transportation Committee. Without his power and seniority, it seems unlikely that the project could have survived budget scrutiny.
Opinion about the project is divided in this borough, four jagged miles of shoreline sandwiched between the Atlantic Ocean and the Shrewsbury River, in spots but half a block wide. Mayor Charles Rooney, a 59-year-old triathlete, said the project would be the salvation of his beloved town. ''Without the rocks,'' he said, referring to the seawall the way residents do, ''there is no Sea Bright.''
Live through one winter here and watch the waves break over the 18-foot-high concrete and stone seawall, residents said, and one can make peace with the water or move. The residents said they were not threatened by the surf's pounding against the rocks, even though they drive daily past lighted traffic signs reminding them, ''Road Flooded When Flashing.''
What some of the 1,800 residents do worry about is how much the reconstruction would cost. The local share is $1.6 million, $150,000 more than the entire 1989 municipal budget.
To Alan V. Hinton, 79, the project is ''a real waste of money.'' He should know what he is talking about when it comes to the seawall, he said, because it sits in his front yard.
Like other homeowners along Ocean Avenue, also designated Route 36, Mr. Hinton's property extends to the eastern side of the road and what used to be the right of way of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, including the sand under the seawall. A few property owners have their addresses painted on the rocks, and they have put up No Trespassing signs and wood stairs to concrete patios on top of the wall.
 
Science and Art
Mr. Hinton insists that the wall is not Sea Bright's responsibility. Another resident, John A. Robertson, said the wall protected a highway, power lines and sewers. ''It's the coastline of the United States we're talking about,'' he said.
Mr. Bennett said the project would provide little public benefit, but insured that the local property values would rise. ''What we're talking about here is real-estate protection, not shore protection,'' he said.
For the Army Engineers, building a beach is a science and an art, an attempt to do with bulldozers and pumps what nature does by whim.
Section 1 covers the 12 miles from Sea Bright to Loch Arbour. Engineers plan beaches at least 100 feet wide and about 10 feet above low water. Hydraulic pumps and tankerlike dredges would carry sand from the ocean floor a mile and a half away to the seawall. Working 24 hours a day in season, the work could take five years.
 
Flow of the Sand
Jetties, also called groins, once the choice to protect beaches, are now recognized as often causing more harm than good. The corps is experimenting with pumping sand at the seawall base and then shooting more sand at Long Branch, south of here. That beach is to be a feeder for the few beaches to the north, providing the ocean with sand to carry up the coast with the natural drift. As the project proceeds, other feeders would be established.
The Army project manager, Michael L. Jurist, said the feeders would have to be replenished on average every six years for the next half-century. Most of the sand would eventually make its way to Sandy Hook, parts of which are badly eroded. The nourishment of Sandy Hook, part of the Gateway National Recreational Area, is considered a principal benefit of this plan.
Studies estimate the project would also prevent $7.2 million a year in storm damage to private property and generate $8.3 million a year in recreation and tourism.
Beach erosion is nothing new in New Jersey. But the state's attitude toward the shore is changing. Regulators have become progressively more concerned about overbuilding in sensitive coastal areas. For 10 years, the state has been reluctant to protect developed coastal areas, except in emergencies.
 
Bicycle Path for Public
For this project, state officials said they decided to cooperate only after Sea Bright and Monmouth Beach had agreed to make the new beaches accessible to outsiders. At the outset, the state had asked for large parking lots at the base of the rocks, but opposition was strong.
''I wouldn't have wanted to come down here on a Sunday and have one of the neighbors say, 'Where'd all these cars come from?' '' Mr. Rooney said. ''They'd shoot me.'' The compromise was for the state to build an 18-foot-wide bicycle path at the base of the wall. There will be a few small parking areas, and stairs will be built in several spots so people can pass over the rocks to the new beach.
Similar arrangements are to be made in Monmouth Beach.
The shore remains critical to the New Jersey economy. Tourism is still the state's No. 1 industry. But to some crtiics, such grandiose projects reflect hubris about taming nature.
''The most comprehensive approach to this,'' the state's coastal resources director, John R. Weingart, said, ''would have been to move all the buildings away and say this is not a safe place to live.''

PUB-DATE: February 27, 1990

LENGTH: 358 words

HEADLINE: Cuomo and Florio Criticize Bush on Lack of Money for Education

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26

 BODY:
The Democratic governors of New York and New Jersey, both of whom face major budget problems at home, criticized the Bush Administration today for failing to commit Federal dollars to the education goals established on Sunday by the White House and the nation's governors.
After joining members of the National Governors Association in a meeting with President Bush this morning, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Gov. Jim Florio both complained that Mr. Bush expected state and local governments to shoulder the full tax burden of improving the country's educational system.
Mr. Cuomo said increases in state and local taxes would hit poor and middle-income Americans the hardest at a time when the Federal Government has slashed income-tax rates for the wealthiest taxpayers. 
''What they're saying right now very clearly is we approve of taxing the middle class and working poor before we go back to the rich people,'' Mr. Cuomo said after the White House meeting.
 
'Weakening the Fabric'
Stephen T. Hart, a White House spokesman, said all levels of government had increased education spending in recent years with little improvement, and he criticized Mr. Cuomo for believing that money alone could solve the crisis. ''He's sounding a familiar refrain, which is that the answer to our education problems is simply more money, Mr. Hart said. ''We disagree.''
Mr. Florio said he was not optimistic about the Federal Government paying a larger share of the country's education costs. ''If it happens, that's fine, that's nice,'' he said. ''But we don't have the luxury to wait around.''
On Sunday, the governors unanimously approved a resolution, negotiated with the White House during the last year, which sets national education goals for the year 2000. The goals include reducing the high school dropout rate to 10 percent and insuring that every adult is literate.
Mr. Bush said today that he will ''encourage the people of this country to support state and local initiatives'' to improve education. But with the exception of increasing Head Start financing by $500 million, his proposed budget includes little new money for education.

HEADLINE: Baseball Factions Leave the Table

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
As union officials left for Phoenix and a players' executive board meeting today, the chances for a settlement that would end the club owners' lockout and salvage the start of the baseball season seemed to hinge on the possibility of a last-minute proposal from the owners. No proposal, however, was forthcoming.
''It's not going to happen,'' Fay Vincent, the baseball commissioner, said last night. ''There aren't going to be any more suggestions or proposals for a while. We just don't have any.'' 
With the lockout of players from spring training camps nearly two weeks old, baseball's labor dispute faces a lengthy recess in negotiations that is virtually certain to affect the start of the season, scheduled for April 2.
Donald Fehr, the union leader, said yesterday that after the executive board meets today, he may hold two or three meetings with groups of players in cities around the country. The owners' negotiators said they had no plans to follow Fehr so they could resume the talks.
 
'Really Serious'
Acknowledging that he saw a lengthy recess coming, Vincent said: ''I think it's really serious. It makes everybody become more extreme. Positions harden. People move further apart. This has all the earmarks of a very serious one.''
Not even a ''courtesy call'' Fehr paid on the commissioner in Manhattan before he left for Phoenix had any effect.
''It was my invitation,'' Vincent said. ''At least I wanted to say I didn't have any more thoughts. I owed them that. I asked Don where he was going after Phoenix and he said he didn't know. I guess he'll go on his trip and we'll see what happens.''
At a news briefing yesterday, Charles O'Connor, the owners' labor spokesman, did release a list of the owners' current proposals, and a few of the provisions were new. None, however, dealt with the impasse over salary arbitration.
The clubs changed their position from two years to three on when either side could terminate the proposed four-year agreement and initiate negotiations on a new one. They offered collusion protection in the form of triple damages and new-look free agency remedies if the clubs again engage in collusion against free agents. And they said that members of the study commission on revenue participation would be non-baseball people.
Negotiators for the two sides did not meet at the bargaining table yesterday. Instead, they spent the morning and early part of the afternoon making telephone calls and sending fax messages dealing with language on such matters as the study commission the owners want and the collusion protection the players want.
Fehr said the communications did not touch on the key issues in the dispute: eligibility for salary arbitration and the owners' contribution to the players' pension and benefit plan. Appearing briefly at a news briefing at the Helmsley Palace, he left the impression that the prospects of a settlement looked bleak.
''We have not broken through the salary arbitration problem,'' he said. ''There have been no new proposals made on the benefit plan, minimum salaries, rosters. I'll report to the players tomorrow as to what the status is and we'll go from there.''
 
'Appropriate to Separate'
O'Connor did not present a rosier picture when he was asked about the recess in talks. ''We have reached the point where it is appropriate to separate for a while,'' O'Connor said.
About 15 minutes after Fehr spoke with reporters, he was at the commissioner's office, where he was spotted by a group of reporters who themselves had hoped to see the commissioner. A few minutes later, Fehr emerged with two of his aides, Eugene Orza and Mark Belanger.
Asked why they had been there, Fehr said: ''We paid a courtesy call to Fay. We came over to say goodbye.''
Fehr was asked whether he was accustomed to saying goodbye to the commissioner before he left on a trip.
''Steve had asked if we would stop by for two minutes before we left,'' he replied, referring to Steve Greenberg, the deputy commissioner. ''We said sure. We stopped by for two minutes and left.''
Vincent was especially downcast over his inability to generate some movement Sunday on the arbitration eligibility issue. The owners have been adamant about keeping the eligibility level at three years of major league service. The players have just as adamantly demanded a return to two years, where the level stood before the 1985 negotiations.
''There's got to be some compromise,'' the commissioner said. ''No one here knows what the compromise might be. It's hard to deal with. The players' position was there should be some players treated as three-year players who aren't. I tried to come up with something, but they didn't move.''
 
'National Disgrace'
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 26 (AP) -Gov. William Donald Schaefer of Maryland and 13 other governors sent a letter to Commissioner Fay Vincent and representatives of major league baseball owners and players today, calling their labor dispute ''a national disgrace.''
''Baseball is too important to our country - both economically and culturally - to allow this to drag on,'' the letter said.
It urged the owners, players and the commissioner to do everything possible to reach an agreement quickly so spring training could begin and the season open on time.
Schaefer persuaded chief executives from three other states with major league baseball teams - California, Massachusetts and Ohio - to sign his letter.

HEADLINE: On Horse Racing;
At Gulfstream, All the Extras Add Up to Less

BYLINE: By Steven Crist

DATELINE: HALLANDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
For Gulfstream Park, life at the top is proving lonelier than expected.
Over the last 20 years, Gulfstream has supplanted Hialeah Park as the Miami area's most successful race track. Beginning in 1972, Gulfstream was given a crack in alternate years at operating during the prime midwinter racing dates and it consistently outdrew and outhandled Hialeah. The state began awarding the prized dates to Gulfstream more often and this year Hialeah shut down altogether. 
Florida winter racing belongs entirely to Gulfstream this season and the game figured to be stronger than ever. Stall space was tight, so only the best and readiest horses would be on the grounds.
Without a dominant Kentucky Derby favorite, the 3-year-old ranks would be busy and contentious. Freed from the usual wrangling with Hialeah, Gulfstream would be able to expend its full resources on promoting and improving its product. An imminent change of ownership, bringing both Gulfstream and Calder Race Course in North Miami under the control of Bertram R. Firestone and partners, would bring fresh energy, money and ideas.
Instead, business is slumping after two decades of steady growth. Through the first 35 days of the meeting, attendance is off 3.61 percent and the betting handle has plummeted by 7.08 percent. The racing, always a mix between national stars and cheap locals, has had more of the latter than ever before. Even the stars have been slow to come out.
The best racing is likely to come over the next three weeks, but the worst business will follow that. Gulfstream is operating a 90-day meet this year, nearly twice as long as usual, and track officials are bracing for a dismal final month.
The top horses and the tourists will be gone by April, and the racing may be indistinguishable from the drab fare offered at Calder during the off season. Having won a 20-year battle to conduct the best winter racing in the East, Gulfstream is now losing customers, bets and quality. What went wrong?
Track officials have a plausible menu of short-term explanations for the business decline. They say this has been a soft tourist season, perhaps because of a mild winter in the Northeast, perhaps because of a slowing national economy. They say the closing of Hialeah has limited the number of horsemen here for the winter, and owners and trainers usually account for about 20 percent of the betting handle. The Super Bowl was in Miami last year, which helped business and the Florida Lottery is more popular than ever.
These factors, though, do not explain the tepid nature of the racing, though, nor do they address the feeling among horsemen and horseplayers that something is amiss this winter. One problem is Gulfstream's highly erratic racing surface. Many top horses are training poorly over it, and their trainers are making noises about wintering elsewhere next year. For much of the meeting, the inside of the track has been so hard and the outside so deep that races were effectively decided at the post-position draw.
The major theme of this winter, though, is excess, and the lesson is the old one that more is sometimes less.
Every time that a race track has expanded its season, the quality of the racing has declined along with the daily average attendance and handle. More subtly, and just as important, the track's appeal has been diluted. Oaklawn Park in Hot Springs, Ark., lost its spring-festival charm when it began opening in early February. New York racing lost all sense of season once winter racing made the game a year-round grind. If you extended Saratoga from four to seven weeks, it would no longer feel like Saratoga.
It is no coincidence that New York and California, which present the very best racing in the country, also offer the fewest races a day. Nine are enough for the most successful tracks, but Gulfstream went to 11 races a day this year. The days are too long, the homework too demanding for even the most dedicated horseplayer. The extra races are just extra opportunities to separate the public from its money while putting up minimal purses for the worst horses in the area.
The betting is down more than the attendance because the turnstiles keep counting all day but more and more fans are arriving late in the card. Unless you are desperate for parimutuel action or a fan of cheap and formless claimers, you can safely skip the first four races on most Gulfstream cards and spend an extra two hours on the beach.
Handicapping the future of Florida racing is as tough as deciphering the early races as Gulfstream, since so much hinges on Hialeah's future. Regardless of that, though, Gulfstream seems sure to operate during the midwinter dates, and is in a unique position to make intelligent choices. Most tracks expand their seasons to ensure their survival or under state mandate to increase public revenues. Once Gulfstream and Calder are officially under common ownership, though, Firestone and his partners can make the Gulfstream meeting however long they choose and run the rest of the dates at Calder.
Firestone has said often that he wants to make Gulfstream the home of the nation's finest winter racing. After this season, it seems clear that the way to do that is to remember that less is sometimes more. A 50-day meeting with no more than 10 races a day would be plenty.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MARKETS
 
Japan's Government and the Tokyo Stock Exchange sought to calm investors amid the largest stock decline since the crash of October 1987. The Bank of Japan offered short-term loans to banks to make sure the market had enough cash to operate. The Finance Ministry bought bonds to push long-term interest rates lower. And the Bank of Japan intervened heavily in the currency markets to try to halt the dollar's rise against the yen. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks today regained part of the lost ground. [Page A1.] Analysts are scurrying to explain why the dive in Japanese stocks during the last week has not pushed down other worldwide markets. [D8.]
 
Turbulence in Tokyo failed to disrupt the American stock market. The Dow Jones industrials jumped 38.29 points, to 2,602.48. [D1.] Prices of Treasury securities moved higher. A stronger dollar and weaker metals prices help to cool inflationary pressures. [D18.] 
 
Prices of precious metals plunged. As share prices tumbled in Japan, many private and institutional investors sold gold, platinum and silver to raise cash to meet margin calls. Gold fell $6.30 an ounce, to $408.70, on the Comex in New York. [D19.]
 
The dollar climbed to its highest levels in eight months against the yen, as slumping stock prices reduced the chance that Japan would soon raise interest rates. [D19.]

American Express said it would inject $750 million into Shearson Lehman Hutton by buying new stock in the firm. [D1.]
 
Control of The New York Times and related properties passes to the four children of Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, who died yesterday, through the automatic termination of a trust. [B7.]

HEADLINE: Wall Street Weathers Japan Jolt

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
The United States stock market showed its resiliency yesterday, weathering the second-biggest drop in the history of the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
Although the Dow Jones industrial average fell at the opening, it rebounded to remain about 20 points higher throughout most of the afternoon. It finished the day with a gain of 38.29 points, or 1.5 percent, at 2,602.48.
The performance yesterday was in sharp contrast to that of last week. The Dow fell 10.58 points on Friday, to 2,564.19, bringing its loss for the week to 71.40 points. 
Stocks were helped by the strength of the dollar on foreign exchange markets. The dollar made strong gains against the yen and was higher against the West German mark.
 
Focus on Blue Chips
Traders pointed out that yesterday's stock market gain, which was also bolstered by bargain hunting and a spate of futures-related buying near the close, was concentrated in blue-chip stocks. Rising issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declining ones by a relatively narrow 822 to 639. Indeed, the overall market was mixed until the final hour, when the buying of secondary issues picked up.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.52 points, to 328.67, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index was up 1.91 points, to 181.26.
Volume on the Big Board continued to be relatively light. Only 148.9 million shares changed hands, up slightly from the 148.5 million of Friday.
 
Japan's 2d-Biggest Drop
In Tokyo today, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 576.08 points to 33,897.95, after tumbling 1,569.10 points, or 4.5 percent, yesterday, when worry about inflation and weakness in the yen led to widespread selling.
On a point basis, the drop yesterday was second only to the Nikkei's decline of a record 3,836.48 on Oct. 19, 1987. Last week, the Nikkei index fell 6.9 percent.
Analysts, noting that the link between movements in the American and Japanese markets may not be as critical as previously believed, said the United States market was also buoyed when other foreign markets did not follow Japan's lead. Stocks were up moderately in London, off a bit in Frankfurt, up slightly in Parisand narrowly lower in Hong Kong.
''The sharp drop in the overpriced Tokyo market to more sustainable levels could have a stabilizing influence - neutralizing a potentially serious threat to world markets,'' said James Kalil Sr., president of Compu-Val Investments Inc., in Wilmington, Del. ''In the absence of panic selling, both the U.S. and Japanese markets will respond to internal factors - the Japanese to interest rates and very high price-earnings ratios, while our concern is for interest rates and the economic outlook.''
Among individual issues, Federal Express soared 4 1/4, to 51 1/2. Analysts attributed the gain to an improved long-term outlook for the company as well as to an unconfirmed rumor that British Airways might be interested in buying the company.
Gold and other precious metals stocks dropped across the board as the spot price of gold on the Commodity Exchange in New York settled at $408.70 an ounce, down $6.30. Platinum sank $15.40 an ounce, to $511, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Traders said the Japanese were selling precious metals to raise cash for margin calls after the drop in the stock market created a liquidity crisis for both private investors and institutions.
Among the hard-hit precious metals stocks were ASA Ltd., down 3 7/8, to 51 1/8; Homestake Mining, off 1 3/4, to 19 5/8; Sunshine Mining down 1/8, to 3 3/4; Newmont Gold, down 2, to 53, and Newmont Mining, off 1 5/8, to 51 7/8.
Tiffany fell 1/2, to 34 5/8, on what traders said were concerns that Japanese consumers would cut back on their purchases of the company's merchandise because of the decline in Japanese stocks.
Pfizer slipped 1/4, to 56, after being off more than a point in early trading. Officials at the Food and Drug Administration and Pfizer, the maker of an articial heart valve linked to hundreds of deaths, were questioned yesterday by Congressional investigators. The Acting Commissioner of the F.D.A., James S. Benson, said questions about Pfizer's marketing of its Shiley valve merited investigation by his agency.
Japanese stocks traded in the United States were sharply lower. Kyocera fell 1 1/2, to 85; Hitachi 1 1/2, to 98, and Matsushita 3/4, to 138 1/4.

HEADLINE: Japan Now Ahead in Nuclear Power, Too

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22

 BODY:
Japan is rapidly outpacing the United States in the field of nuclear power, American experts in Government, academia and the utility industry say.
Japan's advantages are widening in research and development, in construction techniques and in safe operation of the plants, according to a team of seven experts who recently returned from a National Science Foundation trip to Japan.
Even in the areas of nuclear-plant design, where American companies are making progress, the improvements will first make their way from blueprint to steel and concrete in plants built in Japan.
Several of the experts compared the loss of American leadership in nuclear power - a technology invented and first commercialized in the United States - to the fate of the American computer and auto industries, which are threatened by Japanese inventions and manufacturing advances.
Members of the team returning from Japan noted at a conference here this week the long hiatus in orders for nuclear plants in this country and said the American losses were becoming harder to reverse. 
''The infrastructure required to build nuclear plants in the United States is slowly dwindling,'' said Kent F. Hansen, a professor of nuclear engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the chairman of the group. ''Without more projects, our ability to build them as cheaply as others will suffer.''
The last order for a nuclear power plant in the United States was in 1978, and since then utilities in this country have canceled about 65. In the same period, Japan has broken ground for 23 reactors. Japan has 37 operating, compared with 111 in this country. It has 12 plants under construction; this country has 5, all mostly completed.
Kevin D. Burke, an international relations specialist at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, said in a telephone interview that a late start gives Japan a natural advantage. ''They've been able to look at the other nuclear programs in the world and, in many ways, improve on them, learning from the operating experience of the French program, the German program and the American program,'' he said. ''It's unfair to say in black and white that their program is better; it should be better.'' Revival Sought in U.S. Supporters of nuclear power hope American orders will revive in the middle of this decade, spurred by new designs and changes in the system for building and licensing plants. Two American manufacturers, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the General Electric Company, are designing advanced plants in work supported by the Government, and applying to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for generic approval. The idea is that utilities could win quick permission for a new plant by picking one of the approved designs rather than custom-designing, as has been the case in the past.
Still, the first copies of both companies' new plants are likely to be built in Japan, the experts said.
Building those models here successfully would require learning from the experience of the Japanese, said Loring Mills, a nuclear specialist of the Edison Electric Institute, the utility trade association. ''If we don't find a way to build new plants in the next four or five years like they do, we're not going to build them,'' he predicted.
 
More Important in Japan
But experts at the conference here were quick to point out that nuclear power is far more important for Japan, which has virtually no indigenous energy resources and a strong desire for energy independence, than for the United States, which can burn native coal for most of its electricity and is content to import oil and natural gas for much of the remainder.
Experts made these points about the deterioration of the United States leadership in nuclear power:
* Construction of a nuclear plant averages 5 years in Japan, compared with 11 in this country. Because designs are better developed before construction in Japan, a Japanese plant requires only half as many hours of work by skilled craftsmen as does an American one of the same size. And Japanese builders guarantee the prices, eliminating ballooning costs on the way to completion.
* Operation is smoother in Japan, with unplanned shutdowns coming only one-tenth as often as in American plants, on average. Japanese plants ran at 72.3 percent of capacity last year, compared with 63.3 percent in this country. The level of radioactivity in the cooling water in Japanese nuclear plants is 500 times smaller than in American plants, and the radiation dose to plant workers is 10 to 15 times smaller.
* Research and development has produced more advances in many areas in Japan. Among them: computers in some control rooms that respond to the spoken commands of operators and run a growing range of systems automatically. Researchers are making progress toward a new nuclear fuel that will last substantially longer than the current nine months, which would allow a longer interval between refueling shutdowns. And researchers are beginning work on a ''self healing'' plant that will diagnose its own problems and send robots to fix them.
 
Attention to Detail
The team spent a week in Japan last month, visiting 17 agencies, institutions and companies. The visit was part of a series organized by the National Science Foundation's Japanese Technology Evaluation Center, based at Loyola College in Baltimore, to evaluate Japanese progress in such fields as biotechnology, telecommunications and superconductivity.
As with assessments in other areas, the nuclear team found that the United States retains a lead in some areas. For example, the Japanese rely heavily on computer codes developed in this country to simulate various reactor conditions, and the American lead in the field is growing.
But the team found that patience and attention to detail were propelling Japan toward leadership in still another field. From a distance, Japanese reactors are similar to American ones, on which they are based, said Donald R. Olander, a professor of nuclear engineering at the University of California at Berkeley. ''They are very similar, much as a Nissan pickup truck is similar to a Ford Ranger,'' he said. ''But there are small differences which make an enormous difference.'' These, he said, are reflected in higher reliability.
 
New Developments a Factor
In building their own industry, the Japanese have taken advantage of numerous technological developments not available when most American plants were planned, the panel said. These include computer-assisted design, advanced computers for controlling plant processes, fiber-optic communications channels, increased fabrication of large parts in shops instead of in the field, and new construction materials.
Some innovations are not Japanese, but have been perfected in Japan, said Dr. Hansen of M.I.T. ''The heaviest-lifting crane is a U.S. design,'' he said. ''They have several of them there and know more about how to use them than we do.''
In addition, Dr. Hansen said, the Japanese construction industry spends $800 million a year, about 0.54 percent of sales, on research and development of new techniques, some of which can be applied to nuclear plants. By contrast, the United States industry invests $50 million, or 0.04 percent of sales.
Japan also outspends the United States on research and development for advanced reactors, by $775 million a year to $187.5 million, and on research for the current generation of reactors, by $291 million to $180 million. Both figures exclude proprietary research by companies.
 
More Scholarly Papers
The nuclear programs of Japanese universities are well supported, the panelists said, and Japanese scientists in academia, industry and the national laboratories publish nearly twice as many scholarly papers on nuclear materials as Americans do.
Some research is in areas this country has rejected. The Japanese industry has pursued a reactor for ship propulsion, even though it does not think such a reactor will be commercially attractive any time soon, the experts said. In addition, the industry is pursuing plans to recover and re-use the plutonium fuel created in the operation of existing reactors, a step rejected in this country because it could lead to the spread of nuclear weapons. Japan is also building a ''breeder'' reactor, which makes nuclear fuel faster than it uses it up.
While the United States is unlikely to move to a breeder system, with extensive supplies of uranium available cheaply, this country would benefit from a more long-term, safety-oriented approached to the technology, the experts said. But one of the panelists, Victor H. Ransom, a scientific and engineering fellow at the Idaho National Engineering Laboratory, said that while the United States nuclear industry would benefit from adopting the Japanese drive toward quality and reliability, the drive arose not from technology but culture. Regulation is less contentious in Japan, he said, because the Ministry of International Trade and Industry trusts ''that the utilities will actually do the right thing.''
''The same system probably would not work here,'' he said. ''There are enough organizations that have stayed within the law but have done everything on the basis of economics,'' scrimping on expenditures that would mean long-term savings.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Training Unit Sought by Edu

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 26

 BODY:
A former executive of the National Education Corporation offered to aquire its troubled corporate-training division, Applied Learning International Inc.
The former executive, William R. Roach, offered through a company called the Edu Coporation to merge with Applied Learning. Under his proposal, Edu would inject $20 million in capital and National Education would retain a ''substantial minority equity position'' in the new company, which Edu would run. The plan does not call for National Education to receive any payment for giving up control.
Officials at National Education, based in Irvine, Calif., did not return calls seeking comment.
Recently, Mr. Roach has presented several offers for Applied Learning to the board of National Education, which is the nation's largest operator of vocational schools and corporate training programs.
 
Largely because of losses at
Applied Learning, National Education's stock has fallen from a high of over $30 in 1988.
The stock closed at $6.25 today, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Mr. Roach ran Applied
Learning in 1988. He later started Edu, which acquired the Control Data Corporation's training division last year.

HEADLINE: Why World Shrugged Off Tokyo's Stock Tumble

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
For some time, market watchers around the world have expressed concern that if the high-flying Tokyo stock market ever plunged, other markets would be carried down with it. But the Japanese stock market's 11 percent dive over the last week, a fairly big move by most standards, has not touched off sharp slides elsewhere, and analysts are scurrying to explain why.
The most common explanation is that the Japanese market had moved up so much more sharply than other markets that some downward adjustment was due, both to bring it into line with the bond markets in Japan and with financial markets in other countries. Some movement, analysts argued, could be accommodated -even expected. 
''I don't see why this should become self-feeding, because there is no real talk of a worldwide recession and earnings are still reasonable,'' said David A. Robbins, head of the international securities department at UBS Securities. ''This should support equity markets.''
 
'Peculiarly Japanese'
''So far investors look at the Tokyo market decline as a peculiarly Japanese situation, not a global situation,'' said Yuichi Kohashi, executive vice president of Daiwa Securities America Inc. in New York.
This is not to say investors in other markets have not been worried about the 4,138.45-point decline in the Nikkei 225 index of leading stocks in the last six days. A sharp decline in a major market, even if easily explained, can be unsettling. The United States stock markets fell each day last week, although the Dow Jones industrial average shot up yesterday by 38.29 points, to 2,602.48. For the year, the United States is down about 5 percent, Britain has dropped close to 7 percent and France is off more than 10 percent.
The relatively benign view of the decline in the Japanese stock market, which is now down 14.4 percent since the end of last year, rests on the fact that many analysts thought the rise to record levels at the end of December had taken the market too high. Because of this, it was expected that the Japanese market would fall, a move known in market jargon as a correction.
 
'Its Own Correction'
''A lot of stock markets I follow have already corrected,'' said Lawrence W. Harris 3d, manager of the Worldwide Value Fund. ''Japan seems to be having its own correction.''
In addition, the sharper rise in interest rates in Japan and the unusually public fight over interest-rate policy between the Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, and the Finance Ministry have, for now, made this more a Japanese problem than a global one.
While interest rates have risen around the world, the increase in Japan has been sharper than in many other countries. Rates on 10-year bonds in Japan are up about 19 percent this year, compared with 7 percent in the United States. This means earnings on bonds became far more attractive than those on stocks, drawing money out of the stock market into bonds. The divergence in Japan has been larger than in other countries, like the United States and Britain. That is one reason the stock markets in those countries have fared better, said Alistair Ross Goobey of James Capel Inc., a London brokerage firm.
''The Japanese market, more than any other market, was extended in relation to its bond market,'' said Jeffrey M. Weingarten, director of international equity research at Goldman, Sachs in London.
 
Fight Over Interest Rates
Despite the fact that the Japanese wave has not yet swamped the rest of the world, many financial experts say the outlook is still uncertain. The fight in Japan over interest-rate policy could be unsettling. But Mr. Kohashi of Daiwa, for one, thinks Japan's desire to stabilize its market means interest rates will not be raised again soon.
But not everyone agrees. Some analysts warn that Japan may have to raise interest rates further to prop up the yen, which leaves the door open to a continued decline in Japanese stocks. With higher interest rates and a further decline in stock prices - of perhaps an additional 2,000 to 3,000 points - analysts said Japan's market problems could be contagious. Higher rates in Japan could help push interest rates higher around the world, weakening equity prices everywhere.
There are other pressures, too, that investors fear could push interest rates higher around the globe. Perhaps the most important is that the unification of Germany and development of Eastern Europe will push world interest rates higher by increasing the demand for credit. If that happens, that could force stock prices in Japan and other nations down further.
 
Pressure on Institutions
Another fear is that Japan's market weakness could spread if Japanese economic officials get so worried about the fall of their market that they put pressure on large institutional investors to bring some of their money back to Tokyo to support the market there.
''It's not changing my view that the sidelines are the place to be,'' said Barton M. Biggs, director of worldwide strategy at Morgan Stanley, who said he was surprised by the rise in American stock prices yesterday. ''I think it is a silly reaction because the Japanese market is another cloud on the horizon.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Climb in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, bolstered by a strong dollar, a drop in the price of gold and other precious metals, and another big decline in the Japanese equity market.
The selloff on the Tokyo Stock Exchange prompted the initial rise during overnight trading, traders said, as market participants bought securities on the expectation that stocks in the United States would take a plunge.
The anticipated spillover did not take place, however, and as stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange moved higher early in the day, dealers were forced to pare their positions in the credit markets somewhat.
But the dollar's strong performance and the drop in metal prices tempered the declines and encouraged further buying later in the session. A stronger dollar and weaker metals prices help to cool inflationary pressures. 
In addition, participants said the fact that no new Treasury debt issues will be offered to investors for the better part of a month helped to firm prices.
''I think we can do better from here,'' one Government bond trader said. ''We don't get any new supply until late March, and the strength of the dollar is helping us. You don't need to be too sophisticated to see that on a day when foreign markets are doing worse and ours are doing better that money is moving into this country.''
William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said that ''there seems to be a new assessment about what is going on in foreign markets and how it effects the United States.'' He added, ''Among other things, we are learning that turbulence in the Japanese equities market is pushing people into Treasuries.''
 
Long-Term Notes and Bonds
The bulk of the price improvement was reflected in longer-term notes and bonds.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 100 1/8, up more than half a point, or more than $5 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 8.48 percent, compared with 8.56 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 11/ 32, up half a point, to yield 8.45 percent. And 8 1/2 percent two-year notes auctioned last week were offered at 100 1/4, up 2/32, to yield 8.34 percent.
Meanwhile, rates dipped on three-month and six-month Treasury bills auctioned yesterday.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.72 percent, down from an average rate of 7.80 percent at last week's sale.
 
Six-Month Bill Rates
Six-month bills were sold at an average rate of 7.70 percent, compared with an average rate of 7.77 percent a week ago.
While some analysts said that a dearth of new Treasury issues would tend to improve market conditions, others said that Japanese activity over the next month or so could limit any real improvement.
''I still have a lot of uncertainty regarding what Japanese institutions will be doing as they move toward the end of their fiscal year on March 31,'' said Robert Sinche, a fixed-income portfolio manager at Alliance Capital.
''Some institutions may have some unrealized gains in dollar-denominated fixed-income securities that they may want to use to offset big equity losses in Japan. We are optimistic about the market as the year progresses, but we don't think there is much room for improvement until this uncertainty about Japan recedes.''
Activity in the new-issue market for investment-grade corporate bonds was highlighted by a $500 million offering of 10-year notes from the Province of Quebec.
The 9 1/8 percent notes, which mature March 1, 2000 and are noncallable for life, were priced at $99.854, to yield 9.147, 69 basis points, or hundredths of a point, over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA-minus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Corporate bond traders said that prices of most actively traded issues in the secondary market rose by 3/8 point to 1/2 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, participants said that prices of most issues rose by 1/4 point to 3/8 point in sluggish trading.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Broadly, Reaching 8-Month Highs Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar climbed broadly yesterday in foreign exchange trading, reaching its highest levels in eight months against the Japanese yen despite reported efforts by monetary authorities in Japan and the United States to curb its advance.
In New York, the United States currency rose to 148.63 yen, from 147.07 yen in late trading Friday.
Another sharp decline in the Tokyo stock market overnight helped the dollar because the decline reduced chances that Japanese authorities would raise interest rates there, analysts said. Higher interest rates in Japan would encourage foreigners to purchase yen to make investments in that country, but they would also make consumer and corporate borrowing more expensive. 
''They can't raise interest rates because that would send their stock and real estate markets into a tailspin,'' said Jerry Rothman, a currency broker for Elders Futures Inc.
He said the Bank of Japan and the Federal Reserve Board each intervened in the currency markets during the trading day in an effort to curb the dollar's rise and stop the yen's fall.
But Mr. Rothman and other dealers said the dollar sales by the central banks failed to drive the dollar lower.
''This is the highest dollar level against the yen since last June,'' Mr. Rothman said. ''But there is little they can do about it short of raising interest rates.''
Karen Gibbs, a senior vice president in financial futures at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said the dollar also benefited from its traditional role as a safe haven because of the financial uncertainty in Japan.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 148.65 Japanese yen, from 146.47 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 148.80 yen.
It also rose strongly against the West German currency, up a pfennig, to 1.6882 marks from 1.6785.
The dollar gained ground against the British pound. In London, the pound fell to $1.6927, from $1.7090 late Friday. In New York, the pound fell to $1.6903 from $1.7092.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.4860 Swiss francs, up from 1.4740; 5.7140 French francs, up from 5.6825; 1,248.50 Italian lire, up from 1,241.50, and 1.19405 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19825.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Broadening The Study Of Business

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the Great Depression and World War II might have been living drama for their grandparents, they are but historical footnotes for many of today's students, who often complete college without encountering courses in history or the social sciences.
One reason: core programs and emphasis on choosing elective courses related to a speciality tend to leave litte room for a broad range of courses.
That may be changing, however, as several graduate schools of business are giving new emphasis to the study of history, international studies and other areas that provide a broader perspective on business.
Tomorrow, for example, the Stern School of Business at New York University will announce the professor for a new course entitled the history of financial institutions and markets. The professor will fill the new Henry Kaufman chair, named for the economist. 
Dr. Kaufman, who was a graduate of the business school, endowed that chair, as well as the Charles Simon Professorship of Finance. His gifts also established Stern's Salomon Brothers Center for the Study of Financial Institutions.
Forty years ago, N.Y.U.'s business school offered three popular year-long electives: financial history, economic history and the business history of the United States. In recent years, such courses vanished or declined in number at many graduate business schools; they were often relegated to economics departments as the business schools stressed such courses as management and finance.
Dr. John W. Rosenblum, dean of the University of Virginia's Darden School of Business, called the dearth of history courses in business schools ''a serious missing component.''
Meyer Feldberg, the dean of the Columbia Graduate Business School, agreed: ''Students don't have much sense of history these days,'' he said.
Then, in 1986, when Cornell University's Johnson Graduate School of Management introduced a business history course, the trend seemed to reverse, and many business schools began to re-examine their curriculums.
Dr. Feldberg's vision for Columbia goes beyond additional emphasis on history. Shortly after assuming the deanship last July, he named a curriculum review committee to focus on course changes that would broaden the school's approach to prepare students for the growing internationalization of business.
The committee is reviewing how to introduce what he calls the ''ethic of quality'' into courses to instill the importance of productivity in keeping American business competitive in the world market.
Also, Dr. Feldberg thinks that in the 1990's there will be more emphasis on management of human resources. ''There will be a comeback for human resources,'' he said, noting that the area was much less important in the 1980's, when the focus was on financial management.
He poses a question also to be decided by his faculty: ''Do we want Columbia business school graduates who will fill medium- and senior-management positions, or do we want to educate risk-takers?'' He favors training ''perceptive leaders who are builders, creators and innovators.''
''We're not adding more international courses,'' he said. ''The idea is to incorporate international aspects into all courses.''
At the University of Virginia, Dean Rosenblum agreed that there was a new emphasis on global aspects of business.
''The faculty wants to remove the word 'international' from international finance courses because all finance has to be international these days,'' Dr. Rosenblum explained.
At Darden, he said: ''Our first-year changes are in place as of last fall and include adding required courses in ethics and information technology. And second-year changes will be in place this fall, including more variety in electives and more careful sequencing of courses.''
He also stresses the importance of business people teaching and speaking on campus.
''I think this trend toward business schools hiring businessmen will grow,'' he said, adding that he would like to provide tenure to such teachers, which is usually difficult if they lack doctorate degrees.
''Leading business schools can hire a large number of businessmen to teach because most professors do have doctorates,'' he explained. ''The smaller, less prestigious business schools cannot hire many because they need more Ph.D.'s on their faculty for accreditation reasons.'' For accreditation, the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business requires that professors with Ph.D. degrees make up a certain percentage of a school's faculty.
But at a time when business-school professors are in short supply, Dr. Feldberg said he thinks the six-year rule for gaining tenure is not only unfair but unwise. Professors refused tenure often leave an institution.

HEADLINE: TURNOVER IN NICARAGUA;
Chamorro and Sandinista Rulers Begin Delicate Transition Talks

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 27

 BODY:
President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has begun preliminary talks with the Sandinista Government on the first democratic transfer of power in Nicaraguan history.
The talks began late Monday night, after the results of Sunday's election became known, when Mrs. Chamorro held an emotional session with President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in which they pledged to work together. Representatives of the two sides met again today, and they described the negotiations as positive and productive.
But the talks went forward amid lingering questions about the Sandinistas' willingness to hand over military power, and the tension resulting from Mrs. Chamorro's victory set off sporadic confrontations through the night between supporters of the two sides.
 
Days of Uncertainty
The uncertainty shadowing the early days of the transfer was drawn more starkly this afternoon, when President Ortega told a rally of 10,000 in Managua that the Sandinistas would not give up control of the army and security apparatus unless the United States-supported contra rebels were quickly demobilized. 
''The security, the stability of Nicaragua and the development of democracy in Nicaragua is truly one of the fundamental concepts of the revolution,'' he said. ''And this has to be respected.''
But he called on a Chamorro government to ''maintain the integrity and professionalism'' of the Interior Ministry and the national army, which currently amounts to an arm of the party.
Mr. Ortega was clearly trying to reassure the most entrenched and hard-line Sandinistas, who have fought against the rebels in eight years of civil war in which more than 30,000 people have died. But his remarks and the conditions he set on the contras left many in Nicaragua and the United States nervous.
The tension of the moment reflects the country's deep polarization. A decade of war, revolution and economic ruin has created deep divisions between supporters of the governing Sandinista Front and supporters of the opposition, and those suspicions pervade almost all aspects of daily life.
But the worry also grows out of the political void created by the Sandinistas' defeat in Sunday's voting. There has never been a peaceful transition from one elected Government to another here, and the Sandinistas and the National Opposition Union, or UNO, are groping in the dark, seeking a smooth path to change.
Forty-eight hours after the polls closed, both sides are still having trouble believing that the opposition brushed aside what at times appeared to be the immovable force of Nicaraguan life. The Sandinistas had been the public and revolutionary face of power in Nicaragua for the last decade, personifying the country.
But officials from both sides said the early transition talks went smoothly, in an atmosphere of reconciliation. President Ortega so far has complied with the letter and spirit of his vow on Monday ''to respect and obey'' the election results, officials familiar with the negotiations said. ''It was an extremely difficult decision to reach, but I think he's going to stick by it,'' said Eduardo Palacio, a senior spokesman for the opposition coalition.
 
Ortega Gains Credit
Opposition leaders credited President Ortega with taking a vital preliminary step toward reconciliation on Monday night when he and several senior aides went to Mrs. Chamorro's house to discuss the mechanics of the transfer of power.
''My beautiful little father, come in, because I love you,'' Mrs. Chamorro was quoted as saying in greeting President Ortega.
''You know that I respect you and love you and congratulate you on your triumph,'' the President replied before they hugged each other.
''There were no winners or losers in these elections,'' Mrs. Chamorro added. ''What I want is that we all work for the reconciliation of Nicaragua.'' ''I am ready to cooperate,'' the President said. The meeting had particular poignancy because Mrs. Chamorro and Mr. Ortega both served on the five-member ruling junta that took power in 1979 after the fall of the Somoza family dictatorship. Mrs. Chamorro eventually left the junta in a bitter feud with the Sandinistas.
Opposition officials also praised Mr. Ortega for trying to soothe his supporters' raw passions by calling the national radio station here and persuading it to moderate its inflammatory interviews, during which one Sandinista supporter after another condemned the election results.
But some question whether Mr. Ortega can persuade all his supporters and several leaders of the Sandinista Front to follow his lead. They noted that the two sides had yet to discuss the most sensitive or explosive issues, like handing over control of the 75,000-person army and the Interior Ministry, which controls the secret police and what amounts to a second army complete with uniformed troops and tanks.
Tomas Borge Martinez, the powerful Interior Minister who is considered one of the hardest-line members of the Government, did not join President Ortega on the stand during Monday's concession speech and has not been seen in public since the 14-percentage-point defeat.
That has led to speculation that divisions may be emerging in the nine-member Sandinista National Directorate and that hard-line members may be resisting turning over power to a Chamorro administration.
Officials familiar with the transition talks said the Sandinistas had a variety of security concerns. They said the Government was seeking assurances that the Chamorro administration would prevent violent reprisals against Sandinista leaders and their supporters.
As Mr. Ortega made plain today, the Government also wants the Nicaraguan rebels disbanded before April 25, when Mrs. Chamorro is to be inaugurated.
''The Sandinistas want the contras demobilized so they do not return to Nicaragua and carry out vengeance,'' an official said.
Hundreds of the election observers who closely monitored the vote have left the country, even though the final results have not been released. But in unofficial projections based on 81.4 percent of the precincts, the opposition coalition was given 52 seats in the 91-member National Assembly, while the Sandinistas received 38.
The Social Christian Party won the remaining seats. In Nicaragua's last national election, in November 1984, the Sandinistas won 61 percent of the vote. But that vote was boycotted by major opposition leaders, who contended that the election rules were unfair.
 
Some Violence in Streets
Some Nicaraguans expressed hope that the observers would remain long enough to guide the new government into power. The UNO coalition is so splintered that there is some concern that it will not even be able to agree on how to handle the turnover of power.
The sporadic violence that erupted on Monday night was over by late this afternoon. But the skirmishes between UNO backers and Sandinista partisans left a few scars.
Leaders of the National Opposition Union said the homes of supporters and several party headquarters were attacked and stoned on Monday night in a half-dozen northern cities. At least two organizers were arrested on Monday and were being held in jail, party officials in Ocotal said this afternoon.
They said groups of Sandinista loyalists fired assault rifles into the air while attacking opposition leaders' homes. Residents of Esteli said the police stood by while mobs pelted the houses of several opposition members and burned the coalition's headquarters to the ground. A few scattered papers and the charred remains of the office's furniture were all that remained at the site today.
The violence was part of what led the opposition leaders in Esteli to ask that some of the almost 2,000 international observers who came to Nicaragua to monitor the voting remain to supervise the transition.
