HEADLINE: Tokyo Stock Market: Island No Longer

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 27

 BODY:
The turbulence in the Tokyo financial markets in the last week has shown that the influence of one nation's market on another's, a process that has been dubbed globalization, is in some ways more powerful but works in more subtle ways than had been thought. It has also provided a vivid lesson of how much Japan's financial markets, now the world's largest, have changed in the last two years because of the easing of financial regulations and the rise of Japan as a global financial power.
This market deregulation has made it easier for capital-rich Japanese to invest abroad and influence other markets. But over the last week, the flip side of the process has become evident: The Japanese markets are also more vulnerable to influences orginating from the other markets around the globe. 
The deregulation, much of it done under heavy American pressure, allows Japanese investors to do more and has given American and other foreign financial institutions greater entry. Along with the vast investment of Japanese money overseas, this has made Japanese interest rates, Japan's bond market and the yen far more responsive to influence from elsewhere on the globe, whether it be Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman or the economic consequences of the expected reunification of Germany. Interest rates will continue to soar as that nation seeks money to finance the redevelopment of East Germany and the rest of Eastern Europe. Those rates could sway Japanese investors looking for a higher return on their money to convert yen into the Deutschmarks needed to buy German bonds. That, in turn could cause Japanese rates to rise in the domestic competition for the money that remains.
In other words, the Japanese Government is no longer able to closely manage its financial markets, a notion that many here had accepted only in the abstract before the recent volatile market gyrations. The Japanese government's frustration has been one factor worrying investors in Japan's stock market. With the Japanese government holding less sway, the concerns and fears of investors have become more dominant.
''The really important thing is that what has happened to interest rates and the markets has been investor driven, not decreed by administrative orders,'' said John S. Wadsworth Jr., head of Morgan Stanley & Company's Japan operations. ''The markets are a business now, and they weren't before.''
In a particularly revealing comment, Takahisa Iido, general manager of the Treasury Department at the Yasuda Trust & Banking Company, explained what he did when faced with great uncertainty about the direction of Japanese interest rates last December: He flew to Germany to observe the rapid economic changes taking place there, rather than consulting experts or officials in Japan, something that would have been unthinkable just a few years ago.
''When I observed how the markets were responding there,'' he said. ''I understood that the same influences would affect Japanese interest rates.''
Kenneth Courtis, senior economist at Deutsche Bank's Tokyo offices, said: ''Because of deregulation, the government can no longer finesse the markets and make things happen, as they could before. The government and people in the markets are confronting a much more difficult and complex policy agenda.''
A good example of that has been the performance of the yen on foreign currency markets. Early Tuesday afternoon, the yen weakened to 149.5 against the dollar, its lowest level since last summer, and a harbinger of higher rates here. Despite intervening by spending several billion dollars to buy yen to try to prop up the currency in the last week, the Bank of Japan has been unable to force rates to move down as desired.
Higher interest rates - as is the case with West Germany - make that country's currency more attractive to investors and traders to hold on to or to buy investments denominated in that currency.
But if value is falling - as with the yen - it often tends to force interest rates up as a nation's central bank tries to create an incentive to buyers to counter the selling. And if a currency is rising fast it tends to push interest rates lower, because less incentive is needed to attract buyers and because inflation worries begin to emerge.
But the experience of the last six weeks in Japan, in which interest rates soared in response to sharply higher rates in Germany, and then the stock market began to decline after the Japanese election on Feb. 18, has also shown that these cross-border influences can still be difficult to predict and understand.
For instance, when the New York Stock Exchange skidded in January because of rising interest rates, the Tokyo market fell, but much more moderately. Now, the American markets have been relatively stable, while the stock market in Tokyo has plunged about 10 percent since the beginning of last week. That has proved a stunning contradiction of earlier pronouncements that, when the huge Tokyo market fell sharply, the New York markets would quake and perhaps crash.
In fact, after Tokyo went into a 4.5 percent tailspin on Monday that frightened traders and government officials here, New York responded with a smart rally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished the day up 38.29 points, or about 1.5 percent.
''After the crash in 1987, people had this wave theory that said the stock markets would fall like dominos if one really went,'' said Deryck Maughan, chairman of Salomon Brothers Asia. ''That clearly is not true in stock markets. We're not quite sure why, but there are lags and differences in the reactions. It's in interest rates and exchange rates that these things are transmitted much faster. And that's partly due to deregulation.''
He was referring to some of the steps taken by the government here to liberalize financial markets for both Japanese citizens and foreign firms. Among them have been the creation of several new and more open markets in short-term financial investments, and in bond futures and stock index futures; the removal of some rules governing how much interest that banks can pay Japanese depositors, and a opening up of the way the government sells its bonds, in which foreigners can now participate.
The effect of these and other steps has been to inject truer market considerations of supply and demand into how real interest rates and bond prices are determined.
One result has been that in Tokyo, the rate on the government's benchmark 10-year bond rose quickly from just under 6 percent in December to nearly 7 percent now. But with West German rates hovering near 10 percent, the possibility exists that Japanese rates would have rise further to compete for yen and dollars.
Meanwhile, the yen was still falling against the dollar. If this forces the central bank to increase its discount rate, which is the rate it charges banks for short-term loans, it could possibly jolt the the economy, which is vigorous now but might slow under the burden of higher interest rates.
''Deregulation in Japan tied the money markets into each other much more closely and this showed it,'' said Gary Seevers, co-head of the Japan operations at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
What was odd to many here was that the Tokyo stock market, after hitting a record high with a booming rally in December, barely reacted to what should have been the negative effect of sharply higher Japanese interest rates.
''Japanese investors were still thinking of December in the stock market,'' said Mr. Iido of Yasuda Trust. ''They were too optimistic and ignored everything negative until now. The economy has been affected very much by these changes in interest rates and exchange rates, but people neglected that in the stock market. Japan was simply late in looking at these changes.''
Added Mr. Courtis of Deutsche Bank: ''The market had been sleepwalking. The consensus had been that if the ruling party won the election, the yen and the stock market would get stronger. Well, the yen got weaker instead, and the stock market finally reacted.''
''The lesson has been that globalization does not just mean that when the stock market goes down in Asia then it goes down in Europe,'' said Mr. Wadsworth. ''The interest rate influences are more direct, but in the stock market it means that people just begin to think about and look around for values.''
There is clearly frustration by some Japanese officials over their inability to manage the markets here better and a highly unusual dispute between the the markets here better and a highly unusual dispute between the Bank of Japan and Ministry of Finance broke out last week over how the government should react. But few expect the changes in the marketplace to stop.
Computerized program trading, which was made possible by the creation of the stock index futures market 18 months ago, has been blamed by some for aggravating the stock market's decline and the Tokyo Stock Exchange has taken steps to limit its impact. Whatever role program trading is playing, it is a product of deregulation that has added an important new variable to the Tokyo market. It does not seem likely that this variable will be removed.
First of all, the United States is still pushing Japan hard to continue the liberalizing its markets. But most important, like interest rate and exchange rate movements, deregulation has become another influence that travels from market to market, and is proving extremely difficult for any government to resist.

HEADLINE: EXXON IS INDICTED BY U.S. GRAND JURY IN SPILL AT VALDEZ

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
A Federal grand jury in Anchorage today indicted the Exxon Corporation and its shipping subsidiary on five criminal counts stemming from the Alaskan oil spill, after negotiations between the Justice Department and the company on a settlement of the case broke down. .
Attorney General Dick Thornburgh called the indictment on two felony and three misdemeanor charges ''our best shot at prosecuting this incident.''
The indictment comes just four days after the Justice Department acknowledged that it was drafting a plea bargain that would allow Exxon to avoid a criminal trial. Mr. Thornburgh said the company had refused to accept the department's terms for entering a guilty plea and avoiding a trial, although he would not rule out further negotiations.
But the details of what happened behind the scenes to bring about the collapse of the plea bargain were not clear today.
Even so the developments in the case represented a victory, at least for now, for the state of Alaska, environmental groups, and private parties seeking civil damages from the company in connection with the March 24, 1989 accident that spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound. Those seeking civil damages had complained bitterly last week that the Justice Department's proposals would undermine those efforts. 
Exxon's chairman and chief executive, Lawrence G. Rawl, said in a prepared statement that the company was ''disappointed'' with the indictments and that officials would ''defend ourselves in court against these charges.''
Because the potential criminal penalties under the indictment cannot yet be calculated, it is difficult to compare Exxon's potential liability with what it would have been forced to pay under a plea bargain.
Justice Department officials said the indictment could result in penalties of at least $600 million, perhaps far more, but not until a conviction, which is far from assured and could take years to obtain.
The plea bargain, officials said, would have imposed about $200 million in criminal fines and would also have required Exxon to contribute up to $550 million, beginning with an immediate payment of $150 million, to a fund that would be used for environmental restoration. The plea bargain would not have prevented civil lawsuits against Exxon, but the restitution fund could have offset some of the awards won by civil plaintiffs.
If Exxon is convicted, it could be fined more than $1 billion if the court applies legal provisions setting fines on the basis of economic losses or environmental damage. In that case Exxon might have to pay fines calculated at double the damages caused by the spill to the environment itself, and double the costs incurred by the Government and private parties. The Justice Department said $600 million was a conservative estimate of potential criminal fines.
In any event, the criminal penalties Exxon might face are probably dwarfed by the potential civil liabilities. Those are calculated based on the actual damage to the environment, and the cost of restoring it to its original condition or buying equivalent property. The spill killed thousands of birds and animals and crippled much of the state's fishing industry.
Today, after a meeting with Mr. Thornburgh, Governor Steve Cowper of Alaska said: ''If there is an indictment in Anchorage, and there is no plea bargain, at least in the form that we've seen it, that's fine with us. Things can be negotiated from here.''
''People ask me every day, frankly how much we want,'' said Governor Cowper. ''The answer is, we don't know. We're just beginning to put our evidence together.''
Sarah Chasis, a senior attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, which is suing Exxon on civil claims to force it to pay for the restoration of damages caused when the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Prince William Sound last March, spilling 11 million barrels of oil, also welcomed the developments.
''We think it is appropriate that the Federal Government has decided to pursue criminal penalties, and we are glad that the proposed plea bargain has not been adopted,'' Ms. Chasis said.
Mr. Rawl particularly objected to the two felony charges, which are based on the assertion of willful wrongdoing. ''Nobody willfully grounded the ship or caused the spill,'' he said. He also disputed the Justice Department's assertion that fines, under the Alternative Fines Act, could be set at double the value of the damage to natural resources. Unless that law is invoked, the fines would be minimal under the statutes that Exxon is accused of violating.
The indictment does not make any charges against Exxon corporate officers, and thus would not send any individuals to jail upon conviction.
Its two felony counts cite the company for failing to ensure that the Exxon Valdez was operated by competent crew members during its voyage out of the huge oil shipping harbor at Valdez. After leaving normal shipping channels in an effort to avoid heavy ice, the ship's crew ran into shallow waters while the captain of the vessel was below deck.
The captain, Joseph Hazelwood has been accused of drinking before the accident and is on trial in Anchorage on charges in the case; the officer left to navigate the ship was allegedly not properly licensed for those waters.
One of the felony indictments was brought under the 1972 Ports and Waterways Safety Act, which the Justice Department said ''requires the owner, master or other persons in charge of a vessel to ensure that the wheelhouse is constantly manned by competent persons.''
The other felony count was brought under the Dangerous Cargo Act, which the department said ''provides that a felony is committed if a person willfully and knowingly violates a regulation prohibiting any person from being engaged on a crew of a tank vessel, if such person is known to the employer to be physically or mentally incapable of performing the duties assigned to him or her.''
Mr. Thornburgh said that the indictment against Exxon represents the first time the Federal Government had brought such charges under the Dangerous Cargo and Ports and Waterways Safety Acts.
Prosecutors today refused to elaborate on the basis for the charges, saying that the evidence would be presented in court.
The three lesser charges were made under the Clean Water Act, the Refuse Act, and the Migratory Bird Act.
At a press conference in Washington, Mr. Thornburgh said that the prosecution of the company sent ''a strong signal that environmental crimes will not be tolerated. Firms which violate the environmental laws will face tough prosecution in the federal courts.''
Speaking privately, department officials said that they believed the proposed plea bargain might have gone through had Alaskan officials not objected to it so strenuously. But Mr. Thornburgh said that it was rejected by the company, and that the complaints of the state were irrelevant.
It appeared that the state's vehement objections to the plea bargain and the resulting political pressure had, in any event, eliminated any possibility of further compromise by the Justice Department in the final days of its negotiations with Exxon.
Conversely, attorneys said, the indictment would probably increase pressure on the company to seek more negotiations on a possible plea.
Mr. Thornburg rejected any suggestion that Exxon and the Justice Department have actually agreed quietly that the company will later agree to a plea bargain, now that the indictment has been handed down.
But he added that a criminal defendant can at any time approach prosecutors with a plea bargain proposal. He refused to say whether the department would now accept a settlement based on its earlier proposals.
Justice Department officials said that Alaska's consent to the plea bargain was essential because Exxon wanted it to affect not just the criminal case but future civil lawsuits, which will provide the state its main recourse in attempting to recover from the harm done.

HEADLINE: Philippine Support for Aquino Continues

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I found ''Aquino's Rule Is Imperiled as Foes Multiply and 'People Power' Grows Frail'' (news article, Feb. 7) inconsistent with other reliable information coming from the Philippines. To my knowledge, the most reliable sources of information concerning public opinion in the Philippines are the Social Weather Station surveys, which are conducted by the Ateneo de Manila University. Unlike your other news reports on the Philippines, this article did not refer at all to these surveys. 
The results of the public opinion survey conducted last Dec. 11-18 found the latest military coup attempt, which took place that month, to be highly unpopular. Those leaders, military and political, who defended the administration of President Corazon C. Aquino and the democratic system received very high margins of popular support, while those leaders, military and political, who supported or were perceived to have supported the coup attempt received abysmal popular support.
Mahar Mangahas, the driving force behind these surveys, has argued, in The Manila Chronicle for Jan. 15, that it would be incorrect to infer that those military leaders who defended the Aquino Government and are now enjoying strong popular support, sometimes higher than President Aquino herself, would be welcomed by the public should they lead the next coup, a position that is implied in your article.
Dr. Mangahas cites the examples of former Col. Gregorio Honasan and the Scout Rangers, whose public support previously had been high, but who, once they were implicated in a coup attempt against the Aquino administration, experienced a plummet in popularity.
Apparently, these surveys, in contrast to your article, show that people power is still alive and that the democratic system in the Philippines enjoys extensive popular support.
Unfortunately this democracy is now being challenged by a significant segment of the Philippine military and political elite who wish to grab the reins of power through force. Needless to say, United States policy toward the Philippines must continue to be fully committed to supporting the democratic process and its elected leaders during this continuing crisis.
 
HENRY SCHWALBENBERG
 Bronx, Feb. 7, 1990
The writer is director of the graduate program in international political economy and development at Fordham University.

HEADLINE: Poland Resumes Full Diplomatic Ties With Israel

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WARSAW, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Israel and Poland resumed full diplomatic relations today after a 23-year break. Poland was the third Warsaw Pact country to renew relations with Israel in the last six months.
The Poles ended relations in 1967 to support the Arabs in the Middle East war that year. Hungary restored relations in September and Czechoslovakia followed suit on Feb. 9. 
Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki looked on as the Israeli Foreign Minister, Moshe Arens, and the Polish Foreign Minister, Krzysztof Skubiszewski, signed the agreement at a Government palace, and the delegations celebrated the long-awaited event with champagne.
Poland has had low-level ties with Israel since 1987, and the new Solidarity-led Government is hoping that the restoration of embassy-level relations will lead to closer economic and cultural cooperation.
''We are today opening a new chapter in the long history, full of tragedies, of the Jewish people of Poland,'' Mr. Arens said on the Israeli Army radio. ''I hope for good and close relations between Israel and Poland.''
Speaking to reporters after the ceremony, he emphasized that Israel also hopes for Polish support for its diplomatic positions in the Middle East peace process.
He later told the army radio that he found ''great understanding'' for Israel's problems among Poland's leaders. ''It seems even a greater and fuller understanding than we have found in Western Europe,'' he added.
Poland has said that resuming relations with Israel should not disturb its relations with Arab countries. Poland continues to endorse Palestinian rights to self-determination, and Mr. Skubiszewski held a January meeting with Arab diplomats to assure them of continued support.
Nevertheless, the state radio in Libya expressed ''deep regret'' over the resumption of relations. The Polish Ambassador to Tripoli was summoned to the Libyan Foreign Ministry and told that the action would harm Libyan-Polish relations and Arab-Polish relations generally, the Libyan report said.
 
Jaruzelski to Visit Israel
Mr. Arens, in his radio interview, said he had invited the Polish President, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, to Israel. The invitation was accepted but no date was scheduled, he said.
Mr. Arens said he expected that resuming diplomatic ties would lead to ''very extensive economic relations'' as well as closer people-to-people links.
''There is no doubt in my mind that it will bring about a widening, a deepening and a strengthening of the relationship between the Polish people and the Jewish people in Poland and Israel,'' he said.
He spoke of the small number of Jews - about 10,000 - remaining in Poland after the Nazi killings and of the postwar emigration of Polish Jews, mainly to Israel and the United States. In addition, many of the Jewish survivors fled in the late 1960's during an official anti-Zionist campaign associated with the 1967 Middle East war.
On Monday, Mr. Arens paid emotional visits to memorials to Poland's Jews, who numbered about 3.5 million before World War II.
He paid homage at the monument to the Warsaw Ghetto uprising of 1943, when Jews rose up against the Nazi occupiers. Mr. Arens stood in silence at the monument at Umschlagplatz, the depot where Warsaw's Jews were loaded onto trains to the Nazi camps. Today, Mr. Arens also discussed economic issues with Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, met with Prime Minister Mazowiecki and had a session scheduled with General Jaruzelski, who was Communist Party leader when the then-Communist Government initiated contacts with Israel.
He commended Poland's leadership in the democratization of the East bloc during a Monday dinner toast and said this was clearly related to its readiness to improve ties with Israel.
''It is remembered in Israel that Poland was the first country in the Soviet bloc to start the process of improving relations with Israel. It took great courage,'' he said.
At least 350,000 Israelis were born in Poland, including the country's first Prime Minister, David Ben-Gurion, and the present one, Yitzhak Shamir.

HEADLINE: TURNOVER IN NICARAGUA;
Honduran President Asks Contras to Leave Soon

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras insisted yesterday that the victory of the opposition in Nicaragua's election Sunday means that Nicaraguan rebels based in his country must leave as soon as possible.
''I don't want to force circumstances in Nicaragua, which is now going through a period of political transition following a victory by the opposition at the polls,'' Mr. Callejas said yesterday at a news conference in Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital. ''But these rebels should not continue to stay in our territory.''
A contra official, Israel Galeano, said, however, that the rebels intended to stay in their bases along Honduras's southern border until Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the opposition candidate, is sworn in as President in April. 
President Callejas's statement came as governments around the world reacted to Mrs. Chamorro's victory.
Cuba views her victory as ''a great setback,'' its Communist Party newspaper said yesterday, but not necessarily a signal of ''political bankruptcy'' for the Sandinistas.
 
Isolation for Cubans
But with the Soviet Union announcing that it is willing to continue aid to Nicaragua, even under the new regime, Cuba seems increasingly isolated in the region. Japan said yesterday that it is willing to help rebuild Nicaragua's shattered economy, and the United States has already pledged to provide aid and to lift a trade embargo imposed in 1985.
''There is no doubt that it is a great setback, but it doesn't mean political bankruptcy'' for the Sandinistas, the Cuban newspaper, Granma, said in an editorial. Cuba has been one of the Sandinista Government's closest allies since the 1979 revolution.
Granma said Nicaraguans voted as they did because they were ''faced with the contradiction that a victory for Sandinismo would not mean the end of the war or the lifting of the blockade or the end of sanctions.'' Another factor, it said, was that traditional Sandinista allies in Eastern Europe are facing political and economic uncertainty because of ''historical retrogression,'' a reference to Western-leaning reforms sweeping the Soviet bloc.
In Moscow, however, the deputy chief of the Soviet Foreign Ministry's Latin American Department, Ion Bourliai, said at a news conference that the Soviet Union was willing to continue economic aid to Nicaragua under the new leadership. ''The people have made their choice, which must be unconditionally respected by all the members of the international community,'' Mr. Bourliai said, pointing out that trade agreements between the two governments remain in force.
 
Call From El Salvador
Moscow has been providing about $333 million annually in economic aid to Nicaragua on a credit basis, and $25 million tons of wheat and rice free of charge, Mr. Bourliai said. Moscow has not supplied Nicaragua with arms since 1988, he said, but added, ''We are willing to discuss the question of cooperation in the military field with the new Government if the necessity arises.''
The Government in El Salvador, which for 10 years has been locked in a civil war that has left 72,000 people dead, used the occasion to call for reopening of peace negotiations with leftist rebels. Armando Calderon Sol, head of the ruling Nationalist Republican Alliance Party, known as Arena, said: ''With the upset of the Sandinistas, democracy in the region is taking hold. There's no call to go on killing in El Salvador, and we should facilitate dialogue.
''Now is when the Salvadoran democratic process should open political spaces for the incorporation of the guerrillas and seek social harmony,'' he added.
A leader of the Salvadoran opposition, Ruben Zamora, did not say whether the Nicaraguan election offers a turning point for the civil war in his country. But he praised the Sandinista Government for a clean electoral process. The elections ''are an example of democracy,'' said Mr. Zamora, who is head of the Popular Social Christian Movement party and the Democratic Revolutionary Front. Those parties are aligned with guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front.
The Japanese Foreign Ministry in Tokyo did not say how much aid it was prepared to send to Nicaragua, but said Japan is ''determined to make as much contribution as possible in this regard.'' Japan has the world's largest budget for nonmilitary foreign aid, about $10 billion a year.

HEADLINE: Mitchell Set to Move a Clean Air Bill to Senate Floor

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
As bargaining on clean air legislation continued out of the public eye, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, insisted today that he would bring legislation back to the floor Thursday, with or without an agreement with the Bush Administration.
In discussions over the last month, Senate leaders and Administration negotiators have reached agreement on many elements of legislation to strengthen the Clean Air Act of 1970. They include the difficult issues of how to control toxic chemicals sent into the air by industry and new requirements for cities that have not been able to reduce smog to levels mandated by law.
As of today, however, the two sides have not been able to resolve differences on several other important issues, most of them having to do with how stringently to crack down on pollution from automobiles. 
 
Negotiations on Acid Rain
Today the negotiators took on the still unresolved question of how the legislation would deal with acid rain, which is not a major source of contention between Senate leaders and the Administration but is an area of dispute among senators themselves. Both the legislation proposed by President Bush last year and the bill reported by the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, now pending on the Senate floor. would require coal-burning power plants to make steep reductions in the pollution that causes acid rain.
A number of Senators, particularly from the Midwest, where most of the plants are situated, are concerned about the impact the plan would have on their states' economies and are seeking changes.
Senator Mitchell said today that he would introduce substitute legislation on Thursday to incorporate the negotiated changes. He did not say what he would do about those areas of the bill for which there was no agreement.
While negotiators were unable to agree with the White House on how much to control automobile pollution, sources said Senator Mitchell had reached a compromise with Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, that would reduce some concerns of Detroit's manufacturers.
 
Cloture Move Possible
For one thing, car makers would not be required to increase their vehicles' fuel efficiency substantially so as to reduce carbon-dioxide pollution. Carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels is the most significant industrial gas now accumulating in the atmosphere, and many scientists believe this will lead to a substantial warming of the earth in the next century.
A spokeswoman for the Majority Leader said Senator Mitchell might introduce a petition on Thursday to limit debate and the number of amendments that may be offered to the bill. The petition for cloture needs 60 votes to be adopted.
Senator Mitchell has repeatedly said that he has conducted the back-room negotiations because without them he would be unable to block or end a filibuster, particularly if it is supported by the White House.
President Bush has said he would not accept the committee bill because it was too costly. Administration officials said the Senate bill would cost the country $41 billion a year by the year 2000, whereas the President's bill would cost $19 billion. Senate aides and enviromentalists say the Administration's cost estimates are based on incorrect assumptions and are grossly inflated.
The disagreement over controlling automobile pollution is largely about a provision in the Senate bill that would require two rounds of reductions of tailpipe emissions of ozone and carbon monoxide. The Administration strongly objects to the second round of controls, scheduled to go into effect in 2003 under the Senate bill, on the ground that it would cost a huge sum and achieve only marginal improvement in air quality.
The Senate leaders, joined by state air quality officials and environmentalists, maintain that the goal of clean air cannot be met in most cities without the second round of tailpipe controls, given the growing number of cars on the road and the steadily increasing number of miles driven by each car.
The compromise on controlling toxic chemicals in the air removes one of the sorest points of contention between senators and the Administration, which said compliance with the Senate committee's provision would force many companies out of business.

LENGTH: 1001 words

HEADLINE: Fed Chairman Criticizes Social Security Tax Cut

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
As lawmakers continued to grapple for a response to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes, Alan Greenspan, who as chairman of the Federal Reserve is the Government's most influential economic policy maker, said today that Mr. Moynihan had properly diagnosed a crippling national problem but had prescribed the wrong medicine.
Agreeing with Mr. Moynihan, Mr. Greenspan called it ''most improper'' for the Government to continue to use surplus Social Security taxes to cover general operating expenses and said the money was being ''squandered.'' He said the solution was to raise other taxes or cut spending enough to eliminate the deficit in the operating budget.
But if the proposal on Social Security by Mr. Moynihan, Democrat of New York, is adopted, Mr. Greenspan said, ''support for the system may well erode when the next generation is asked to take on a tax bill that their parents were unwilling or too short-sighted to assume during their own working years.'' 
As a private economist, Mr. Greenspan was chairman of the Presidential commission in the early 1980's that established the current payroll tax structure for Social Security.
 
Strauss Takes Exception
Later, Robert S. Strauss, a Democratic Party elder, also took issue today with the Moynihan plan but said leading politicians in both parties need to join forces to correct an unwise and unjust tax and spending system.
''The political process has failed our citizens,'' Mr. Strauss said. ''We can talk openly about sex, violence, war, condoms and deviant behavior on television, in the newspaper and on the floor of the Congress. Yet we cannot seem to talk honestly and openly about whether we need more or less taxes, more or less spending, or what, if anything, we should do about the rising cost of entitlements.''
Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Strauss testified before the Senate Finance Committee. While neither is in a position to do anything about taxes or spending, Mr. Greenspan's opinions on the economy and Mr. Strauss's on politics are important because of the stature of the two men.
Mr. Greenspan is treated in Congress with a respect bordering on reverence. At a time when fiscal policy seems out of control, he is seen by lawmakers as having single-handedly kept the country out of a recession with his deft manipulation of the money supply and interest rates.
Mr. Strauss is a former chairman of the Democratic National Committee and for years has been an adviser and friend of Presidents and other politicians in both parties.
 
Democrats Look at Alternatives
Behind the scenes, a group of Democratic leaders prepared to meet this week to try to develop an alternative to the Moynihan plan on which the party can agree. Republicans have not formed a similar group, but President Bush's proposal to begin using part of the Social Security surplus in 1993 to pay off the national debt has won little support.
The Social Security surplus has also drawn the attention of the House, where the Ways and Means Committee voted today to recommend that the surplus be removed from deficit calcualtions to draw attention to the size of the deficit in the day-to-day operations of the Government.
This proposal has widespread support among lawmakers of both parties, but it is symbolic and would do nothing to solve the deficit problem.
Mr. Bush has maintained that $14 billion can be raised by cutting the capital gains tax, stepping up enforcement of the tax laws and extending some minor excise taxes that are due to expire. He has said he would veto any measure that amounted to a real tax increase.
 
Democrats Critical of Bush Plan
But Representative Dan Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat who is the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said he saw ''absolutely no way'' to increase tax collections by $14 billion, as Mr. Bush wants, without risking a veto.
Democrats oppose a cut in the capital gains tax, which they believe would mostly benefit the rich and cost the Government large sums in lost revenue in years down the road, and maintain that the prospect of raising billions from tighter enforcement is a pipe dream.
The Moynihan plan has caused political turmoil since he proposed it two months ago.
Economists and politicians of both parties agree that these are the facts: Social Security tax increases were legislated in 1977 and 1983 to generate enough so that workers in the next century would be able to pay the retirement benefits of the baby boom generation. But the Government has failed to raise enough money from other taxes to pay for the general operating expenses of the Government, from battleships to paper clips, and the Social Security surplus is being used to offset the deficit in the rest of the budget.
As a result, money that should be saved is being, in Mr. Greenspan's word, ''squandered.'' And the Social Security tax, which is borne mostly by low- and middle-income workers, has partly supplanted the income tax, which falls more heavily on the affluent.
Just as they agree on the problem, the economists and politicians agree on the solution: balance the budget and save the surplus in Social Security taxes. What they disagree on are the steps to reach that end.
Mr. Moynihan, frustrated by the lack of progress, argues that since the President and Congress seem unwilling to balance the budget and save the Social Security surplus, the tax ought to be reduced and the retirement system put on a pay-as-you-go basis. Others want to bring the budget into balance by dramatically cutting spending. Still others want to raise taxes. So far, there is nothing approaching a consensus.
Neither Mr. Greenspan nor Mr. Strauss had specific recommendations on how to balance the budget. But Mr. Strauss said he was confident that the President and Congress, working together, could work their way through the ''political mine fields'' and reach an accommodation. ''Whatever we decide to do,'' he said, ''we must do it together.''

HEADLINE: TURNOVER IN NICARAGUA;
Lenders Say Managua Has a Long Road Back

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Despite a newly proclaimed eagerness by the Bush Administration and the World Bank to breathe new life into Nicaragua's economy, economists predict that the rebuilding will take years after more than a decade of war and a United States-sponsored trade embargo.
The Bush Administration is preparing to end the 1985 embargo that has cut trade to a trickle, and to reverse the virtual veto that the United States has held since 1983 on loans to Nicaragua from international financial organizations like the World Bank.
The White House has begun consultations with Congress on a new aid program and has just invited economic advisers of Nicaragua's newly elected democratic leader, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, to visit Washington.
The World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund, other potential sources of major funds, are preparing to resume talks with Managua. 
 
Pauperized and Afflicted
Still, the Nicaraguan economy is so pauperized and so afflicted by hyperinflation and mismanagement that American and international officials say it will take years to put it right.
While the Administration may shortly ask Congress for humanitarian funds for Nicaragua, no one expects much money from donor countries or international lending organizations until after the April 25 inauguration.
''There's still a lot of doubt about what happens then, about what kind of government will emerge and about the economic program they will put forward,'' said an Administration official.
The Agency for International Development, the arm of the State Department that manages aid programs, is expected to send a delegation to Managua within the next few weeks to make a preliminary assessment of aid needs, another Administration official said.
 
Harder Case Than Panama
Most officials agree it will be harder for Nicaragua to attract investment than for Panama and even the newly democratic states of Eastern Europe.
''In Nicaragua there just isn't much to invest in,'' said Riordan Roett, a Latin American scholar at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. ''What you're really doing economically is starting all over again.''
William T. Archey, a vice president at the United States Chamber of Commerce, added, ''Businessmen are going to be very, very cautious until they see the way this thing works out. Remember, until recently it took considerable courage down there to propound capitalism.''
Still, experts point out that the country, with a low population density, excellent ports on the Atlantic and Pacific and a superior soil fertilized by volcanic ash, has considerable economic potential.
 
How to Redress Trade Deficit
One of the main problems is how to redress a trade deficit estimated by Prof. Lance Taylor, a development economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, at $300 million to $400 million a year.
Nicaragua's economy is based on exporting commodities, mainly bananas, coffee, sugar, cotton, beef, shellfish, sesame, forest products and a little gold. It imports machinery, consumer goods and petroleum.
Until now the gap has been filled by credits from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and some aid from Nordic countries.
A Soviet Foreign Ministry Official, Yan Burlyai, told a news conference in Moscow that his Government was providing $333 million annually in credits to Nicaragua and $25 million worth of wheat and rice free, Reuters reported.
 
Continued Soviet Help Doubted
Although Mr. Burlyai said that Moscow would be willing to continue its Nicaraguan aid, Professor Taylor and other analysts said that with the Soviet geopolitical interest fading, they doubted Moscow would continue its support for much longer.
''I can't imagine anybody else's lap that Nicaragua will fall on except ours,'' said Professor Taylor.
The extent of economic assistance for Nicaragua, Administration officials said, will depend in large measure on the arrangements that the Chamorro Government makes with the I.M.F., an international agency that lends to countries facing severe short-term economic strains. But to qualify for the money, borrowers have to pursue sometimes painful economic changes.
In Eastern Europe, the Philippines and other countries, agreements with the I.M.F. have been a seal of approval for other assistance. The I.M.F. could lend Nicaragua about $270 million over three years, but would probably force the state to sell off state enterprises and take even more austere measures to cut inflation, now about 25 percent a month. $250 Million Overdue To get money from the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank, Nicaragua still has to clear up $250 million in overdue debts to both organizations. Officials here said that there would probably be some international help with those arrears.
Both organizations' lending programs, which are intended for long-term construction, could be critical to building up power plants, telecommunications networks and other such structures to support expanded business and investment. They can also aid agriculture and social projects like schools and hospitals.
In addition to lifting the trade embargo, Administration officials said they are studying ways to provide trade preferences to Nicaragua that are similar to those already offered most developing countries, including neighbors in the Caribbean Basin.
Also, the Administration wants to restore Nicaragua's quota to sell sugar in the United States. The quota was withdrawn early in the last decade.

LENGTH: 227 words

HEADLINE: TOPICS OF THE TIMES;
Tolls Gov. Florio Can Support

 BODY:
Former Gov. Thomas Kean of New Jersey did commuters no favor in December by blocking a proposed $1 toll increase on bridges and tunnels run by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. They are vital to the region's economic health and badly need maintenance, and the region's airports can no longer subsidize them. 
The issue now tests New Jersey's new Governor, Jim Florio. Last week Mr. Florio rightly rejected a premature request for higher tolls from his state's troubled Turnpike Authority. But the proposed $1 toll increase on bridges and tunnels merits support.
The plan would increase round-trip tolls from $3 to $4 beginning July 1 on four bridges and two tunnels. Monthly commuter discount packages would jump from $40 to $60. The $1 PATH fare would rise to $1.25. The Automobile Club of New York complains that drivers are again being asked to pay for losses on the PATH train line. But drivers clearly benefit from PATH: it reduces congestion. Further, the proposed fare compares favorably with the $5 toll charged on crossings run by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
Mr. Florio's decision is likely to influence Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, who shares veto power but not the same keen pressure from trans-Hudson commuters. The burden is now on Mr. Florio either to approve the higher tolls or suggest a prudent alternative.

HEADLINE: A Postal Showdown in Westchester

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
Working conditions in the cramped regional mail center here are bad, postal officials concede. The roof leaks, sorting is done on several levels and employees have only a third of the space they require. In summer tents are put up.
On Monday, accompanied by engineers and technical experts, Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank arrived from Washington to help resolve what he said had become ''our No. 1 priority, a new facility for Westchester County.'' The postal center, which also handles mail for Rockland County and parts of Connecticut, accounts for 1 percent of the nation's mail. 
But selecting a replacement site has not been an easy task for Mr. Frank.
 
Choice Narrows to 2 Sites
Dozens of sites have been studied, selected and rejected, with a choice likely to be made within a week. The final contenders are a site next to Westchester County Airport and one on hilly land in Yonkers that opponents of the airport site favor.
Mr. Frank was familiar with the airport site, but had not seen the one in Yonkers. So he explored it, often ankle deep in snow, asking questions and offering comments that seemed to suggest a measure of uneasiness in converting the wooded, undulating land into the site of a postal center.
The post office had surveyed 70 possible sites in the last two years, finally proposing to build the new center in Armonk, a central Westchester community of comfortable homes and abundant open space where I.B.M. has its corporate headquarters.
When that site encountered strong opposition from residents, the Postal Service chose one on Route 120 next to the airport in Harrison for the 569,000-square-foot building. Opposition rose there, too.
 
Environmental Study Sought
A citizens' group, the Purchase Environmental Protective Association, headed by Robert Wise, sued the Postal Service last year contending that it did not comply with environmental requirements. Purchase is a residential community in Harrison.
Mr. Wise said that ''if you look at the size of the proposal - 1,600 employees and 500 trucks coming and going every day through a semi-rural, low-density residential area - and say that it has no environmental impact, it's ludicrous.'' Traffic would use Interstate 684 and Route 120, a local road, to reach the site.
Last year Representative Nita Lowey, a Harrison Democrat who won the Congressional seat in 1988, took up the struggle against putting the postal center near the airport.
''When I took office, my goal was to establish a procedure that would stop the Postal Service from proceeding with the airport site for three months to provide time for a final study,'' she said.
She formed the Citizens Advisory Committee, which conducted its own survey of postal center sites, selecting as its first choice the wooded ridge in Yonkers that stands between two north-south arteries, the Sprain Brook Parkway and the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.
 
Roads to Site Evaluated
The only occupant of the ridge is the Loral Corporation, a manufacturer of electronics and other equipment used mostly in jet fighters and other defense-related industries. Loral is accessible from the Thruway at an interchange that is being expanded to provide access to an industrial park being built in Yonkers.
Mr. Frank, who said he would make a decision ''in a few days,'' noted that access to a postal center from the same Thruway interchange, but along its own road, would be ''steep'' and the project would be expensive. But, he said, ''it's a viable site.''
He also said that while the airport site would contain two points of access, from I-684 and on 120, ''here there would be only one access road - and very steep, and with a sharp curve.'' If ''some truck gets stuck - we'll have a truck every three minutes - that's the end of mail service for Westchester that day.''
He said that cost also was a factor, possibly the principal factor ''for a service that has to pay its own way.'' Mr. Frank said it would cost about $150 million to build the postal center in Yonkers, compared with $100 million next to the airport.
 
County Help Possible
After members of the citizens' group met, there were reports that the county, which owns the land in Yonkers at what has come to be called the Loral site, would give the Postal Service an easement that would lower the cost of development there.
Representative Lowey said ''there is support in Yonkers for the Loral site, and it would be part of the city's economic revitalization plan.'' She said a postal center would be ''welcomed'' in Yonkers, and opposed in Harrison.
She also argued that a Yonkers site would mean less employee dislocation ''because half of the 1,200 postal workers live in Yonkers or Mount Vernon.''

GRAPHIC: Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank examining property in Yonkers as a possible site for a new postal center. With Mr. Frank are Representative Nita Lowey and Dolph Rotfield, an engineer. (NYT/Alan Zale)

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
U.S. and Cape Town Team Up to Train Managers

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
In an unprecedented move, an American university and a South African university are starting a joint program aimed at training black, Indian and mixed-race South Africans for business management posts in the racially divided nation.
Beginning next fall, 15 to 20 graduate students from the University of Cape Town are expected to attend the Rochester Institute of Technology for a year of intensive study in its business school. The students will then be placed in United States corporations for six months of practical work before returning to South Africa, Rochester officials said yesterday.
Blacks make up about 70 percent of South Africa's 35.6 million people, but there are relatively few blacks among the country's managerial class, American and South African educators said. Primarily as a result of the Government's apartheid policy, relatively few blacks and mixed-race South Africans are adequately trained for management jobs, said the institute's president, M. Richard Rose. 
Ninety-two percent of all South Africans who hold undergraduate degrees are white, according to a report issued this month by the South African National Students Congress. Of those holding graduate degrees, 92.2 percent are white, the report said.
 
'There Have to Be Opportunities'
''With this program, R.I.T. can participate in a very positive way in helping destroy apartheid,'' Dr. Rose said. ''For racial equality to ever be established, there have to be opportunities for people to move up the economic ladder to positions of influence.''
The program is expected to cost about $35,000 per student. South African companies are expected to shoulder much of the cost, said Piet Human, an associate professor at the University of Cape Town, who is recruiting companies to participate.
In a telephone interview on Monday, he said some aspects of the joint program, which promises its graduates a master's degree in business administration, have yet to be worked out. ''We are still negotiating it,'' he said.
Dr. Rose said he was confident that South African companies willing to invest $35,000 per student in the program would be likely to employ those students later.
 
'In a Bit of Turmoil'
The release earlier this month of Nelson Mandela and the legalizing of the African National Congress, of which Mr. Mandela is a leader, have moved some South African educators to advocate broadening the R.I.T. program to include training black managers for roles in the South African Government.
Recent events have ''put us in a bit of turmoil,'' Dr. Human said, adding that the University of Cape Town, known for its politically progressive policies, is ''reflecting on the implications of the changes.''
Current plans call for the program to gradually expand over the next four to five years to include 100 students. But there are no plans at present to prepare students for government management.
In the meantime, the program is expected to begin on schedule, Rochester officials said.
Response from corporations both in the United States and in South Africa has been good, said Prakash Sethi, a visiting professor from the City University of New York, who is teaching international business at Rochester. The program was his idea. ''The university has done some informal checking and the response has been almost uniformly supportive,'' Dr. Sethi said of American companies who have been asked to employ the students for six months. ''They all want to know the details of the program.''
 
Protecting Investments
South African corporations have responded in much the same way, said Dr. Human, of Cape Town. But he added that South African companies are concerned about how to protect their investments by insuring that students they sponsor return to work for them.
Susan Mnumzana, an African National Congress member who works with the Archbishop Tutu Southern African Refugee Scholarship Fund in New York City, called the program ''a good idea,'' and praised the participation of the University of Cape Town.
''It has become an anti-apartheid center in terms of education,'' she said, adding that the school has distinguished itself in recent years by accepting students on merit, not by race.
The university's racial sensitivity provided a twist, Dr. Rose recalled: ''They were concerned that there could be some sort of reverse discrimination. We assured them that that would not be the case.''
While the program's emphasis will remain on nonwhite South African students, a group historically denied educational opportunities, white South Africans will not be excluded, Dr. Rose said.
The widespread perception among many nonwhite South Africans is that South Africa's white business community, now hard hit by anti-apartheid trade sanctions, is an extension of apartheid.
''Because of this, a career in business is not particularly attractive to blacks and coloreds,'' Dr. Rose said. ''But it is easier for a manager to influence his company than if he is a laborer.''

GRAPHIC: photo: Rochester Institute of Technology is involved in a program aimed at training minorities for business jobs in South Africa. ''With this program, R.I.T. can participate in a very positive way in helping destroy apartheid,'' said M. Richard Rose, the college's president. (The New York Times/Phil Matt)

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs by 14.64; Tokyo Market Gains

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices advanced for the second straight session yesterday on slightly stepped-up volume.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.64 points, to 2,617.12, as investors absorbed the news of an exceptionally large drop in durable goods orders much as they did the 4.5 percent plunge in the 225-Nikkei stock index in Tokyo the day before. The Dow weathered that drop to post a 38.29-point gain. 
Yesterday the Nikkei index spurted 576.08 points, to 33,897.95, its ninth-largest one-day gain in terms of points. Psychologically, at least, the sharp rebound in Japan's shares lifted the American market, which also benefited in early trading from technical and futures-related buying.
Analysts said that the stock market received some indirect help during the day from the bond market, where prices rose and interest rates declined in part because of the weakness suggested by the 10.5 percent drop in durable goods orders for January, the biggest drop on record. Lower interest rates make investment in bonds less competitive with stock investments.
By late in the day, the 30-year Treasury issue was up about a half a point to 100 19/32, to yield 8.43 percent.
Japanese stocks traded here fared well across the board. Kyocera rose 5 3/4, to 90 3/4; Hitachi 3 1/2, to 101 1/2; Matsushita 2 3/4, to 141; Pioneer Electronics 6, to 86, and the TDK Corporation, 2 3/4, to 41 1/4.
The advance was broad based yesterday, with 927 issues rising in price and 558 falling. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.59 points, to 330.26, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index added 0.90, to 182.16.
Volume on the Big Board rose to a still-moderate 152.6 million shares, from 148.9 million on Monday.
American Express was the most active stock, falling 5/8, to 28 1/8, on a volume of 3.4 million shares. Traders said the company's new recapitalization plan for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. disappointed some investors who had hoped American Express would carry through with its plan to lower its stake in Shearson to below 50 percent.
Pfizer jumped 3 1/8 points, to 59 1/8. The stock rallied after Congressional hearings produced no significant new information on regulation of heart valves.
AMR rose 1 point, to 59 1/2. Wertheim Schroder's airline analyst, Candace Browning, upgraded her rating on AMR from ''neutral'' to expected to outperform the market.
The rise in AMR helped propel the Dow transportation average 16.89 points higher, to 1,116.29. Other airlines also contributed, with UAL Corporation up 2, to 128 1/2; Delta Air Lines 1 1/2, to 68 3/8; USAir 1 1/2, to 30, and Pan Am, 1/8, to 3 1/8.
Honeywell gained 1 3/4, to 80 5/8. A Paine Webber Inc. analyst, Mark Altman, upgraded his rating on the company to ''attractive'' from ''neutral'' on the prospects that Honeywell, which began a restructuring last year, would show better earnings.
Active blue-chip stocks included General Motors, up 1/2, to 45; I.B.M., off 1/4, to 103 3/4; General Electric, up 3/4, to 62; Philip Morris, off 1/8, to 37 5/8, and A.T.&T., up 1/2, to 39 5/8.and A.T.&T., up 1/2, to 39 5/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 1.04 points, to 351.40, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.66 points, to 422.61.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
 
Companies
A Federal grand jury in Anchorage indicted Exxon and its shipping subsidiary on five criminal counts stemming from the Alaskan oil spill, after negotiations between the Justice Department and the company on a settlement of the case broke down. [Page A1.]
Northrop pleaded guilty to charges of failing to conduct tests and agreed to pay a $17 million fine, one of the largest penalties ever imposed on a military contractor. [D1.] 
Wal-Mart said fourth-quarter profits rose 31.8 percent. For the year, it earned more than $1 billion for the first time. [D1.]
The entertainment realm of the pop superstar Prince is radically altering the reputation of Minneapolis. [D1.]
Several electronics companies are discussing the formation of a venture to develop and produce display screens for use in laptop computers, military gear and television sets. [D2.]
A three-judge panel of the Delaware Supreme Court ruled that corporations have a right to decide their own future rather than sell to the highest bidder. [D2.]
Drexel's chief executive defended the performance of the failed firm's management. Frederick Joseph said there was ''nothing that we could have done differently.'' [D2.]
 
 
 
Markets
The turbulence in Tokyo has demonstrated that the influence of one nation's market on another's is in some ways more powerful, and more subtle, than had been thought. News Analysis. [A1.]
U.S. stock prices advanced for the second straight day on slightly higher volume. The Dow Jones industrials rose 14.64 points, to 2,617.12. Yesterday in Tokyo, the Nikkei index rose 576.08, to 33,897.95, and it gained 571.94 by midday today. [D10.] The N.A.S.D. reported a 9.2 percent rise in short interest. [D8.]
The Government accused a retired executive of Philips Industries of violating Federal insider trading laws. [D1.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher. [D18.] Yields on C.D.'s and money market accounts at banks and savings and loans were basically unchanged for the last week. [D22.]
The dollar reached an eight-month high against the yen, despite intervention by central banks. [D17.] Prices of gasoline futures plunged on the New York Merc. [D17.]
 
 
 
The Economy
Orders for durable factory goods tumbled a record 10.5 percent in January, the Commerce Department reported. The drop was about three times as much as expected and was attributed mainly to a drop in orders for transportation equipment. [D1.]
 
Technology
A fledgling science is beginning to provide scientists a new class of software tools whose behavior mimics that of living creatures, by evolving into more powerful computer programs. [D9.]
Coal may power a clean home heating system of the future that bears little resemblance to coal furnaces of the past. [D9.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
Investors resumed purchases of stock mutual funds at a rapid rate in Feburary. They had moved out of such funds in January for the first time in seven months. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
A new report clouds the moral case for raising taxes to deter cigarette smoking. A less problematic deterrent would be a ban on advertising. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
''We are certainly not shopping the agency around,'' says Hal Riney, despite a spate of rumors that his famous shop may be in takeover talks. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Note and Bond Prices Are Higher

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
An economic report that was much weaker than anticipated helped to push up prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday.
The Commerce Department report showed that durable goods orders slumped by 10.5 percent in January, about three times as large as market participants had been expecting. Traders said that its release encouraged retail accounts, absent from the market for much of the year, to do some buying.
''Now that the refunding auctions are out of the way, people are feeling more comfortable,'' one bond trader said. 
''Every day you see investment money pouring in, from both domestic and international accounts. And while the economy may not be on the Street's mind, with the buying we saw today it seems that it is on the mind of retail investors.''
Analysts said the steep decline in the volatile orders statistics, which followed increases recorded in November and December, does not suggest rampant weakness in the manufacturing sector. But the new figures, they said, tend to reaffirm the notion that the economy is far from vibrant.
Moreover, the analysts said the numbers might force credit market participants to refocus their attention on domestic developments after spending the last few weeks reacting to financial and political events beyond the borders of the United States.
''These numbers tell you the apparent run-up in durable goods orders was clearly suspicious,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''But all they do is take you back to a couple of months ago, when the numbers were showing that the industrial sector was flat.''
Jeffrey Leeds, chief economist at Chemical Bank, said, ''You can pretty much date the beginning of the recent run-up in interest rates to the release of the November durable goods report in mid-December,'' he said. ''That one number got people into a certain train of thought about the economy, which was kept moving by subsequent events.''
Mr. Leeds added that one number would not be enough to change the current mood of the market, or of the Federal Reserve Board.
''If there is going to be a change in psychology, which invariably leads to a change in policy, we will need to see some corroboration of weakness from additional data,'' he said. ''But I don't doubt for a minute that that will happen down the road.''
The next report on the state of the economy could come tomorrow, when the February survey of the nation's purchasing managers is expected to be released.
 
Durable Goods Numbers
The durable goods numbers were sufficient to encourage buying yesterday, however.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 100 19/32, up half a point on the day, to yield 8.43 percent. Late Monday the bellwether issue was offered at a price to yield 8.48 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 21/ 32, up 11/32, to yield 8.40 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 5/8, up 5/32, to yield 8.33 percent. Treasury bill rates were mixed. Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.71 percent in late trading yesteday, up five basis points, or hundredths of a point. But six-month bill rates dipped by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.64 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.49 percent.
A number of new issues were offered in the investment-grade corporate bond market yesterday, including a $200 million issue of first refunding mortgage bonds from the Virginia Electric and Power Company.
The 9 3/4 percent bonds, which mature March 1, 2020, were priced at $98.85, to yield 9.87 percent, 1.40 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent 30-year bond at the time of pricing. The bonds are noncallable for five years.
Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting, which is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the secondary corporate bond market, traders said that prices of the most actively traded issues rose by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point.
The sale of new issues of New York State and South Carolina bonds had little negative impact on prices in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities.
Market participants said that prices of most issues in the secondary municipal bond market rose by about 3/8 of a point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Against the Yen Despite Bank Intervention

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen yesterday, reaching an eight-month high despite intervention by central banks. It closed mixed against other currencies.
Thomas Palladino, a trader with the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York, said the Federal Reserve sold dollars in New York in an attempt to drive down the currency's value against the yen when the dollar reached the level of 148.80 to 148.85 yen. He said the intervention appeared to have little effect. 
Earlier, the Bank of Japan tried to stem the dollar's rise against the yen in the Tokyo market. On Monday, both central banks sold dollars, but the currency moved up against the yen despite the intervention.
The dollar rose yesterday to 148.73 yen in late trading in New York from 148.63 late Monday. The dollar has not closed that high against the yen since last June 15, when it reached 151.30 yen.
 
Softened in Morning
Traders said the dollar softened a bit in the morning after the Commerce Department reported that orders to United States factories for durable goods plunged 10.5 percent in January, the biggest decline since the gauge began 32 years ago. But the dollar soon regained its strength.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 149.03 yen from 148.65 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it slipped to 148.57 yen.
The dollar was mixed against the British pound. In London, the pound traded at $1.6915 late Tuesday, down from $1.6927 late Monday. In New York, the pound cost $1.6908, up from $1.6903 of late Monday.
Against the West German currency, the dollar slipped to 1.6880 marks, from 1.6882.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Monday, were: 1.4840 Swiss francs, down from 1.4860; 5.7150 French francs, up from 5.7140; 1,248.75 Italian lire, up from 1,248.50, and 1.1938 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19405.
 
Gold Is Down
Gold prices fell yesterday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid for gold at $408.25 an ounce at 4 P.M., down 25 cents from late Monday.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery dropped 70 cents an ounce, to $408.
Earlier, gold traded in London at a late bid price of $407.25, down from $411.75 bid late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $411.25, unchanged from late Monday. In Hong Kong, gold fell $4.30 to close at a bid of $407.85.
Silver bullion closed in London at a bid price of $5.11 an ounce, down from $5.23 on Monday. In New York, silver for current delivery fell to $5.075, from $5.147 on Monday, on the Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Fall 10.5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27

 BODY:
New orders for durable factory goods, the backbone of the nation's manufacturing economy, tumbled a record 10.5 percent in January, the Commerce Department reported today.
The drop, to $118.2 billion, was about three times as much as expected and was mainly attributed to a falloff in orders for a broad range of transportation equipment, including aircraft. Without the transportation category, orders for durable goods, which are items expected to last three years or more, were down 3.4 percent.
Much of the decline in the transportation category in January reflected the comparison with an unusually strong figure in December, when aircraft orders surged following the settlement of the Boeing strike in late November. 
 
Generally Poor Results
Still economists regarded the results as generally poor, and some said they raised fresh doubts about further export gains and about whether companies would carry through plans to increase capital spending by more than 6 percent this year. New orders for capital goods, which are items used by businesses to provide goods or services, plunged 17.8 percent last month, or 13.7 percent when military orders are excluded, today's report showed.
Analysts cautioned, however, against concluding that the overall economy has begun to slide or even that the battered factory sector had taken a significant turn for the worse.
''They look mighty weak,'' an economist with Bankers Trust, Jay N. Woodworth, said of the durable-goods orders. ''But I wouldn't extrapolate the January softness to the whole first quarter.''
 
Subject to Wide Swings
Private and Government analysts said this series of statistics is normally subject to wide swings, and they suggested that several mitigating factors were at work this month, including bookkeeping aberrations, like the tendency of companies to post orders just before the end of the year, thus exaggerating the figures for December at the expense of January.
There was also a sizable decline in electrical machinery, especially communication equipment. But primary metals and nonelectrical machinery posted modest gains.
The stock market shrugged off the report early in the day and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.64 points. The bond market was encouraged by the news, which provided further evidence of weakness in the economy and therefore less chance of higher interest rates.
The markets might have taken a cue from the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan. In an appearance before Congress on the subject of Social Security today, Mr. Greenspan said in response to a question that the durables orders numbers, which he called ''highly unstable,'' were not particularly worrisome.
''Our judgment is that orders are basically flat,'' Mr. Greenspan said. ''Other data that we have suggests that the order pattern is soft,'' but the evidence, he added, is ''by no means accumulating on the downside.''
Mr. Greenspan and other analysts also observed that much of the decline was in aircraft, which had previously risen sharply, and in automobiles, which are measured as shipments and thus really reflect current production rather than longer-run business. Auto maker's statistics show that the output of motor vehicles has rebounded somewhat in February.
 
Undercuts Minority View
Wayne M. Ayers, senior economist for the Bank of Boston, described the durables orders as consistent with other recent weak factory data. While not forcing a policy change on the Federal Reserve, he said, the indicator ''at least undercuts'' the minority view that the Fed's next move is to raise interest rates in the wake of recent sharp - albeit probably temporary - increases in inflation.
Over all, the 10.5 percent drop in orders for dubable goods was the biggest since the Department started recording them in 1958. The second-biggest decline, 9.2 percent, came in February 1982.
Last month's drop followed gains of 1.4 percent in December and 4.8 percent in November. The December gain had previously been put at 3.2 percent until revised downward today.
Transportation equipment plunged 27.6 percent, to $27.9 billion, following increases averaging 7.8 percent in the preceding two months. Aircraft and parts, which had been running at unusually high levels, accounted for nearly half the decline, but motor vehicles and parts and shipbuilding and tanks were also both down sharply, the Department reported.
 
Too Soon to Show Up
A Commerce Department analyst, Ruth Runyan, said she thought it too early for reduced international tension to be reflected in orders for military equipment. ''That wouldn't have shown up yet,'' she declared.
Not counting military orders, factory durables orders fell 8.4 percent last month after gains averaging 3.2 percent in November and December.
Electrical machinery fell 17.6 percent, to $18.8 billion, following increases averaging 6.5 percent in November and December. Nearly all the decline was in communications equipment, the Department said.
Nonelectrical machinery, however, rose 2.6 percent to $22.3 billion, while primary metals rose 1.5 percent to $11.1 billion.
Before seasonal adjustment, durable goods orders slumped 17.4 percent to $110.2 billion, or 8.9 percent below the level of January 1989.
Today's report also showed that shipments of factory durables fell 3.7 percent, to $117.7 billion last month, the 10th decline in the last 13 months. Unfilled orders edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, to $494.7 billion.
