HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
So Long, Marlboro Man

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE latest figures on death and destruction from tobacco, released last week by the Department of Health and Human Services, hold few surprises. The $52 billion financial toll estimated for 1985 looks downright conservative next to the $65 billion calculation made five years ago by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.
What may surprise, though, is the department's little-noticed acknowledgment that smokers carry most of the financial burden themselves. Indeed, those who abstain may actually benefit from the tobacco pestilence: Smokers have a habit of dropping dead before they consume their share of Social Security and private pension benefits. 
If someone must pay, one supposes, it might as well be those who make the choice to smoke. But the department's confirmation, based on a number of economic and epidemiological studies, does cloud the moral case for raising excise taxes to deter cigarette consumption. For smokers, who on average are poorer than nonsmokers, already pay as much as 54 cents a pack in state and Federal taxes. A less problematic deterrent - one that may, paradoxically, serve the interests of cigarette makers as well as tobacco's victims - would be a ban on advertising and promotion.
According to ''Smoking and Health, a National Status Report,'' cigarette consumption for each adult American is down 15 percent since 1985. But it is hardly out: The 26 billion packs consumed last year shortened smokers' lives by an estimated three million years. In 1985, smoking-related illness cost $34 billion, while income lost from premature death added $18 billion.
This $2-a-pack cost offers a tempting rationale for raising cigarette taxes. Along with generating tens of billions of dollars in revenue, a tax in the $2-a-pack range would have a powerful impact on the habits of those at greatest risk. One study indicated that an increase of just $1 a pack would cut smoking by 12- to 17-year-olds by half.
But Ken Warner, an economist at the University of Michigan, points out that taxing smokers is the economic equivalent of double jeopardy. Tobacco addicts obviously have the most to lose from smoking-related illness and death. According to two Swiss researchers, R. E. Lau and T. Schaub, over a lifetime smokers' medical insurance costs are not appreciably greater than nonsmokers'. And as a Stanford University economist, John Shoven, has calculated, premature death saves society about $20,000 in Social Security benefits for each smoker.
In any event, survey data from the Centers for Disease Contol suggest that smokers could not easily afford the levy: while just 16 percent of those with college degrees still smoke, 36 percent of high school dropouts continue to puff away.
One alternative to deterring smoking with taxes is to clamp down on cigarette promotion that seduces teen-agers and reinforces adult addiction. This approach, pressed by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, has proved a political non-starter in Congress because it draws fire from advertising interests as well as from the tobacco lobby. But changes in the politics and economics of the cigarette business could turn the tide.
The cigarette market is increasingly dominated by one company, Philip Morris, and its overwhelming best seller, Marlboro. Research by Mark Roberts and Larry Samuelson, economists at Penn State, concludes that advertising existing brands will not reverse the trend; the only practical way for competitors to regain market share is to offer new brands. But the recent experience of the No. 2 manufacturer, RJR Nabisco, suggests that even that route is fast closing.
Premier, the no-tar, low-smoke cigarette aimed at the health-conscious, never made it out of the St. Louis test market. The debut last month of Uptown, aimed at blacks, was sunk in a wave of adverse publicity. And the same fate may await Dakota, RJR Nabisco's best hope for winning back the legions of young blue-collar smokers who identify with the Marlboro cowboy.
If the barriers to creating a Marlboro-buster have indeed become insurmountable, it may well pay all cigarette makers to stop worrying and enjoy their shared monopoly over a shrinking market. Promotion, everything from billboard ads to the sponsorship of tennis tournaments, cost the industry $2.4 billion in 1986. A ban on these expenditures would transform that $2.4 billion debit into a $2.4 billion credit, increasing the industry's earnings by a third overnight.
Cigarette makers are not likely to endorse so direct an assault on the legitimacy of their product. Probably all that would be needed to disarm the opposition to a ban on promotion, however, would be a few second thoughts. The days of cigarette advertising may be numbered.

LENGTH: 992 words

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Densie Webb; Densie Webb, a freelance writer and editor, is a registered dietitian.

 BODY:
FOOD manufacturers seem to have a penchant for taking nutritious foods and processing them to the point where they are no longer wholesome. Potatoes are a good example. In its purest form, a medium 5-ounce potato provides only 155 calories and is virtually free of fat and sodium. Potatoes are also good sources of complex carbohydrates, fiber and vitamin B6, and excellent sources of vitamin C and potassium.
But processing often transforms potatoes into oily or cheese-laden concoctions like potato chips, french fries, deep-fried hash browns or scalloped potatoes with bacon. These might have up to 230 calories a serving, with more than half of their calories as fat, and more than 500 milligrams of sodium a serving. That is a far cry from what nature intended. 
Potato consumption is up slightly in recent years, said Nancy McCarthy, director of consumer relations for the Potato Board in Denver, a trade association of growers. ''But we're eating more processed potatoes than fresh potatoes,'' she added.
The Potato Board cites figures from the Economic Research Service of the Federal Department of Agriculture. In 1988, the most recent year for which figures are available, Americans consumed one-third more processed potatoes than fresh. From 1968 to 1988, the consumption of fresh potatoes per person dropped 17 percent, while the consumption of processed potatoes rose 46 percent.
The nutritional decline of potatoes starts in the early stages of processing, when they are peeled. Peeling removes about half of a potato's fiber. After the fiber has been stripped, fat is added by frying or dressing with cheese. Along the way, potato products also lose most of their vitamin C, which is easily destroyed by exposure to heat and air.
Of the more than 500 million pounds of frozen french fries produced for retail sale in 1988, most were fried in processing so they could be baked in a microwave or conventional oven and still have a deep-fried appearance. Thus, even if consumers bake these french fries instead of frying them, fat has already been cooked into them. If they are deep fried at home, more fat is absorbed. A few french fry producers go a step further and spray on additional fat after longer-than-average frying.
Most major manufacturers of french fries fry only with polyunsaturated vegetable oils, which do not raise cholesterol levels, but no such assurance can be made for fries sold by fast-food chains. Some chains fry their potatoes in a mixture of oils that include beef fat. The saturated fats in beef raise blood cholesterol levels.
At the more healthful end of the spectrum, are ''light'' fries, in which fat is cut two-thirds by reducing the frying time.
John Lord, senior manager of quality assurance at Ore-Ida Foods, the largest American manufacturer of processed potato products for the retail market, said a good guideline for choosing a french fry is the larger the cut of the fry, the lower its fat content. Smaller cuts, like shoestrings, absorb more oil than larger cuts, like a dinner fries.
Sodium in processed potatoes is not quite as widespsread as fat. Most frozen french fries are actually low in sodium, providing less than 50 milligrams in a 3-ounce serving. The products most likely to be heavily salted are packaged dehydrated potato side dishes, like scalloped or au gratin potatoes, or potato products that are mashed and then reformed into desired shapes, like hash brown patties and frozen stuffed potatoes.
Sodium in these products can run as high as 700 milligrams a serving or about 20 percent of the daily maximum recommended by the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute in Bethesda, Md., a branch of the National Institutes of Health.
Though chips are thought of as the saltiest potato products, most packaged potato side dishes contain at least as much sodium per serving as four ounces of tortilla chips.
''With fat and salt often comes sulfites,'' said Jayne Hurley, associate nutritionist with the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer advocacy group in Washington. Sulfites, which are sometimes added to dehydrated potato products to prevent them from turning brown, can cause life-threatening allergic reactions to those suffering from asthma or others who are sensitive to sulfiting agents. The ingredient list on a package will include ''sodium bisulfate'' if sulfites are present.
Though frozen french fries are usually free of additives except the oil absorbed in frying, packaged potatoes acquire a long list of additives, preservatives, colorings and flavorings in processing that further distance them from their origin.
Considering that fiber is stripped, vitamin C is destroyed and sodium, fat and unnecessary additives and preservatives are processed into potato products, most nutritionists agree that a half-cup serving does not count toward the five or more servings of fruits and vegetables that they recommend people consume each day.
''You don't have to resort to things that come in a package for a fast side dish,'' Ms. Hurley said. ''If you have a microwave, you can bake a potato in just a few minutes.'' She suggests topping potatoes with low-fat or nonfat yogurt, salsa or Parmesan cheese.
To bake a potato in a microwave oven, pierce it with a fork, then place it on a paper towel in the oven. Cook on high in a 650-to-700-watt oven for four to six minutes, turning once. Let stand for two minutes. Cook six to eight minutes in a smaller oven.
Ms. McCarthy of the Potato Board said potato skins make a quick snack or side dish. Though those served in restaurants are usually fried, Ms. McCarthy says they don't have to be. ''I bake them, scoop them out and then bake them again with toppings,'' she said.
Baked potatoes or potato skins can also be topped with leftover vegetables, stews, pilaf, lentils, split pea soup, fresh tomatoes, chilies, mushrooms, bell peppers or onions to create a healthful potato dish.
